PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: ANU and CSIRO: Fellowships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1.Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that the Adult Migrant Education Program (AMEP), including Workplace English Language and Literacy, must continue as a fully Government funded educational program with equality of access for all non-English speaking permanent residents. The implementation of fees for adult English as a Second Language (ESL) programs will disadvantage migrants who cannot afford to pay. The limit of 510 hours tuition will disadvantage most students who need a minimum of 900 hours of English for work or further study.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate restore access to all migrants and refugees regardless of length of residence in Australia and employment status, and to provide continuing funding for all adult ESL Programs to public education institutions, in particular AMES.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest support for the existing National Flag.
The Australian National Flag is the most important symbol of the Australian nation and our national unity, and has evoked deep feelings of honour and respect from many generations of Australians.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to preserve our current Australian National Flag and to ensure that its design is not changed without the support of a referendum carried by the majority of Australians in the majority of States.

PETITION.TITLE: Japanese Plutonium Freighter
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament of Australia assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that the Japanese plutonium freighter Akatsuki-maru will be sailing from the Cape of Good Hope across the Southern Ocean to the south of Australia and through the Tasman Sea on its route to Japan.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
(b)demand that the Japanese government forbid this freighter to approach Australian shores.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kimberley Region: Pastoral and Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

In view of the uncertainty regarding the future of the Kimberley Region of Western Australia we the undersigned call on the Parliament to offer security to the Pastoral and Mining Industry of this area.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the embarrassing admission by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) on 7 December 1992 that the Government has failed dismally to attract young Australians to the Ready Reserve Scheme, and
(ii)that this shortfall has occurred despite widespread youth unemployment and a $1 million advertising campaign;

PARA.TAB: (b)recalls that it was only 6 weeks ago that the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) was lauding the Ready Reserve as an `outstanding success';

(c)notes that, as long ago as October 1991, Senator Newman said that the Ready Reserve proposal gave all the signs of a `gung-ho' proposal developed without attention to critically important detail and that its proposed implementation meant that Australia's vital defence needs had been jettisoned;
(d)recalls that Senator Ray, when questioned at an Estimates Committee hearing in 1991, acknowledged that if the Ready Reserve failed at a later stage the Government would reverse its decision;
(e)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Coalition's defence policy says that the case against the Ready Reserve Scheme is overwhelming and the whole effect of the scheme has been to weaken combat capability at a great financial cost, and
(ii)the Coalition will therefore cancel the Ready Reserve program and return to the Regular/General Reserve integrated structure for 6 Brigade in Brisbane; and

PARA.TAB: (f)condemns the Government for:

TAB.TAB: (i)misleading the public on the progress of the Ready Reserve Scheme, and

(ii)failing to heed the scepticism of the vast majority of Army personnel, the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the Coalition on the viability of the Ready Reserve

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)there has been an alarming increase in the number of reported cases of the highly contagious viral infection rubella,
(ii)the incidence of rubella in the State of Victoria has reached epidemic proportions, with 1 000 cases being reported so far in 1992 compared with 180 cases in 1991, and
(iii)the rubella infection in the first 26 weeks of pregnancy can cause severe foetal abnormalities;

PARA.TAB: (b)joins with the Deafness Foundation in urging all Australian women to undergo a blood test prior to pregnancy; and

(c)calls on the Federal Government to pay serious attention to this current rubella epidemic and to take whatever action is necessary to reduce, with a view to eliminating, the incidence of rubella in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

PARA.TAB: (b)strongly condemns the Groom Government for overriding the democratic processes of government and handing over immense powers to an elite within the government; and

TAB.TAB: (i)to withdraw the legislation, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)with dismay, the figures released by the ANZ Bank which show that the number of job vacancies is growing very slowly,
(ii)that the increase of 0.6 per cent in November 1992 represents the fourth month of very modest rises,
(iii)that the weakest level of activity is in the private sector, and
(iv)that business investment is still contracting 3 years after the slump began;

PARA.TAB: (b)confirms the fact that the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) `that the recession is long over' is not true; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the results of the Australian Private Hospitals Association's national audit, released on 3 December 1992, which have found that:
(A)19 779 Australians were being treated in the 230 private hospitals surveyed on 26 November 1992, and
(B)more than 17 000 beds in these hospitals were occupied on that same day;
(ii)that the Keating Labor Government's health policies have placed an unbearable strain on the public hospital system causing waiting lists for elective surgery of between 70 000 and 100 000, and

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There are 42 documents to be presented today and dealt with in 30 minutes. There were none whatsoever yesterday. I think there were none last Thursday and two or three the previous Wednesday. Very few documents have been presented to the Senate for debate in the last week or so. This is exactly what happened this time last year. All of a sudden on one day we are hit with 42 of them.

PARA.TAB: This is simply intolerable. Many of them have been with the offices of the relevant Ministers for some time. The National Science and Technology Centre report was received by the Minister's office on 21 November but not presented until now. The Film Australia report was received by the Minister's office on 24 November but not presented until now. Many of these documents are from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and affect my portfolio responsibility. I am very disheartened by this lumping. I have received a note from our Whip saying that this situation is understood. I discussed the matter with our Leader, who was not aware of any problem with my raising it. If there is some method of overcoming this problem, I would be very grateful to hear it. I ask that some arrangements be made for us to have proper capacity to deal with these reports, many of which are on important matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The reason for the bunching up of these reports is that, when the extra week and extra day of sitting were arranged, there was no allowance made for reports to be dealt with. The provisions of the resolution determining what business could be constructed on those days excluded reports, hence the bunching up now. We will have only 30 minutes to speak to these documents today, but any of them can continue through to the extra half hour.

PARA.TAB: There was a desire, perversely, to get some of these matters dealt with this week and not next week because the real complaint was that there is more rushing in the last week. There are still quite a few departmental reports to come in, mostly because they are awaiting certification from the Auditor-General, which has held them up. The Government acknowledges that it is not desirable to put down 42 reports in one go, but a lot of the build-up has been because they were precluded previously under the order of business for the extra days. I do not know whether there will be a lot tomorrow or the next day. If not, the Opposition can work its way through these over the next two or three days. I understand that we are not having general business on Thursday.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are.
—I would be happy to dispose of Senator Walters's matter and put the reports back on the agenda, but I do not think those opposite would want to take up that fight in the party room.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade relating to a review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks at a later hour this day.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The tabling of this report, A Review of Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Human Rights, is a significant event for the Australian Parliament. It is the first comprehensive report on human rights to the Parliament and, as such, recognises the growing importance and the growing acceptance of human rights as a central issue in both domestic and international politics.

There is a good deal of rhetoric around on this subject and like all things there can be a danger of overkill. I would hope that this will not be the case with human rights because in the end our adherence to the principles and our promotion of those principles, are a measure of our civilisation. Human rights are central to the purposes of government—the purpose of providing a rule of law that is just and fair, not arbitrary or partisan; that substitutes for the raw and violent use of power institutions which will peacefully reconcile conflicts.
If human rights are about the provision of laws that are just and recognise the intrinsic dignity of people then they are a noble pursuit of great importance to this Parliament.

It was Amnesty which perceived the need for a more focused and formalised reporting mechanism on human rights issues. They wrote to the Committee in September 1990 proposing that some mechanism be established whereby the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade should provide an annual report to Parliament on his Department's work in this field and that this report should be referred to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for examination. The intention was to `expand parliamentary responsibility and community support for the continued development of human rights protection'. The emphasis was to be on the record of the Australian Government in its activities to promote and protect, not an examination either of individual cases or of the human rights records of other countries.

The Human Rights Sub-Committee was established in May 1991 as a permanent Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Its first reference received in May 1991 was to inquire into and report on Australia's international efforts to promote and protect human rights. In November 1991 the first annual report on human rights was received from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. This became the basis of the inquiry.

The inquiry generated wide interest and the Sub-Committee itself has quickly become the focus of attention for many groups in Australia who are concerned, often because of ethnic ties, with the many human rights abuses in the world. While this was not intended to be the central work of the Committee and, in many ways it is not equipped to deal with the volume of material that is provided to it, it is probably an inevitable extension of its work and recognises an earnestly felt need in the community.

The inquiry received 89 submissions many of which contained voluminous and comprehensive information about human rights situations around the world. Public hearings were held in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra between December 1991 and June 1992.

Central to the inquiry has been an examination of the ways in which the Federal Government has incorporated its human rights principles into policy and practice at an international level—the incorporation of human rights into foreign policy, defence cooperation and aid policies. The Committee looked at the international structures established by the United Nations to promote human rights and examined Australia's relations with these organisations and our ratification of and compliance with the international human rights treaties.

The inquiry was told in no uncertain terms that Australia had failed in significant areas by placing reservations on a number of articles in important human rights Covenants and Conventions. These articles relate to the passing of legislation outlawing racial vilification, the separation of adults and juveniles in gaols and those articles which allow individuals to make complaints to the various human rights committees. The failure to ratify these articles has detracted from our position on human rights, it reflects weaknesses in our record and may inhibit the full exercise of rights within Australia. If we are to speak with any authority on human rights these omissions should be rectified. The Committee recommends that this is done without delay.

The most critical and controversial question that arose in the inquiry was whether there should be a linkage between aid or trade and investment and the human rights records of recipient countries. Australia has taken the view so far that this issue should be decided on a case by case basis because the circumstances are complicated and the results of such linkages hard to govern.
The Committee has not been unsympathetic to this view for a number of reasons.

The Committee is very aware of the trend, since the end of the Cold War, of increasing linkages between human rights and aid. However, many of the countries which are making the link do so from a position of strength where the impact of such a link is substantial. The European Community through the European Council has a common cultural history which makes consensus, and therefore concerted action, a relatively easy task; the United States can make unilateral decisions on aid and human rights and often has done so with great effect; Japan is currently in a similar position of strength and has recently developed guidelines for the relationship between military expenditures and aid donations; the multilateral banks—the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and also the United Nations Development Program are all talking of setting a ratio of military to social expenditure as one of the criteria for assistance.

The Committee would support such linkages in principle and indeed where international action can be achieved Australia should support it. However, Australia is in a unique position vis a vis the implementation of such policies. We are not a large power easily able to make an impact through the withdrawal of aid or the imposition of trade sanctions, nor have we found it straightforward to find regional support for the human rights principles we wish to promote.

Nevertheless we should not sell ourselves short. The Australian economy, measured in the size of GDP, is in the top 20 nations of the world. Moreover, recent initiatives such as APEC, the peace settlement in Cambodia, the Chemical Test Ban Treaty, the Cairns Free Trade Group and its consequent impact on GATT and the Antarctic treaty have established for Australia a credibility which can be used to raise human rights issues effectively with other countries.

It would seem imperative for us to seek to build regional consensus on what constitutes good governance and to do this either informally as at present through dialogue and representation or more formally through a regional forum which would be able to keep the discussion going with a view to developing a regional understanding. No doubt within the terms of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the major human rights covenants and conventions there is room for discussion which could produce a view of human rights applicable to this region. The Committee recommends that the Government explore the possibility of establishing such a regional forum.

In the meantime, the Committee supported the view of many submissions that the aid program could make contributions to better observance of human rights through a proactive policy within the aid program. Many of the suggestions were innovative and practical.

The first public hearing of the Human Rights Sub-Committee was held on 2 December, made necessary by the tragic situation of the massacre in Dili on 12 November 1991. On that occasion the Committee took oral evidence from Mr Bob Muntz, the Community Aid Abroad worker who was injured during the shooting in Dili, written evidence from Russell Anderson, Amy Goodman and Allan Nairn, three other Western eyewitnesses to the killings, as well as statements from Amnesty International and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

This hearing was an unusual one created by unusual circumstances. The intention was not to conduct a definitive inquiry into what happened in Timor but to place factual information about the events of 12 November 1991 on the public record. The Committee does not expect to conduct hearings of this kind into the many and dreadful human rights abuses that occur in the world. However, it may from time to time have such hearings on matters of public interest to Australians. Timor fell into this category because of its proximity, its historical links with Australia, its sizeable refugee community living here and because of the interest that exists over our policy regarding Indonesia. The Committee was able to send the evidence collected that day to the Djaelani Commission investigating the incident in Indonesia.

A further eyewitness account was given to the Committee by Major-General Chamlong Srimaung, the leader of the pro-democracy forces in Thailand. The Major-General was arrested by the military government during the demonstrations in May 1992. He spoke to the Committee about the demonstrations and the shooting of civilians by the army. On 14 May, Lyndal and Sophie Barry and Patricia Garcia gave first hand accounts of the refugee situation on the borders of Burma.

All other hearings were conducted in response to the submissions received. A very great volume of material was received by the Committee on the human rights abuses that are occurring in many parts of the world. We were overwhelmed by the extent and range of the problems described to us. Neither the resources available to the secretariat nor the time frame set for the inquiry has allowed the cases to be examined comprehensively. Nor has the Committee been able to seek information on situations which we know are occurring in other parts of the world, which are as severe as those presented to us, but which for one reason or another were not formally brought to the Committee's attention. Therefore, there is an ad hoc list of situations dealt with in the last three chapters of the report. However, given the very great concern of very many people who put this material to the Committee, we have been at pains to portray accurately what has been told to us and to set out the requests for help and the recommendations for action that have been made to us. We do not pretend that this section of the report represents the final analysis of the last year's human rights situation for the world.

The Committee is very aware of the delicacy and sensitivity of the issue of human rights. We had to hold a number of hearings in-camera because the evidence being given would have put people at risk. This brought home to members that human rights is still a matter of life and death for many people around the world.

An important function of the Human Rights Sub-Committee is, through debate, to clarify and enunciate the nature and role of human rights in international relations. With the establishment of this Sub-Committee, human rights are on the political agenda and that is important.

I would like to thank the Members of the Committee for all the time and effort spent on this inquiry. Finally the Committee Members extend their appreciation to the members of the Secretariat, Denise Picker for her work in the organisation of public and private hearings, Margaret Brown for her assistance in the preparation of the report and in particular Margaret Swieringa, the Secretary of the Sub-Committee whose work in compiling this report has been invaluable.
I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of Estimates Committee B on proposed additional expenditure for the year ending 30 June 1993 as contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1992-93 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1992-93, together with the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I point out to the Senate that this Government claims that the local capital works program announced in the Budget will create 13,000 jobs, but it has absolutely no way of proving that figure or of ensuring that the funding it has given to local government under this program will actually be used to create jobs. Estimates Committee B was reconvened to look at the expenditure by the Government under Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 of 1992. Under these Bills $55m is allocated to the local capital works program which was announced in the Budget. When announcing this program the Government stated that it would generate 13,000 new jobs over the next two years. This statement was a misrepresentation of the truth, to put it politely.

PARA.TAB: During the Committee hearings coalition members questioned the Government and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on the progress of the local capital works program to date, in order to justify the additional expenditure on this program under these Bills. The result of the questioning was far from satisfactory, as we expected.

The Government made this $345m program the centrepiece of its job creation program in the Budget. The Government stated that the program was a genuine attempt to address the problems of serious unemployment in regional areas. However, a major fault of the program is that it is not a requirement for councils to employ people who are currently unemployed. This is where the Government has deceived the unemployed people of Australia. It is not the fault of local councils; it is the fault of this ALP Government. By trumpeting during the Budget debate that 13,000 jobs would be generated under this program, the Government gave hope to the unemployed that 13,000 fewer of them would be struggling on the dole queues. This was not to be the case.

When questioned on the exact number of previously unemployed people who had acquired a job under this program, the Department replied that it could not provide such figures because `it was not an employment program', and it did not see such figures in relation to unemployed people being taken on. Clearly, therefore, the Government has misrepresented this program to the Australian people. This misrepresentation has given false hope to many of Australia's unemployed. A typical case was presented in the Telegraph Mirror on 30 November this year under the heading `Job Sham'. The case which was highlighted in the article was that of an unemployed 20-year-old, Ben Sullivan, of Byron Bay. The Byron Bay Council was given $1.2m under the local capital works program. It has spent $400,000 so far, but not one new job has been created from this expenditure. The money has been spent on the reconstruction of a footpath in the main street using council labour. When Ben Sullivan was asked whether his predicament had been eased by the money received by the local council, he is quoted as saying, `What money? I didn't realise it was money meant to create jobs for us'.

The Byron Bay example appears to be typical of the expenditure under the local capital works program. The Newcastle Morning Herald reported on 1 December 1992 that a similar lack of job creation had occurred under this program in the Hunter Valley. The Lord Mayor of Newcastle was quoted as saying that there was no guarantee that the work created under the program would go to the unemployed in his area. Singleton Shire said it would be using no unemployed people in spending the $400,000 grant that it had received—neither will Dungog Shire, when it spends its $200,000, nor will the Port Stephens and Muswellbrook local council areas.

If this is the case across Australia, and I very much suspect it is, it is clear that the Government's statement that 13,000 jobs will be generated is a complete fiction. It must be remembered that it is not local government that is at fault here; it has been spending money allocated to it in ways that are perfectly justified under the guidelines to the program. The problem lies with the fact that sufficient guidelines have not been laid down by the Federal Government under this program to ensure that the $345m is being spent in the way that the Government originally intended. The Government should be wholeheartedly condemned for leading the Australian people on with the hope that something was actually going to be done about the 13,000 people on the dole queue and the opportunities that they may have to get into productive employment when it was never going to be the case—nor did the Government have any intention that it would be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement about the matter just referred to by Senator Tierney.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following Government Business orders of the day be taken together for their remaining stages:
No. 1—Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and two related Bills

PROCTEXT.PARA: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992
Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992, and

PARA.TAB: No. 2—Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992.

DEBATE.TITLE: SEX DISCRIMINATION AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1992COMMONWEALTH SUPERANNUATION SCHEMES AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate on Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992 resumed from 24 November, and debate on Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992 resumed from 5 November, on motions by Senator McMullan and Senator Button:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the first three of the four Bills in this package—that is, the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992—and to basically put down the Opposition's position in relation to these pieces of legislation. I understand my colleague Senator Short will be speaking to the somewhat unrelated matter of the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992, which is being debated cognately.

PARA.TAB: These three Bills might be described as part of Labor's agenda on equal opportunity and affirmative action. There is much in the package with which the Opposition agrees; unfortunately, however, the Bills do not address what we think are the major concerns of women in the Australian community at the moment. The major interest of women at the moment is in fact to get employment, as many have suffered within the overall figure of a million Australians out of work as a result of Labor's policies.

Certainly my colleague Senator Newman, who will be addressing this package also, in many ways is better qualified from her considerable dialogue with women around the country to report directly on the expressions of women to her, but I am sure that at the moment the first consideration of women out there in the community is the lack of work, the lack of job opportunities for their spouses and the lack of job opportunities for their children. They will be particularly worrying about the school leavers that will be coming on to the labour market in such desperate circumstances in only a few weeks.

Beyond that, women will talk about their concerns regarding a lack of appropriate education, particularly skills and job training both for themselves and, again, for their families. They will talk about their difficulty with child-care, the lack of child-care opportunities and the fact that such opportunities seem, unfortunately under this Government's program, to go to the better off, particularly in cities such as this one. They will talk about their worry about not being able to pay for private health care when they see that one of their first responsibilities is to ensure the provision of adequate health care for their families. They will talk about their frustration in not having the same superannuation opportunities as men within the work force, despite all the reforms we have seen in recent years.

They will talk about the fact that so many small businesses—a third in fact—are run by women and about their frustrations within small business: the lack of demand for their products because of Labor's recession and their frustration and disappointment at having made a commitment to their small businesses only to find them failing under the economic failure within the country as a whole.

We speak to rural women, who have found the going particularly difficult in recent years. They have worries for their children's schooling as they see schools disappearing from the farming areas of the country, and about insufficient recognition of the cost burdens and the social stresses of having to send children to cities for education.

Migrant women are concerned about the difficulty of getting language training. Older women are worried about health care and about the fact that they did not have the superannuation opportunities that men did and therefore are concerned about how they will maintain themselves during their senior years.

These, I think I can say confidently, are the issues that will be raised by Australian women before the issues that are encompassed within these pieces of legislation. I do not want to start this brief presentation by being particularly critical of Labor's priorities because some of these packages in relation to sex discrimination are very important, but I think, when we look at the overall record of 10 years of Labor government and how it has affected women, we will see that the areas of frustration and disappointment that I have outlined and that Senator Newman will enlarge upon are those that women will put as their first priorities. It is that distorted priority that is so disappointing after 10 years of Labor.

I come to Labor's agenda—that is, the package of reforms that is before us for debate today. I will start with the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992. We will not oppose this Bill. The Act requires employers to introduce affirmative action programs and procedures designed to promote equal opportunity for women in the workplace and to eliminate discrimination against women in employment matters. The Act has, of course, been subject to a number of recent reviews, including one by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which entitled its report Half way to equal. That Committee strongly endorsed the concept of equal opportunity for women in the workplace. Of course, that is something which is also strongly endorsed by the coalition parties.

In the Government's response to the report, a commitment was given that the Government would legislate to give the Director of the Affirmative Action Agency the power to vary reporting requirements where organisations have demonstratively complied with the Act over a period of time, and to extend the operation of the Act to cover voluntary bodies employing 100 or more people. The present exclusion for voluntary bodies is removed so that organisations, such as private schools and charitable institutions, which employ 100 or more people will be relevant employers and will be required to develop affirmative action programs. We are not opposing that.

The Bill varies the status of the Affirmative Action Agency. That is an aspect which we are unhappy with. We do not think that it needs to be structured into a statutory body with defined functional responsibilities. We believe that those responsibilities can be more than adequately handled either within the Attorney-General's Department or within the Department of Industrial Relations.

We are concerned about the proliferation of new structures of statutory authority and, therefore, although this may give the Government some sort of additional rhetorical armament, we think that it does not advance the interests of women any further. The third change, which gives the Affirmative Action Agency the power to waive the public reporting requirements—which I mentioned a moment ago—where there has been reasonable compliance with the requirements of the Act for at least three years, has our support.

As I said a moment ago, I want to stress that whilst we have had reservations about aspects of this legislation over the years—I mentioned a reservation about this Bill in itself—nevertheless, the coalition strongly supports and is committed to equal opportunity for all people in the workplace. We intend to use the opportunity of a second reading amendment to reiterate that commitment. That amendment, which I understand has been circulated and which I will move, reiterates our support for the concept of equal employment opportunity for all employees. It also calls upon the Government to support the recruitment, training and promotion of all employees solely on the basis of merit. I trust that the Government, even within its philosophical constraints, will feel that it can support that amendment. We would like to think it is something that would be supported by all Australians. I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)reaffirms its commitment to the principle of equal opportunity for all employees; and
(b)calls on the Government to support the recruitment, training and promotion of all employees solely on the basis of merit".

PARA.TAB: The second piece of legislation is the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, which we are supporting. It consists of amendments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and also to the Sex Discrimination Act. In relation to the former, it provides for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner within the Commission. This was one of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. As you may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, we generally welcomed the recommendations of the final report of that Commission and the Government's response thereto. We specifically support the recommendation to establish this Commissioner. We hope that the Commissioner will be able to better serve the interests of that particular community.

The second amendment proposed by the legislation is the elimination of discrimination involving the dismissal of employees on the ground of family responsibilities. I understand that this is in line with International Labour Organisation convention 156. This convention, which covers equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women workers with family responsibilities, was ratified by Australia in 1990. Although the coalition has reservations about some of the ILO's conventions, this convention and the content of this amendment are very much in line with the coalition's attitude towards families and our responsibilities to families. In that the amendment makes it unlawful for discrimination on the basis of family responsibilities, we are pleased to support it. It is consistent with our fundamental view that important factors in employment such as talent, ability, diligence and family responsibilities are just as relevant as other factors such as race, gender and marital status.

The third Bill in the package is the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. The majority of the changes within this legislation are also supported. Let me briefly deal with the important parts that we are supporting and then I will touch upon our few concerns. The first amendment seeks to broaden the definition of sexual harassment. Whilst we understand the Government's motivation, sexual harassment will now be defined to mean `an unwelcome sexual advance, an unwelcome request for sexual favours or other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in circumstances in which a reasonable person would have anticipated that the person harassed would be offended, humiliated or intimidated'. We put on the record that we are concerned that this is a very vague definition. When rights and responsibilities flow from definitions, we strongly hold the view that it is important that definitions be precise.

We have noted that there has been particular concern expressed by such bodies as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. It has said that it would prefer to see a definition which specifies that conduct amounts to sexual harassment where a reasonable person would have found the conduct grossly offensive, humiliating or intimidating, or if the conduct satisfies a disadvantage test. That argument is somewhat persuasive. But having expressed reservations, we are not going to vote against the extension of this definition.

The second amendment which we support is designed to help people who have made a complaint under an anti-discrimination law and are then victimised. Not surprisingly, we strongly oppose victimisation that might follow from the making of such a complaint.

The third area in which we will not be opposing the Government's proposals is in relation to the enforcement of a determination of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Again we have some reservations in this regard. It is a move away from the conciliation process, which was the basis of the legislation, to something much more legalistic and provides for appeals to the Federal Court.

We will not oppose this proposal on the basis that the current requirement is that if one is dissatisfied with the Commission one could start the process again in the Federal Court, which would simply lead to a repetition of the hearing. So, on balance, we will not vote against it. But we express the reservation about heading down the strict legal path as opposed to the commonsense conciliation approach, which was very much the spirit of the initial legislation.

However, there are two areas which we cannot accept in this Bill and which I indicate at this stage that we will oppose. The first is the extension of the Bill to cover Federal industrial awards. At present, the Act does not apply to an act done by a person in direct compliance with an industrial award. This Bill introduces a new section designed to extend the Act to cover such awards. The new procedure will involve a person's complaining to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner that a person has committed a discriminatory act under an award. Unless the Commissioner is of the view that the complaint is frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance, he or she must then refer it to the Industrial Relations Commission.

We are of the view that it is inappropriate for the IR Commission to deal with this question of discrimination and that it is inappropriate for this legislation to be expanded in this way. If one has a complaint about discrimination the remedies, as we know, are already in existence in the legislation. It is unwarranted to start trying to blend together the two responsibilities of the IR Commission and the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. In other words, we do not think a case has been made by the Government for this claimed reform.

We will also be opposing the provisions in respect of representative complaints. We believe that the further extension is unnecessary. Coalition members who were parties to the House of Representatives report on the subject, which I mentioned a moment ago, put in a minority report on this matter. You may well be aware of that, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Opposition is consistent with the view that was expressed at that time. You would know from recent experience with other legislation the concerns that we have had about the Government's design for representative actions, which we believe are basically heading in the wrong direction.

So we will support most of the reforms the Government wants to introduce. As I said, there are a couple that we cannot support and there are a couple about which we have reservations. However, I finish where I started: the major problems faced by Australian women are not those included within this package; they are out there in the community.

I urge Australian women to take the opportunity to read the coalition's Fightback program in relation to women. See what we say about providing them with the jobs that they are not getting at the moment; how we can improve the education opportunities for women through our programs; how we can particularly help rural women and migrant women who are discriminated against within our community, especially in relation to language; how we can give support to women in small business who have worked so hard but have suffered under this Government; and how we can provide another $90m for child-care opportunities for women who want to get into the work force but find that they cannot afford to, whilst at the same time providing the type of child-care they want for their children. If they read that package, I am sure they will agree with me that there is a better opportunity for them out there. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and allied Bills. After I examine the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill, I will deal very briefly with the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: The Bill that I want to deal with specifically today extends the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and amends human rights legislation. Although we can perhaps be a little cynical about the timing of these changes, they are important ones and they certainly have the capacity to have a significant impact on the lives of Australian women.

Many of the changes in this area come out of the recommendations of Half way to equal, the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Committee did a great deal of work. It took submissions from a great many people in the preparation of this report and it emerged with evidence of inequality between Australian men and women across a range of areas. I will list a few points today.

The report reveals that women's wages in Australia are currently, on average, 87 per cent of average male wages; women make up only 13 per cent of government representatives in Australia; since the inception of the Australian honours system in 1975, women have received only 24 per cent of all awards and they generally have been in the lower orders; more than half of the women in the paid work force in Australia earn less than $21,000 a year, while two-thirds of men have incomes greater than that figure; Australia has one of the most sex segregated work forces in the OECD countries; and there is the infamous `glass ceiling' which is demonstrated by the fact that Australia's senior business managers, public servants and professionals are five to 10 times more likely to be men than women. So, as the Committee noted, the battle for equality is far from being won. I think it is important to keep in mind that the changes we have before us today are directed as much towards cultural change as towards remedying specific problems.

One of the main changes introduced by the Bill is the extension of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to Federal industrial awards and certified agreements. At present, discriminatory actions carried out in accordance with the terms and conditions of an award are exempt from the Sex Discrimination Act. Under this Bill, a complaint alleging discrimination under an award may be lodged with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

If it appears to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner that the act is a discriminatory one, the Commissioner must then refer the award to the Industrial Relations Commission. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner is then given standing as a party as the award is reviewed. If the IRC finds the award is discriminatory, it must take the necessary steps to remove the discrimination by setting aside or varying the award. However, the IRC is not required to take action which it believes would not be in the public interest. The Australian Democrats welcome these provisions.

The Bill also widens the current definition of sexual harassment, and there have been many concerns expressed about this, with some people claiming that it could be rather subjective or open to abuse. I do not pretend that this area is not a very difficult one. We certainly are aware of the difficulty involved in sorting out truth from fiction when there are allegations of sexual harassment. Basically, it comes down to the word of one person against another but, more often than not, unfortunately, it is the word of a woman who is claiming to have been harassed against the word of a man denying the allegation.

A few things have to be said about these situations, and they are the exception to the rule. They have been given prominence by some recent very public cases such as the specific case of Thomas v. Hill in the United States. Despite all the hysteria that tends to be generated, particularly by the critics of this type of legislation, these situations are not the most common. Of the many complaints made to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, the vast majority are settled by conciliation. In other words, there are very few cases where the two parties remain intransigent and hold their line right to the wire, and where there is absolutely no supporting evidence from anybody else. This is, in part, an unforeseen reflection on the environments in which sexual harassment occurs because such harassment rarely goes totally unnoticed by anybody; in fact, it is frequently the subject of office gossip—sometimes people are prepared to do something about it; sometimes they are not—or it has been observed by others who might find it very embarrassing or humorous. Perhaps people are reluctant to speak up because they are worried about their position in the office, a promotion or are afraid of losing their jobs.

It is fairly rare, as is the experience of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, to have a case where nobody saw, heard or knew anything of the case and where it comes down to the word of one person against another. Such cases do occur and they are the ones that make the public arena. They are also well-publicised. We must be sensible and realistic about this: they are not common and they can occur in any jurisdiction, not just this one.That does not mean that it is the fault of the jurisdiction or the legislation; there is simply very little we can do in any jurisdiction to stop people being vindictive or vexatious in their dealings with one another if they are determined to behave that way.

Critics of this legislation also like to imply that it means people cannot banter or flirt with anyone of the opposite sex without being accused of sexual harassment. If we read the legislation, we find that to be rubbish—and they know that it is rubbish. I am not going to say that there are not occasionally double standards as we have all heard stories about that. Those attitudes are not very helpful. Most people, and certainly most women, know the difference between banter and harmless fun or sexual harassment. Most women can deal with what I would call mild harassment. They may find it irritating and juvenile, but they can deal with it. We know the difference between that annoying level of behaviour and the sort of behaviour which is designed to offend, humiliate or intimidate us.

It is also the case that harassment is generally linked to power, and this is again where women do have some difficulties. This power difference is highly relevant—for example, a woman might be able to stop harassment from a fellow employee, but when it comes down to an employer or someone in a senior position it can be very difficult.

The Bill says that harassment must, firstly, be an unwelcome sexual advance or an unwelcome request for sexual favours or other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature and, secondly, that that sort of conduct must occur:

SPEECH.PARA: in circumstances in which a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated that the person harassed would be offended, humiliated or intimidated.

The Australian Democrats think that this is a fair test and will be supporting these changes. Another measure the Democrats support is the extension of the application of the Sex Discrimination Act. I will go very quickly through the way in which it is extended. It is extended to the provision of goods, services and facilities; to clubs; to the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; and to dealings in connection with the land and the provision of accommodation. The Bill also makes changes in the area of representative complaints. The Sex Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Disability Discrimination Act are all amended to make it easier for a representative—or class—complaint to be commenced.

PARA.TAB: There are several preconditions for making a representative complaint. The Commission has the power to reject such a complaint. The Opposition is opposing the representative complaint provisions, basically because they do not seem to support subsuming individual rights into class rights. The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments. I think there are instances where a group action would be more cost effective for all concerned but we particularly need to look at taxpayers as well as individuals. It makes little sense to have several individuals pursuing very similar, if not the same, issues.

I realise the class can be very broad, although I note that any determination as a consequence of such a complaint must describe or identify the class members to which it will apply. Of course, there will be some problems with the opt-out system, but ultimately it is more practical than the other way around. I believe the provisions under which the Commission can reject a representative complaint provide a more than adequate protection for ensuring that ridiculous or vexatious actions do not get up as representative complaints.

One of the most important things this Bill does is set up a mechanism for enforcing determinations made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner. Until now, a complainant wanting to enforce a Commission determination had to take action in the Federal Court. This has been the subject of a great deal of criticism from just about every organisation and individual with an interest in the operations of the Commission. It has been a waste of resources and a totally unnecessary duplication which has resulted in increasing costs for all parties, as well as encouraging some respondents to adopt a rather cavalier attitude to the decisions of the Commission.

The new mechanism provides for a determination of the Commission to be registered in the Federal Court. It will then take effect as if it were a Federal Court order. This is a sensible and practical move which is welcomed by the Australian Democrats.

Finally, I want to mention briefly our support for the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes (Amendment) Bill. Basically, this Bill brings the Commonwealth schemes into compliance with the anti-discrimination legislation.

In the 1984-86 sex discrimination legislation there was a blanket exemption for all funds. In 1991, this total exemption was narrowed down to four. They are: conditions in a fund based on actuarial data, for example, recognising the difference in longevity between the sexes; lesser death and disability benefits being provided to single people relative to those provided to people with dependants; provisions concerning vesting and preservation of portability; and, finally, protection of the existing expectations of members of discriminatory schemes. Currently, the Commonwealth schemes are exempt from these provisions. This legislation brings the Commonwealth schemes into compliance. The Democrats support this move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has already addressed the details of the three Bills before us today: the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992. In the interests of time constraints, I do not intend to cover the details again. Let there be no doubt at all that the Opposition is committed to equal opportunity for all. We support the recruitment, training and promotion of employees solely on the basis of merit. We oppose victimisation, sexual harassment and sexual discrimination. We support the maintenance of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Office of the Status of Women.

PARA.TAB: Our record on matters of importance to women is a good one, ranging from having had the first woman member in each State and Federal Parliament of this country, the first woman Minister in the Federal Parliament, and a long record of supportive legislation over many years. I emphasise that it was a coalition government which in 1980 signed the Copenhagen Convention outlawing all forms of discrimination against women. The three Bills before us today were based on that landmark Convention and our support for it.

I cannot help but be cynical about the presentation of these Bills today because they are really part of a bigger game plan. Although we support most of the amendments in the Bills, as Senator Hill said, there are some about which we have a few concerns. The real concern is why the Bills are being introduced. We believe they are part of a bigger effort to try to refine the image of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with women. The Prime Minister hired a consultant, Dr Anne Summers, believed to be at a cost of about $80,000 of taxpayers' money for five months work, to do a facelift on the Prime Minister—his attempt to woo the women voters. She has tried to make him out as a caring human being. The only trouble is that women have seen him in other guises over many years, often operating like a back street spiv in the gutter. Those images will not disappear very fast.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The language used by Senator Newman is totally unparliamentary. She knows it, and she should be forced to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Yes. Senator Newman, I ask you to withdraw the comments you made about the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the comments I made about the Prime Minister. The images which Australian women have of the Prime Minister, however they are described in this place, will remain in women's minds and cannot be overcome simply by a PR campaign devised at taxpayers' expense. Dr Summers has also tried to make the Prime Minister out as sympathetic to the feminists of Australia. Unless those feminists are wearing party political specs, they are not going to be fooled by the image makers, either. Both of these attempts by Dr Summers are too contrived and too far from the very real image of the Paul Keating who has strutted the political stage for a couple of decades.

PARA.TAB: The legislation being amended today is the Sex Discrimination Act, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act. These amendments represent only a handful of the recommendations of the report of the joint parliamentary committee into equal opportunity and equal status for women in Australia. Almost all of the recommendations of that report received all-party support. Yet has Mr Keating committed himself to implementing that report? The answer is no. The major issues remain untouched, despite the fact that that committee recognised what were the important issues that need attention.

Mr Lavarch, reported in the Age on 22 July, blamed the slow pace of reform on Ministers, claiming that, while many introduced women's programs with fanfare and publicity, they often lacked the commitment to follow their rhetoric through. The Age goes on to say that his claims contradict the recent assertions by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, that the Labor Government had greatly improved the lot of Australian women during its 10 years in power. That would be my view as well. I have no doubt whatsoever that the Chairman is right. There have been great flourishes, great rhetoric and PR claims, but not a lot of action. The issues that the committee was dwelling on were issues of employment, industrial relations, taxation, retirement income, health, education and the needs of rural women, non-English speaking background women and Aboriginal women. Are we seeing any of that in this legislation today? No. But those are issues which are addressed by Fightback. That is why I am very proud to claim that Fightback is pro-women.

Let us look at the Government's record on employment. The Government will claim that it has been good to women because there has been a growth in women's employment. If the Government were not so confined to its ivory tower it would realise that many of those women—not all—work because their family's standard of living has been so reduced during the reign of this Government that they need extra financial support. Many women claim that they have lost the right to choose. I consulted with women's organisations around Australia for a year, as a result of which Australian Women Speak was produced. Let me quote a couple of women's comments from that little book. Comments like these were made everywhere. One woman said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see a situation where we don't say you're lucky to be able to afford to be at home.
Another woman said:
It should be your right and your choice, your true choice, not denied to those who don't have enough money.

Even those women who are in the work force have been suffering. We all know of the desperate growth in the unemployment of women. Nearly 400,000 women now show up on the unemployment lists. About 100,000 women are described as `discouraged job seekers'. Nearly 600,000 women are described as having a `marginal attachment' to the work force. One of the alarming pieces of information I was given the other day referred to English language studies. I was told that only 17 per cent of referrals by the CES for English language studies were women. When I asked why there was such a low percentage of women, I was told, `We believe it is simply because women are not registering with the CES'. First of all, they do not believe that the jobs are there to be had and, secondly, if their husbands are in the work force, there is not much point in applying for benefits so they do not bother with the CES.

PARA.TAB: Let us not forget the impact of payroll tax on employment. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, is on the record as having said that about 200,000 jobs would be produced if payroll tax were abolished. Only this year it was reported that, for the first time, superannuation costs in the private sector surpassed payroll tax as the major component of labour costs other than earnings. The cost of superannuation cover in the private sector was up 29.5 per cent to $1,140 in 1990-91, compared with $992 an employee for payroll tax. These are the disincentives that keep people from getting jobs. These government imposed taxes, levies and charges are taxes on jobs. There are measures that this Government could take action on to improve the employment opportunities of all Australians, including women. Why does the Government not do so?

We have underemployment. Many women in the work force in Australia are in part time work, particularly because it suits those with family responsibilities. What is not showing up in those awful statistics is the fact that for many of those women the hours of their part time work have been considerably reduced. That can have a terrible effect on those families where the spouse has lost his job, especially in those families where that part time work is critical to their well-being.

The Government has failed to take meaningful action on industrial relations, an area which is very important for women. Industrial relations changes will mean flexibility in working hours and conditions, which is extremely important. We hear the Government talk about workers with family responsibilities. There has been no action from this Government on that.

There are many recommendations in the Lavarch Committee's report on industrial relations which have not been addressed by the Government's response. This is really important action that would make a big difference to the lives of many Australian women in the work force. Our industrial relations policy allows for negotiations which are important and very valuable to women.

There is a need for changes to the taxation system, yet the One Nation statement delivered earlier this year gave no tax support by way of reductions for those earning less than $20,700 a year; 42 per cent of all Australians earn less than that amount, about two-thirds of whom are women. So much for this Government's concern about women. Where it really counts—in their pockets—they get no help.

If the tax threshold were raised from $5,400 to $7,000, as proposed in Fightback, something like 320,000 Australians on low incomes would no longer pay any tax at all. A heavy proportion of women are in that number. In Fightback women also benefit from the doubling of the family allowance for those families which have under $30,000 in family income. Where is the Government's action to help people in those circumstances?

I think one of the greatest failures of this Government in terms of women is its sexist superannuation policy. There is no coverage for women with broken work patterns, those caring for children at home, or those who are volunteers in the community. The majority of people in those situations are women. In Fightback the superannuation entitlements for people in that position are wonderful. For the first time there is a real opportunity for those who are not in the paid work force to have access to some form of retirement income.

Has this Government done anything about freeing up the retirement age? No, not at all. Fightback will abolish compulsory retirement and allow people to work past retirement age and receive a bonus pension. For every year that they do not retire when they are entitled to a pension, they will be entitled to an 8 per cent larger pension. For the couple of years that people stay on with a work force wage, their pension eventually will be 16 per cent greater than it otherwise would have been. For women—who have a long life expectancy—this is a very important and practical measure, the need for which the Government has totally ignored. Yet it brought out a brand spanking new superannuation policy in June this year which condemns women to remain on the pension because it makes no provision for the large number of women who go in and out of the work force continually.

The final evidence of the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister is his endorsement the other day of the National Strategy on Violence Against Women. There are very important questions which demand responses from this Government about the strategy. The strategy says that, in order to relieve the oppression of women and to improve their status, discriminatory conditions in superannuation schemes must be removed. Why then has the Prime Minister not done anything about his sexist superannuation policy?

The strategy says that women of non-English speaking backgrounds who are victims of violence are disadvantaged through their lack of knowledge of the English language and a shortage of specialist interpreters. Why then has the Labor Government neglected the needs of migrant women exposed to violence by closing off the options for migrant women to learn English after three years here? Currently around 70,000 people are awaiting vacancies in the programs.

The national strategy says that all governments in Australia must ensure the further development and effective implementation of guidelines for video material which portrays, condones or incites violence against women or degrades women. Why then has the Labor Party refused to foster a community in which women are safe—firstly, by not acting on the recommendations of the 1988 report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material; secondly, by not supporting Senator Walters's private member's Bill, the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988; and, thirdly, by not supporting the debate of her Bill currently before the Senate? Why the inconsistency? Why the hypocrisy?

The national strategy says that income security is essential if a woman is to live free from fear, threat and actuality of violence. Why then does the Labor Party still have no credible policy for long term sustained employment when the record unemployment levels show that nearly 400,000 Australian women are looking for work? Why is it that we have this legislation before us today, important and useful though it may be, yet no attempt has been made to deal with big issues such as retirement income, the choice as to whether young mothers can stay home with their children, violence and economic security? They are the important questions; yet this Government is trying to buy an image for the Prime Minister by responding to just seven recommendations out of the 79 from the parliamentary committee.

I will list some of the recommendations of the Committee. It said that there should be some proposal whereby superannuation could be used to purchase a home. That is in Fightback, and that is a recommendation of the Committee. Another recommendation is that there should be adequate resources for TAFE. Fightback makes major changes and improvements in resources for TAFE. The Committee says that there should be subsidies for petrol for pensioners in rural areas. I draw the Senate's attention to Fightback's removal of the petrol excise, which will allow people in rural areas to access all sorts of services they currently cannot afford to access.

The Committee recommended that there should be qualitative assessment of the Affirmative Action Agency reports. This is very much an issue which the Opposition agrees with. The Committee recommends that there should be help for sole parents through training to get work. Fightback provides for that too.

I have talked about what Fightback proposes for superannuation, and that is also referred to in the Lavarch Committee's report. I have spoken also of the resources for English language training. Over and over again, Fightback covers those issues and makes proposals to deal with those needs. This Government has been in office for 10 years, and it is still failing to deal with those important issues that are so vital to women in this country.

The Government seems to be pretty much on one track when it comes to dealing with issues concerning women. This procedure is not confined to women; it is quite normal for this Government. Firstly, if it wants to be seen to be doing something, it hires a consultant. Secondly, it has a conference or two to make it look as if it is doing something. Thirdly, it produces a strategy and has a Minister announce it with a great flourish. Fourthly, it has a busy and expensive media exercise, thanks to the generosity of the taxpayer. Fifthly, it rests on its laurels. That is this Government's five-point plan for trying to deal with anything. It makes it look like action, but, as Mr Lavarch said—and as I quoted earlier in my speech—`The rhetoric is better than the action'.

If the Prime Minister believes that women are taken in by this procedure, he is sadly mistaken. They know what the big issues are. They know whom to blame for their problems and for the pain that they and their families are suffering. They know that PR campaigns fix nothing. Sadly, although the Opposition is prepared to support this legislation, we do not do it with great enthusiasm because of the failure of the Government in so many areas of importance to women which affect every part of their daily lives. This is, in a sense, window dressing after the Government has spent 10 years ignoring the very big picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The Bill is in two parts. It contains amendments to the human rights legislation to establish the office of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. Secondly, it contains amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act to prohibit discrimination against employees on the grounds of family responsibilities and, in particular, dismissal of a worker on such grounds.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of the office of Commissioner arises out of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The report of that Royal Commission highlighted the need for a continuing monitoring process and for public education to make sure that we, as a community, ensure that the human rights of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are protected and their position in the Australian community is progressively improved. The Australian Democrats welcome and applaud this initiative.

The second part of the Bill seeks to protect workers with family responsibilities against discrimination by the employer and, as I said, in particular against dismissal by the employer. The provisions cover a situation where an employee has responsibility for the care and support of a member of his or her family. Taking account of changing family patterns, the Bill covers, apart from the obvious dependent child, spouse, and immediate family members—defined as an adult, child, parent, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling of an employee, or his or her group—a definition of spouse, which is defined as a former spouse, a de facto spouse, and a former de facto spouse. The definition does not specifically limit de facto spouses to a relationship between a man and a woman. Therefore, it would be reasonable to assume that it does include gay and lesbian de facto couples.

However, an inquiry to the office of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) elicited the information that this amendment is based on ILO convention 156, and that this convention does not enable the Government to extend that definition in this way. However, ILO convention 111 specifically provides that power to the Government. I note that, in providing these amendments, the Government has not specifically stipulated that they are based on the implementation, under the external affairs power, of ILO convention 156. Hence, there is absolutely no reason whatsoever why the definition cannot be extended to cover gay de facto couples under ILO convention 111.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you moving amendments soon?

—I will be moving an amendment to that extent, yes. In view of the Opposition's strong support for civil liberties in the past, I look forward to its support for this amendment. I also look forward to the support of the Government for this amendment, since the Government has taken the courageous step of enabling gay people to serve in the defence forces. I shall confine any further remarks to these points, and raise related issues during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992. I want to confine my remarks to the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992, which effectively—if my understanding is correct—amends the Commonwealth superannuation schemes to remove the discrimination that presently exists on the ground of marital status. The amendments in this Bill are necessitated by the Government's amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act. I must say, by way of an aside, that Senator Spindler's contribution was somewhat alarming; not in relation to what he said about the provisions for benefits being extended to de facto relationships for same sex spouses but, in particular, in relation to his continuing references to the ILO.

PARA.TAB: With this Government's current proposal to introduce industrial relations laws based on International Labour Organisation conventions to override the States rights to legislate in this area—and, of course, it is abusing the external affairs power to do that—one is led to think that, with the support of the Democrats, there is very little reason to have a Federal parliament or any State parliaments. We may as well allow the United Nations, the International Labour Organisation, and all of the various other international organisations to run our country for us, if we have to continually look to these international covenants and treaties to find the basis of our legislation. It is a very alarming trend, which has happened over the last 10 to 15 years. It is certainly a trend that I am appalled by.

The Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill amends the following superannuation Acts: the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, the Governor-General Act 1974, the Judges' Pensions Act, the Parliamentary and Judicial Retiring Allowances Act 1973, the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, the Superannuation Act 1922, and the Superannuation Act 1976. The main change involves removing discrimination between legally married spouses and de facto ones. The Bill will define the criteria for spouse, which will replace the term `widow' or `widower'.

The amendments will broaden the eligibility for qualification as a spouse. The amendments will also remove the different treatment between a nuptial and an ex-nuptial child for the purposes of revisionary benefits. As I said a few minutes ago, whilst the legislative amendment is expanding the definition of spouse to include de facto relationships, it will not be expanded to recognise same-sex spouses.

One of the points of concern that I have—and I want to spend a few minutes on it this morning—is the cost and financial impact not only of this Bill, but the financial impact of unfunded superannuation liabilities as they apply across Australia and across the world. This is a problem that needs to be addressed at all levels of government in Australia. Again, the Bill gives us an opportunity to debate this growing problem.

The Government has not provided any costing of the financial impact of the amendments, even though it claims that the cost will be very small.
