I am not in a position to argue that, but it does raise the very important question of unfunded liabilities. We need go no further to find recent comment on this matter than the excellent report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation chaired by Labor Senator Nick Sherry. On page 24 of the third report of that Committee, some statistics are drawn together from across Australia on the liabilities accruing in the various Commonwealth and State superannuation schemes. It is important to know the definition of an unfunded liability—and that is provided in paragraph 74 of that report. It is basically where pension payments pledged by government to retirees are made from current revenue and where no fund exists to fund those future liabilities as they fall due.

The level of the problem accruing in Australia is becoming quite alarming. At this stage, the Commonwealth unfunded superannuation liability is in the realm of $33 billion; in Victoria, around $18 billion; in New South Wales, $14 billion; in Queensland, $3 billion; in Tasmania, $1.8 billion; in Western Australia, nearly $4 billion; in South Australia, nearly $3 billion; and in the Northern Territory, $0.4 billion. Across Australia, the size of this unfunded liability problem is now in the realm of $88 billion.

I put it to the Senate that, if action is not taken to address the problem of unfunded liabilities at State, local and Federal government levels, there will be a big price to pay in future generations. It is always very easy for governments to come to terms with their current year financial considerations and keep putting off these problems year after year but, as we all know, if we keep doing that, sooner or later a crisis develops. There is very good evidence across the world now that, if governments do not come to terms with these unfunded superannuation liabilities, a crisis point will be reached. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation found that the crunch will come in Australia a lot sooner than most of us would like to think.

For the Commonwealth Public Service, the current cost percentage—that is, employer financed costs of superannuation as a percentage of salaries—in the year 1984-85 was 12.5 per cent; in 1987-88, it was 16.9 per cent. By the year 2010, that is expected to rise to about 18.9 per cent to 19 per cent of salary. So the cost is getting quite enormous and quite out of hand.

The experience internationally is quite similar. Only a few countries have actually taken remedial action on this unfunded superannuation liability question. I think Great Britain and Denmark are the two best examples, but France, Italy, most of the European countries, and even Japan, have a rapidly rising problem. Indeed, there was a White Paper tabled in France recently which showed that contributions to its state pensions would rise from the current 19 per cent of payroll to between 31 per cent and 42 per cent by the year 2040. If payroll contributions to superannuation increase to between 31 per cent and 42 per cent within 40 years, then it is an enormous problem which needs to be addressed now; the problem certainly needs to be addressed in Australia before it gets much bigger.

The other point worth noting is that, when international ratings agencies and financiers start to focus on the unfunded liability question, they would be sensible to take those into account when they are determining the risk associated with lending to the Government or the private sector. When that focus begins to take place, it will place pressure on interest rates and the rate on sovereign debt. So Australia's current $88 billion problem, which is rising rapidly at the moment, will become an enormous problem as the baby boomers begin to retire in the year 2000.

The international experience was very well pointed out by Mr Brian Russell, the Chief Executive of the United Kingdom Steering Committee on Local Government Superannuation, who addressed a conference in Canberra a couple of months ago. One of his more interesting statements, which I will share with honourable senators, was that if we do not face up to the problem of unfunded superannuation liabilities and just continue with pay as you go—that is, funding people's superannuation payments by taxing the young to pay the old—we will be faced with a major problem. Mr Russell, whom I had the pleasure of meeting while he was in Australia, said to the conference in Canberra:

SPEECH.PARA: If countries fail to learn from them,—
that is, the funded schemes—
they will find themselves staring down into a yawning, unfunded, abyss with mounting debts and an over-burdened work-force, which has diminished at the worst possible moment.

There are a number of remedial actions that can be taken. Because the unfunded superannuation liability question is a matter which will affect the lives of every single Australian as we move towards the year 2000, it is certainly something that requires a non-partisan approach. I hope that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation—or some other committee that is set up to do so—will do more on this question.

PARA.TAB: Another action that could be taken is to investigate the usefulness and the appropriateness of setting up notional funds—that is, a fund that is designed in a notional way to fund those superannuation liabilities as they fall due. They are not proper funds; they do not actually include any investments. They are a book entry where the funding requirements into the future are assessed and a notional investment fund is established: it is an artificial arrangement.

If we do not have some thorough, well-considered assessment of the funds' requirements into the future—such as through a notional fund which could be regularly scrutinised by actuaries and auditors—then we will not know the size of the problem. It would then become a focus for public attention. The size of the problem would become more a day-to-day focus for the people and it would not then be so hard politically to convert that notional fund in steps into an actual fund—they may be small steps—to actually begin to fund those superannuation liabilities.

In conclusion, if we do not face up to the funding of these superannuation liabilities as the baby boomers start to retire in the year 2000, then we will have an enormous problem which will make our current debt problems pale into insignificance. This is an appropriate time to raise this matter as this Bill extends the benefits to a new range of people and, according to the Government, no cost has been associated with these new provisions. The coalition will not oppose the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992; we support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up a few points in my contribution today on this legislation. Firstly, I came into the chamber just in time to hear Senator Newman talking about the very recent discovery by the Liberal Party of women—
—Outrageous!

—Good! Splendid! What a good reaction straight away. I just refer to Mr Howard's document—I do not even remember its name. Was it called Future Directions, the Back to the Future document—the one that did not know how to spell `women' and devoted two column inches to child-care? That was the Liberal Party's document on women. I do not know, but I suspect that Senator Newman may have contributed to this within that Party. But the Liberal Party has finally found women to be something else besides barefoot, pregnant and in the kitchen—although that is to quote their National Party colleagues, and I have never heard any of them deny it. It has an interesting history. Someone in the Liberal Party who was interested in women's issues and rights might have despaired by now.

PARA.TAB: I remember the debate in this place about the sex discrimination legislation, and it makes terribly entertaining reading, mainly because of the `beyond farce' contributions from many members of the Opposition, certainly in this place, and in the other place. I think `barefoot, pregnant and in the kitchen' probably was said by one of the Queensland members of the National Party as a contribution to that debate. In fact, it is nice to reflect on what happened with that legislation. Some people in the Liberal Party crossed the floor to support the Government on it, and what happened to them? If one were interested one could ring Ian Macphee and ask; or one could ask Kathryn Sullivan where her career went because she supported women—to name just two. The Opposition does not like the cause of women. Women had to be in their place—at home, domesticated, married, dutiful and submissive. It has taken a long time for the Opposition to recognise, firstly, that women who have votes are worthy of being taken notice of but, more importantly, and less cynically, that women also have rights. So I find it entertaining today to listen to Senator Newman telling us how she has just discovered women; she has been talking to them for the last year, she said—that is a breakthrough, I suppose.

We should acknowledge that the Opposition now does want to talk to women, but I have to submit that people would not really be too carried away with what Senator Newman had to say because it is so recently discovered—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't.

—I am glad that Senator Faulkner is not persuaded. I was concerned about the misinformation that Senator Newman was giving us, particularly as the fact that it is so new had not necessarily been put on the airwaves.
—I raise a point of order. I ask that Senator Crowley withdraw the word `misinformation'. Nothing that I gave in my speech today was misinformation. I am offended. I ask her to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—There is no point of order. You may make a personal explanation at the conclusion of Senator Crowley's speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to get picky about these things, but Senator Newman did not tell us that it is a recent discovery of the Liberal Opposition—
—And it's not—
—Senator Newman did not tell us the history—
—And you know it. Talk about misinformation.

—I do know. That is the problem. I have been around watching it and talking to women for much longer than Senator Newman has. She certainly did not tell us about how the Opposition sent to Coventry its members who supported the sex discrimination legislation in the first place. Senator Newman did not tell us those things and she did not tell us that if one supported women's rights, one was likely to get very nasty treatment in the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: This Government put sex discrimination legislation in place. It took a long time and it took a few things that really matter. Proposing and promoting anti-discrimination legislation requires a combination of special characteristics. It requires political will; it requires serious commitment to the issue. One needs to be prepared to stay in there for the long haul—and, if one is concerned, one could ring John Stuart Mill; he would have a story to tell and so would his wife. One needs to know that it takes commitment. All of those things characterise the Government's record on sex discrimination legislation.

I welcome to the chamber the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Gareth Evans—a strong proponent of sex discrimination legislation and the rights of women, and certainly one of the people who have joined this Government's fight to see that those anti-discrimination measures were put in place. It is this Government that has put anti-discrimination legislation on the statute books, and it is this Government that is known and acknowledged for it.

Women of Australia recognise their rights. This is no longer the 1970s or 1980s. Ten years of Labor government has changed a lot of things in this country, particularly the perception women have of their own selves and how they are valued—and there is no going back on it.

In this package of legislation, this Government has added some further amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act. The one in particular that I would like to briefly comment on is the changes to provisions on sexual harassment. I have heard, and I suspect in the further contributions in this place today we will hear again if one is minded to listen, some very strange claims about what will happen to the world if we introduce the sexual harassment changes that are proposed in this legislation. We are really only bringing the Commonwealth legislation into line with the legislation that has been in South Australia for a few years and the legislation which, as I understand it, is now in Queensland and the ACT.

This legislation is actually a continuation of what the sex discrimination legislation says. It says that one is worthy of respect. Essentially that is what anti-discrimination legislation is about. It says that this society and this country will not go on allowing harassment, particularly sexual harassment. That is what this Government says to the people of Australia. It says that women can expect under the law to have an opportunity to bring a complaint and seek redress, and for men it says, `Don't do it. It is not legal. It is now illegal to behave in those ways that might have been a distraction or something that people thought was okay some time ago'. Sexual harassment is not acceptable. Women will say that it has never been acceptable. They have never liked it and they are very interested that the law has finally caught up with their view.

I am also interested to note—I find it curious to put it this way, but I think it is true—that the sex discrimination legislation and the sexual harassment amendments are not about protections for women, although of course the majority of people who have brought complaints have been women and the majority of people who are discriminated against in sex discrimination terms are women. It is certainly not the case that this legislation is specific to women. I suppose most of us would have noticed—certainly I did and I suspect other honourable senators would have—the complaint of harassment brought by a man against his employer not too long ago. The claim was that favours were sought and, in colloquial terms, the hard word was constantly being put upon him. That is the nature of sexual harassment. It is apparently a legitimate complaint if a man brings it. I think it is about time we recognised that it is a very legitimate complaint for women to not want, or to protest against, harassment.

What I particularly like about this legislation is that the definition of sexual harassment is no longer tied to detriment in employment. That has not brought the South Australian Government to its knees; it has not wrecked Queensland or the ACT. It is merely saying that if we are serious about anti-discrimination legislation, if we are serious about saying to women, more particularly, but also to men in our society, that they should feel free not to be attacked or harassed, then we will legislate for that.

A very interesting challenge, and a question that is often asked, is: if one knows of discrimination—and I suppose a lot of us can recognise it—what does one do about it? That is the question that one is faced with. The minute one takes steps to remove discrimination one is open to the charge of a different sort of discrimination; that is, positive discrimination or discrimination in favour of. But I do not worry too much about the abuse that is hurled at me if I stand in support of anti-discrimination, whether it is anti-race discrimination, anti-sex discrimination or whatever sort of anti-discrimination, because I am of the sort that believes that, once it is recognised, steps should be taken to do something about it.

The whole affirmative action program was to address the question of not dealing with discrimination by introducing a further discrimination. It took a long time for those of us who were concerned to work through that proposal to make sure we were not replacing one discrimination with another. It is the easiest and cheapest form of criticism of any changes to discrimination legislation. I do not find it persuasive. I believe that if one recognises discrimination, or harassment in this case, one must take steps to do something about it. As the community has seen what the legislation says, it has very quickly understood that it is a protective mechanism; it is an ensuring and a protection of rights. It is about saying to people in the society that they ought to know that those rights actually do mean that they can expect protection and that they can expect not to be discriminated against.

For women it has been a very long wait, but I can tell the Senate that for many women I know it is extraordinarily well valued. I particularly like the story of three young Aboriginal women, two of whom worked with the Public Service, who went into a bar in a hotel in South Australia some few years ago. They were in their early twenties and they asked for a drink. One of them actually used to go quite often after work with mates to drink in this hotel so she was particularly surprised when she was, with her colleagues, denied a drink in no uncertain terms. I think the man behind the bar probably was never more surprised than when those young women said, `You can't do that to us. We know the law. We know it protects our rights. We know how to complain about you. We know where to go. Do you want to reconsider whether we get our drink?'. I am sure they said it somewhat differently, but that is the sense of what was said. They did know that the law protected them, they did know what to do about it and they were confident and able to say what the law was on their behalf. I suppose it is probably the very best story I have about the benefits of anti-discrimination legislation.
I want to make a few comments about Senator Newman's wish list for women. The remarkable complaints that this Government in 10 years has done nothing for women—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the Lavarch Committee's recommendations?

—The honourable senator has what is called a very selective memory. Would Senator Newman like to compare the number of women completing education to year 12 now with the number way back then? The general retention rate of school children in this country was around 36 or 37 per cent when we came into office and it is now around 70 per cent across the country. From the last statistics I heard, more than 50 per cent of those retained year 12 students were girls. In tertiary education, in excess of 50 per cent of students going into universities now are women.

PARA.TAB: Anybody who has actually trawled over the history of the last century in this country and knows the fight women have had to get access to tertiary education should find the achievements in the last 10 years for rights for women to enter university, for access and opportunity for them to get into universities and for TAFE training, a matter of the greatest joy. Here is another sort of right for women: the right to actually have an education—a right that was denied them by tory governments for centuries. It has been the battle of women to get those rights—the right to an education and the right to a tertiary education as well.

Senator Newman was selective about another claim. She did not actually say that she will tell the women on the campaign trail that she knows that under Medicare they were relieved of the burden of worrying about whether they could pay when they went to the doctor or took their families to the doctor. But she has a special project: under Fightback, they will have to pay at least $5 per head each time they visit the doctor. And that is if they have taken $6 a week gap insurance—which would be $312 a year—on top of the $5 to cover them for the gap from 75 to 85 per cent of the rebate.

That is a good little package. Why does Senator Newman not tell the women of Australia about that? Why does she not tell them that when they are sick and have to go to the doctor or have to take a sick family to the doctor she has a project called `whack'em with at least $5 every time'? She is shifting the cost of health to the benefit of the specialists, the private hospitals and the AMA, rather than the people.

Senator Newman should tell the women of Australia that when they are sick they will have to pay more to see the doctor. She should also tell them that she is going to force them, encourage them or coerce them into buying private insurance so that the specialists' fees listed on the AMA schedule will be even more expensive. She should tell them that every time they want some meat or some clothes they will be hit with that whacko con vivo GST. I am sure that the women of Australia will be very pleased to know that when they go to the supermarket Senator Newman's 15 per cent GST will make everything cost at least 10 per cent more. That should win their hearts and minds. Why does she not tell the women of Australia that?

The honourable senator trawled through a very selective list. The women of Australia will be able to make their decision at the next election. They will be able to say that they were quietly winning under the awards and the Industrial Relations Commission. They were enjoying being nurses, for example. Nursing is a good job category to look at in Victoria. It has taken the nurses a very long time to get anything like wage justice. Then, goodness gracious me, Mr Kennett gets elected and what does he do? He has a few tricks for the nurses. He is particularly interested in removing penalty rates and overtime rates.

Senator Newman might ask nurses how much of their shifts are worked outside the standard hours of 9 to 5. She might ask policemen and women what they think about the changes under Mr Kennett. She might wonder whether Mr Howard will not do to Australia what Mr Kennett has done to Victoria. I think those things ought to win the hearts and minds of women.

I have heard about the Opposition's industrial relations policy for women: how they can go, one by one, to the boss and negotiate an arrangement—an individual deal—especially for them. This would have to be the joke of the century. Women who, on the whole, are in lower paid work and who are actually without industrial clout—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have been sitting here for what seems like hours listening to a string of misinformation. That last one takes the cake. Senator Crowley well knows that our policy does not require people to go, one by one, to their boss. They can have union representation, they can have workplace committees—
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Senator Evans, there is a senator already on her feet and she is taking a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am entitled to take a point of order against her point of order if it is not a point of order at all.
—Senator Evans, when the honourable senator is on her feet addressing the Chair and taking a point of order you are not entitled to do that. Please be seated.

—With respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you for a ruling on that. Is it not the case that we can take a point of order when somebody is already on his or her feet taking a point of order? It must be the case that we can.
—Senator Evans, the point is that Senator Newman is addressing the Chair. She is taking a point of order. I am listening to what she is saying. When she finishes, I will take your point of order.
—I have concluded my point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—There is no point of order, Senator Newman. If you have a personal explanation to make, you may make it at the conclusion of Senator Crowley's speech.

—I raise a point of order. I seek your formal determination, Mr Acting Deputy President, as to whether it is appropriate to rise and take a point of order when somebody is in the middle of taking a point of order. Because if the point of order that is being taken is not itself a point of order, it must be appropriate to challenge that. And the only way we can challenge it, consistent with the forms of this House, is to take another point of order. That is my understanding of the way the procedure works. I would be most unhappy if a precedent were to be set by your sitting me down.

—Senator Evans, to the extent that Senator Newman was expressing a point of order to the Chair, in order to allow me to gain a sensible and comprehensive understanding of her point of order I was required to hear her to exhaustion. To that extent, I do not allow other senators to interrupt the speaker when he or she is on his or her feet.
—Nonetheless, I seek a ruling on this matter on a considered basis, if you would not mind.
—I am happy to refer the matter to the President. My ruling shall be, for the duration of my period in this chair, that a senator taking a point of order shall not be interrupted.
—I thank my colleagues very much for wasting three or four minutes of my time.
—I am sorry.

—I certainly do not mean the Minister. I will close with an item that is rather topical—that is, the Singleton advertisement. Of course, we know that we should not be giving it air time, but I think he is doing a good enough job without any special assistance from me. I think that advertisement captures in some ways the problem with the Opposition. The advertisement referring to beer men is 10 years out of date—if not longer. In fact, as a feminist with a sense of humour, I am hoping that Mr Singleton will run a series of non-discriminatory ads which actually go on to tell me what a beer man's body is like. (Time expired)

—I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Crowley and I wish to make a personal explanation. It is very difficult to know quite where to begin because Senator Crowley has spent the entire time misrepresenting both my Party and me. I can now respond only on the basis of her misrepresentation of me. She suggested that I had only newly come to the issues of status of women and that my interest in women's issues was of very short duration. I point out that I first became aware of the problems that women face in our community back in 1961 when, as a Commonwealth public servant, I married and found that I could no longer be a permanent public servant, leading through to problems with obtaining finance without my husband's guarantee. Then practising under the Family Law Act, I saw many women in real difficulties because they had nowhere to go to escape an abusive husband.

PARA.TAB: I suppose I was sensitised by all these issues, and in 1972 I joined the Women's Electoral Lobby to fight for more women in parliament and to make sure that the men in parliament were also sensitised to the needs of Australian women. Through the 1970s, I was the convener for laws and the status of women with the National Council of Women in Tasmania. I was a founding member of two women's refuges to protect women who needed refuge from domestic violence.

I have debated issues of importance to women as well as issues relating to defence, education, veterans affairs, et cetera, in this Parliament over the 6 1/2 years I have been here. I undertook my consultations with women, which I referred to in my speech and which Senator Crowley referred to slightingly in her speech, as a shadow Minister as part of Dr Hewson's consultation process with the Australian people—the Australia 2000 process. This led to the establishment of Fightback. The words, aspirations, hopes, dreams and even the fears of Australians were incorporated in Fightback to make Australia a better place to live for all of us and for our children and grandchildren in the decade ahead. Those consultations with women's organisations led to my editing the book Australian Women Speak, which I referred to in my speech.

Mr Acting Deputy President, that is a potted, thumbnail sketch of how Senator Crowley has maligned me and misrepresented my involvement in the concerns of women over 20 years. I find it very offensive that she took that line. I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that any fair person listening to this debate would realise that if she so grossly misrepresented me, so too did she grossly misrepresent my Party, my Party's policies and the value of Fightback for the women—indeed, the men, women and children—of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the package of Bills before us: the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, and the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992. I listened with interest to Senator Crowley's cynical contribution, in which she said that she was proud of her Government's efforts in the area of sex discrimination and equal opportunity for all Australians.

PARA.TAB: I would like to highlight some of the failures of the Government's efforts in these areas, particularly in the area of women's health, which is a favourite subject of Senator Crowley's. I am sorry that she is not in the chamber to hear this. I would also like to repeat the comments of Mr Michael Lavarch, when he talked about the Government's failure to tackle the problems with serious policy options. Mr Lavarch blamed the slow pace of reform on Ministers, claiming that, while many introduced women's programs with fanfare and publicity, they often lacked the commitment to follow their rhetoric through.

I would like to highlight the Government's failure to implement a lot of its important policies to help Australian women after 10 years of empty rhetoric. I would particularly like to outline its failure to provide adequate health care and services to Australia's rural women.

Health issues are clearly of major importance to women because they are the major users of the health system—not only for the usual illnesses and traumas, but also for services and illnesses that are particular to women. The Government has made many promises to improve women's health services. It has even put aside large sums of money to back its promises, but in many cases the money simply has not been spent and the promises have been broken.

The Government has failed women in four specific areas in health. Firstly, osteoporosis costs the health budget between $200m and $500m each year. Yet the Government has failed to provide Medicare benefits for bone density measurement—a simple preventative measure which could save the Government millions and millions of dollars. The second area is contraception. There have been no new contraceptive pills made available in Australia since 1981. The third area is breast cancer. This Government failed to live up to a March 1990 election promise to spend $64m over three years on the national program for early detection of breast cancer. In total, the allocation, including this year's estimate, is only $33.6m. The fourth area is the Government's failure to fund adequately specific women's health programs. In fact, five women's health programs suffered a drop in funding in 1991-92. These five programs, as contained in Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2 of 1991-92, show a total shortfall in funding of over $4.5m.

All this is bad enough in itself, but spare a thought for some rural women who in the 1990s are supposed to receive not only the same treatment as men but also the same treatment as their city sisters. They have always suffered from abysmal health care. Rural people are actively discriminated against and are candidates for rural poverty, yet the services they need access to have been taken away from them. If for no other reason, rural women need ready access to doctors and health services simply because of the enormous stress they are under.

All this comes on top of an increasing workload for rural women. They have always worked full time on farms. They have done things such as bookkeeping, farm work and domestic work, as well as bringing up children and looking after aged relatives. The rural decline has added to this work because women are now taking the place of hired workers whose wages many primary producers can no longer afford.

The same factors are stopping rural women taking part in social activities. A community nurse in a town in north-east Victoria contacted by the Healthsharing Women journal in 1991 said that the people in the district were not visiting each other or attending social functions as much because of the cost of petrol. She described it as a `social health consequence of the economic downturn'.

Yet despite all this, the Government has been exceptionally slow in providing rural counsellors; and those counsellors that do exist simply cannot cope with the existing workload. A 1989 study has shown that of the 72 types of social and community services available, less than half are available in rural areas. The most marked differences in services available in rural and non-rural areas occurs in the areas of counselling, medical specialists, alcohol rehabilitation and disability and women's services.

Private, public and bush nursing hospitals across rural Australia have been downgraded and closed. Local GPs have packed up shop and moved to larger cities and regional centres. As a result, rural areas have significantly higher `population to general practitioner' ratios than urban areas. In the city it is one GP per 156 people; in the country it is one GP per 434 people. In addition, child-care facilities are not available, the high cost of petrol makes trips to see a doctor very expensive and there is no adequate public transport. Many rural families now cannot afford private health insurance.

If we combine all of these things, there can sometimes be unfortunate or tragic results. One example, quoted in the Healthsharing Women article on `Women, Health and the Rural Decline', is of a Victorian woman with an 8-month old epileptic baby. The woman wanted to know where the nearest support group was. When she found out it was two hours' drive away, she said she could not go—she simply could not afford the petrol costs. What happened to this woman and her epileptic baby? Has she got the information and the support that she needs? Is she coping well or is she not coping at all?

Where is the Labor Government's rhetoric on human rights, equal opportunity, sex discrimination and affirmative action when it comes to health services for women in rural and remote areas? I do not know where it is. But what I can tell the Senate is that the first thing we need to do is get the wealthy off our public hospital queues by encouraging more Australians to take out private health insurance. In 1992 only 44 per cent of Australians were privately insured. In fact, between 20 and 25 per cent of Australians earning more than $50,000 do not have private health insurance and take their places alongside the poor and the elderly in our public hospital queues.

The coalition's plan to improve health services, and health services to rural women in particular, includes improving access to health services, especially with mobile units providing mammography and bone density testing in rural areas. It also includes providing health insurance subsidies for those on incomes up to $30,000, and those aged over 65 at various rates depending on incomes. This will be of great benefit to rural women, particularly those living on farms, because farm losses will currently ensure that they are entitled to the maximum subsidy. The coalition's plan also includes retaining Medicare for the genuinely needy; increasing the remote area allowance and zone rebates by at least 25 per cent to ease the disadvantages experienced by women in remote areas of Australia; and reducing petrol costs, which will reduce the cost of travelling distances to hospital and specialist medical care services.

We will ensure that women of all ages, and from a variety of backgrounds, whether living in the city or the country, will have ready access to general and specialist health services. In the 1990s it is simply not good enough that women die and suffer from easily preventable illnesses and traumas. The coalition will not shirk from the responsibility to bring Australia's health policy for women into the 1990s. Fightback provides the means to bring about a fundamental change to our health policy for all Australians; and we will fight to bring Australia the fair, equitable and quality health service it deserves.

Finally, in the context of the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992, I would like to make a brief comment on women gaining access to superannuation. Under this Government's policy, people who are outside the paid work force are discriminated against when it comes to providing for retirement because they are unable to contribute to a superannuation scheme.

In addition, people who work only part-time or casually are unable to provide adequately for their retirement. This is because the Government has based its assumptions on a full-time worker earning an average of $30,000 a year over 40 years, who can then generate around 40 per cent of average weekly earnings in retirement compared with the age pension which equates to only 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. But, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, only 30 per cent of the 5.3 million workers in 1989-90 were women. In addition, 25 per cent of our work force is part-time or casual, and 75 per cent of these people are women. Also, 50 per cent of taxpayers earn less than $20,700.

This Government's scheme is a narrow occupational based scheme and therefore affects a disproportionate amount of women who will be unable to provide for their retirement. By contrast, the coalition's policy extends superannuation to spouses and partners, which will make a dramatic difference to women, both in and out of the paid work force.

One of the means by which superannuation will be extended to women is by allowing universal rebates of 25 per cent on contributions up to $6,000 a year for individuals and $12,000 a year for couples. The coalition estimates that superannuation will be extended to two million women outside the paid work force. For the first time, men and women who do not work or who are in part time or casual employment or with broken work records will have access to security in retirement. That is what equal opportunity is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the Bills before us, the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity Employment for Women) Amendment Bill 1992, is to amend the Affirmative Action Act. One of the purposes of the Bill is to extend the application of the Act to voluntary bodies which employ more than 100 people and also to unions and to group training schemes.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also establishes the Affirmative Action Agency as a statutory body and gives it discretionary power to waive the current reporting requirements under the Act. In its current form the Affirmative Action Agency has been a great success. But now is the time to recognise that, if we as a community are serious about the principles of affirmative action, then the agency needs to be independent of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and to become a statutory body in its own right.

The principles of equal employment opportunity and affirmative action need a strong body not only to monitor their implementation but also to spread their application even further. In 1991, 83 per cent of respondents to a workplace attitudes survey felt that affirmative action for women was necessary but an almost equal number felt that the majority of employers paid only lip-service to the program and were not moving beyond the bare minimum requirements of the legislation.The recent review of the agency indicated that the status of the agency, as an appendage of an appendage within a government department, was an inhibiting factor in the progress towards true integration of the principles of affirmative action into workplace reform strategies.

At present the agency is forced to operate in a volatile political environment with a fluctuating level of commitment. At present it is constantly having to prove the value of the affirmative action legislation while being hamstrung by a lack of status and resources. The need for affirmative action strategies which go further is becoming greater with the advent of enterprise bargaining in the workplace.

Women now make up 42 per cent of the paid work force and the majority of the unpaid or volunteer work force. Forty-five per cent of women with children under the age of five are also in paid work. But there is still a significant amount of gender segmentation, with women clustered in a small range of occupations with limited advancement opportunities and reduced pay scales. I note that the Government is bringing on a package of reforms to the Sex Discrimination Act at this time which will attempt to address some of these inequities.

I could go on for some time listing the obstacles which women face, including the fact that at the closing end of this century, which has seen so many changes in the workplace, women still do not actually receive equal pay for equal work and have less access to award rates, bonuses and overtime. That is the difference between the rhetoric and the application. An affirmative action program with a strong agency to enforce and encourage its implementation is necessary to change the model of the family and the woman worker which now still holds back workplace reform.

If we are to use enterprise bargain agreements to their fullest potential, we need to ensure that they are made with the principles of EEO in mind. An ideal enterprise bargain could well include flexible working hours; pro-rata award benefits; work related child-care, something in which I have had a particular personal interest in for some time; and it could also establish workplace environments which are non-discriminatory and not ruled by prejudicial behaviour.

With scarce resources, the focus of the agency has been on reporting and compliance of existing requirements, rather than actively pursuing its strategic policy objectives. The amendments give the agency the discretion to waive reporting requirements under the Act and to concentrate its resources on achieving what should be its unanimously supported vision of increasing the acceptance, understanding, implementation and extension of the principles of EEO.

The agency has a hitherto undeveloped role to play as an educational and advisory body as well as a policing body. In my interpretation, this Act enshrines the principle that there should be one rule for all, in that unions and voluntary bodies of considerable size must also comply. It also acknowledges that, despite the achievements of the agency so far, there is still much work to be done. The Democrats will be supporting this package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, on the same day we learned our foreign debt passed 42 per cent of gross domestic product, the Senate debated and passed the Endangered Species Protection Bill. That Bill will be a further impediment to mining industry development, notwithstanding the fact that, so far as is known, there is no evidence that mining has caused the extinction of any species.

PARA.TAB: We are now debating a Bill to amend the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and affirmative action legislation. These amendments are, I understand, principally responsible for the substantial increases to the running costs of these agencies—23 and 31 per cent respectively in the current Budget compared with 1991-92. These are ominous signs and strange priorities for a country with our foreign debt problem.

I have a qualitatively different objection to the proposed sexual harassment amendments to the HREOC Act. These amendments propose that anyone who claims to have been offended, humiliated or intimidated by alleged sexist remarks will be able to complain to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. If conciliation fails, HREOC would be able to award substantial damages against the respondent—damages which would be legally enforceable unless overturned in the Federal Court. This, of course, would require the respondent to have enough money to take the matter to court. Not many people have.

Previously, or more accurately, under the existing provisions, a complainant is required to demonstrate disadvantage before receiving damages, and awards are not legally enforceable unless the complainant secures an order of the Federal Court. Legal onus of proof, therefore, under the proposed conditions is thus transferred from the prosecution to the accused.

Moreover, the concepts of offence, humiliation and intimidation are entirely subjective. How would anyone prove—even in a real court—that a complainant was not offended, humiliated or intimidated? How much harder would it be to prove in a kangaroo court in which evidence is not necessarily sworn and proceedings are not necessarily conducted in public?

Any system which provides an opportunity for an individual to receive monetary damages obviously offers an incentive for exaggeration, if not the outright falsification of evidence. In a real court, or other procedures in which sworn statements are mandatory, the risk of perjury charges is a major deterrent to that sort of behaviour. But if these amendments are passed that deterrent will be watered down to the point of insignificance.

These amendments have been incestuously conceived by a group of activists citing and recycling each other's reports and opinions in a round robin process. They were midwifed by a subcommittee of the House of Representatives, the majority of which recommended them. At least one member of that majority has subsequently privately repudiated and ridiculed the subcommittee recommendations. No credit to him for allowing his name to be associated with them.

They were then, most unfortunately, adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), railroaded through the Caucus committee and passed at midnight under guillotine in the House of Representatives. I can only assume that the Prime Minister adopted them because the same or similar activists referred to above convinced him that this was a recipe for improving his standing with women and share of the women's vote. I believe that conclusion is misguided. In this case—and probably in all similar cases—the activists neither speak for, nor represent the views of, those for whom they claim to speak and represent.

For similar reasons—and at the behest of similar activists—former Western Australian Premier, Brian Burke, established the Women's Information Referral Exchange, known as WIRE, which then, or so it would appear, advised at least some of its clients to invest or, more accurately, lose their money in Western Women, an outfit run by a crook named Robin Greenburg—reminiscent of Ronald Reagan in 1987.

Finally, unlike some 10 of my Caucus colleagues who said at the time of the Gulf War that they would not vote in parliament in accordance with a Caucus decision, I will not vote against the Bill. I actually take the pledge and Party discipline seriously. If people want to know why, I suggest they have a look at the United States Congress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak on these Bills, I would like to respond to some of the comments made by Senator Crowley earlier in this debate, in particular her gratuitous insults of the Liberal Party in general and Senator Newman in particular.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Crowley said about the Liberal Party's attitude to women was just a clear nonsense. She said that the Liberal Party took the attitude that women should be barefoot and in the kitchen. Obviously anyone who says that has not met up with the luminaries in the Liberal Party, in particular Senator Bishop in this chamber and, in the New South Wales Parliament, the Hon. Marlene Goldsmith, the Hon. Virginia Chadwick and the Hon. Helen Sham-Ho. These are people who have, over the last few years, shown that they can make a tremendous contribution to the cause of women in the Party.

Senator Crowley is probably also totally unaware what an affirmative action party the Liberal Party was as far back as 1940. When the Party was established it set up in its constitution the provision that women should take particular places. For example, in New South Wales two of the four vice presidents must be women. In the State Executive, of the 12 country and city representatives, at least four must be women. If men achieve a higher vote than women, as I did on one occasion, they get passed over because there is a requirement that at least four women must be in these positions.

Obviously Senator Crowley, in terms of her Liberal Party history, has no idea of the fact that this has been an affirmative action party for many years. I would like to compare our record, and the special position these women hold, with that of the Labor Party and its treatment of women within its party ranks.

I thought Senator Crowley's comments on Senator Newman were absolutely disgraceful. Senator Newman pointed out her very long and distinguished track record on women's issues within this Party, which goes back to 1970 when she joined WEL. She has been a very keen advocate for women's causes and has shifted party policy in the direction that assists women. So to say that Senator Newman has had an interest in this area only over the last year is an absolute nonsense.

As Senator Newman pointed out, in the production of the Australia 2000 document, which I will further allude to later in my speech, she was responsible for producing Australian women speak, which targets the particular aspects of Liberal Party policy as it affects women. She has a very distinguished record in this area. It certainly does Senator Crowley no credit to take such liberties with the truth in relation to the Liberal Party in general and Senator Newman in particular.

I turn now to these specific Bills that we are considering today in the Senate. In looking through this legislation I find it truly disappointing that the Federal Government has really failed to implement some very important policies which affect Australian women. I believe this stands in very stark contrast with the policies of the coalition which have been developed with women's issues particularly in mind.

I also want to point to the impact this policy will have on women in the education area. I am well aware that over the last 10 years this Labor Government has severely damaged the education sector. This impacts quite dramatically on women and on their chances for an education, work and a decent future.

When we turn to the various sectors of education, we see that in post-secondary education over 50,000 school leavers, over 50 per cent of whom are female, are denied access to higher education. The Labor Government has neglected the area of further education and vocational training by turning away up to 140,000 people each year, again more than half being women. After 10 years of allowing the sector to languish, this Government has finally been prodded into reforming the technical and further education area.

More specifically, the Government has failed migrant women in Australia with cuts in the adult migrant education program. The Federal Government has shown a very blatant disregard for child-care, which is often so critical for women participating in education. These areas of education are absolutely critical to Australian women trying to regain access to the work force. After 10 years in office, this Government should be condemned by its record across the various sectors of education that I have alluded to.

The views of Australian women were very well considered by the coalition parties during the formulation of the Fightback program. One of the seminal documents in terms of forming this policy was a program that we ran across Australia called Australia 2000. This was a political, grassroots consultation program that gave many people their first chance to express their opinions and to become actively involved in the design of their country's future. The findings were printed in a document called Australia 2000, and a subsequent report, Australian women speak, specifically targeted the findings to the needs of women. This report was mentioned by Senator Newman earlier in the debate.

During the Australia 2000 program the importance of education in enhancing the self-esteem of Australian women was constantly emphasised. The encouragement of women to engage in education was seen as crucial to their future career opportunities. But the need for equal opportunity in the workplace for those who look for career advancement remains unchanged. To women in the paid work force who at the same time are trying to maintain the responsibilities of a family, issues such as child-care are absolutely critical.

This is something of which I personally have a lot of knowledge from my own family situation. My wife of 25 years and I have six children. Throughout our marriage my wife has been a full time home-maker, a part time employee and a full time employee. We are very aware of the issues concerning women who try to move in and out of the work force in response to changing family economic circumstances.

Having experienced this through the seventies and eighties, and now into the nineties, I can assure the Senate that it is extremely difficult for women. A lot more government focus is needed on the whole crucial issue of child-care. It was frequently stated during the Australia 2000 program that the provision of quality child-care on an affordable basis—including long day care, occasional care, after school hours care and holiday care—was imperative for women undertaking careers outside the home.

This comes into particular focus with the Christmas holidays approaching. There are situations in many homes in this country where both husband and wife work and where children have to be cared for over a very long period of time. Society has not responded very well to this need, and in many cases we have the situation where there is no supervision at all for children.

In the coalition policy we have put aside funding of up to $90m for this area of child-care over and above what the Government is currently proposing to spend. It came home to many of us last year, when we were conducting the adult and community education hearings in the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, that this was the crucial issue for women. As we moved around Australia, we realised that there were many women who, through no fault of their own, had missed out on education and needed to catch up. Many of these women had been out of the work force for many years because they were in a full time child-care role and they wanted to come back into the work force. Yet they were often blocked, not only because there was inadequate access to courses but also because there was inadequate access to proper child-care.

In our Fightback policies we have addressed the question of additional funding for child-care and also the question of additional funding for education. In the Fightback document, the area that does best in terms of additional funding is education. This is of great benefit to women. We will spend another $945m over the next triennium on the expansion of vocational education and training, providing over 220,000 new training places. This funding commitment is an increase of $225m over the Keating Government's recent TAFE allocation increase. This massive injection of new funds into TAFE, plus the extra funding for places in tertiary education, will give women a wider range of better quality education and training opportunities. With these new skills, women will achieve the important first step towards re-entering the work force.

Our commitment to women does not just show through education policies. Equity considerations are built into all aspects of the Fightback policy, which is truly the most comprehensive and all embracing policy package presented by any political party in Australian history. The policies for women in Fightback are many and wide reaching. Under Fightback, the creation of two million new jobs by the end of the decade will provide unemployed women, women who are discouraged job seekers and women with a marginal attachment to the work force with either full time or part time employment and will ensure that these women no longer remain vulnerable members of our society. Increased funding for child-care support under Fightback by $90m will help women who have found that the high cost of child-care fees has precluded them from the paid work force in the past to get jobs.

A suitable system of family support has also been provided under Fightback. Family allowances will be doubled, which means an extra $1,500 per year for a three-child family. The dependent spouse rebate will also be increased by $300. We will introduce a $1,500 superannuation rebate for a non-working spouse, and an additional 320,000 families will pay no personal income tax because we will be lifting the minimum tax threshold. These policies, combined with the coalition's encouragement for employerassisted child-care, will provide women in the paid work force with greater access to child-care and give women in unpaid work better access to occasional child-care facilities.

Under Fightback women will also benefit through our policies regarding industrial relations and superannuation, and there are benefits for older women, Aboriginal women, migrant women, career women, and women in rural towns and small business. Time precludes me from going through all the specific ways in which women will benefit from those policies. While I support the legislation for its equal opportunity provisions and other measures to correct the imbalance against women in our society, I recommend that, for women to benefit more fully in our society, the Government needs to adopt the complete policies of the Fightback package. After the next election I am sure that they will have the opportunity to do this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the time available to me is brief. Other than for the fact that I had the dubious distinction of hearing Senator Crowley, I probably would not bother to rise. I make but one simple point. I believe that there is an absolute gulf of difference between anti-discrimination and affirmative action. Affirmative action, by its very nature, is discrimination by one group in society against another group and inevitably at the expense of that other group. Employment based on sex or gender is discriminatory by its nature. It is reasonably argued by the more balanced, sensible women in the community that in the past there has been discrimination against women on the basis of their sex and that very often their talents and abilities have been overlooked. Senator Crowley and others in the Labor Party obviously actively support the proposed quotas, which will have the effect of discriminating against people in society on the basis of sex or gender, and prevent them from realising their full potential.

PARA.TAB: There are two other aspects. If we allow appointments to be made on the basis of gender and not on ability, it reflects poorly upon those people who have, by dint of their natural ability and talent, been promoted because they fall within the general category of people who have been promoted on a basis other than ability, and it detracts from their natural talent. A problem for American negroes is that they have become the lost class in middle management; because of the quota system, negroes have been promoted to a category and then shuffled sideways. They have simply been put there to fulfil the social engineering aspirations of a section of the community. We have human rights and equal opportunity legislation which ought properly to accommodate areas where there is discrimination against women.

It seems to me, on the statistics that I have looked at, that between 1976 and 1983, when the coalition was in government, there was a fall in the percentage of women in employment positions which have been their traditional role. Since 1986 to 1992 there has been a rise. So the Affirmative Action Agency does not appear to have had any marked statistical effect upon the occupations and the roles which women fill in society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make one or two points in the general debate and some on the specific Bills: the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992. I was disappointed that Senator Crichton-Browne, in his remarks just now, chose to raise the old bogey of quotas in the context of the affirmative action legislation which is being amended here today, and amended to advantage. In my view that argument is a furphy. It always has been a furphy in the context of this Government's affirmative action legislation, legislation which I have always supported. I have supported its being strengthened along the way, as it is being strengthened again today.

PARA.TAB: It is a furphy that is also raised in the Opposition's second reading amendment—but more gently than Senator Crichton-Browne raised it—which I viewed as perhaps a last gasp, a final go at raising that old bogey, which in past years has been insisted on very strongly by the Opposition. I am sorry that it has raised its head again. I thought the Opposition had realised by now that affirmative action legislation is just that. It does not interfere with employment or advancement on the basis of merit; it simply seeks to ensure that that merit is seen, is acknowledged and is then able to be acted upon.

I also raise my voice in opposition to the coalition's policy to abolish the Affirmative Action Agency and disperse it throughout a range of other agencies and departments. I believe that equates to dispersal of the impact of the Affirmative Action Agency—an impact which I think has been clear over the years and will be improved by the amendments before us today.

I noted the lack of a definite proposition in Senator Hill's contribution as to what would happen with the role of the Affirmative Action Agency. I welcome the moves to cement the independence of the agency represented in this package because I believe that may, as is the Government's intention, retard that intention of the Opposition should it come to government after the next election.

In the present context, and in the possible context of a change of government, I believe that Liberal and National industrial relations policies, as implemented in my home State of Victoria—with the prospect of implementation federally—are harmful to women. The removal of overtime and penalty rates from awards, or their being tossed into a basket for negotiation, is of particular concern and disadvantage to women. I have my own reservations about the enterprise bargaining system put in place by the Government in that same context. Because of the constraints of time, I will not go into this matter in detail; I simply want to put it on the record.

Many times in debate on these Bills, contributors—when speaking on these Bills and on general issues of equal opportunity and sex discrimination—have referred to the proposition that legislation is important in moving our society in enlightened directions in these areas but that legislation is not the complete answer. I thoroughly agree with that proposition. We cannot necessarily legislate to change public attitudes. Nevertheless, as legislators we have a responsibility to play our part in shifting community attitudes and responding, in our responsibility to changing laws, to attitudes in the community which are already changing ahead of the legislation and ahead of the laws.

We can see that measures taken in a bureaucratic sense towards affirmative action do not always work to improve the role and opportunities of women. Perhaps the best example of that was brought to our attention through Senator Tierney's contribution to this debate in which he pointed out the many provisions that exist in the Liberal Party's arrangements to advantage women. Yet the role of women in the Liberal Party, particularly in past times—with the possible exception of those in this chamber—has not been a strong one when it comes to the elected and decision making positions. We know that legislation, bureaucracy and those sorts of processes do not always work, and it is important that community attitudes are moved by other means.

I think it is very good to see the debate on women's issues and policies for women that is so much a part of this election campaign, which we seem to have been engaged in for many months already. This debate has been noted, and participated in, by members of the press. I think it is useful in advancing the interests of women. Women, by their voting patterns, have given increased significance to the issues that they want addressed. As former Senator Susan Ryan has said, the women's vote is now volatile and hard to win. That is why the respective contenders for government, some of whom we have heard in this chamber today, are engaged in the debate.

In this debate—as noted in a major article in the Age by Margo Kingston—it appears that the Liberal Party is trying to persuade women that the Labor Party's approach to women's policies is tired and that women are no longer victims needing protection. The Liberals are changing their approach as well. Something has been said about this matter in the chamber already this morning. Margo Kingston contended in her article that the Liberals now say, in a switch of rhetoric, that women are the same as men. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Treating women as women almost by definition implies that women are different. Treating women as people means that women and men by definition start on equal footing.

Clearly, that is not so, even though it is probably the basis for the approach that the coalition is taking. We do not have to go very far to see that men and women are not equal or even that they do not start on an equal footing. That is why I am concerned, in relation to industrial relations processes—whether they be coalition processes of individual contracts or Government processes of enterprise bargaining—that we should not take this approach or start from the mind set that women are equal or start from the same position. Some are, but too many are not.

PARA.TAB: If honourable senators flick through the Half way to equal report, which forms the basis for most of the amendments in this package of Bills, as I did in my office a few minutes ago, they will find information on issues such as women in the paid work force who have family responsibilities. On page 30 of that report, Helen L'Orange, First Assistant Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, when speaking at a women and employment seminar, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: However, many employers still take the view that women employees have the primary responsibility for finding solutions to family problems. There is little recognition of the fact that these problems result often from a work environment designed around a family structure which consists of dad going to work and mum staying at home full time with dependent kids.

There is any amount of statistics, many of them in this report, that indicate that gender segregation in the work force still exists. In the Half way to equal report there is a great deal of evidence of the position of women in academia being far from equal. For example, there is an under-representation of women in senior academic positions, a low representation of women on academic staff and a clustering in junior academic positions. Page 59 of the report refers to the Public Service. It states:

If women and men with the same qualifications and length of service had reached the same levels, there would be about 60 per cent more women in the ASO6 to 8 level and almost twice as many in the Senior Executive Service as at June 1989.
On page 163, referring to women in politics, Maxine McKew, the ABC's senior political journalist, said:
The dominant ethic in politics is still overwhelmingly male. Women have undoubtedly influenced the agenda, but they have not yet managed to change the rules of the game.

Attitudinal change is important. In spite of all the legislation—and I acknowledge the amount of legislation regarding equal opportunity and anti-discrimination that has been passed in the last decade in this place and which is improved on in this package of Bills—community attitudes remain a problem. Since in this debate a good deal of emphasis is put on the fact that there is an ongoing responsibility for women, which many women choose, of full time home making for at least part of their life—in my case, for 20 years of my life—I think it is to that area that we can and must look. In an article in the Weekend Australian in June of this year, Bettina Arndt made some very important comments on that issue. I commend that article to my colleagues. She drew together a great deal of research, all of which makes the same point: in spite of legislation and in spite of rhetoric, the burden still falls most heavily on women within the home—and, of course, it becomes the double burden.

PARA.TAB: This conflict in attitudes is vested on children, and this is borne out by Sydney sociologist Hugh Mackay. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Boys are confused by the messages their mothers are giving them and the contradictory role model their fathers are providing.

We need to look at the approaches that are taken in legislation that has already been passed and in amendments that we are passing here today to see whether, in each of our lives and in the lives of our community generally, we are really moving in directions which confirm the sorts of changes which we are trying to implement. We have a responsibility to legislate for these changes, but as individuals we should also see whether we are playing our own roles, as we should, in the attitudinal change of the community.

PARA.TAB: The issue of observation is referred to in the Bettina Arndt article. She explains that when mothers pick up their children from school, the boys automatically hand their school bags to their mother. In the handing and the receiving of the school bag there is a quite strong social statement. That might seem to be a small thing, but it equates with picking up dirty socks and a range of other things which we need to think twice about before we do. I do express a word of sympathy for women described in the Bettina Arndt article as having a double burden. Despite their good intentions it is often hard to summon the energy to fight the fight over school bags dropped in the hallway, unemptied dishwashers, unfed dogs, wet towels on the floor and so on.

I strongly support this legislation to the extent that it can make some changes that are necessary in the lives of men, women and children in the community. It goes far beyond legislation, which we all agree with; we all have a role to play, both as legislators and as individuals, in advancing the interests of all people for equal opportunity and non-discrimination in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today debating a series of Bills. The first three Bills are the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill. Lumped with those Bills is the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill. Some honourable senators have spoken to that Bill.

PARA.TAB: The debate on the first three Bills has been quite wide ranging and I refer to one aspect of it. In a debate of this kind it is inevitable that a number of issues will be brought up. The Liberal Party has been discussed by at least two senators on the other side of the chamber. They have substantially indicated their ignorance of Liberal Party policy and in particular their ignorance of the role that Senator Newman has played during her life with respect to the advancement of the cause of women. It is in addressing that matter that I will take a little time of the Senate. I think it is better that this be done now, rather than the matter being left on the record as it is.

Senator Tierney spoke briefly of the record of the Liberal Party and women. I shall not go through it all because it is on the public record in each of the six States of this country. The first women elected to any of those parliaments, starting with Edith Cowan in 1921, were from non-Labor parties such as the Nationalist Party and the United Australia Party, which was the predecessor of the Liberal Party. In each of the six States non-Labor women were the first women elected. This is also the case with Dame Enid Lyons in the House of Representatives.

I could go through the record of the Party in the Parliament and the organisation. It is my view that the strength of the organisation is very important indeed. It is there that women have played a very important role. Joy Mein used to be President of the Liberal Party in Victoria and other women have been presidents of divisions since that time. Women have played a prominent role in that respect. To suggest, as one Government senator has, that the Liberal Party had just discovered women flies in the face of the facts. One will find this if one takes the trouble to read the history of the Liberal Party, inquire about the way it is structured at an organisational level and find out about the opportunities that there are for women to a play a very meaningful part.

It is in the area of policy initiatives that the record needs to set straight. Suggesting that we had only discovered women in the last year or so almost implied that nothing had ever been done previously. I will run through some of the issues of importance, starting with the Child Care Act of 1972 introduced by the McMahon Liberal Government. Family allowances were introduced in 1976-77, being paid directly to mothers in whose care the children were. That rate was raised in 1981-82 by 50 per cent for larger families and by that much in 1982-83 for the first and second children. The allowance was debased quite soon after the Hawke Government came to power because it did not increase those amounts.

The National Women's Advisory Council was established in 1977 following a national inquiry into the role of women. The Human Rights Commission was established by the Liberal Government and Dame Roma Mitchell was appointed its first chairman. The Office of the Status of Women was established after the establishment of the Office of Women's Affairs in 1976. The Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee was appointed in 1976 to advise the Social Security Minister on issues relating to the special welfare needs of women. The Office of Child Care was established within the Department of Social Security in 1976. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, though you would need no reminder of it, that Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was Minister for Social Security in those years.

In 1976 the Superannuation Act gave equal treatment to female public servants in the area of superannuation—one of the areas dealt with in the Fightback package. There are many areas of Fightback which are of benefit to women, and they have been spelt out. Superannuation is one area where we stress that there is a need.

Labor has made a number of changes to superannuation in recent years. Nobody could possibly have kept count of the number of changes that have been made. Never once has the Labor Party made a change which has recognised the right of women to have meaningful superannuation. Women have never been able to have a superannuation scheme which can be paid into whether they are in employment or not at any particular time. At no stage has this been recognised by the Labor Party. It has failed women badly in the area of meaningful superannuation and retirement income. To be doing that at a time when we know that the population is ageing and there will be larger numbers of women retiring as the years go by is criminal neglect.

In 1980 the Liberal Government established the Institute of Family Studies. It was a Liberal Government that signed the United Nations Convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women and moved towards the process of ratification. The shopfront information services were established in the ACT in 1978 by the Office of Women's Affairs as collection points for women's ideas on government plans and policies.

The Liberal Party established the Women's Film Fund to support production of films for and about women. We extended rehabilitation services to housewives in 1978. We extended the eligibility for pension health benefits to single parents and dependants in 1979. We increased the child allowance for pensioners by 25 per cent in 1980. In 1983 we developed the family income supplement scheme to assist low income families.

There are other matters that I could go on with; those I have mentioned are some which should be placed on the record in this debate in view of the comments that senators on the other side have made. Those comments about the Liberal Party discovering women in only the last year indicate their lack of knowledge of the role the Liberal Party has played and the concern it has had for issues relating to women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I wish to thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on what is an important package of Bills dealing with the status of persons in our Australian society. This status is being accorded to them because of their inherent dignity as human beings and without committing any discrimination on the grounds of sex. I believe that this is an important further reinforcement of a cultural reform that has been undertaken for many years.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge Senator Newman's point that when one looks at the history of the women's refuge movement, one will see many of the bases and foundations for a new attitude in Australian society to the status and plight of women in our society, whether one is looking at the particular issue of criminal violence in the home or household—sometimes euphemistically referred to as domestic violence—or in these wider matters of discrimination in regard to employment opportunities, education opportunities, the right to participate in a non-discriminatory superannuation scheme, and so on.

I pay tribute to Susan Ryan, a former Senator, who has already been mentioned in the debate. Many of us who were in the Senate chamber in the very early days of the Hawke Labor Government can recall endless weeks of debate. It was her fierce determination, her strong-willed perseverance and her particular role then with the basic statute—which was subject to a lot of misunderstanding and misrepresentation in the community, and perhaps even some of that crept into the chamber—which put that initial statutory framework into place. We have been building on it ever since, and this afternoon is no exception.

The major elements of this Bill have already been well-rehearsed in the course of the debate. In regard to the Sex Discrimination Act, the Bill will focus on the question of sexual harassment.
