This is a situation where a person need not suffer any particular disadvantage as a result of the unwelcome sexual advances made by another person. The fact that he or she is subject to such advances and feels humiliated and offended by such unwelcome conduct will be sufficient to ground the processes provided for in the Act, provided that there is also an element of a check on the mere assertion by somebody of perhaps very sensitive or tender sensibility that they have been offended or humiliated by some course of action by the person about whose conduct they are complaining. It will be necessary for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to conclude that a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated that the complainant would be offended or humiliated by the course of action engaged in.

I believe it is also very important to notice in this Bill—as will become clear in the committee stage—that we are providing a mechanism so that, when we move into this current phase, and even more strongly enterprise bargaining and certified agreements between employers and employees, there will be a mechanism which will allow a person to bring to the attention of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission an allegation that there is discrimination under the award, which will include certified agreements. If that is the case in the view of the Sexual Discrimination Commissioner, then the Commissioner must refer the award to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in most circumstances.

There will be a hearing to review the award and the Industrial Relations Commission will, with the benefit of the Sexual Discrimination Commissioner appearing before it, determine whether there has been a discriminatory clause inserted into the award and, if so, take whatever action is necessary to remove the discrimination, unless it believes that that variation from the award or certified agreement would not be in the public interest. We believe that this is just a simple mechanism to permit that course of action to take place to reinforce the situation which, as I understand it, is pretty widespread in the workplace now under awards. A lot of what once might have been regarded as discriminatory provisions five or six years ago have been progressively eliminated, and one does not want to see them creeping back under the pressure of enterprise bargaining and the certified agreement process. They are perhaps the major matters within this Bill of a substantial nature.

There is also the question of the way in which a determination by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission—the disability discrimination legislation is also relevant, not just the Sex Discrimination Act or the Racial Discrimination Act—might be enforced. At the moment a complainant who wishes to enforce a determination of the Commission must bring proceedings in the Federal Court. The Federal Court virtually has to start from scratch. This is at considerable expense to the complainant. It is proposed that a determination will be registered in the Federal Court. It will have effect as if it were an order of the court, unless the respondent to the determination applies to the court within 28 days for a review of the determination. In the absence of such an application, action can be taken through the usual processes of the court to enforce the determination. I believe this will greatly strengthen anti-discrimination laws within Australia, and that is to be welcomed as a mechanism to help achieve that.

In the package of Bills before us we also have the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1992. It seeks to further strengthen the status of the affirmative action provisions that are already in place and operating in the Australian community. The legal status of the authority, the Affirmative Action Agency, as a statutory body is achieved by means of this Bill. I believe it is a substantial and important protection for that agency as it moves through the next several years.

This particular affirmative action Bill is important not only in that regard but in its widened scope to include trade unions, group training schemes, voluntary bodies, and so on. Indeed, it is extremely pleasing to see that in relation to such voluntary bodies such as major education providers, including the Catholic schools system, over the signature of the Reverend T.M. Doyle, Director of Catholic Education in Victoria, there is a very clear indication that the Catholic schools system will be pleased to cooperate with the provisions of this Bill. The final paragraph of that letter says:

It is hoped that all our schools, whether covered under the legislation or not, would support all measures to guarantee human rights and social justice for members of the disadvantaged in the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: One can see very considerable cultural and social changes occurring in Australia, which are there given support in an area which is sometimes wrongly stereotyped and caricatured as being hostile to this type of advance. This is an important part of our maturing as a nation where discrimination on the grounds of gender is slowly—quite rapidly in some areas—being eliminated.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992 brings certain Commonwealth legislative based superannuation schemes into line with matters that we dealt with in the chamber—and I remember in a long Committee hearing I think back a year or so ago—to provide for the superannuation schemes of the Commonwealth to eliminate that sort of discrimination that does occur on the grounds of marital status in the provision of benefits to surviving dependants of scheme members or beneficiaries and, in general, the way in which those schemes treat de facto spouses less favourably. This is done either by not recognising them at all or by placing a qualifying period or dependency test on the de facto spouse, modified in a way which brings the Commonwealth schemes into line with the way in which the private schemes that we dealt with before will be required to operate from, I think, 25 June 1993.

I believe these various Bills round off and build on the very firm foundations that have been set in place with widespread support and understanding in the Australian community. I confidently commend the second reading of these Bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the second reading amendment, for the record I make it clear that the Government did support paragraph (a) of the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition but felt unable to support paragraph (b) because it did not provide scope for the support of, for example, the disabled in the community in their employment opportunities.

PARA.TAB: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: SEX DISCRIMINATION AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two groups of amendments. I suggest that they be dealt with in groups because there are two separate issues. The first issue is that of extending the Sex Discrimination Act to cover Federal industrial awards. We object to that and I put the argument supporting our objection in the second reading debate. That issue relates to amendments 2, 11 and 21. The amendments will have the effect of taking from the Bill the provisions that enable the sex discrimination regime to interfere in industrial relations work. I seek leave to move those amendments together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 4, page 2, subclause (4), lines 23 to 28, omit the subclause.
11.Schedule, pages 11 and 12, proposed amendments of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, omit the amendments.
21.Schedule, pages 25 and 26, proposed insertion of sections 50A and 50B of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, omit the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to Senator Hill's speech during the second reading debate and I am still not sure what his difficulty really is. He spoke of having difficulty with the Industrial Relations Commission actually making decisions as to whether or not an award is discriminatory because the Commission is not an authority on sex discrimin-ation—which is fair enough. But he went on to say that he also had difficulty with the Sex Discrimination Commissioner arguing the case relating to discrimination in awards before the IRC.

PARA.TAB: I have to ask Senator Hill: what will actually happen? Is he saying that we should continue to exempt industrial awards and agreements from the Act, or is he saying that any discrimination which occurs in the context of an award is all right? I do not believe Australian women would be terribly happy to hear that. If Senator Hill is saying that discrimination in awards or agreements is not acceptable, then presumably, at some point, if the matter cannot be sorted out a decision making body will have to get involved.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's comments on the 7.30 Report last week when he confirmed that economic growth of a little over 2 per cent would do nothing to help school leavers find employment. Will the Minister rule out an increase in the number of young people unemployed—which now stands at an horrific 160,000—when the thousands of school leavers enter the job market in the next couple of weeks?

—We have been through the debate about the levels of youth unemployment in here on a number of occasions. The Opposition, for its own purposes, always calculates youth unemployment in a different way from the way the ABS does.
—Wrong brief, John.

—Senator Kemp will get a lot of practice in opposition in the next few years, and he will learn in that time, if he is ever called on, how to answer a question. I am answering the question today. The fact of the matter is that, in the political debate, there has always been disagreement about this issue.

PARA.TAB: I have nothing to add to what Mr Dawkins said. We are one of the few economies in the OECD which are coming out of recession. We are one of the few economies which are actually growing, compared with economies such as the United Kingdom which has now had nine quarters of negative growth. Of course, that is the Opposition's model. The United Kingdom is a country governed by a conservative government, the antecedence of which the Opposition has used as its model for its proposed Fightback initiatives.
I cannot add anything to what the Treasurer said. We hope that the growth rate will improve. As the growth rate improves, that will have beneficial effects on employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I remind the Minister that the figure of 160,000 is in fact taken from Labour Force Australia, October 1992, by the Australia Bureau of Statistics, so it is not our figure. The question I asked the Minister is: in view of the low growth rate, does he rule out a further rise in unemployment with school leavers coming on to the market? As there are 164,000 teenagers underemployed, does he rule out a further increase in that group also? Furthermore, in the light of these appalling figures, when is the Government going to address employment policies that will give these young people some hope?
—Senator Hill says that his figure comes from the ABS. His figure for the underemployed does not come from the ABS; it is an invention of Access Economics.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the major portion of the question is concerned, I have already answered that. I have said that, with improved economic growth, the employment situation for young people as well will improve. If Senator Hill believes that there are magic wands which can be waved by any political party to encourage that growth rate, I would like to hear about them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get rid of payroll tax for a start.

—Senator Hill says get rid of payroll tax. One of the original authors of the Opposition's Fightback proposal says that it will have no effect on employment at all. The Opposition should not deny its spiritual heirs. That is what he says.
—That is a lie; it is a lie.
—It is true. It will make no difference.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask for the interjection to be withdrawn.
—Senator Short, I ask you to withdraw.
—I said that the statement by Senator Button was a lie, and it is a lie. That is not, in my understanding, an unparliamentary statement.
—Order! It is, and it is the very point that Senator Cook was made to come and apologise for yesterday.
—No, he called someone a liar.
—Order! I am asking Senator Short to withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister advise the Senate when the Government will legislate for equal pay, fair minimum wages and protection for employees against unfair dismissal? Will this legislation be developed in consultation with the States, employers and unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December last, the Prime Minister and I announced our intention to encode in Australian legislation the principles of the United Nations labour agency, the ILO, and its conventions on matters of minimum wage, equal pay, unfair dismissal and redundancy pay. We said that we would do this using the external affairs power of the Australian Constitution and that this would ensure that we were putting together a safety net, taking as our bible the International Labour Organisation and its declared international standards. Honourable senators will know that the World Health Organisation, for example, of the United Nations sets international health standards. The ILO sets world labour standards and they will be the standards that we will use.

PARA.TAB: The legislation will be framed in such a way that it will not undermine State jurisdictions where States maintain open access to arbitration—not where, like in the Kennett case, they are abolishing free access of aggrieved parties to an arbitration commission—so that there can be fair decisions through industrial relations by an independent third party if the two parties who share the grievance cannot resolve it between themselves.The legislation that we indicated last Wednesday was reaffirmed yesterday by the Prime Minister at his meeting with the State Premiers.

The Prime Minister made a statement that a steering committee will be set up. This is directly in line with what we said when we announced our intention to legislate. We said then that we would consult properly. At that time, in the press conference that I attended with the Prime Minister, I named the Ministers of Labour Advisory Council as an appropriate forum in which those consultations could be conducted. I see that the Premiers and the Prime Minister have now agreed to have a special steering committee which will not report back to the Prime Minister and the Premiers but which will enable the consultations. That is an appropriate vehicle.

There is no change, of course, in the Commonwealth's position on this. Our legislation will enable the Australian people to have a free choice. On one hand, they can choose our system of industrial relations which has an independent umpire to determine disputes if and when they occur, which has a safety net of minimum standards below which workers cannot be driven, and which protects basic rights; or, on the other hand, they can choose the individual work contracts approach of the Kennett Government and of the Hewson Opposition, an approach in which there are no real minimums and the choice offered to workers by employers is the contract or the sack.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister's commitment to consult with employers, unions and the States a new commitment or was there a commitment given to do that prior to yesterday's discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the Prime Minister and I committed ourselves to do that on 2 December when we announced our proposals. We stand in clear contradistinction to the Victorian Government which, in the dead of night, rushed its legislation into the legislative chamber without appropriate consultation. It did so to the extent that yesterday the head of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry criticised the Kennett amendments as being too hasty, containing too many errors and denying a number of reasonable possibilities, and asked for them to be stood aside. So the leading spokesperson from the employers was critical yesterday of the Kennett manoeuvre to rush industrial legislation. The fact that the Kennett Government has behaved badly is not a reason why we would. We will not. We will engage in proper consultation and we said that on 2 December.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government. I refer to the Government's much trumpeted $345m local capital works program, which the Treasurer claimed would generate 13,000 jobs. In the Senate Estimates Committee B hearing last Friday, the Office of Local Government could not provide details of how many people had found jobs under this program because `it was not an employment program, we did not seek figures in relation to unemployed people'. However, the Treasurer states on page 79 of the Budget-related paper entitled Working for the Future that the local capital works program `will focus on those local government areas which are experiencing higher than average rates of unemployment'. Given that no records are being kept of the minimum number of jobs being created under this program, can the Minister please explain how the Government intends to ascertain how many new jobs have been created—if indeed reducing unemployment is what was intended?

—The aim of the local capital works programs in various jurisdictions around Australia where municipalities want to cooperate with the national government in generating further economic activity in their regions is based on a completely non-political set of criteria. It is a matter of looking at the unemployment figures in those municipalities and deciding to put money into capital works programs in those areas where there is an above average unemployment level.

PARA.TAB: The object of the exercise is to generate local economic activity in the purchase of services; to keep employed members of local work gangs who might otherwise be put off; and to allow subcontractors who work with local governments to provide facilities and build additions to the community infrastructure to keep people on or take people on. In all these ways we estimated at the time of the Budget that some 13,000 jobs over an average period of, I think, six months would be generated—I think this was the terminology used—in order to get economic activity under way in those areas.

This partnership between the elected municipal representatives of these areas and the national government to foster activity in terms of the purchase of goods and services in order to put community infrastructure facilities and improvements in place will, I am sure, be of great enduring benefit to these municipalities and their ratepayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to state specifically how many unemployed will be given jobs under the local capital works program, keeping in mind that to date the local government areas of Byron Bay, Newcastle, Wyong, Singleton, Dungog, Muswellbrook, Greater Lakes and Port Stephens, and probably many more, have not yet provided a single new job to unemployed persons under this Federal Labor initiative. If the Minister can provide a figure, how has it been calculated?

—So far as Byron Bay is concerned, I understand that various stages of that project are being implemented over time. To carry out projects resulting from its $1.2m allocation, I understand that Byron Bay will employ 20 to 25 additional day labourers, mostly in the early half of next year. So in the very example that the honourable senator has brought forward, I understand that there will be instances of day labourers receiving employment opportunities that otherwise they would not get. At the same time, enduring community infrastructure will be established. This will benefit the community in the years to come. Those 25 day labourers will have the opportunity for employment which otherwise they would not have received.

PARA.TAB: But generally what I am saying is that the object is to ensure that economic activity in these regions is stimulated. This is part of the fiscal stimulus which is necessary. Municipalities—certainly in Tasmania and I believe on the mainland—are very keen to cooperate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister inform the Senate of any proposals to increase the disability support pension and to pay additional disability allowances for educational and employment opportunities for the disabled? Has the Minister seen other proposals to support the disabled? Are those proposals feasible and will the Government implement them?

—This is another area in which the community will be presented with a very clear distinction between the Government and the Opposition. Welfare of the disabled is an area which this Government has over 10 years seen as a major priority. Consequently, our Government's record in disability—
—You are about 12 months late. We put out our proposals on this last year.
—Would the honourable senator mind hearing the answer first of all.
—Yes, I do mind.

—If he does mind, he should go outside the chamber. He is very rude and impertinent. Consequently, the record of this Government in the disability area is outstanding. This is so because it has been developed in a—
—You have taken 12 months to get around to copying us.
—Order!
—This really is trying.
—Order! There are too many interjections. But I would also ask Senator Bolkus to ignore them.

—It is very hard to do that, Mr President. The Government's achievement in this area has been developed in a way which does address all the needs of the disabled in one integrated package. There are four features of that package. Our disability reform package combines these four main features: adequate income support, assistance in training, work rehabilitation, and job seeking assistance for people with disabilities.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the first part of the package—income support—the Senate should know that we have indexed the disability support pension, we have provided a mobility allowance and we have provided payments for education and employment entry.

Senator Sherry asked about initiatives in respect of income support and training. He should remember and the Senate should note that in the 1992-93 Budget the Government continued with the introduction of initiatives to help those with disabilities by increasing the disability support pension by $6 a fortnight, increasing employment entry payments, introducing a $200 education entry payment and increasing the mobility allowance and extending its coverage. These are the first batch of initiatives that Senator Sherry asked about.

We have seen other initiatives and other proposals. We have been made aware of other proposals in relatively recent days. For instance, the Fightback package proposes a number of measures, the main one of which is a fortnightly allowance of some $45 for the severely disabled—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to a point of order. Under standing order 187 a senator is not entitled to read his or her speech. I am just wondering whether you will give a ruling as to whether Ministers should be continually allowed to read their answers.
—Order! Ministers have read answers for years.
—Mr President, on a point of order. Just because they have done it for years does not mean that they should be allowed to continue to do it.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Mr President, what we have seen during this answer is a deliberate attempt by the Opposition not to have placed on the record our record in terms of the disabled and the shallowness of their record.

PARA.TAB: I have almost run out of time. I really need to go to the point that Dr Hewson in recent weeks told a number of disabled people in Adelaide at a conference of ACROD that he would extend the $45 allowance to cover all DSP pensioners. What he did not tell them was that under the initial Fightback costings of $57m there was not enough to cover the initial target group. This would be less so under the extended ambit. If DSP pensioners were all to be covered, as Dr Hewson promised very cruelly that day, it would cost some $200m. It is money that has not been allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to yesterday's agreement—and the emphasis is on `agreement'—by the Council of Australian Governments to the national greenhouse response strategy. Does the Minister agree that there would be no need for the proposed Collie coal-fired power station, costing some $2 billion of which $500m will go offshore, if the Federal and Western Australian governments had the political will to encourage sustainable energy sources, including energy conservation, solar water heaters and co-generation from such sources as the proposed Bunbury compact steel mill? Secondly, will the Government block the construction of the Collie power station on the grounds that it is both unnecessary and incompatible with greenhouse gas targets now adopted by all governments, including the Federal Government and the Government of Western Australia?

—I have not had the benefit of fully studying the communique issued following the heads of government meeting yesterday. I am not in a position to even consider, and more definitely I am certainly not in a position to commit any opposition to, any of the things which Senator Coulter referred to in his question.
—Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce inform the Senate of the new arrangements for that part of the telecommunications industry that covers customer premises equipment?

—I can only give a brief answer on this. The Government has decided to extend the industry development arrangements which currently exist until 1996 for those companies operating in the customer premises equipment manufacturing area. That has been done for a variety of reasons.

PARA.TAB: The telecommunications industry is in transition in this country. Many of the companies which will benefit from the industrial development arrangements have made substantial investments in equipment for the production of customer premises equipment. Those investments have to be realised and successfully used in terms of the plant and equipment which have been installed.

We have proposed total deregulation of the telecommunications market in Australia in 1997. The benefits relating to the customer equipment manufacturers will extend until 1996, but they will also be available to companies which are members of the partnership for development program. That will enable possible new entrants into the market provided they engage in industry activity in Australia as are the present beneficiaries of the IDAs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Does the Attorney-General or his Department have a copy of the official report on criminal and terrorist infiltration of Victorian unions, which was submitted to the former Victorian Labor Government, about which the Minister was asked yesterday? Has the matter been referred to any Commonwealth officers other than those employed by ASIO? If so, to whom has it been referred? What conclusions have been drawn, or—at least three years after the event—are the investigations still continuing? What has the Minister specifically done since yesterday?

—Senator Vanstone asks what I have done in relation to this matter since yesterday. For example, at 8.30 this morning, I phoned Mr Pat McNamara, the Deputy Premier and Minister for Police in Victoria, and spoke to his personal secretary. I indicated I wanted a mere two minutes to speak to the relevant Minister. Of course, I have had no response, even though we phoned again at 1.30 this afternoon before coming into Question Time, which shows the real rather than the propaganda importance which is attached to this matter by the Minister.
—Was he there?
—He was in Melbourne, yes.
—He might be busy.

—Yes, he might be. But I am indicating what I was doing in order to come to an understanding of the report that he has called for from the Acting Commissioner of Police in Victoria. I would have spoken to him in terms such as, `If there is anything in the original report or any subsequent inquiries which, in the opinion of your Commissioner of Police, indicates the possibility of a Federal offence, under the normal arrangements would you make that available to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police?'.

PARA.TAB: In looking back at the historical record, the Australian Federal Police inform me that there was nothing in the occurrences of three or four years ago which led the Victoria Police—and apparently this investigation was carried out by the Victoria Police—to transfer any material or to suggest to the Australian Federal Police that they should undertake any specific investigation. So that indicates what I have done.

I am waiting for a response from Mr McNamara. Of course, the commissioners are well equipped with very good working arrangements to transfer any material which might be properly investigated by the AFP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate of progress to date in the development of a uniform national rail freight network? What are the implications of the development of such a network for the Australian economy?

—The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following information. The legislation that has finally provided for the creation of a National Rail Corporation has, thankfully, at last been passed by the Western Australian Parliament.
—No jobs of course; no jobs!
—Senator Bishop, you would have been a lot more effective in terms of advancing some micro-economic reform in this country—
—On a point of order, Mr President: I ask that Senator Collins address his comments through the Chair, not directly to Senator Bishop.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I would acknowledge Senator Collins's point that we would have been more effective on micro-economic reform had we been in government; that is quite true. This Government has failed. The Industry Commission has indeed backed it up. We would have done better.
—Order! There is no point of order. If spurious points of order continue—
—It was not spurious.
—I am not referring to your point of order. If spurious points of order continue, I will name the next person.

—Senator Bishop, who did not appear to be in the least bit offended by my reference to her, would have been far more instrumental in assisting the process of micro-economic reform under our Federal system if she had prevailed upon her Liberal Party colleagues in Western Australia to support this initiative instead of holding it up and opposing it, as they did in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Not even the Western Australian National Party would support them in that opposition to this sensible and long awaited initiative. But it was substantially as a result of the Liberal Party's opposition in Western Australia that this has been held up for as long as it has been. So instead of coming into the Senate complaining about this and crowing about some sort of alleged victory over the Federal Government because this initiative has not been progressed, Federal Opposition members would have been a lot more effective if they had prevailed upon their State colleagues to have it supported. Fortunately, it has now been passed and now the shareholders will be asked to progress this matter.

The Federal Government holds only one vote, the same as every other State government, in respect of the National Rail Freight Authority. That body is now in a position to begin its national marketing and terminal facilities operations next month, I think to the relief of everyone who wants to see a sensible rail operation in this country.

On the projections that have been made, I am pleased to say that National Rail is expected to be self-supporting within five years. The establishment of a National Rail Freight Authority is a key element of the Government's strategy to reform the total transport system of this country. That strategy is well advanced.

Dramatic gains have been made by this Government in micro-economic reform. But certainly the focus during the next term of this Government will be to ensure that the strategy that has been put in place with the National Rail Corporation and the National Road Commission will be to establish those national freight networks in both rail and road.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the comments today of the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, about the Australian Treasury report on the GST in New Zealand. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: A few unrepresentative people in New Zealand were asked their views about the introduction of the GST.
He said that the Treasury officials:
weren't there to do a thorough job . . . They were there to ask a few of their counterparts and a few academics their views about the introduction of the GST.

As the Treasury report is apparently of such little importance, I ask: why were the officials sent to New Zealand at all, why is the Government afraid to table the full report, and why is it not prepared to tolerate informed debate on the coalition's tax reform proposals in which a GST makes possible a one-third reduction in personal income tax, a doubling of family allowances for most families, and the opportunity for Australian firms to lower their costs, increase their production and employ more people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's decision on this matter, and particularly the Treasurer's decision, is not based on any domestic political concern about the content of the document. There is plenty of evidence to indicate that, whatever the Treasury document says, the people of New Zealand have not benefited from recent economic policies. For example, only yesterday the Reverend Richard Randerson, the social responsibility commissioner for the Anglican Church in New Zealand, was quite scathing in his comments on the effects of the GST. He made the point that the initial compensation provided for when the GST was first introduced has been stripped away. He said—
—Mr President, on a point of order—
—Why do you want to silence the Anglican clergyman?

—Because it is utterly irrelevant to the question. In my submission, the question was: why is the Government so loath to have a debate on the subject, why is it so loath to release the document, and why did it send officials to New Zealand? The answer to date has simply been about what some Anglican clergyman might have thought about the state of affairs in New Zealand. Mr President, I invite you to direct Senator Button not to stray into those irrelevant areas but to answer the question.

—Mr President, on a point of order: you talked earlier about spurious points of order. This has been an argumentative point of order. In taking the point of order, no reference was made to any standing order. It was an occasion to make a party political speech and was meant to break the flow of Senator Button's remarks. It was not related to any rulings that you made previously, Mr President. If you put all those facts end on end you arrive at the conclusion that this is indeed a spurious point of order. It should be ruled out of order immediately and Senator Alston should be sat down.

—Order! The end of Senator Short's question, I believe, was a very wide open question as far as the effects of the GST are concerned, and that is the reason I will let Senator Button continue at this stage.
—Of course, Mr President, it was a bit of propaganda.
—Are you going to name Cook?
—Order!

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer to your ruling a little earlier where you said that you would name the next person who did not put up a proper point of order. Are you indeed going to name the Minister or are you not?
—Order! I did not regard the points of order made by Senator Alston or Senator Cook as spurious points of order.
—Mr President, further on the point of order: could you tell me the standing order that Senator Cook was referring to?
—Order! I have ruled on the point of order.

—I am intent on giving this answer, if I may. I was referring to the comments that had been made about the GST in New Zealand. We are challenged as to why we do not debate the GST more frequently here. We do debate it quite frequently. One of the difficulties is that the GST is seen by those opposite in the way Thomas Carlyle saw his bath: they throw everything into the bath and say that the GST will fix it. The fact of the matter is that the GST is a totally moveable feast. Senator Knowles interjects enough here. Only last week on Perth radio she was saying that local government services, such as garbage collection, will not be taxed.
—No, no, if they are commercial.
—That is what Senator Knowles said. She has hung out garbage here today while I was answering a question.
—You are lying again.
—Senator Knowles is on the record. Listen to what Fightback says:

ANSWER.PARA: It is our intention that services such as rubbish collections and disposal provided by local government authorities will be subject to the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lies.
—There is no such distinction, Senator.
—Stop lying!
—Senator Knowles speaks with a forked tongue: one time in here, and another time in trying to woo the worthy burghers of Perth to support this iniquitous tax.
—You are a born liar and you know it.

—I will come back to Senator Short's question: the Treasurer will not release a record of confidential discussions with foreign government officials, business people and academics. These conversations were held in confidence. The Treasury has advised the Government that there will be adverse implications for Australian policy making if the Government does not guarantee and preserve the confidentiality of communications between its officials and officials of foreign governments. Senator Short's little exercise, picked up by the Sydney Morning Herald—
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. On seven occasions Senator Knowles has interjected that Senator Button was lying.
—Too right. He is a lying hound.
—Mr President, it should be withdrawn. Senator Knowles should show a bit of imagination in her insults.

—Order! During Question Time today there have been a number of unparliamentary comments which I have let go because they are not heard over the broadcasting. It is not in order to ask a Minister, `Why don't you tell the truth?', and it is not in order to say that the Minister is lying. I ask both sides of the chamber not to engage in it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. If a person is telling what is regarded as being a `tiddie hopper', an untruth, how do you explain to him that he is doing the wrong thing? Could I have your ruling on that, Mr President.

—It is a matter for rebuttal in debate or a matter for taking a point of order after Question Time. It has never been the role of the Chair to determine whether a Minister or a member of the Opposition is telling the truth or not when he is answering a question.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Once again, the Leader of the Government in the Senate has absolutely failed to answer any of the questions put to him by this side. My questions were very simple. I will just repeat them to see whether the Minister will have another go at them. If the report is as trivial and irrelevant and of as little consequence and importance as the Treasurer asserted this morning, then, firstly, why did the officials go to New Zealand in the first place; secondly, why will the report not be released; and, thirdly, why will the Government not allow and tolerate informed debate on this subject in Australia? If the Treasurer is so concerned about the confidentiality point regarding New Zealand officials, will the Government approach the New Zealand Government for permission to release the full report or, failing that, will the Government release the unexpurgated version of the Treasury report but with the names and other identifying details deleted where appropriate?

—If I said yes to all these questions by way of answer, the honourable senator would still be up the creek without a paddle. The first point I want to make is this: Australian officials go to New Zealand and other countries frequently to discuss a variety of economic matters, including taxation. If all their discussions are to be bandied about in the Senate because the Liberals have seen what they think is a favourable headline in the Sydney Morning Herald, then there will be no respect for those discussions between officials.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has been so long in the wilderness that it does not understand anything about these points which have a degree of finesse about them. It just does not understand that these sorts of conversations have to be respected if they are to continue to take place.

The honourable senator asked me why we will not debate the Opposition's GST. We would be happy to debate it at any time. I was asked whether the Government would approach the New Zealand Government. No, because the discussions extended over a whole range of issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade confirm reports from East Timor which suggest a military crackdown in the province, including the death of Jorge Manuel Serrano and the arrest, torture and rape of supporters and family members of East Timor resistance leader Xanana Gusmao? Does the Minister accept that there is a possibility, with so much international attention now focused on the safety of Xanana Gusmao, that his supporters and immediate family members face renewed risks in any tightening of security in East Timor? Given the uncertainty of the situation, will Australia's ambassador to Indonesia visit East Timor in the immediate future in order to make a first-hand assessment of the situation there?

—I am not sure that what is happening in East Timor at the moment can be described as a full scale military crackdown, but certainly the atmosphere there reportedly has been tight and tense for some time. I am, of course, aware of reports that a number of others in East Timor besides Xanana have been detained, apparently including his sister and brother-in-law. East Timor's military commander, Brigadier-General Theo Syafei, is reported as saying that around 20 others have been detained and that they are Xanana's close friends and aides. I understand that further detentions have been made in other parts of the province.

PARA.TAB: In addition to these detentions, around 36 Fretilin members have reportedly surrendered to Indonesian authorities, while two large groups of youths in Dili and Baucau have publicly disbanded—again, reported as disbanded; we have not got precise confirmation of any of these things.

I have seen reports being circulated by Amnesty about the possible torture and death of detainees, including Jorge Manuel Serrano, whom Senator Bourne mentioned. I am simply unable to offer any further information or confirmation of those allegations at this stage.

As to the question of maltreatment, Indonesian authorities are very aware of international concern, not only about Xanana's case but also about the detention of others in East Timor. Their actions so far have shown, I think, that they are responsive to that concern. I have made repeated representations through our Jakarta Embassy and here raising the Australian Government's concerns in connection with the detention of both Xanana and the others I have mentioned. In Xanana's case, Senator Bourne should be aware that, as I have said publicly, I have received assurances at the highest levels from the Indonesian Government that he would not be ill-treated.

The Australian Government has also specifically requested, as have others, that the Indonesian Government allow access by the ICRC to Xanana, seeking assurances that this would be granted and supporting the Red Cross's efforts. In that context I now welcome the fact that ICRC representatives did meet with Xanana yesterday in Jakarta at police headquarters. As the representative said in a radio interview this morning, the findings of the ICRC do remain confidential in accordance with its terms of operation in Indonesia and, indeed, in many other parts of the world. However, it can be said that Indonesian authorities, in allowing the ICRC to visit Xanana without witnesses, have complied with an important condition of access set by the organisation. The ICRC representative also said that permission to meet Xanana at the place of detention and provision for a repeat visit, which was indicated would take place, met its further conditions.

On learning of the detention of others in East Timor besides Xanana, I immediately raised that matter with the Indonesian Government. I urge, and I continue to urge now, the Government to allow all detainees to be accorded due and proper legal process, including representation, and for them not to be ill-treated. We continue to urge that the ICRC also have access to them. As to the last part of the question, Senator Bourne will have to ask me a supplementary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will Australia's ambassador to Indonesia be going to East Timor in the near future?

—The Government maintains a close watch on a range of political and economic developments in East Timor through dialogue with the Indonesian authorities, through contact with independent and non-government bodies and also through regular visits by officers of the Jakarta Embassy. I am able to tell Senator Bourne that there have been 10 such visits to East Timor in the last 13 months by Australian embassy officers. In the normal course of events, we would anticipate that such a visit might again be made in the next month or so. We are certainly hoping for that.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the events surrounding the arrest of Xanana, the Government has been focusing its efforts in raising our concerns with key decision-makers in Jakarta. As I have indicated, again that has included urging Indonesian authorities to permit the ICRC to have access not only to Xanana but also to others detained in East Timor. We will continue to make that point with some vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Now, behave yourself this time.

—Listen to who is talking. My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Could the Minister please explain how it is and on whose authorisation Mr Ron Edwards, the Deputy Speaker and the honourable member for Stirling, would be permitted to allow Mr Ray Clohessy, from a company called Union Industrial Advisory Services Pty Ltd, to use Mr Edwards's office fax machine and telephones and also to use the office as a point of contact for his industrial advocacy business? I have many examples here of exactly that. What action does the Minister plan to take to prevent Mr Edwards from allowing a person to run a private business out of a taxpayer funded office?

—Unlike the Opposition, I do not invoke instant judgment and instant guilt. Senator Knowles has raised a particular question here. It is one that, in the normal course of events, we would be looking into. If Senator Knowles has any information that would assist, obviously I will take that on board. From time to time allegations are made. From time to time they are raised in this place. In terms of a strike-out rate from the Opposition, over the 2 1/2 years that I have been in this position answering questions, there has not been one that has stuck. So I will take that on board.

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles has raised an issue that arises from time to time. It has been put to me that there is a person working in the office of the Opposition Leader who, for instance, is not paid for by the Commonwealth. That is a particular instance which I am not rushing into judgment on. Senator Knowles asks about the use of government resources and government facilities. In an even-handed way, I will look at Dr Hewson's position and the allegation that there is a person working in his office using government resources in the same way as I will look at Senator Knowles's allegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and concerns the space industry. Firstly, has any decision been made about the formation of the Australian Space Council, for example, the number of people who will constitute the board and what representation there will be from private industry? Secondly, can the Minister advise me whether the Federal Government is in a position to provide financial assistance to the southern launch vehicles project for a proposal to launch two rockets from Woomera in South Australia?

—The Australian Space Council, the membership of which will be announced shortly, in a statutory sense will not have more than 15 members, eight of whom will be government members from various user organisations and departments. For example, departments like the Department of Defence and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and statutory authorities like CSIRO and so on would constitute the government membership and there would be seven members from industry and the research community. I hope to announce the membership in the very near future. As the honourable senator is a South Australian senator I have to say that, because of the space industry involvement of several companies in South Australia and the historical relationship with the space industry, there are some strong contenders from his State.

PARA.TAB: In respect of assistance to the southern launch vehicle project, the project definition study recommended a report on the commercial aspects of the southern launch vehicle project. We are waiting for the final part of that report, which is due later this year. The question of funding in the future development of the project will be resolved on the basis of that report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister indicate whether the Chairman of the Space

QUESTION.PARA: Council will be someone from the private sector or one of the government or statutory authority representatives?

TALK.START.PARA: —He or she certainly will not be from the government sector directly. If a university is regarded as being in the public sector, for example, it may be someone from a university. My preference would be somebody from the private sector.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—You are not reading that, are you?
—As a matter of fact, I am. I refer him to page 7 of the Cabinet handbook, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Ministers at meetings of the Ministry, Cabinet and committees must declare any private interests . . . in matters under discussion, where those interests conflict or might conflict with their public duty as Ministers.

Quite apart from any formal written declaration, when Cabinet discussed the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, currently before the Parliament, which relates to changes in the pig industry, did the Prime Minister at that meeting declare his interest in an $80m multinational pig joint venture? Will the Minister table any such declaration as recorded by the Cabinet officers?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no recollection of that Bill being dealt with by the legislative committee of Cabinet. The Prime Minister is not in attendance for committee hearings on many of these Bills, anyway. I will try to obtain an answer to Senator Boswell's question and give it to him as soon as I can.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen an article by Adele Horin in today's Sydney Morning Herald saying that the Opposition spokesperson for industrial relations, Mr Howard, needs to explain how the coalition's policy of individual employment contracts could benefit a casual woman clothing worker or a 17-year-old in Mount Druitt? Has the Government any intention of introducing legislation for similar individual employment contracts? What effect would such legislation have, specifically on women workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The conclusion we could draw from the article by Adele Horin, a correspondent for the Sydney Morning Herald, is that the individual work contracts policy of the Kennett Government—the same policy that has been adopted by the Opposition federally—is anti-woman worker. It works against the interests of women workers because it does not provide protection from exploitation and it provides no regular safety net. To see this we need only look to what the Kennett Government did to nurses in Victoria when it unilaterally reduced their income per week by between 25 per cent and 30 per cent by virtue of the removal of weekend penalty rates.

PARA.TAB: The article by Adele Horin says that many women in the clothing, food processing and retail industries lack bargaining power at the best of times—and when the economy is like this their lack of bargaining power is even more pronounced—and that that enables them to be exploited. It leads to their being put in a situation by unscrupulous employers in which they are required to sign whatever work contract is put to them or face dismissal from employment.

What Ms Horin has said in her article is exactly right, in my view. It sets out the reasons why the Government will not introduce an industrial relations policy that is as unfair and as lacking in principle as the industrial relations policy of the Kennett Government and of the Federal Opposition. Among the observations that Ms Horin makes are that, under a system of individual employment contracts, many women will be forced to accept big cuts in their take home pay; that young women are particularly vulnerable and could be forced to work for only $3 an hour; and that women with children could also be forced to work 60 hours a week without overtime rates or penalty rates or to work 12-hour shifts on the weekend even though they have no time to mind their children. These observations constitute a number of reasons, on the grounds of fairness, why the Government will not act to produce an unfair effect on living standards of women workers in Australia.

We recognise that women workers and others are vulnerable and need a safety net to protect them. That safety net is the institution of an Australian award as a product of a fair and independent industrial relations system. We believe that this system offers all the flexibilities necessary for employers, and there is enough evidence to demonstrate this. Yesterday I referred to two significant agreements which demonstrated workplace flexibility to the level that anyone could ever want. The flexibility that it does not provide is the flexibility to cut wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The New Zealand Stevedores Network advises having passed on to New Zealand exporters $20m a year in waterfront improvement for each of the past three years of waterfront reform. How much in savings has the Australian port system passed on to the Australian exporters from the much vaunted reforms of the Australian waterfront over the same period?
—The answer is nil.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the interjection from Senator Panizza that the answer is nil. That is an example of the ill-informed approach by the Opposition on this subject—or the misleading approach, if I am being generous by saying `ill-informed'—in talking down the very real benefits of waterfront reform to the economy. Independent research by the Prices Surveillance Authority under the chairmanship of Professor Allan Fels has shown that the savings to exporters and importers by greater efficiencies on the Australian waterfront were of the order of 25 per cent; a reduction in charges by the stevedoring companies of around 25 per cent.

PARA.TAB: He also made the pertinent observation that the shipping companies seemed to have captured some of the benefits from wharfies having succeeded in becoming more efficient, and that the full benefits of the efficiencies dockside are not in the pockets of exporters because of the capturing of those gains by the shipping companies and, to a lesser extent, by the port authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that, according to a BTCE report titled Monitoring of Trans-Tasman Shipping, stevedoring costs in New Zealand have fallen from $A298 to $A192 per TEU between 1988-89 and the latest period for which figures are available, while the Australian figures have risen from $282 to $294 for the same period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of that comparison. What I am aware of is the real authorities upon which we must base proper judgments—that is, the independent findings of the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. They make the pertinent point that there has been a reduction in shipping costs.
—No, the costs have gone up.

—I hear Senator Archer's interjection that the costs have gone up. That is not supported by the facts. The fact is that there has been a significant reduction—so much so that I see now in articles by the professional pundits about the effectiveness of micro-economic reform that they have stopped talking about micro-economic reform on the Australian waterfront and among people in the Australian shipping industry; they are concentrating on other areas of micro-economic reform. The gains are real.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. The Minister would be aware of the New South Wales Government's decision to discontinue the practice of approving the appointment of Queens Counsel. What is the Commonwealth's position on the future of such appointments?

—The Commonwealth regards the title or status of Queens Counsel as anachronistic. It comes from a time when certain senior counsel would be available at first call to the Crown and, for a modest fee, would provide some advocacy service. That convention has long since died, and certainly the convention of a small fee for QCs died a long time ago, as I think Senator Cooney's committee looking into the cost of justice will have discovered.

PARA.TAB: We do not believe that there is any need for the Governor in Council to add what is really a fictional gloss these days to the status of senior members of the Bar. No doubt, with the sense of theatre and deference to hierarchy which characterises the legal profession, some other substitute recognition will evolve within the profession, but without that imprimatur of a Governor in Council.

I noticed that yesterday in Perth most State governments and Territories agreed to no longer appoint Queens Counsel, choosing instead to allow the legal profession to take over the process of appointing a more senior level of barristers. I understand that the Chief Justice of the Northern Territory very successfully argued that the appointment of QCs was an outmoded, archaic and anti-competitive practice which, he said, increased the cost of legal services. I believe that that matter is already well in hand in those jurisdictions where it is important. At the Commonwealth level, it is not a matter of great importance. I think only two QCs have been appointed by the Commonwealth, one being Dennis Rose; I forget the name of the other one. That is only two over the whole history of the Commonwealth.

In relation to this whole matter, the mystique that surrounds this superior level of the profession needs to be dispelled—along with wigs and gowns. I understand that in the High Court wigs are not worn when cases are heard before it—and certainly its judges do not wear very elaborate gowns. When I entered the Senate 14 years ago, the President did wear a very elaborate wig and gown. Mr President, you do not need to add to your very eminent status by such gorgeous apparel. I believe that that is something which the legal profession itself should take note of as a precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 3 December, Senator Reid asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, a question relating to a taxation ruling. I have an answer to that question, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator Reid asked the Minister representing the Treasurer without notice on 3 December 1992:

(1) Is it a fact that there has been an interim tax ruling pursuant to the superannuation guarantee Act so as to include in the calculation of the levy, upon the termination of employment, components of holiday pay, long service leave and some sick leave?
(2) When the Minister answers the question, will he also tell me whether in fact there has been such a ruling and, if so, how much additional revenue will be raised as a result of it?
Senator Button—The following is the answer to the honourable Senator's question:

(1) Yes, the Commissioner of Taxation has issued a draft superannuation guarantee ruling which concludes that payments for long service leave, annual leave and sick leave are included in an employee's salary or wage. As the calculation of the charge is based on an employee's salary and wages, these payments are therefore included in the calculation of the superannuation guarantee charge.

(2) I am advised that there will be no additional revenue as a result of the ruling as these amounts were always understood to be included in salary and wages for the purposes of calculating the superannuation guarantee charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, Senator Crichton-Browne, when in the chair during the debate on the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill and associated Bills, undertook to refer to me a question raised by Senator Gareth Evans. The question was whether it is in order for a senator to take a point of order while another senator is speaking to a point of order which that other senator has taken. Whilst it is open to a senator to rise on a point of order when another senator is speaking to a point of order—for example, to submit to the Chair that the other senator is debating the question—it is within the discretion of the Chair to decline to hear any further points of order until the Chair has sufficiently heard the senator raising the initial point of order to make a determination on that point of order.

PARA.TAB: I have examined the transcript. I believe Senator Crichton-Browne exercised that discretion of the Chair, and declined to hear a further point of order until he believed he had heard sufficient of the earlier point of order to allow him to make a ruling on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make one observation: I agree absolutely with your impeccable judgment, Mr President. But having said that, it might be a suitable opportunity to remind those on the front bench that the Acting Deputy President, when seeking to make a ruling, is not helped by those who seek to interject and rise on points of order when he is in the middle of a deliberation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not at all mind Senator Crichton-Browne, while in the chair, exercising his discretion not to listen to me. If I were him, I would not have heard me either in that situation. However, the point that I was seeking to make was that it was technically in order to seek to rise on a point of order if someone already making a point of order is abusing that procedure, or if it is necessary to make a point in that context.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crichton-Browne sought to rub me out not just in the exercise of his discretion but absolutely on the technicality that it was improper to raise a point of order when somebody was making a point of order. He was wrong about that. I am glad that you, Mr President, have given a couple of bob each way in your ruling. A rough justice has been done, but it is one that I am perfectly prepared to accept in the circumstances.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Knowles this day relating to the use of electorate offices.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I raised during Question Time was that Mr Edwards, the honourable member for Stirling, is allowing his parliamentary office to be used by a person running a business. Senator Bolkus tried to be smart and say that someone is working in a voluntary capacity out of Dr Hewson's office doing parliamentary and electorate work. The Minister is trying to say that is the same thing; that is absolutely and utterly absurd.

PARA.TAB: I have many documents that give details of Union Industrial Advisory Services Pty Ltd operated by Mr Clohessy. Each of these documents has Mr Ron Edwards's fax number and name across the top of the letterhead. This was first drawn to my attention when Mr Clohessy had rung and harassed an employer about a dismissal that that employer had undertaken. I will read this letter because it will summarise some of the concerns I have. This letter from the businessman to the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia states:
Following this weeks meeting with the Commissioner . . . I feel it necessary to express our concerns with some of the events that have unfolded specifically regarding Mr Clohessy.

During the phone call I had with Mr Clohessy he introduced himself as an employee of Mr Ron Edwards and that following a complaint from a constituent of the City of Stirling he was phoning to supposedly reach an amicable agreement.

Mr Clohessy's manner was abrasive in the least. He suggested that I should take the applicant `into our coolroom and slap him around a bit and make up'. This comment was taken fully in the seriousness that it was presented. He strongly suggested that we . . . were unfair and should seriously re-consider our decision.
I have learnt that Mr Clohessy is not an employee of Ron Edwards—

SPEECH.PARA: I have also established that fact—
and that Mr . . . lives in Inglewood apparently not within the Stirling registry.

PARA.TAB: The blatant mis-representation and stand-over tactics of Mr Clohessy have greatly offended us.
We are members of the CCI and as such feel compelled to express our thoughts in the hope that the mis-representations given by Mr Clohessy may be addressed in the most fairest and just manner.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of people have phoned Mr Edwards's office and spoken to Mr Clohessy while he has been acting in the capacity of director/agent of Union Industrial Advisory Services Pty Ltd. Many people have spoken to him at Mr Edwards's office. The letters are drawn up and sent out on the office fax. There is a discharge of claims that one would suspect has also been done on an electorate computer, because the style of it is remarkably similar to that which we use. That is more than just a coincidence, I would imagine. There are many examples of this, yet the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) simply brushes it aside.

PARA.TAB: I know that Mr Edwards holds the most marginal Labor seat in Australia. I know that he wants to get his bully boys out in the community working on his behalf to try to curry up some favour with some of these people who are being dismissed. It is his Government and his Government's policies that are seeing these people dismissed day after day. They are but a million people who are on the scrap heap thanks to this Government. I ask the Minister yet again: what is he going to do about ensuring that Mr Edwards does not have someone running a private business out of a taxpayer funded electorate office that, according to the information in the documents, is to be used purely to discharge electorate and parliamentary responsibilities?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—Senator Knowles raised a matter during Question Time and she has raised it again now. Her question refers very much to the use of electorate offices and the fact that they should be used for the purpose for which they are provided. Government after government has determined that the offices should be used for the purpose of parliamentary or electorate business.

PARA.TAB: The point I made in response to Senator Knowles's question was that if she gives me information in the normal way I will make an assessment; that was an answer I gave during the course of Question Time. In answering her question, I also made the point that I have allegations thrust at me from time to time in this chamber. All of those have been assessed, looked into and had action taken where it has been necessary.

I also raised the fact that—and Senator Knowles was quite wrong in what she said—I have had assertions and allegations put to me that there is a person working in the office of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson; that person is not paid for by the Commonwealth, is not on Commonwealth staff, is not on the Parliamentary staff here and is not voluntary or part time. In respect of that person, I am having investigations conducted at the moment to ensure that government resources are not being used in a way that is improper.

It does not just end there because, as custodian of this particular responsibility in the Government, I do have the responsibility to determine from time to time that offices are used for those particular functions. One complaint put to me quite recently that I also have to look at with a view to try to clarify the air, and to help Dr Hewson again, is this concept of changing the title of electoral offices to Fightback information offices. On our side we do not mind how often those opposite use the words `Fightback' or `GST'—go your hardest—but I have a responsibility to ensure that offices are there for parliamentary and electorate purposes—

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the question of Mr Edwards's actions?

—In the same way that Senator Knowles raised that issue, I have to ensure consistency across the board. In respect of those Fightback information offices, if the determination is that the electoral offices are changed in their name and in their nature from parliamentary and electorate business to, primarily, Fightback information offices, then I have some concern. That concern has to be reflected in the action that I take. I did not say to Senator Knowles that I would not look at the assertions she has made; I will obviously do that. I have said to her that I have to be consistent in my approach in this area. Consistency demands that where there is an alleged misuse of resources, whether it is the Opposition Leader or a backbencher, then I have to intervene, and I do so.

PARA.TAB: For instance, I intervened in the case of Mr Blunt—the most notorious incident that has come before this Parliament in recent years. Senator Chapman would remember allegations that were made about his acting as an immigration agent out of his office. Those allegations were investigated at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie. That is an absolute lie.

—They may not have been sustained in the end, but the allegations were made at the time. They have to be investigated, they have to be tested, and if there is something improper being conducted, then that action stops. I suggest to Senator Knowles that others have raised these sorts of issues with me. They have written to me, and they have had these matters considered and followed through. I will do the same, no matter who the person is.

—I support my colleague Senator Knowles in her comments and the questions she put to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). The Minister introduced the greatest furphy of his life when he talked about the Fightback information offices.
—My office is a Fightback information office.

—Senator Collins's is an information office. The Minister also raised the question of whether or not voluntary workers can work in terms of selling policy. Senator Bolkus knows full well, as does Senator Collins, that it is quite legitimate and right to sell or promote policy out of an electorate office. That is servicing one's electorate. It is quite clear that electorate offices are to be used only for activities associated with electorate and parliamentary responsibilities, and selling policy is one of those responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: The first letter that Senator Knowles quoted from shows quite clearly that, in terms of the business operation that is being run out of the office of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ron Edwards), intimidation is being used, but I want to deal with a couple of other points. I have letters in my possession which have fax numbers across the top. They are headed, `Union Industrial Advisory Services Pty Ltd', and addressed to a number of people. The first letter is dated 10 July 1992. The letters run right through to November, so this is not a one-off thing. The letter goes into a whole range of business activities of this particular company. Each one is signed by Mr Clohessy as director, not as a voluntary staff worker of Mr Ronald Edwards.

In a letter of 5 November 1992, under the heading `Discharge of Claims', there is `Urgent Please', signed `Mr Clohessy'. The next one is dated 22 October. Once again, there is the name Union Industrial Advisory Services Pty Ltd, signed once again by Mr Clohessy. I even have a working paper that has been faxed through with `Raymond Clohessy' on top of `Union Industrial Advisory Services Pty Ltd'. Once again, there is Mr Ronald Edwards's name, and the date is 20 July 1992.

In answering Senator Knowles's question today, and again in responding to her motion to take note of his answer, Senator Bolkus introduced an enormous, irrelevant furphy in trying to taint quite unfairly the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, in terms of voluntary workers. Senator Bolkus should make a clear statement right now as to whether or not voluntary workers can assist in promoting policy and servicing an electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or assist in an electorate office.

—Or assist in an electoral office. The other question that Senator Bolkus needs to answer quite clearly is this: can one employ one's own people and have them work out of one's electorate office for the purpose of carrying out parliamentary work? These questions need to be answered precisely. As Senator Bolkus wanders out of this chamber, he needs to get back to the issue raised here; that is, that Mr Clohessy is operating a business out of Mr Ronald Edwards's office. That is the issue, and that is what should be addressed. The Minister today failed to do that here.

—The question that Senator Knowles asked of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), as I heard it, was whether he would investigate the allegations which she then went on to explain. Am I not accurate in that?
—No. I asked him on whose authority was Ron Edwards able to do that.

—In his response, the Minister said that he will look into it. I think that is a fair reply to a question. An allegation has been made in the chamber and the Minister responsible has said that he will investigate. I am not going to try to convict an individual on the strength of a letter. Every senator in this chamber—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator McKiernan has the floor.

—We all get letters. From time to time we get bogus letters and we have to make our own decisions about whether they are real, phoney or whatever. I have been a member of a very trying committee, the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, and we had a number of bogus letters sent to us which, upon investigation, were tossed out.
—These are not.

—Senator Crane says `these are not'; we on this side of the chamber have not seen them. I am not sure how many senators opposite have seen them. I am not casting any aspersions on Senator Knowles in bringing the matter before the chamber, but it does need to be investigated. It cannot be taken, simply on the word of an individual or of a couple of individual senators, however much I respect them, that a fellow member of parliament, Mr Ronald Edwards, and a colleague of his, Ray Clohessy, whom I know very well, are guilty of some misappropriation or abuse of a taxpayer funded service. We cannot do that. We should not get down in the gutter and do that. Some senators in this chamber have been doing that and trying to turn this place into a Star Chamber. On all sides of the chamber we should protect the Senate from doing that. If one of us plays those games then everybody else can do it and they can do it merely by innuendo because we are protected by parliamentary privilege.

PARA.TAB: But some of us have some standards. Some of us have some principles. We will maintain those principles on this side of the chamber and we will maintain them when we get over on the Opposition benches, if that happens. It is doubtful that that will happen because we have Hewson and Fightback going for us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment briefly on the response given by Senator Bolkus to Senator Knowles. Senator Knowles asked in this chamber a perfectly legitimate question of the Minister for Administrative Services. The question related to the alleged operation of a business out of an electorate office.
