PARA.TAB: Senator McKiernan quite correctly said that we are not in a position to judge. He also made the statement that we should not get into the gutter. No-one would agree with that more than the Opposition. However, who got into the gutter? In answer to a perfectly legitimate question from Senator Knowles, Senator Bolkus got up and tried to smear the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson. That is what we are talking about when we talk about people getting into the gutter. It is not awfully subtle.

Let me make an admission on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition. He does have someone working in his Canberra office who is not paid for by the taxpayer; I make that admission on behalf of Dr Hewson. That person happens to be a student volunteer who lives in Canberra. We get Senator Bolkus coming in here and making an assertion during Question Time—in radio broadcast time—as though Dr Hewson has done something wrong when what he has done is give someone a chance to get some work experience—

TALK.START.PARA: —And paying him nothing, I suppose?

—That is absolutely correct. There are volunteers in this world. I would also like to make an admission. In the past six months, I have had three volunteers in my offices—in my Brisbane office and my Canberra office—most of them qualified and I want to tell Senator Collins why. It is because they do not have jobs. Some of these people have two degrees and Senator Collins's Government has thrown them onto the scrap heap. It has no policy and it has thrown these people onto the scrap heap.

PARA.TAB: Ministers have clearly shown in Question Time, time and time again in the past week, that the Government has nothing to offer the Australian people. But Dr Hewson is offering young people hope; he is offering them jobs through the Fightback package and all those opposite can do is go around bucketing it. Let us have something positive from those opposite. Let us stop this smear; let us stop the untruthful remarks made by Ministers.
We heard from Senator Cook today. We cannot say certain remarks are lies—even though we know when people make them that they are lies—because it is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook? What did Senator Cook say?

—We have heard Senator Cook and Senator Button abusing the truth. Senator West should stop chirping like a budgerigar over there. She is one of the people who caused the great unemployment problem. I think it is quite offensive that the Minister should try to divert our attention from the answer to a perfectly legitimate question because it related to one of his own colleagues by trying to smear the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, who has an incredible concern for the one million people who are out of work and is prepared to give work experience to someone in his own office.

—I have no difficulty indicating support for what Senator Parer is saying in respect of a commonsense approach to the proper use of electorate offices. There would probably be few subjects on which there is more cant and humbug expressed than questions such as this: so-called innocent questions that are clothed in anything but innocence.
—It was not clothed in anything; it was perfectly straightforward.

—Yes, it was. Senator Knowles did not simply raise the question. Senator Knowles also reached an instant conclusion and then passed judgment on it. As was stated a moment ago, Senator Bolkus rightly said of a subject of which he was being made aware for the first time that he would investigate the matter. Those opposite cannot expect him to do any more than that.

PARA.TAB: When I said that I agree with Senator Parer, it is on this matter that I agree with him. So far as the use of volunteer workers in offices is concerned, providing those people are working for the member or senator on legitimate electorate and constituent work, in my view there should be no difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —This guy is not; he is running a business.

—I am not talking about that case because I know nothing about it. Of course people should not be running businesses from electorate offices. I am saying that we will all be in a ridiculous position if people who are prepared to give their services free are no longer allowed to. Provided they are working on legitimate constituent and electorate work, of course they should be allowed to continue to do so.

PARA.TAB: In relation to Senator Bolkus's concern about electorate offices being nominated as Fightback information offices, I make it clear that I am certainly happy to have my office nominated as a Fightback information office. In fact, we are disseminating as much information about Fightback as we can manage to. I certainly hope that Senator Bolkus is not going to close down an office because it is nominated as a Fightback information office. As Senator Faulkner interjected earlier, I would think that, for the sake of the Labor Party, we would want to double or triple the number of those offices currently available because the information in Fightback is a total turn-off for the electorate.

I will conclude on that point. No more horrible prospect is available for young unemployed people than that of having to face an industrial relations regime such as the one that is proposed by the coalition. There is no more horrible prospect. Senator Zakharov is not in the chamber at the moment, but I heard her interject in a previous debate when people were talking about the marketplace determining the value of labour. She said that this is not a new concept. The concept of classical economics is a very ancient concept indeed. In fact, John Maynard Keynes made his reputation opposing it.

There is nothing new or startlingly refreshing about this business of the marketplace determining the value of labour. It is as old as economics and it has been rebutted and rejected in every sensible economy around the world. There is no more horrible prospect for young unemployed people in a depressed economy than to have to compete in a marketplace where they will be put on the lowest wages possible with absolutely no protection offered to them at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —All they want is a job.
—It is a truly horrible prospect for them to have to face and those opposite confirm it by interjection: it is better to have a job as slave labour than no job at all. I reject that assertion.

—I support my colleague Senator Knowles who raised a perfectly proper question. Let us get it straight. Why is that person in the trade union movement able to use a government paid for office for his own personal gain? That is the question. Let us get it right. Let us accept none of the subterfuge and innuendo indulged in by Minister Bolkus.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator McKiernan. I think the words `Bolkus' and `bogus' are truly synonymous. Senator McKiernan made that analogy during his own address. I must say that Minister Bolkus, as opposed to other Ministers who presently reside on the Government benches, is not a man who is recognised for his honesty or integrity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, you will withdraw that.
—I said that the man was not recognised for those attributes.
—That is an imputation against the Minister. You will withdraw.
—If you insist, Mr Deputy President, I will in fact withdraw; but on a subsequent occasion we may choose to debate that issue in its own right.
—Without qualification.
—Order! You will withdraw without all of those qualifications. Simply withdraw.
—I will not talk about phone bills either.
—You will withdraw.

—I withdraw. I will go back to the issue that is at hand: the fact that the Labor Party applies a standard to itself that it does not apply to anybody else. It believes that it is able to flout the law and to flout propriety. Not only do we have this instance in Western Australia of a man using a government funded office for his own personal gain, but also we have the example of Senator McMullan. Senator McMullan in the Estimates hearings was questioned at some length and, indeed, referred to the Prices Surveillance Authority. We saw its report come in today and I was looking in vain to find anything that said how the Secretary—paid by a grant out of taxpayers' money—works out of Senator McMullan's office. She has an office and a desk and she uses the fax and the telephone.

PARA.TAB: If we go to the relevant Hansard report, we will find all the answers to those questions. In other words, the Labor Party is at all times prepared to bend the rules for itself, and then has the audacity to come in here and try to draw an analogy with people on this side of the House who are prepared to give young Australians a chance to get work experience, to get out there and compete for jobs that are denied them by this Government. We see the duplicity and the double standard this Government lives by and will die by—the Government that says that somehow we cannot give a break to a young school kid who is trying to get a go. There is no fair go for ordinary Australians in this place, but there are special privileges for the trade unions. We have the Minister for the BWIU, who passes for the Minister for Industrial Relations, the sidekick of John Halfpenny, doing his work at the present time. We have double rules.

We have, as I said, Minister Bogus—I mean Bolkus—who says that he is a man who is trying to put in the same breath somebody who condones a government-paid for, taxpayer-paid for office being used by a trade unionist for personal gain and somebody who is giving work experience to a young Australian trying to get out there and fight in an unfair world, brought upon after 10 years of Keating Government. There we see it in a nutshell: duplicity, double standards, unfairness. We have mateship in action. There are special rules for all those people in the trade union movement—the people who are the bully boys, the ugly face of the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop got her facts as comprehensively wrong as she got the argument.
—As she did in the Castlereagh by-election.

—Yes, as she did with her scurrilous allegations about the Castlereagh by-election, the scurrilous allegations she made about Mr Boucher, the scurrilous allegations she made about Richard Butler, and the scurrilous allegations she made about me. Of course, the Prices Surveillance Authority has absolutely nothing to do with any activity that takes place within my office. The Prices Surveillance Authority is a government instrumentality, operating entirely independently and quite properly, and is respected. The Opposition has just announced that it will continue it in operation, so let us get that clear. It is true that, as with, I understand, all these community-minded people over here—

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Is Senator McMullan purporting to take note of the answer given to Senator Knowles's question or is he seeking to make a personal explanation? Why does he not make a personal explanation at the end of this instead of taking up other people's time?
—Stop trying to filibuster and use up the debate.
—I am not filibustering.
—It is a spurious point of order.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I am speaking to the motion, in case it was not obvious. I am responding exactly to the argument that was put in the debate. As it was put in the debate, it must be in order, otherwise Senator Bishop would not have done it. Therefore, I am speaking to the same point.

PARA.TAB: I, as do others, including many Opposition senators who have just indicated so, allow constituents who are doing valuable community work to do so from my office. It is not true that they have designated desks, et cetera. That assertion has been contradicted in the past, but those facts never seem to interfere with Senator Bishop's enthusiasm for making assertions. She has never let the facts get in the way of a good argument before, and she was not about to start today. What she said is, first of all, very unfair to the Prices Surveillance Authority, which does an excellent job on behalf of the Australian people. It is also absolutely untrue, if there is any imputation that the taxpayers' money is being in any way misused in my office or that there is any secret about what takes place in my office.

It is, as best I can judge, comparable with the assertions that people were making about whether they allow constituents to provide assistance—in this instance not to me, but to other constituents of mine—from my office. It is something that I think is socially worthwhile. I am prepared to be judged on it as to whether the public thinks it is an appropriate thing for me to do. I certainly make no secret about it. I put out regular press releases indicating what I try to do from my office. I am prepared to stand up and be judged by it. It is a proper thing to do. That is something that I think we should all be prepared to argue for. Our activities are funded by the taxpayers and our offices are funded by the taxpayers. We all need to be prepared to argue about how they are used. I am happy to do that on any occasion.

I came in here only to say that playing fast and loose with the facts does not add in any way to the debate. It did not today. It does not on the other occasions when Senator Bishop does it. It does the Senate no good—and it does her no good, which is her problem. To the extent that the argument was directed to me, it is inaccurate, but I am very happy to debate the facts about my situation, as I put them on the record to the Estimates committee, with anyone else who wants to ask me about them, and as other honourable senators here have done today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for taking note of answers has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Senator Bishop's contribution to the previous debate, she implied, or said, that I drew a particular analogy about Senator Bolkus. I did not. I do not know how her twisted mind could infer that I drew any form of analogy of the nature that she said I did.
—Mr Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—The point of personal explanation relates to the principle I raised with regard to Senator McMullan—the fact that he has working out of his office a person who is paid for by a grant by way of taxpayers' money. She works in his office. The Hansard shows that she has a desk, a phone, access to the photocopier, and so on.
—I cannot see how this can be a personal explanation.

—The personal explanation relates to the fact that he said I distorted the facts. In fact, he is correct in saying that it is the price watch network as distinct from the Prices Surveillance Authority which is the body in question and which is in his office. My personal explanation is that the body concerned is the price watch network funded out of taxpayers' funds, not the Prices Surveillance Authority, which is also funded by taxpayers' funds. The principle remains constant: that Senator McMullan uses his office for an improper purpose by having in his office someone funded by taxpayers' funds.
—Order! You are now debating the question.
—Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the debate that ensued on the motion to take note of the answer to Senator Knowles's question, drawing further red herrings across this issue in responding on behalf of the Government, Senator Bolkus made the claim that there were allegations some years ago that I was operating a migration agents business from my electorate office and that they had to be investigated. Then in response to my protestations across the chamber, he said, `Well, it may have been that those allegations were found to be false'.

PARA.TAB: The truth is that those allegations were never made. Four years ago the Government introduced the licensing of migration agents to deal with business migration. It changed the whole way in which business migration applications were processed through the Department by licensing private agents to virtually approve them—a policy the Government has subsequently abandoned because it was proven to be quite inadequate and quite unsuitable.

The point that was raised at that time was whether a firm in which I and other partners had an interest was an appropriate firm to be granted one of those licences, having a member of parliament as a partner in that firm. There was never any suggestion made at that time, nor could it have been made, that that business was being operated from an electorate office. Other people were involved in the business. It was operated from completely separate premises. So the allegation that Senator Bolkus made across the chamber was false in the extreme. That ought to be understood and recognised. Of course, one can debate the other issue as to whether a member of parliament ought to be part of such a firm which is licensed by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not think it was debatable. The answer is no.

—Senator Collins raises that point. It is interesting that this Government licenses parliamentarians as tax agents and other agents who deal with government instrumentalities, in exactly the same way as those migration agents were dealing with government instrumentalities. One can debate that matter. Anyway, it is history, because that whole system has now been abandoned. In terms of a policy matter, I am very glad that it has been abandoned because it was a very poor policy to have been introduced.

—Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to explain why an answer has not yet been provided to my question on notice No. 2194 relating to the Commonwealth's decision to grant five sandmining leases at Shoalwater Bay to Pivot Projects Pty Ltd and Pivot Mining NL, of which notice was given on 27 August 1992.

—I was advised that in fact an answer had been sent to Senator Coulter. I am sorry that it has not yet arrived. My office had a copy of the answer that was sent to him. I have had it brought down to the chamber. I will give it to Senator Coulter now.

—Mr Deputy President, pursuant to that same notice of 28 September 1988, and in particular to subclause (c), I wish to move a motion with regard to the Minister's failure to provide either an answer or an explanation and in particular to draw—

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I think we had this debate a few days ago. The argument that was accepted, as I recall, was that where an answer is simply provided rather than an explanation given for not answering, that particular order does not allow the senator to pick up the issue and move a motion such as that which Senator Coulter is seeking to move.
—Order! It was not quite that way.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Coulter

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: I draw your attention to part (1) of the particular order of the Senate which says:

PARA.TAB: . . . provide to the Senator who asked the question an explanation satisfactory—

INTERJECT.PARA: this is the explanation in relation to the delay, not the answer—
to that Senator of why an answer has not yet been provided . . .
The point is that no explanation has been offered and therefore it is quite unsatisfactory. An answer has been offered but an explanation for the delay has not been offered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, perhaps I may just speak to the point of order. Although I support the point made by Senator Hill, I think the sequence of events today has put Senator Coulter in a very difficult position. I do not wish in any way to overturn that previous ruling. But I suggest that we might change the order of proceeding in the future. This answer was not given prior to the moving of motions to take note. In the normal course of events, had Senator Collins given his answer prior to the moving of motions to take note, Senator Coulter would have had the opportunity to move a motion to take note of the answer. If he was concerned about the answer, he would have had the normal opportunity available to honourable senators to debate such a motion.
—He wouldn't have had any opportunity because the half hour he imposed had run out.

—I understand that it would not have worked today. I agree that an amendment moved by Senator Macdonald to my motion was an improvement. But in the normal course he would have had that opportunity. He does not have it today because we got our sequence of events a bit out of sync. That does not change the interpretation of the standing order which was made the last time this matter was raised, which I think is correct. I am simply suggesting that procedures ought to be dealt with in a different sequence at subsequent Question Times so that these matters come up before the moving of motions to take note.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall just read what is in the Journals of the Senate for last Wednesday. The Journals state:

INTERJECT.PARA: Point of order: The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) raised a point of order to the effect that Senator Collins had provided an answer to the question rather than an explanation of failure to answer it, and therefore Senator Chamarette was not in order in moving to take note of an explanation.
Then under the heading `Ruling of Deputy President' the Journals state:

The Deputy President (Senator Colston) indicated that, having examined the information provided by Senator Collins, he concluded that it was not in the nature of an explanation of failure to answer the question, but was in the nature of an answer. Therefore he ruled that Senator Chamarette was technically not in order in moving to take note of an explanation, but could seek leave to make a statement.
I would also note that after having made that ruling, Senator Coulter indicated to me that perhaps one could move to take note of the lack of an explanation. That is an interesting point.

PARA.TAB: I have not seen the answer so I cannot say at this stage whether there is an explanation. It might be worthwhile Ministers doing what Senator Collins has done and providing at the start of an answer an explanation of why the answer has not been provided until that point. Then it would be in order for an honourable senator so to move. I would suggest that at this stage we should probably try to give Senator Coulter the avenue to make a comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could make a comment by leave rather than by way of speaking on the point of order. Mr Deputy President, whilst I recognise that you are, of course, being constructive, I do not think you are interpreting this provision correctly. I think the provision relates to debate on an explanation for an answer not being provided out of time. It seems to me that on a normal commonsense interpretation of this provision, if the answer is provided the opportunity for debate on the explanation for not providing it is overtaken. Then, if one wants to deal with the answer, there are other procedures for doing that. One can seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of the answer and debate it accordingly.

PARA.TAB: The trouble with Senator Coulter's position in this instance is, as my colleagues on this side have said, that he does not come to this debate with clean hands. He conspired with the Government to restrict our capability to deal with answers. We have had to live under that curtailed regulation. And so, today—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. The point that has been raised is irrelevant. It is not relevant to the question before the Chair.
—Order! It certainly was not relevant. I ask Senator Hill to continue.

—I have nearly finished, Mr Deputy President. The Democrats want it all their own way. Last Thursday Senator Coulter had a Bill that he regarded as an important piece of legislation. We in this chamber had to debate it from half past nine in the morning until half past ten at night. Apart from Question Time, there was basically no other business because the Democrats thought that was important business.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are quite happy to see curtailed everything else in this chamber that other senators regard as important business. We saw this with the debate on the Appropriation Bills. The Democrats came in and voted with the Government on the guillotine. They are likely to do so again in the next few days because they have done so at the end of every other session.

The Democrats agreed with the Government that debate on answers to questions should be limited each day. Yet, outside that period of limitation, Senator Coulter comes in here today and asks for special opportunity. The Democrats do not play the game. They want it all their own way. They forget the responsibility and right of other senators to properly scrutinise legislation and deal with matters that we think are of importance in the national interest. If Senator Coulter thinks we are a bit unreasonable with the Democrats in relation to giving leave on things like that, I say: when the Democrats start playing the game fairly, they will get a better response than they will get at the moment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Coulter

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. If the Opposition knew that the issue that I want to raise goes, in my view, to the heart of quite significant corruption in both the Queensland and Victorian governments, of course it might take a rather different view. On the point of order, I just point to the wording of part (1) of the motion. The motion states:

INTERJECT.PARA: That, if the Senate Minister does not answer a question on notice asked by a Senator within 30 days—
clearly that is established; the answer was not given within 30 days—
. . . provide to the Senator who asked the question an explanation satisfactory to that Senator—
of why an answer has not yet been provided . . .

Then it goes on to say that without notice I may move a motion with regard to the Minister's failure to provide either an answer or an explanation. It seems to me to be absolutely clear. The explanation is not satisfactory as to why an answer was not provided within 30 days. That is the point.

I think, Mr Deputy President, I am perfectly in order to move a motion. If you still will not accept it, I will seek leave to deal with this matter within five minutes because the matter is important as it deals with a very serious issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: I do not really want to test your patience on this too far. Indeed, it is entirely within your discretion as to how much unsolicited advice you want to receive on points of order. There is no requirement for you to endlessly pursue this debate.

PARA.TAB: I was rising in my place, originally, to say what Senator Hill said. I just wanted to indicate, had not Senator Coulter pursued the matter, that I would not have wanted to prolong this debate. But Senator Hill's interpretation of this matter is absolutely correct. One has only to apply that very scarce commodity, commonsense, to this procedure to understand why; one does not have to be a lawyer. This procedure is here, rightly, to put the heat on Ministers to provide answers to questions. The kind of debate which Senator Coulter now wants to have is a debate which properly takes place when the Minister fails to provide an answer.

When Senator Coulter rises in his place and raises an unanswered question, were I then in a position of having to rise—and sometimes this happens—without the answer that Senator Coulter is pursuing, then that matter is properly debated because there is no answer. But I checked on the matter, as I think I had an obligation to do, and found that in fact an answer had been sent. That was the advice that we received. My office had a file copy of it and I asked my office to immediately send it down.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no explanation at all.

—In response to Senator Coulter's interjection, he is really putting a nonsensical interpretation on those words. Having provided the answer that Senator Coulter was looking for, I think that the resolution no longer applies. I do not think that that is only the correct interpretation of that procedure, but that the procedure itself will be abused if that is not the way in which it is interpreted.

—I have another issue, Mr Deputy President, and that is the fact that we currently have a sessional order to the effect that the period for taking note of answers is limited to half an hour. If the first case that Senator Coulter was raising were correct, which of course it is not and which he adequately explained and which Senator Collins and Senator Hill also confirmed, then the question of taking note of the answer, which is virtually what he is trying to do, is out of time because we have used the half hour today anyway. Whichever way it is, I am sorry, he is just out of luck.
—Could I put a matter of fact before you, Mr Deputy President—the matter of fact that there is no explanation in this document at all? There is an answer to the question but no explanation.

—Order! Senator Archer, they are two separate matters, so one does not impinge upon the other. I can see some ambiguity in the order that we have. But I will hold to my previous ruling and, after having disposed of it this afternoon, I think it is something that the President and I should discuss to make sure that we understand what is in the position.

PARA.TAB: The rationale of the ruling is that if an answer is given the whole procedure, which is designed to deal with unanswered questions, no longer operates. I will uphold the ruling that I gave on Wednesday last. If Senator Coulter wishes to raise the matter, I think that he should look at some other procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a five-minute statement in relation to this very important matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The total failure of the Government's economic program, its refusal to put forward policies to address the national economic crisis, and its subordination of the public interest in favour of the vested interests of trade union leaders.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Hill, I announce that informal arrangements have been made to limit the time for discussion today and that speaking times during the debate will be as follows: the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, 15 minutes; the Manager of Government Business, Senator McMullan, 15 minutes; and the five remaining speakers 10 minutes each. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate moves on again to really the most important matter on the national agenda. I refer to the economic crisis facing this country; the consequences of that crisis to so many hundreds of thousands of Australians; the failure of the Government even to recognise that we are facing a crisis, let alone producing and implementing plans or a program to give some hope for those Australians who are suffering as a result of the Government's errors of judgment; and, most recently, this attempt to divert attention from the national crisis by seeking to interfere in the Victorian Government's efforts to remedy what it has inherited in the form of a disastrous economy down there and, by doing so, to benefit its union mates, the leaders of the union movement and their vested interests.

PARA.TAB: It is therefore a most serious matter. It calls for attention and debate. Every day this week and most days last week, we put these matters to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). We put to him the latest depressing statistics on the economy and said, `What is the Government going to do about it? What is the Government's plan?'. On not one occasion was he prepared to answer those questions. On not one occasion was he prepared to say, `We recognise we are in error. There is a major problem out there and we propose to fix it by adopting certain economic policies'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not even here to debate it.

—As my colleague says, not only has he ducked the question every day, but today he has even ducked the debate as well and sent in Senator McMullan to do his job. I asked him again about another of the depressing statistics that are before us, namely, the number of young people—the 15- to 19-year-olds in this country—who are out of work. According to the figures of the Bureau of Statistics, at the moment in Australia 160,000 are looking for work and unable to get work. That is an enormous figure. And they are about to be joined, regrettably, by many thousands more school leavers who are finishing their secondary education.

PARA.TAB: That is only half the story because other research tells us that another 160,000 teenagers are part employed when they are seeking further employment. So this is the fact of underemployment on top of existing unemployment. In relation to young people in this country there are around 330,000 underemployed or unemployed with further numbers, regrettably, about to join them. This is happening because this Government's economic policies are not resulting in a growth level in our economy that is sufficient even to maintain the current level of employment. The Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, acknowledged that in an interview on the 7.30 Report when he was asked, `What hope is there for school leavers coming on the market with growth levels of 2 per cent?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Growth is 2 per cent. Employment is growing.

—No, it is not. It will not even maintain the current level of employment. Even the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, understands that. People are coming onto the employment market at a rate in excess of the growth in the economy. I would have thought even Senator McMullan could understand that. But he is typical of his Government: rather than face up to the responsibility and put an alternative program before the Australian people that can give hope to all young Australians who are suffering, he sits here and says that there is not a problem. That is the fundamental error before us: this Government does not acknowledge the problem, no matter how great it is.

PARA.TAB: The problem does not relate only to youth unemployment. Look at what we had last week. For the first time, foreign debt in this country is in excess of $200 billion gross. That is ten-fold what this Government inherited. Senator Button says that that is not really a problem. The current account is blowing out again: Australia is sucking in imports even though the growth level is so low. We are hardly out of a recession, yet we are again sucking in imports. For nine months the trend has been upwards. Last week we received the highest figure in the last three years, but this Government says that is not a problem. The growth figure indicates that the level of unemployed will not be absorbed and that there is no hope for the unemployed in what we are getting from this Government at the moment.

Until the intervention of the Victorian issue, the best we have been able to get is that the Government will stand on its record. It offers Australia no plan at all. Its political strategy has been to simply attack the Opposition for its plan or talk about what is happening in Great Britain or any other irrelevant matter. It will not face up to the Australian people with a plan or a program that will demonstrate how it can bring the Australian economy out of the mess it created and how it will give people in this country some hope for the future.

This Government has created a mess. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) acknowledged when he was Treasurer, this was the recession we had to have. His strategy was to push interest rates up to try to dampen demand. However, the result was that he put good Australian businesses out of business; bankruptcies soared; many people went out of business forever; and people found they had no alternative but to import goods. More jobs went as a result. So this downward spiral continues. But this Government will not acknowledge it; this Government will not face up to it; and this Government will not put an alternative set of policies.

Independent commentators are starting to recognise that there is this policy vacuum and this failure on the part of the Government. I think it is worth quoting Ross Gittins, a respected economic commentator, who on 23 November said that Labor does not deserve to be re-elected, has nothing positive to offer and that since February Paul Keating has done `nothing but hope like hell the economy would recover in time for the election' and `as to what he'd do if he wins the election, his mind's a blank'. That is the future the Prime Minister offers for Australia: his mind is a blank. A day or two after that Terry McCrann, in somewhat dramatic terms, although I do not think he overstated it, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have a Prime Minister determined to win the coming election, to win the coming election at any cost—and that cost is the future of Australia. With utter and almost clinical cynicism, he will do anything to court short-term popularity. Now we have a government ruthlessly feeding on our fears and uncertainties about the reforms we desperately need.

What a sad commentary about this Government. But how this Government deserves it. With the misery it has inflicted on so many Australians and its unwillingness to face up to its economic failure and to provide an alternative program, it certainly does not deserve re-election at the forthcoming election.

PARA.TAB: The fact there is no agenda was confirmed by Peter Hartcher, who is the last of the three commentators I will mention, when in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 November—Peter Hartcher has good sources in the ALP; he snooped around looking for the Labor Party's fifth term agenda—he came up with:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating has told us very little of his own intentions for Labor's fifth term. The Labor secretariat has, apparently, stapled together about 10 pages of factional wish-lists and leftovers from the 1980s and called it a draft fifth-term agenda . . .

On that record, this is not a government that deserves re-election. It is not offering to the Australian people any alternative than more of the same—and that more of the same that has led to so much misery in this country.

PARA.TAB: If we search for something from this Prime Minister, the one item we would come up with is the One Nation statement. Out of that statement, we can see another aspect of the Prime Minister's approach to politics—that is, building up false expectations. No matter the harm that might be done, the Prime Minister always overstates his position in the hope of short term political gain. We saw it with the now infamous One Nation speech which is typical of Mr Keating's exaggeration. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's plan for the next four years will create over 800,000 jobs—
since making that speech, unemployment has gone up by some 37,000—
without increasing the current account deficit—
last week we had the highest figure in three years—
and at the same time, return the budget to surplus and Australia to growth.

The Budget deficit is skyrocketing. That is the record of this Government. In February 1992 he had no sound basis at all for making that statement. But that would not worry him. A month later, in March, he said:

As it starts to move, we push the extra stimulus of One Nation into it, which will then see the Government spending between about March and Christmas and June of next year which should push the economy along quite nicely back to growth, back to employment growth and back to lower levels of unemployment.

He went on to talk about the Government hitting its straps. The record since One Nation has been appalling—unemployment has gone up, the growth figures are depressed—and there is no hope coming from it at all.

PARA.TAB: Why did One Nation fail? It failed because it required the so-called special relationship between the ALP and the union movement to provide a recipe for growth, particularly in relation to the infrastructure developments and, in turn, in relation to railways. Despite that special relationship, the unions did not cooperate; so One Nation did not provide the jobs it was intended to. One Nation broke down. A month or so ago the Government had no alternative but to in effect abandon it. It had to take money out of the infrastructure projects and out of the job projects and put it into an attempt to gain short term political growth, mainly through local government.

The lie in that has been demonstrated so aptly by some of my colleagues who have looked at what local governments are doing with this money. The program originated in the last Budget, but my colleagues have found that it is not producing new jobs at all. When the Treasury officers appeared before them in this Parliament earlier this week, the Treasury officers had no figures to indicate how this would produce growth, what jobs were to be created or where they were to be created. That is not surprising because it was not supposed to do that. This was another of Mr Keating's political tricks. That is all he is interested in.

The latest of these political tricks is what is happening in Victoria. In Victoria, the incoming Premier and his Government inherited some $30 billion worth of debt and record unemployment—a disastrous legacy of 10 years of appalling government by Labor. The new Victorian Government has a mandate from the Victorian people to set it right, to make Victoria efficient again, to give it the opportunity to be competitive, to give businesses the opportunity to be competitive and, therefore, to provide long term, sustainable jobs. That was the mandate Mr Kennett was given. But was he allowed to get on and do that job? No, he was not.

The Prime Minister saw here an opportunity to raise another political issue, another diversion, whilst at the same time showing respect for his Labor mates and their vested interests into which he is locked. We must not forget that when the Prime Minister did his deal with the former Prime Minister at Kirribilli House a few years ago, carving up the future job of Prime Minister of this country, who his second was. It was Mr Kelty.

Who do we know has had more influence than anyone outside this Parliament on the policies of this Government over the last 10 years? It is Mr Kelty—unelected. It is these people—Mr Kelty and Mr Halfpenny—from whom this Government requires support for its survival. So when they see their vested interests suffering under policies such as the Kennett policy of abolishing compulsory unionism, they call upon Mr Keating to respond and he calls upon the nation—in effect, he endorses it—to go out in mass industrial action.

He did it in the political way. When the unions, Halfpenny and others in Victoria called upon mass industrial action, Mr Keating and his Minister here said, `We understand why it ought to be done nationwide'. So their response was to call mass industrial action. When that started to become politically difficult, their second response was to legislate to interfere in the Victorian process of recovery by trying to provide an alternative method of industrial relations, a method of industrial relations which over the last 10 years has contributed to the economic disaster and the record level of unemployment in this country.

It is not good enough. It is not a government that is deserving of re-election. It is not a government that has a fifth term agenda. All it goes to the Australian people with is a record of failure, of hundreds of thousands of Australians who have unnecessarily suffered misery as a result of that failure. So, whatever this Government might say about Fightback, it is a program that can provide recovery to this country, that can provide the parameters for an efficient and competitive Australia, and that can give Australians the long term possibility of real, sustainable jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contrast which this debate will display leaves no doubt why all the polls are showing big swings to Labor. The Morgan poll, the Bulletin poll, the Newspoll and Saulwick all indicate a minimum swing of about 3 per cent to the Government. Just to point out what that would mean to my colleagues, who I am sure are interested, any swing of that proportion would mean a gain to the Government of about 12 seats, or a majority of 30. I thought I would point that out just in case the Opposition has not understood what those four polls mean. The Australian people know—everybody knows—that the economy is growing too slowly. They do not need people to come up with policies to wreck it; that is not an alternative they want.

PARA.TAB: The economy is growing too slowly, but the unpalatable fact to the Opposition is that it is growing better than any other country in the OECD. Consensus Economics, on 2 November, did a survey following the survey by the Economist in June, which I quoted and which said that in 1992 Australia will be the best and that in 1993 Australia will be the best. Consensus Economics now does a survey of most of the OECD countries and what does it say? It says that Australia will grow more quickly than the other countries listed, but not quickly enough. We should be doing better. It is not grounds for complacency, but it is doing better than any other Western economy. Compared with the United States, Japan and Germany—the three great engines of growth which are compared in this survey—Australia is expected to be faster in 1992 and faster in 1993; two per cent in calendar year 1992 and 3.8 per cent in calendar year 1993. That is the expectation of the international economic consensus, as surveyed by Consensus Economics, which publishes that report regularly. It is the same conclusion as that of the survey of economists conducted by the Economist in June.

That is not grounds to say that we should not be doing better and that we need not do more. But the signs of improvement are there. They are the sorts of mixed messages that we always get when the economy is in transition. We got them when the economy was in transition from growth, and slowing down. That is why the decision to reduce interest rates was taken too late—too late, we acknowledge, although when we first reduced interest rates, Dr Hewson said that we were doing it too early. Nevertheless, it was too late. That is the problem we have to cope with now.

The mixed messages now indicate that the economy is turning again. The ANZ job survey indicates that job advertisements are picking up. According to the last figures published in the Department of the Parliamentary Library's monthly economic and social indicators, it had picked up 4.7 per cent over the last 12 months. That has improved. Since then, the most recent figures show a further modest improvement. The most recent Westpac forecasts indicate that for 1993 the revised estimate for GDP growth in Australia is 3 per cent, with inflation at 2.7 per cent and unemployment still too high but falling. I might say that growth in Australia is higher than in New Zealand and unemployment in Australia is lower than in New Zealand. So if the Opposition still aspires to turn Australia into New Zealand, there is little in that data to recommend it.

The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry survey released today—at least, I got the copy today; it is a November survey—indicates that its respondents, that is, businesses, expect an upturn in conditions within their own businesses and are expecting improvement to continue across the next half year. Production levels are expected to rise slightly, while investment is expected to be maintained—a positive investment result for the first time.

None of that is to say that, therefore, everything in the garden is rosy. The 2.1 per cent growth in the economy over the last 12 months, notwithstanding that it is better than any other Western country, is not sufficient. We need to do more. The key to growth in this state of our economic cycle is demand. The thing which is mainly driving growth at the moment is government demand, arising from One Nation, the youth employment statement and the Budget. The worst thing one could contemplate doing is what Fightback suggests, which is to withdraw that one element driving growth at the moment—government demand. The only two public figures in the Western world suggesting that the appropriate economic strategy is to withdraw government stimulus are George Bush and Dr Hewson—nobody else. The Government of Japan is saying, `We should give massive economic stimulus because we are getting into a recession'. As a proportion of GDP, it would be a much more significant stimulus than Australia is giving because Japan's economic base is stronger from which to do it.

The UK is giving a very substantial stimulus, a much bigger percentage of GDP than is the case with Australia. President-elect Clinton has just been elected on a strategy of doing exactly the same in the United States. Every other country in the Western world is suggesting that the appropriate thing for government to do at this stage in the economic cycle is to give a stimulus. Who says that stimulatory policy fails? George Bush and Dr Hewson are the only two people in the world who say that—one who lost and one who is losing.

The Labor Party, when it goes to the next election, will put before the people a comprehensive policy program for the fifth term, based on economic growth, decent wages, low inflation, decent social conditions and a cooperative society. When we release the elements of that is a matter for us. If Opposition members are getting frustrated by their position in the polls and wish we would release a policy so that they might be able to find a problem with it, I am sorry to disappoint them, but we are not going to produce it on cue just for them. When we go to the next election we will be doing that.

There is a dramatic contrast, and at the next election there will be a dramatic contrast, between Government and Opposition on those five issues: jobs, prices, wages, social welfare conditions and the nature of our cooperative society. They are fundamental to the choices the Australian people will make about the sort of economy and society they want, and fundamental to the response to the issues Senator Hill sought to raise in this matter of public importance.

We hear expressions of concern about the unemployed from the Opposition. We heard it from Mr Kennett when he was in opposition. We heard it from Mr Groom when he was in opposition. Mr Groom and Mr Kennett have both made absolutely clear what their solution for unemployment is: they keep sacking people. They say, `The unemployed must be lonely. We will put a few more people on the dole to join them'. Mr Groom this week sacked 200 construction workers from the Tasmanian Government. Mr Kennett is seeking to sack several thousand. That also is the policy of Fightback—to solve unemployment by sacking people, massive sackings involving hundreds of millions of dollars. The only thing they are going to spend more money on is redundancy payments.

I now turn to the issue of prices. For the first time, Australia has not only low inflation but inflation below that of our trading partners. We have broken the cycle of inflationary expectations. Every day our inflationary competitiveness gets better because our inflation is less than that of our trading partners. It is a matter of arithmetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe this, Bob?
—I understand that Senator Patterson cannot count, just as Senator Hill cannot understand that 2.1 per cent growth means that employment goes up. That is a law of arithmetic.
—It does not. Four per cent is what you need. Your own Prime Minister said so.

—Senator Bishop also does not understand the difference between employment going up and unemployment going down. It is straightforward; it is absolutely clear. Those opposite should look at the arithmetic. Employment is going up and it will continue to go up. Senator Hill can try to deny it as much as he likes, but it is simple arithmetic. I am sorry if it is painful. Those opposite wish it was not true, but it is.
—What a charlatan you are.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Senator Bishop will withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, are you asking me to withdraw the remark that Senator McMullan is a charlatan?
—Yes.
—On the understanding that Senator McMullan understands what a charlatan is, I withdraw it.
—Unconditionally withdraw the remark.
—Unconditionally, I withdraw the remark.

—Thank you for that, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I have not the slightest concern about what Senator Bishop calls me. I take pride in joining the long line of people about whom she has made unsubstantiated allegations. There are many fine Australian citizens in that queue and I am proud to join them.

PARA.TAB: The price increases generated by the GST will destroy that inflationary achievement even if those opposite are able to achieve their prediction, which I do not believe they will, of making that price increase a one-off. Even if they are able to achieve that, it will break the cycle of inflationary expectations and undermine the competitiveness that we have gained.

The third area of contrast will be wages. The Government is committed to a high wage strategy, not a low wage strategy. One of the key decisions we have to make is the choice between the high wage and low wage strategy. If we want to know what is the Opposition's option, we can look at one of two clear examples that are on the record. One is the policy of the Kennett Liberal Government. It is clear that it is opting for a low wage strategy for Victoria. The other example is the Opposition's with regard to youth wages—a youth wage of $3 an hour. Those opposite tried to interject today when Senator Cook made the point that the Opposition had proposed a $3 an hour wage, but it is on the record. Those opposite claimed it as a great bonus—until the young people of Australia rejected it. Now those opposite are trying to hide and say, `We didn't really mean it'. But that is what their policy means.

There will also be a contrast in social policy. The Opposition's way of improving the conditions for people in need is to slash their support from government and their access to social welfare. When anybody says, `You're going to cut the unemployed off the Jobsearch allowance after nine months', those opposite say, `No, we are not'. Fightback says that the Opposition will save $755m. I think that figure is wrong, but those opposite claim that they will save $755m by throwing people off the unemployment benefit. But they want to make the omelette without breaking the eggs. They say, `We can save the $755m, but no-one will lose anything'. That is where the $755m savings come from. It is $755 taken away from benefits that would otherwise have been provided to people who are unemployed. If no-one will lose, there is no saving. That arithmetic is also compelling. I know it is uncomfortable, but the Australian people are waking up to it. That is why they are making their views clear.

The fifth area of contrast concerns cooperation. One of the great changes that took place in 1983 was the movement away from industrial confrontation towards cooperation. We have had a decade of the most successful industrial relations management in Australian history, and the lowest level of disputes. The Australian people greatly appreciate that. The last thing they want is to see Australia going back to the bad old days of confrontation; of Australian against Australian; of driving Australia into unnecessary confrontation. That is why the recent ANOP poll, in accordance with the most recent surveys, made it clear that 82 per cent of Australians and 90 per cent of women say they want to keep the current award system. They know that that is where their security lies and that is the way to a cooperative Australia rather than one that is riven by conflict.

The alternative that is being proposed by those opposite, which Senator Hill almost forgot to mention—he got it in in the last 15 seconds—because the Opposition is now trying to shy away from it, is a recipe for disaster. It is like one of those big signs we see when driving the wrong way on a freeway that says, `Wrong way, go back'. I think the people are showing that to those opposite now. The Australian people are flashing that sign now and saying, `Wrong way, go back'.

The message from the Australian people is that they do not want sackings, they do not want prices to go up through a GST, they do not want their wages cut, they do not want jobs destroyed by Opposition policies, they do not want the social wage slashed and they do not want cooperation abandoned for confrontation. Until Opposition members learn that lesson they will continue to slide, because the Australian people are too intelligent to fall for a package of policies such as that proposed by the Opposition. The people certainly do not want those policies. The contrast is stark; the choice is clear. As the package unfolds and the people see the choice between growth and contraction, between decent wages and wage cuts, between low inflation and the GST, and between cooperation and confrontation, they will continue to reject the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance from the Opposition which reads:

PARA.TAB: The total failure of the government's economic program, its refusal to put forward policies to address the national economic crisis . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We have no quarrel with that aspect of the motion. It is clear that the Government's policies have failed. This afternoon we have heard the catalogue of unemployment, foreign indebtedness and the failure to put forward programs which will address these problems. The matter continues:
. . . and its subordination of the public interest in favour of the vested interests of trade union leaders.

Talk about the pot calling the kettle black! In recent days we have dealt with Bill after Bill and the Opposition has made it absolutely clear that its concerns are very much with the vested and financial interests in this country, the powerful forces of business, and that it has very little interest in the plight of the less well-off and the ordinary worker. I think that has come through quite clearly from the debates we have had in recent days.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan has had a lot to say about figures, mathematics and calculation. I remind him of the term—I think it was by Disraeli, but others have often used it—`lies, damned lies and statistics'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it wasn't; it was Eysenck. Get your history straight.

—It was long before him. Senator McMullan pointed out a growth rate of 2.1 per cent in the GDP, but he failed to point out that we have the highest population growth rate of any of the industrialised countries, a rate of roughly 1.9 per cent. On a per capita basis, that growth looks pretty shocking.

PARA.TAB: We all know that the Opposition's Fightback package is simply an extension of economic rationalism, an increase in the flow of wealth from the poor to the rich. The Opposition hopes, rather disingenuously, that the trickle-up phenomenon will result in a trickle-down which, through recovery of the economy, will somehow benefit the less well-off. Well, it has not worked during all the years that Labor has been in office and it will not work under the Opposition. They will be even less well-off under the Opposition when Dr Hewson screws down the bolts on the economy even more tightly than this Government has screwed them down.

What is required—and I would agree with Senator McMullan on this point—is much greater stimulation to the economy, but stimulation which is very selectively targeted into those areas of the economy which fulfil certain criteria. They must provide employment but, in providing that employment, they must also address the problem of foreign indebtedness. In other words, they must address increasing exports and, particularly, import replacement—something that we have been stressing in recent days through a series of questions to Senator Button, all of which have been totally unsatisfactorily answered. At the same time, the industries which need to be established in this country need to move us towards what governments, at least in theory, recognise—namely, ecologically sustainable patterns of development, patterns which are sustainable in the future and which do not run up enormous environmental costs which will be paid either by this generation or by later generations. Those are precisely the criteria that we put forward in our Getting to Work document. Those are the criteria we set ourselves.

That document contains a number of proposals which do exactly what the Opposition is accusing the Government of not doing. One of the matters to which we give great prominence in that document is that the stimulation clearly cannot come by increasing the deficit still further. We have a large and growing foreign debt. The stimulus can only come by increasing taxation revenue. We are proposing specifically a jobs levy, structured in exactly the same way as the Medicare levy, to raise $2 1/2 billion each year for five years. This money would be targeted into providing jobs—and not just any jobs. They would not be just jobs for the sake of jobs; not just jobs such as we saw with the RED scheme under the Whitlam Government—that is, throwing money at projects, painting rocks white, as many people have called it—but jobs which clearly are identified as having a long term social and/or environmental and/or economic benefit.

There are a number of such jobs available in this country. There is no shortage of work needing to be done. What is lacking is the money to pay for those jobs to be done, because we are, as everybody needs to recognise—and it is worth stressing again—a low tax country, not a high tax country. Compared with all the OECD countries, we share with America the ignominy of being the second lowest tax country of all the OECD countries. Only Turkey has a lower rate of taxation. So those who have jobs, those who are well-off in this blessed country of ours, can afford to find money to provide jobs for those who are less well-off. That is what we should be doing.

One of the areas which has been identified as urgently needing work to be done on it is the water supply. The major river system of this country, the Murray-Darling Basin, is in urgent need of reclamation. We are in danger of losing that whole waterway. The blue-green algae threatens the water supply of not only all of the towns along the Murray, but also the city of Adelaide, in which I live. If we lose that Murray-Darling Basin to blue-green algae, Adelaide will lose its water supply, and a city of over a million people will simply disappear because there will be no water to sustain it—and, particularly, in a dry year when the catchments in the Adelaide Hills are inadequately filled; it is precisely under those conditions that we may well lose the Murray-Darling supply.

There is an enormous amount of work to be done in relation to sewage treatment, the disposal of effluents, run-off from farms, revegetation and so on throughout the whole of the Murray-Darling Basin. Every single city in Australia pours its nutrient-rich fresh water out into the ocean with quite calamitous environmental impacts. Many billions of dollars-worth of work needs to be done to lessen the impact of sewage disposal on the marine environment. The long term ability of that marine environment to supply fish and other necessary biological services to the human population is very much threatened.

The rail system was also mentioned today. We need to spend quite massive amounts of money on the national rail system. In the Democrats' document Getting to Work we have proposed a very simple revenue neutral procedure by which third party insurance and registration would be replaced nationally with an increased excise on fuel.

We import $3.1 billion worth of petroleum each year and that figure is going to rise steadily as our self-sufficiency falls. We need to address this problem. We have massive air pollution over all our urban areas. We have a rising incidence of respiratory disease and that is something which the Opposition, with its concern for market systems, needs to recognise. The medical costs for the treatment of those diseases need to be internalised into the cost of the transport system.

In Melbourne alone, over the last 30 years asthma among children has risen from roughly 20 per cent to nearly 50 per cent as a direct result of air pollution. That is mostly as a result of exhaust emissions from motor vehicles. By contrast the Opposition would reduce the price of fuel, put 15 per cent on public transport fares and so increase the problems of air pollution very markedly.

In many aspects of the solar industry, world class work is being done in Australia, both for low temperature hot water for domestic use and for high temperature hot water for industrial use. We have leading technology in this country, but it is technology which is being applied overseas. It is not being applied in Australia simply because government has failed to recognise that this is the way of the future.

An enormous industry could be established which would have enormous employment and export opportunities, and very significant import replacement capacity. That was the substance of my question to Senator Button today in Question Time. We do not need to build another $2 billion power station in Western Australia. That situation can be avoided. Of that expense, $500m would go overseas for the importation of the very heavy generating equipment. There are many alternatives and the Democrats are the only ones who have an alternative to what either the Government or the Opposition offers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to remind the Senate precisely what we are debating. We are debating this matter of public importance in two parts. The first part states:

SPEECH.PARA: The total failure of the Government's economic program, its refusal to put forward policies to address the national economic crisis—
One could term that as past failures and the absence of new policies to deal with those failures. The second part states:
and its subordination of the public interest in favour of the vested interests of trade union leaders.

I listened with interest to the contributions from, firstly, Senator McMullan and then Senator Coulter. It was interesting to listen to Senator Coulter because he dedicated much of his speech to the failure of the Government in the areas that were of particular interest to him, whereas the wider community is interested in employment, the failure of the economy and falling standards of living.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan seemed to be of the view that everything is all right, everything is fine, and if anybody brings forward any bad news then we had better shoot the messenger. He even deigned to single me out for particular comment because I have raised many issues which are of particular embarrassment to the Government. His attitude to that is to sweep it under the carpet and shoot the messenger.

I am afraid the electorate is not going to put up with that sort of attitude. If we look at the weight of statistics, we see what a failure the past policies have been. Senator Tate said in the chamber the other day that the Government has no policies. That was the one truthful statement that we have heard in a long time.

Let us look at figures. Today there are 980,000 Australians out of work, 320,000 of those being long term unemployed—destroyed lives. Since February alone 72,000 more Australians have lost their jobs. I will deal with Senator McMullan's rather cute definition of growth—that is, there are more people employed. For every job created since February nine other people have been put out of work—that is some growth. I see he has left the chamber; he does not like to see his arguments refuted. We have two percentage points growth and he says that is wonderful and that we are ahead of everyone else—but we are not ahead of our major trading partners and we are not ahead of the people in our own region.

Four per cent, Mr Keating said: if a government could not do 4 per cent growth, it was not worthy of being re-elected. That is a truthful statement and one that the electorate will no doubt act upon. The One Nation statement said that there would be growth of 4.7 per cent—wonderful. Then we came back with a little statement around the time of the Budget, and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said, `No, I think we are doing 3 per cent. We have restructured that down to 2 per cent. Where are we going to end up? In other words, all the projections, all the statements by the Government have been proved to be wrong. Kerry O'Brien on Lateline the other night did a splendid job showing what a facade, to begin with, the One Nation statement had been and how it had failed on every indicator.

That failure means that there are 680,000 children who live in homes where no-one has a job. More than one in six children live in families where the normal breadwinner simply does not have a job. Unemployment in Australia stands at 11.3 per cent. The OECD average, which Senator McMullan chose to use as a comparable figure earlier in the day, is 7.5 per cent. Compared with the last two recessions of 1974-75 and 1982-83, job losses in the current recession have been far more widespread. Recent figures show the largest job losses have occurred in Victoria, with 139,000, and in South Australia, with 20,400.

In Victoria, the falls have been concentrated in construction, wholesale and retail trade, property and business service, and manufacturing. This is the mess that Jeff Kennett is faced with cleaning up. This is the mess that resulted in a blow-out in the Loan Council approved borrowings, where Victoria borrowed outside the Loan Council limits to the tune of at least $1.3 billion, of which the Treasurer was fully informed on 6 July and chose not to inform the Parliament or the people by declining to include that in Budget Paper No. 4, where that information should have been contained. In other words, we have a sorry state of decline on every indicator. According to the most recently released annual report of the Industry Commission—a most worthwhile document, which does tell it like it is—Australia's productivity levels are substantially below those achieved by countries such as the United States and Japan. Productivity in electricity, for instance, is only 70 per cent of that in the United States. The productivity of railways in Australia, which was supposed to be a central feature of the One Nation statement, is only 10 to 30 per cent of that in the United States.

The policies of this Government have simply led Australia into a decline. Remember, we went in first. Well may the Government argue that the rest of the world is suffering from recessionary impacts, but we went in as a deliberate plan. Mr Keating told us, `This is the recession we have to have'. This is the recession that he described in terms of `lovely numbers'. This is something he was anticipating, and initially he told us we would have a soft landing. In other words, the word of the Prime Minister cannot be relied upon in any statement that he makes.
Then we see this sudden flurry, this activity on the industrial relations front, particularly in Victoria, where we see the sudden resuscitation of Mr Halfpenny, kept quiescent for 10 years—

TALK.START.PARA: —By us.

—Senator Sherry is quite right; he is spot on. It works like any other protection racket: as long as you pay the money they will not smash your windows in. But the moment the protection money is cut off and not paid any more, along come the bully boys, who start to smash the windows in or destroy the power supply or say that public transport will not run. They use the bully boy tactics, the ugly face of the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: Who have we got as Minister for Industrial Relations? I am pleased to see that Senator Cook has come in. We frequently wonder whether he is speaking as a Minister of the Crown, charged with the peace, welfare and good government of Australia or whether he speaks with his old voice as trade union official, a current, card-carrying member of that well known and highly respected organisation, the BWIU. On one occasion it took us 2 1/2 hours to get the Minister to admit that he was a paid up card-carrying member of the BWIU. He claimed at the end of the 2 1/2 hours of debate that it was all disclosed anyway. Again and again at the beginning of that debate he was asked by Senator Crane whether he was a paid up member of the BWIU. I asked him myself, but it was not until we sent out for the official record that we finally had it disclosed in the Parliament.

Well we might ask, when we have seen examples of the power and influence of the ACTU, of which the Minister also was a pre-eminent official during his earlier years—whether Mr Kelty has been the unofficial member at the Cabinet table, the man who in fact said what policies could go forward and what could not. Well we remember when Mr Keating was pushing his cart. Remember option C—the one that was going to have a broad-based consumption tax? It was all going fantastically, right up to the moment of the summit, until Mr Kelty summoned the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, in the dark of night, at midnight, to a motel down the road, where he said, `It's not on'. Back they came into the summit, and suddenly, after weeks of saying, `I won't change my mind; this is necessary for the economy', the trade union movement pulled the strings, called the tune, and the Government did a double somersault, reversed its previous policy, and said, `No, we are not going to have that policy right now'. We remember it well. It was well documented: the motel in the middle of the night and who summoned them to the meeting—Mr Kelty, the unnamed person at the Cabinet table.

Turning to the money supply, let us remind ourselves how much money it is. In the last 10 years the trade union movement has been paid conservatively $41m of taxpayers' money. That is pretty good protection money in anyone's book. That is about to get cut off at the knees. As well, we have all the trade union people who have been appointed to boards and committees. We have had today the TUTA report. Jenny George has been pre-eminent, I think, in this latest industrial thuggery. She gets paid $11,000 per annum for that job. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop's contribution to this debate was no surprise. She has carried on a long-standing tradition of attacking the backgrounds of members of the Government. It is a particularly unfortunate aspect of the debate on economic policy and other debates that take place in this chamber that the Opposition insists upon that method of attack. It does not do those opposite any credit. I am pleased to say that the Government does not reflect on the backgrounds of honourable senators opposite—whether they come from a farming background, a business background or a law background—and assume that they carry some vested interest into this place.

PARA.TAB: We have a very serious economic recession in Australia at the present time, and there are a number of reasons for it. There is no doubt that interest rates were kept too high for too long, and that has contributed to the recession we face. The rest of the world is experiencing a recession as well. No matter what we might say and do, we cannot divorce our economy from the rest of the world. As part of that, there is a massive upheaval taking place in the former Soviet Union and eastern Europe. There are significant trade problems, and we all know the difficulties we are having with the negotiations in the GATT Round on trade and the barriers that have been erected to many of our exports.

We are undertaking a significant restructuring with the introduction of new technology into the economy. It would have been well and good if those opposite, who were in government for decades, had started this process, but alas, they did very little but twiddle their thumbs and let the world go by. They did not commence the necessary restructuring of our economy. The longer that restructuring is left, the worse the restructuring is.

A fourth factor that is not often mentioned is the cultural insularity of Australia as a nation and the particular problems we have to face up to. The basic reason this economy is in a recession is not labour inflexibility, not an alleged lack of freedom in the labour market, not irresponsible trade unions—as the topic of the debate clearly implies and as members opposite have been clearly attempting to outline in their various speeches—and not the trade union movement. The trade union movement in the past decade has been very responsible, as illustrated by admissions by management that trade unions have taken their part positively in negotiations on industry restructuring and award restructuring and as illustrated by the decline in the number of industrial disputes over the last decade—a very significant decline and a decline that occurred well before the current recession.

What is the Opposition's solution? Where does it lay the blame? It says that the blame is to be laid on the trade union movement and the members of trade unions, the workers in this country. It lays the blame at the feet of the trade union movement and its members. Its solution at both State and Federal level is to introduce a system of individual work contracts; to abolish the independent industrial commissions, at least in the State of Victoria, which ensure that contracts are fair and reasonable; and to scrap weekend and night shift penalties. The Opposition advocates all of those things as solutions when in fact those things have not had anything to do with the cause of the economic recession in Australia.

The Opposition's solution is quite interesting. One of the central points of its solution to the recession is to punish those people who are the very victims of the recession and who are not in a position to defend themselves individually against employers in negotiating their wages, their conditions, their superannuation and suchlike.
