The Opposition has put forward as part of its solution—from its so-called Fightback, `Frightpack', Doomsday Book; all the other names it has been given—individual work contracts, the scrapping of the current industrial relations system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your policy?

—I will get to our policies in a moment. It has also put forward a goods and services tax. Interestingly, there has been some debate about how popular this GST is in New Zealand. I have just been on a delegation to Canada. The conservative government introduced a goods and services tax there of 7 per cent with many goods being exempt. It is so unpopular in Canada that the conservative provincial governments took their own Federal Government to court to try to stop the introduction of a GST. That is how popular it is in Canada. Frankly, I hope the Opposition continues to think it will be a popular policy because it is one of those policies which will ensure that the Opposition will not be elected. The Opposition's policies are labour market reform and a goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly, Australia's major export now is tourism. The tourism industry is now the leading export earner of this country. What will a goods and services tax do? It will put a 15 per cent impost on tourism. It will flatten the tourism industry. The Opposition well knows that members and representatives of the tourism industry have been lobbying fast and furious to have the tourism industry exempt because the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and payroll tax on that industry will have a negligible offsetting effect against the cost of a goods and services tax. So the Opposition's solution is to bash and comatose Australia's biggest export industry and destroy the only industry at the moment which is rapidly expanding and absorbing some of the unemployed.

The Opposition is obsessed with trade unions. The motion before us highlights that. The Opposition believes that trade unions are the root of all evil in this country when clearly that is not the case. Senator Bishop referred to the various funds that were allocated to the trade union movement, but she failed to mention that there is just as much money—in fact, in some years much more money—allocated to various business and management organisations in this country to ensure that those organisations are effectively equipped to participate in the restructuring of our industry.

Trade unions are made up of people. They are made up of human beings who, believe it or not—I do not think the Opposition can understand this—are not fools. They know what is in their best interests and they know that to effectively bargain with an individual employer workers have to have support; they have to have some backup. An individual employee going into an employer's office is not exactly evenly matched when it comes to bargaining.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what is going to happen.

—Senator Patterson continues to show her ignorance of industrial relations by claiming that that is not what is going to happen. The Opposition boasts about how individual contracts will boost productivity and efficiency. I do not think the Opposition knows the difference between productivity and efficiency. An employee's wages and conditions will be driven down. During the negotiations the employer will be flanked by a lawyer, an accountant and a security guard to escort the person off the premises if they do not go when they are sacked. That is the way it will go—the implied threat.
—What about the people who get beaten up by your union mates?
—An individual employee—a young person out of school, for example—is supposed to negotiate on a fair and equitable basis with the employer.
—What about the lad who got beaten up at Clayton the other day?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator Patterson, one interjection, say, every 10 minutes would be acceptable, but a constant barrage is unacceptable. Senator O'Chee is in the same position. Please do not interrupt Senator Sherry again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee can make his contribution next; he is down to speak. Senator Patterson is not down at all and she has been talking through this whole debate. If she wants to make a contribution about industrial relations, which she obviously knows nothing about, she should get up and make a contribution.
—Such rubbish!
—Order! Senator Patterson! I have asked you once. You continually interject. If you want to speak, you must put yourself on the speakers' list; otherwise, you have no right to interrupt the speaker.
—Tell him to speak the truth.
—It does not matter whether you disagree with what Senator Sherry is saying. That is totally irrelevant. You do not interject on someone who has the floor.

—Unfortunately for the Opposition, the people of Australia are recognising the truth. They certainly recognise that we are in a recession. We all recognise that. Unfortunately for the Opposition, the people of Australia want nothing to do with its proposed solutions. They want nothing to do with a GST; they want nothing to do with individual wage bargaining.
—Your nose is growing and the pimples on your tongue are getting bigger.
—Order! Senator Knowles!
—It is a bunch of lies; that is the problem.
—Order! Senator Knowles! You will withdraw that immediately and unconditionally.
—I will withdraw that I said `a bunch of lies'.
—I will take the point a bit further. I have already spoken to Senator Patterson about interjecting continually—
—We are sitting here working; a bunch of lies.
—Withdraw that again!
—I will withdraw that I said `a bunch of lies' again.
—I call Senator Sherry.
—Time has expired.
—Gee, you are a smart arse.
—Senator Sherry, withdraw that please.
—I withdraw that.

—Before Senator O'Chee takes the floor, I will explain once again the rules of debate in this House. Some interjections may be tolerated. All interjections are supposedly out of order, but continual interjections when someone is speaking, deliberate attempts to ruin the time allocated for someone's speech, are inappropriate in this chamber. This House agreed that we would in fact allow a limited amount of speaking time—a few minutes per person apart from the leaders of the various parties. I believe that it is most inappropriate that people continually interject and make those precious five minutes or so totally irrelevant. Senator O'Chee, I will call you and I ask everyone in this chamber to give you the respect that any speaker should have.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order, and with respect to what you have just said, we on our side of course will respect your ruling. However, the events of just a minute ago are not without precedent. Effectively, what has happened is that the chamber has become unruly, necessitating your intervention and therefore taking speaking time from speakers on our side. If that circumstance persists, can we have extra time added so that we can complete our speeches without being silenced by virtue of strategic, planned and coordinated points of order or interventions from the Opposition?

—In response to your point of order, Minister, the agreement that was made in terms of time allocation for this particular debate was an informal agreement. I presume, with the concurrence of the chamber, it would be up to me to determine how long people would, in fact, have if the chamber wished that time to be extended. A certain amount of time was taken from Senator Sherry's speech by the need for me to talk to some members of the Senate and to ask for two withdrawals from Senator Knowles, for example. I made a choice a minute ago not to give Senator Sherry extra time, but if there are more interruptions of either side then that person, with the concurrence of the Senate, will be given more time, in order to be fair. I call Senator O'Chee.

—The speech we have just heard from Senator Sherry was straight from under the gum tree in Barcaldine in 1891. Absolutely nothing has changed in the rhetoric that we have heard from people like Senator Sherry in the last 100 years. What has happened in the last 100 years in this country is our economic demise—an economic demise which has taken place not over the whole of that last 100 years, but over the last 10 of that 100 years, which is the last 10 years that the people who sit opposite have occupied the treasury bench. The reason I say that is that we only need to look at a reasonable basis of comparison between this country and the countries with which we compete to see the very real damage that these people have done to our nation's economy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button, who is the Leader of the Government in the Senate, loves to talk to everybody in this chamber about having a world recession. He loves to talk about a world recession because it seems to get him off the hook. It will make everybody believe that we are in the same boat as everybody else. Even you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have to smile at that. The truth is that, elsewhere around the world, things are not as bad as they are in this country.

In the last five months in Australia, unemployment has risen from 10.6 per cent to 11.3 per cent—the highest number of unemployed people in the history of this nation. What has happened in the United States? In the United States over the same period of time, unemployment has not risen but has fallen from 7.8 per cent to 7.2 per cent. Incidentally, that high of 7.8 per cent in the United States is comparable with the lowest level of unemployment that this nation has experienced over the last seven years. And the United States was in recession! That is exactly how bad our economy is. That is how bad those people on the other side have made it.

I beg honourable senators to look at those people who sit opposite because every single one of them, by omission or by commission, is personally responsible for the human face of Australia's unemployment, the human face of a million Australians out of work. They are personally responsible for the 680,000 young Australians who live in families where neither parent has a job. They are the people who are personally responsible.

Of course, things have changed in the industrial relations area too, and I think we should talk about that. If one listened to Senator Sherry, one would believe that all employers in this country are some sort of bully boys who employ a lawyer, an accountant and a security guard every time they want to talk to their staff. That is just blatantly ludicrous. It is interesting to know what is going on in Queensland. In Queensland recently a shearing contractor was taken to court and prosecuted. He was committing a criminal offence, but I will tell honourable senators what he was doing. He was committing a criminal offence because he would not show the union official the wages book for his employees. That is what is going on in this country.

What we are seeing is the so-called representatives of the workers going out to beat the workers over the heads with a big stick. Who has the biggest stick of all? It is Paul Keating. Not only is he going to beat the workers over the heads who want to enter into their own agreements—

TALK.START.PARA: —He's got a twig called Senator Cook, though.

—He may have that as well. Not only is he going to beat the workers over their heads, not only is he going to beat the employers over their heads and not only is he going to beat the State governments over their heads, but also he is going to try to overturn the constitutional basis of the States and the Federal Government.
—And use external powers.
—He will attempt to use external powers to try to fix up a situation which was his own making in the first place. That is the truth about what is happening in this country.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Knowles interjected and asked Senator Sherry what policy he had, the answer was, `I'll tell you in a moment'. It would have taken only a moment to hear the Government's policy because it does not have a policy. The truth is that the Government does not have a policy. It was so convenient for Senator Sherry that he ran out of time. There must be a running out of time disease because it occurs frequently with speakers on the other side of the chamber. Whether they are speaking in a debate such as this or whether it is Government Ministers answering questions, they always promise to give us their policy in a moment and the moment never comes. The reason why the moment never comes is that there is no policy there to talk about.

Senator Sherry said that all we wanted to do was impose a GST on the Australian populace. Did he want to take the interjection when we suggested he talk about the fact that we will reduce the personal income tax bill of every Australian by an average of 30 per cent? Did he want to take the interjection when we said that 19 out of 20 Australians will pay 30c in the dollar or less taxation?

TALK.START.PARA: —And the abolition of petrol excise.

—No, the Minister did not want to talk about the abolition of petrol excise that will save taxpayers $6 1/2 billion. Did he want to talk about the fact that the coalition, in stark contrast to the Labor Party, is talking about reducing the total tax bill of this nation? The answer, undoubtedly, is no.
—So 70 per cent are worse off.

—That is an interesting interjection because, after all, we are talking about a reduction in the total amount of tax that Australians will pay. We are changing the way in which we will take the tax, but at the end of the day we will take less tax. This is a matter of simple economics that is obviously well beyond Senator Cook because he cannot understand that the private individuals who make up this nation are better off with less taxation than more. The coalition is offering a package that will reduce taxation by $4,000m a year—taxes that this unruly mob opposite rip out of the pockets of Australians every single year.
—And no compulsory unionism either.

—And no compulsory unionism. Some of the people on the other side would have one believe that we do not like unions. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, under us there will be more unions than there are at the moment because people will have the right to join the union of their choice.
—Or they can form their own.

—Or they can form their own. If they do not like the people running the union, they do not have to be members. That might fill some people on the other side of the chamber with absolute fear and trepidation, because they know that they are on the best game in town and that if one wants a job they have to pay to buy their job. That is what a union ticket is—paying somebody for the opportunity to work. If one does not have a ticket, one does not get a start.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly, about 18 months to two years ago the Minister who sits opposite introduced into this Parliament legislation to give preference to unionists—everything from hiring, holidays, promotion, long service leave and firing. That was an attempt to legitimise what has been going on in this country for a long time—the old tactic of no ticket, no start.

My family has been touched by the bully boy tactics that we have seen. My brother had to pay for the job that he already had. He was told that if he did not pay his union dues they would fix him and he would end up out of work. So much for the caring side of the unions in this country! Nothing could be further from the truth than to suggest that this bunch of people on the other side of the chamber care about the future of this nation.

Those opposite do not care about the fact that they have given Australia an enormously high rate of unemployment. They do not care about the fact that they have just about bankrupted this nation, pushing gross foreign debt to over $200 billion. They do not care about the fact that this nation is haemorrhaging almost $2,000m a month. They do not care about the fact that the only legacy that will be left from their days—like the only legacy from the Whitlam days and the only legacy from the days of Cain and Kirner—will be desperation, desolation and despair. The coalition is the only group of people in this nation who offer a real alternative of incentive and opportunity to get this nation moving again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is an important debate. The ability to cover it all is beyond me—and probably beyond any reasonable speaker. Most of the debate has been about whose father is the biggest fellow on the block and who is going to do best. It has been peppered with some unkind observations from each side about the other. The issue that underlies this debate is a very important one: the suffering that is going on in the community because of the economic recession. We as a chamber have to understand that people throughout Australia are suffering because they are without a job or there is the threat that they or their children may be without a job in the future.

PARA.TAB: It is proper that policies should be discussed. Indeed, they have been discussed during the time that this Parliament has been meeting. I do not know whether we get very far by seeking out scapegoats. Senator Cook has not always been the popular man with those on the other side. I doubt whether any flowers come to his door from the other side. However, it is unfair to single out his proud, may I say, periods of office in the BWIU and the ACTU. It is unfair to criticise Senator Cook on the basis of what he did prior to coming here and attributing to him a perversion of his task because of his previous occupation. That sort of thing could be attributed to any of us in respect of what we may or may not do in the chamber. It is proper and right that people should come into this place from a wide variety of backgrounds. I can say about Senator Cook that he is a man whose integrity has never been impugned and a man who has carried out his job and his Ministry in an exemplary fashion.

Let us look at what the unions do. This is very important at the moment. In Victoria, tribunals outside the employer group and outside the employee group were set up to deal with matters that arise in the workplace. The Accident Compensation Tribunal was set up as an independent body, with its 11 members being given the status of County Court judges, to decide whether the compensation people got because of injuries they suffered in the workplace were fair or otherwise. Another body set up was the Industrial Relations Commission, whose task was to see that conditions of work—whether in the factory, the office or elsewhere—were fair. As a result of this new Government coming in, the Accident Compensation Tribunal and the Industrial Relations Commission have been abolished.

This is a matter of concern for people who are liable to suffer from severe injuries such as the loss of a leg below the knee or the loss of a non-dominant hand. It is very difficult for them to be faced with the proposition and the reality that after two years of compensation, they have to cover the situation themselves. After two years, people who, through no fault of their own, have been fearfully injured in the workplace—who are injured perhaps through the fault of the employer—must, nevertheless, look to social security payments to fix them up for the rest of their life. They may live a long time and thus may be condemned to a very impecunious situation, whereas otherwise they could have lived very well.

In that respect there has to be some sort of group in which they can gather and that is provided by the union movement. In so far as the Federal system is concerned, that is provided by the union movement under the Australian Industrial Relations Act of 1988. This Act provides that the officers of those unions will be elected in accordance with strict requirements by the people who are in the unions. When we talk about union bosses we are talking about bosses who have been elected according to the formula set out in this particular Act, which passed through this Parliament as recently as 1988.

That legislation is subject to further amendment. If the Opposition, or indeed anybody on this side, says that the union officials are not elected properly and in accordance with the desires of the majority of their members, then there ought to be brought forward a provision to ensure that that is done. As far as I am concerned, no attempt has been made—and certainly no suggestion has been made in this debate—to amend that Act which sets out a democratic way of electing union officials.

This Government wants to enable more people to come under that system if they wish to do so. It has been said that this gives the unions the opportunity to come under the Federal scheme if they so desire, but it does not give people that same opportunity. To some extent that is true because the system that is set up federally is one that is based on the existence of organisations of employers and organisations of employees. People have to be in a union to be covered by the Act, as it now exists. They voluntarily become members of the union—in spite of what is being said here—and, as members of that union, they have a right to vote for the leadership. What has been offered by the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is a further opportunity for people who would otherwise be without sufficient strength to negotiate in the workplace.

I just give an illustration of that. Much has been made in this chamber recently of the Copperart contract. Much debate has occurred as to whether it is a good or a poor contract, but what is clear is that it is a contract written by an employer, not by an employee. The employee can either accept or reject it without amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. The employee can stay on the award.

—That is a very useful interjection—as it usually is from Senator Kemp. I am saying that the contract that is offered has been written by one side. It was the same position with Troubleshooters. In the Troubleshooters case the contract was written by Troubleshooters which the worker could or could not accept, but he had no part in the writing of it. I will read from the case.

PARA.TAB: His Honour also found that the rates of pay offered to its workers were adjusted unilaterally each year by Troubleshooters without consultation with the workers who were nevertheless advised of each adjustment shortly before or immediately after it occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the system proposed in Victoria, the reality is that the employer will be writing the contract. The employee will have no effective way of varying it. That is the part the union plays in giving them some strength. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! The time allocated for the debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1990 election. I seek leave to incorporate the report in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS REPORT ON THE 1990 ELECTION
SCOPE AND CONDUCT OF THE INQUIRY
Recommendation para 1.13

1.1The Committee recommends that as a matter of urgency the Government respond to Report No.3 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, The 1987 Federal Election: Inquiry into the Conduct of the 1987 Federal Election and the 1988 Referendums, May 1989 and priority be given to the introduction of any resultant amending legislation.
1.2Response: Supported.
1.3Comment: The Government has responded and amending legislation has been enacted.
MAKING VOTING EASIER FOR THE PUBLIC: THE QUEUING PROBLEM
Recommendation para 2.18
2.1The Committee recommends that:

PARA.TAB: . the Australian Electoral Commission develop a system, which should include reports from all presiding officers on queuing and any other delays, to provide it with reliable data of voter turnout patterns and any queues at each polling place at future federal elections.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.2Response: Supported.
2.3Comment: Appropriate systems have been put in place, and were tested successfully at the Menzies and Wills by-elections and the ACT Legislative Assembly election and referendum.

2.3. the Australian Electoral Commission set a formal performance standard for the length of time that it is reasonable for a voter to wait to cast a vote, and use that standard as the criterion against which the Australian Electoral Commission's level of service can be measured at the next election.
2.4Response: Supported.

2.5Comment: The Commission believes that maximum waiting times of up to ten minutes from arrival to issue of ballot papers would not be unreasonable, and it will strive to achieve this performance standard.
Recommendation para 2.52
3.1The Committee recommends that to alleviate queuing problems at future elections the Australian Electoral Commission:

PARA.TAB: . employ additional staff where necessary to ensure that the ratio of ordinary vote issuing staff to potential voters is at a realistic level

SPEECH.PARA: 3.2Response: Supported

3.3Comment: The Commission has reduced the maximum voter to issuing staff ratio from 700 to 600 for ordinary votes and from 150 to 120 for declaration voters at the next election. It has also introduced the use of morning only staff in some polling places.
3.4. revise its National Polling Place Resources Policy to provide flexibility in the staffing and resourcing of polling places
3.5Response: Supported.
3.6Comment: The Commission has endorsed the provision of more flexibility in the staffing and resourcing of polling places than was the case for the 1990 election.
3.7. print the certified lists in a larger type size to facilitate the process of striking the voter's name from the list
3.8Response: Not Supported.

3.9Comment: Certified lists are printed in `Bell Gothic' typefaces designed especially for the Bell Telephone Company to retain the legibility of highly condensed information at small point sizes. It has been used successfully in telephone books throughout the world, including Australia, for many years. The form in which it is used in the certified lists has been designed to the best typographic and legibility standards. It is larger, carefully emboldened and uses proportional white space between lines to ensure significantly higher legibility than a telephone book. From a typographic point of view the amount of white space between lines is as important as the size of type. Larger type without white line space is less legible.

3.10The average size of the certified list is 350 pages, each containing 200 names in two columns of 100. A larger type face will mean that fewer names will appear on each page and may well mean that two columns could not be used. Decreasing the number of names per page by 10 increases the number of pages of the average list by 19. A decrease of 20 per page increases the list by about 39 pages, and so on. Apart from the additional time and cost for producing the lists, there could be an increase in the search time for names at the polling place.
3.11It should also be noted that the voter's name is not struck from the roll in the strictest sense, rather, an identifying line is made next to the name which is picked up by an optical scanner.
3.12. ensure Divisional Returning Officers review polling premises and their equipment on a regular basis
3.13Response: Supported.

3.14Comment: Divisional Returning Officers are required to review polling places and their equipment on a regular basis, and at least once between elections. As pointed out in the Report the options for reallocating polling places are often limited by the available premises, whether due to prior bookings or nonexistence.
3.15Polling place equipment supplied by the Commission is continually reviewed and upgraded.
3.16. improve training for Divisional Office and polling place staff to ensure that they have all the knowledge and skills necessary to perform more effectively their tasks on polling day.
3.17Response: Supported.

3.18Comment: This has been identified as a priority in respect to training and development of Divisional staff. The training programs in place for polling staff, updated each election, generally have been accepted as good. However, the limiting factors for training polling staff are that they are employed once every two or three years, training time is limited and staff recruited are often the `best available' rather than the best.
Recommendation para 2.53
4.1Prior to polling day the Australian Electoral Commission advise polling place staff that disciplinary action will be taken if staff engage in unacceptable political activity at polling places.
4.2Response: Supported.
4.3Comment: Polling place staff are employed under the Act and the disciplinary procedures laid down under the Public Service Act therefore do not apply to them.

4.4However, applicants for polling place casual positions are advised that they must refrain from any political activity during their employment by the Commission. Polling place staff who breach the undertaking they are required to make are not re-engaged as polling place staff at future elections or referendums.
MAKING VOTlNG EASIER FOR THE PUBLIC: OTHER ISSUES
Recommendation para 3.7

5.1As part of the Australian Electoral Commission's consideration of the redesign of the Senate ballot paper the typeface used to designate Senate groupings be reviewed to ensure that there is no potential confusion of the alphabetical `I' with the numeral `1'.
5.2Response: Supported.
Recommendation para 3.23
6.1The Australian Electoral Commission:

PARA.TAB: . improve its newspaper and other advertisements to inform the public on polling place, pre-poll and mobile poll locations and consider advertising general polling places in newspapers on the day before polling day

SPEECH.PARA: 6.2Response: Supported.

6.3Comment: For future elections polling place locations in all States will be advertised before polling day. Increasingly, for recent elections locations of polling places have been advertised on the day before polling day, or, if two insertions have been arranged, the first advertisements have appeared midweek and the second on polling day itself.
6.4. develop an information and education program to assist electors who are blind, visually impaired, and/or print handicapped
6.5Response: Supported.

6.6Comment: Electors with these disabilities are eligible for assistance under section 234 of the Act. This section provides for a person appointed by the voter to accompany the voter to the voting compartment and fill out the ballot paper in accordance with the wishes of the elector. Such electors may also be eligible to register as general postal voters, or may apply at each election for a postal vote.

6.7The Commission's program will be developed further to ensure that information about these facilities is available to the target audience by increased use of radio advertisements on print-handicapped radio stations during the election period and by increased ongoing contact with organisations providing assistance to the visually impaired.
6.8. develop an information and education program to assist electors with lower literacy skills
6.9Response: Supported.

6.10Comment: The Commission's current programs already recognise this audience. The high cost of the Commission's election advertising is due largely to the substantial use made of radio and television because of the greater effectiveness of the non-print media in reaching those segments of the community less likely to be well informed on electoral matters and also those with lower literacy skills. The high turnout and significantly lower informality rates at the 1990 election are indications of the success of these programs and of the newly designed plain-English and large print House of Representatives ballot paper.

6.11Components of the Commission's education programs are also specifically aimed at young people with low literacy skills (eg information on enrolling and voting in comic book form and in publications like `Streetwise') while the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service, the primary audience of which is voters in remote, traditional communities, focuses in its delivery on electors with lower than average literacy skills. Included in the increasing number of school groups visiting the Commission's Electoral Education Centres are classes with special learning needs, including those with literacy problems.
6.12. improve its information and education program on declaration voting issues and procedures
6.13Response: Supported.

6.14Comment: The Commission's advertising and information programs are reviewed after each election. In this review polling place and divisional office staff have the opportunity of raising concerns about these programs. Account is also taken of comments made by members of the public in correspondence with the Commission. Suggestions for improvements to these programs will be put into effect in the lead up to the next general election.
6.15. give a higher priority to reaching young adults approaching voting age through school visits and distribution of enrolment cards relative to other components of the youth enrolment campaign
6.16Response: Supported.

6.17Comment: Action in this area is underway with a pilot scheme using enrolment promotion inserts in two publications aimed at young people (`Smash Hits' and `Graduate Outlook'). A specific target identified in the Commissions' operational plans for 1992-93 is to increase the number of visits made to high schools by the staff of divisional officers.
6.18. conduct an information campaign to remind aged electors of their right to vote
6.19Response: Supported.

6.20Comment: This issue is being addressed within the general context of the Commission's information programs. Aged persons are exposed to the Commission's general and specifically targeted advertising as are other members of the community. The Commission will ensure that in its general advertising the media and the message design will be available to and attractive to aged audiences as well as to others.
6.21. review its voter information and education program giving close attention to:

PARA.TAB: -the balance of use between print media and radio and television advertising in the information and education program
-the value of continuing with the elector pamphlet distributed to all Australian households prior to the election.

SPEECH.PARA: 6.22Response: Supported.
6.23Comment: The Commission reviews all aspects of its operations following an election. The issues are part of that review.

6.24In post-election research 69 per cent of respondents reported receiving the householder pamphlet and 72 per cent of these indicated that they had read the pamphlet. Seventy seven per cent of readers classified it as `useful' or `very useful'.
Recommendation para 3.26

7.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission co-operate with the trade union movement and employer groups to ensure that both employers and employees are fully aware of their obligations and entitlements under sections 183 and 345 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
7.2Response: Supported.

7.3Comment: The Commission will be writing to the relevant peak councils seeking their co-operation in a programme to advise employers and employees of their rights and obligations under sections 183 and 345 of the Act.
Recommendation para 3.31

8.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission investigate the performance of overseas posts in undertaking electoral responsibilities and implement procedures to ensure that overseas declaration votes are returned prior to the election date, and that all relevant Australian Electoral Commission and candidates' how-to-vote material is prominently displayed and freely available at overseas posts.
8.2Response: Not Supported.

8.3Comment: The Government does not believe there is sufficient evidence to support the need for an investigation of the performance of overseas posts undertaking electoral responsibilities. Prior to the 1990 election the procedures for persons assisting with the issue of overseas votes were extensively revised. Further, a Commission officer presents a briefing session on the election process at all Consular Training Courses held for Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade staff prior to their departure overseas. These briefings are conducted approximately every six weeks. The procedures for overseas posts explain fully the process of voting, however, the Commission is limited in further action it can take. In fact overseas staff are under no obligation to undertake the duties.

8.4The recommendation that overseas declaration votes be returned prior to polling day is impractical as voting overseas can take place up to and including polling day, depending on the post's location. The changes to procedure for the 1990 election included revised despatch arrangements for ballot material back to Australia which involved the use of an international courier instead of diplomatic bags, and as a consequence, there were delays only in a few locations where the courier did not operate. No final counting was delayed as a consequence, unlike previous elections.

8.5All official material necessary for voting is made available to overseas posts and instructions are given for its display as appropriate. The Commission has not been involved with despatch of party how-to-vote material and to do so could be seen as infringing upon its neutrality. As to its display, the Commissions's instructions state that all material received should be displayed but in an area separate from the area where voting is taking place. The Commission does not have any legal basis for insisting that how-to-vote material be displayed. This is a matter for the candidates and the parties to negotiate with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It should be noted that the collation and dissemination of how-to-vote material for all candidates (House and Senate) in all electorates and every State would be a massive task, verging on the impracticable.
Recommendation para 3.37

9.1The Committee recommends that section 226 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that the presiding officer or electoral visitor who visits a patient for the purposes of a mobile pole should display the how-to-vote cards made available for the purpose by candidates in the election.
9.2Response: Supported.
Recommendation para 3.42

10.1The Committee recommends that section 329(3) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to include a general prohibition on the distribution of any material which discourages electors from numbering the ballot paper consecutively and fully.
10.2Response: Supported.
Recommendation Para 3.43

11.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission report to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on possible changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 that would have the effect of minimising the incidence of optional preferential voting.
11.2Response: Supported.
KNOWING THE ELECTION RESULT ON ELECTION NIGHT
Recommendation para 4.21

12.1The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to add a new step to the House of Representatives scrutiny process to guarantee that scrutineers would have the opportunity to readily observe a `two-candidate preferred vote' in each polling place on election night.
12.2Response: Supported.

12.3Comment: The Commission is planning to carry out an interim two-candidate preferred distribution of preferences in all polling places on election night and to display the result. This will enable the Commission to provide the public, candidates and the media with interim two-candidate preferred results in electorates on polling night. It will, however, indicate that judgement should be suspended in any cases where the result is very close. An interim distribution was tested successfully at the Menzies and Wills by-elections.

12.4The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 will be amended to formalise the requirement of the two-candidate preference scrutiny and the rights of the scrutineers appointed by the candidates to observe fully the distribution of preferences. These amendments will reflect the interim recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee's current inquiry into the Commission's preparedness for the next election, which called for strict adherence to Recommendation 4.21.
Recommendation para 4.24

13.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission ensure that it has in place frontline and backup systems to record, process, transmit and publicly display House of Representatives results as soon as they are available on election night.
13.2Response: Supported.

13.3Comment: Frontline and backup systems are already put in place for each election. Results are displayed on computer screens as soon as received in the National Tally Room and as soon as possible thereafter they are manually displayed on the National Tally Room Board. Backup systems (telephone and facsimile transmission of results) necessarily transmit data more slowly than the computerised election night results package but these systems are called into play only when a problem occurs with the computer system.

13.4A review of tally room procedures at the 1990 election has resulted in changes to the procedures for monitoring the input of results from individual States at the next election to ensure that any problems with the input and transmission rates are detected as soon as possible.
Recommendation para 4.30

14.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission review its overall procedures for conducting and reporting the Senate count, particularly its data input procedures, to ensure an improved performance in the percentage of the Senate vote counted and publicly announced for every State on election night at future elections.
14.2Response: Supported.
14.3Comment: Such a review is underway.
Recommendation para 4.32

15.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission review the layout of the National Tally Room for future elections and provide suitable office accommodation for political parties as was provided during the 1987 election and previous elections.
15.2Response: Supported.
15.3Comment: The layout of the National Tally Room will be altered for the next election to allow for the building of offices for the parliamentary parties.
CAMPAIGN MATERIAL
Recommendation para 5.13

16.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission ensure that cardboard litter bins are provided at all polling places for the disposal of waste paper generated from elections, including how-to-vote cards, and that all bins are subsequently collected by recycling firms for the recycling of that paper.
16.2Response: Supported.

16.3Comment: From the next election, provision of cardboard litter bins will be extended to all polling places, and recycling facilitated. Cardboard election equipment is retained by the school where it is useful for educational purposes.
Recommendation para 5.16
17.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission use recycled paper for the production of all its election material wherever practicable.
17.2Response: Supported.
NOMINATION AND ENROLMENT
Recommendation para 6.8

18.1The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that proceedings for the deregistration of a political party that is a parliamentary party be not undertaken until after the next election for the relevant House subsequent to the political party becoming liable to deregistration.
18.2Response: Supported.

18.3Comment: The recommended amendment to the party registration scheme will not strengthen the constitutional requirement that Senate casual vacancies be filled by a member of the party under the banner of which the departed Senator was elected.

18.4So far as a House of Representative vacancy is concerned, it would seem that all that is needed is to provide that the party remains a Parliamentary party until the by-election (or general election if there is no by-election). If at the by-election the party's candidate is returned, it would retain its Parliamentary party status. If its candidate is not returned, there may not be a case for Parliamentary party status to be carried to the next general election.
Recommendation para 6.18

19.1The Committee recommends that the Minister for Administrative Services seek a ruling from the High Court on what constitutes an office of profit under the Crown and when a candidate has to resign from such an office.
19.2Response: Not supported.

19.3Comment: The High Court is not able to provide advisory opinions. On 12 May 1983 the then Attorney-General introduced in the Senate a proposed law for an alteration of the Constitution, entitled Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) 1983, which inter alia would have inserted in the Constitution specific provision for the High Court to give advisory opinions on the questions of the interpretation of the Constitution. The proposed law was never put to a referendum.
19.4However, the result of the challenge in the High Court to the Wills by-election may provide further clarification of the meaning of the office of profit provisions.
Recommendation para 6.21

20.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission produce a nominations `checklist' to be given to each candidate, and a copy to be held at each Divisional Returning Office, to assist both candidates and District Returning Office staff in ensuring that all relevant nomination procedures are complete.
20.2Response: Supported.
20.3Comment: The process to be followed and available documents will be included with the nomination form. The requirements for nomination are already included in the Candidates Handbook.
Recommendation para 6.24
21.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission improve the level of service and advice provided to all candidates and political parties in the lead-up to federal elections.
21.2Response: Supported.
22.3Comment: The Commission is constantly seeking to improve the level of service it provides to candidates and political parties in the run-up to federal elections.
Recommendation para 6.27
23.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission extend its online Roll Management System to all Divisional Offices in the eastern States as an immediate priority.
23.2Response: Supported.

23.3Comment: This has already occurred. All States and Territories except South Australia now have access to the Commission's central Roll Management System (RMANS) at a Divisional Office level. South Australia does not use RMANS, but continues to use its own roll management system (EAGLE) which resides on the South Australian Government Computing Centre mainframe.
Recommendation para 6.38

24.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission report to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the current round of habitation reviews when those reviews are complete and that the report include an evaluation of the adequacy of procedures used for dealing with eligible non-English speaking, aged, infirm and Aboriginal voters.
24.2Response: Supported.

24.3Comment: Habitation reviews are being conducted in all States this calendar year. In Western Australia, Queensland and Victoria reviews began earlier this calendar year in order that they would be completed before the anticipated State elections. Although some States have completed their field work, follow-up action is continuing and the whole process is not completed until objection action takes place. Later this year a report, as requested by the Committee, will be submitted.
Recommendation Para 6.47

25.1The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to include a provision that House of Representatives and Senate candidates are entitled to purchase one copy of the latest print of the Divisional or State roll (respectively) for the electorate for which they have nominated in accordance with the rolls that are being made available to Members of the House of Representatives and the Senate under section 91 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and, if requested the copy of the roll should be made available in tape or disc form.
25.2Response: Not supported.

25.3Comment: Candidates are already entitled under section 90(1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to purchase copies of the latest print of the roll for any Division. In addition, under the new section 91C of the Act, the Commission must now give House of Representatives candidates a free copy of the certified list for the Division in which they are seeking election. Sitting members and Senators currently receive roll information on floppy disks. At election time it may be possible to extend this service to all candidates, however, this would raise problems of costs and may also lead to public concerns regarding privacy of electoral information.
Recommendation para 6.49

26.1The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to provide for the distribution to each candidate, as soon as practicable after the close of rolls, and at least one week prior to polling day, one copy of the certified list of voters for the Division in which the candidate seeks election.
26.2Response: Not Supported.

26.3Comment: This recommendation is similar to one made in the Committee's Report on the 1987 election, which led to a recent amendment to the Act which provides for the Commission to give each House of Representatives candidate a copy of the certified list for the Division for which he or she is seeking election as soon as practicable after the close of the rolls.
MANAGEMENT AND OPERATION
OF THE AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL COMMISSION
Recommendation para 7.7

27.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission investigate the extent to which it can devolve financial and management responsibility to Divisional Returning Officers and, where this is appropriate, does so with concomitant reporting and accountability practices.
27.2Response: Not supported.

27.3Comment: The current arrangements for estimating Divisional election financial requirements and control of Divisional election expenditure have been the result of studies of Commission performance at the 1984 and 1987 elections which showed that:

PARA.TAB: .there was no standard recording of election expenditures, making any comparison of the efficiency of election operations in Divisions and the assessment of future election funding requirements basically flawed; and

.there were significant differences in the parameters used for estimating election resource requirements amongst the various States, leading to perceived inequities (by both Divisional and Central Office management) in allocation of resources in terms of the comparative volume and difficulty of election workloads undertaken in individual Divisions.

SPEECH.PARA: 27.4Current election financial management systems were set up in an effort to provide an equitable distribution of election funds throughout the Commission. Election financial allocations are now made on the basis of the tangible factor of estimated workloads that can be supported by past experience and/or current conditions, with additional funds being granted where there are nonstandard circumstances.

27.5It must be emphasised that the thrust of the system is the equitable distribution of available funding between a large number of offices discharging the same functions. Information from the system is collated centrally, and supervisory management does examine estimates both in order to query apparent excessive or insufficient requests to determine whether funds are planned to be used in the most efficient manner. In order to adjust estimates to available funds, estimation of resource requirements is undertaken by the Divisional or project manager responsible for the expenditure. The funding is dependent on the ability to justify the accuracy of the workload and resource need projections.

27.6The 1990 election was the first where such proposed election finance information could be collated and compared on a national basis. Obviously there were some problems that became apparent in the operation of the system. These are being examined with a view to streamlining the data collation, assessment and approval process in order to provide more timely information to Divisions, and reducing the amount of information required.

27.7Systems in operation at the 1990 election to enable control of actual expenditure of budgeted funds in each Division were not as fully developed, and did not allow for sufficient judgement to be exercised at the Divisional Returning Officer level. While the policy intention was that Divisions be given, as a result of their approved election estimates, a total election budget that would be fully managed by each Divisional Returning Officer, different interpretations of this in the various States meant that Divisions were subject to a varying degree of supervisory management control over expenditure in minute detail within their election budgets. This was in reaction to past experiences of significant overexpenditure in particular election budget items by some individual Divisions at past elections. Certainly the Commission is mindful of the need for improvement in this area and is addressing it.

27.8Particular attention is being given to developing systems of accountability whereby all units of the Commission are encouraged to increase the efficiency of their use of election funds, and those where inefficiencies occur are held accountable for these.
Recommendation para 7.14
28.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission extend its online information network to all Divisional Offices as an immediate priority.
28.2Response: Supported.
28.3Comment: This has already been substantially achieved, although it must be noted that the South Australian Divisional Offices are not yet linked to the Commission's on-line system.
Recommendation para 7.18
29.1The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission take urgent steps to guarantee a more service oriented approach to its task of conducting federal elections.
29.2Response: Supported.
29.3Comment: The recommendation accords with the Commission's overall objectives as expressed in its Corporate Plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the operation of the Aboriginal and Islander electoral information service. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS REPORT ON THE OPERATION OF THE ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER ELECTORAL INFORMATION SERVICE
Principal Recommendations and Responses
1. The Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service (AIEIS) be continued as a national special needs program (3.11)
Agreed.
Additional resources will be required to achieve this recommendation as the program does not yet operate nationally. These will be sought through the 1992/93 budget process.

2. The name of the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service be changed to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Electoral Information Service to reflect more accurately the service's intended target clientele (3.2)
Agreed.

3. The Australian Electoral Commission take immediate steps to present policy proposals to relevant state governments for the extension of AIEIS to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in NSW, Victoria, and those parts of Queensland not already served (3.17)
Significant progress has been made towards extending AIEIS in 2 of the 3 States mentioned in this recommendation:

A third Field Officer has been recruited for Queensland and this will provide coverage for the entire State. The formation of the new Queensland Electoral Commission may allow for improved coordination of the operation of the program in that State.

In NSW, a Field Officer has been recruited and activities will be coordinated with the NSW State Electoral Office. Discussions with the State Electoral Office have taken place in this regard. Current resources preclude the employment of further Field Officers required to adequately service NSW.
No contact has yet been made with the Victorian State Government. An expansion of the program into Victoria is dependent on an increase in funding for the program.

4. The Australian Electoral Commission formulate a policy for the extension of the program into more settled areas, including major metropolitan regions, and develop a special urban strategy for the implementation of the program in those areas (3.17)
Agreed.

To date the program has focused primarily on remote locations. Funds secured under the 1991 new policy proposal have allowed for the beginning of work in urban areas. A strategy to cover this work has recently been formulated.
5. The Commonwealth government fund, as a matter of high priority, the extension of the AIEIS program to those areas not already served (3.17)
Agreed in principle but any expansion of the program will depend on increased funding.
A New Policy Proposal seeking the required resources will be prepared for consideration in the budget context for the 1992/93 financial year.

6. The Australian Electoral Commission formulate an unambiguous policy giving priority to education and information work relative to enrolment work in the AIEIS program and provide a clear statement to both divisional and field staff concerning the priority of each function (3.8)

While the AIEIS program has and should include elements of education, information enrolment and roll cleansing, a clear statement of the program's objectives will be prepared identifying education as the highest priority among these sometimes competing activities. This emphasis will be conveyed to state and divisional staff to overcome the current confusion between the priorities given to education and enrolment.

While AIEIS field staff will be expected to assist with enrolment drives and engage in incidental enrolment in the normal course of their work their assistance in formal enrolment drives will be negotiated between senior AIEIS management and state and divisional staff as the need arises.

7. The AIEIS program include more information and materials, developed in conjunction with the relevant bodies, on the workings of state and local government and on state and local government elections (3.22)
Agreed.

Coverage of state or local government elections is already provided by field officers in their work in the communities. Significant progress has been made in the States/Territory where the program operates to increasing this element of the program with information on State and Local Government elections being included in training and information materials. Relevant State electoral and local government bodies have been assisting the Commission by providing this information.
In addition, information on ATSIC elections is being incorporated in the program.
8. Basic facts and procedural information on the role of political parties be included in the AIEIS program (3.26)
This is already done to the extent consistent with the need for the public to maintain confidence in the neutrality of the AEC.

The Community Electoral Assistant training manual incorporates a section on the role of political parties and officers discuss in training sessions how parties operate, the selection of party candidates, group voting tickets etc. As noted in the Report the AEC should not be involved in disseminating party literature. (3.25)

9. There be greater emphasis placed on fostering wider community interest and developing stronger community participation in disseminating electoral education and information via the AIEIS program (6.7)
Agreed.

The program already operates with considerable support from and close liaison with Aboriginal community organisations. A meeting was held in January 1992 to review the current AIEIS remote area strategy with one aim being the formalising of wider community participation, including community school activities. This has been agreed to and has been included in the program objectives.
10. Senior management of the Australian Electoral Commission develop and disseminate an appropriately informed, active and supportive attitude with regard to the AIEIS program (5.6)
Senior management of the AEC is highly supportive of the AIEIS program (30% of the total Information and Education budget is allocated to the program annually).

Senior Central Office management will ensure, however, that this supportive attitude is clearly understood by all staff concerned in State and Divisional Offices and by field staff. In particular, clear policy directions and lines of control for the program will ensure that there is no potential for confusion in the minds of those staff about the supervision and reporting arrangements.

11. The existing National Coordinator become the coordinator for the Remote Area Strategy and continue being responsible for the strategy in all states, except Tasmania, where the program currently operates (5.27)
Not agreed (see Recommendation 12.).

12. A new coordinator position be created at the Senior Officer Grade C level, and its responsibilities encompass the AIEIS program in the eastern states, focusing on the new Urban Area Strategy in New South Wales, southern Queensland, Tasmania and Victoria (5.27)
Not agreed.

The Commission believes that two field coordinators for a program with only 12.5 officers is unnecessary and that one coordinator is adequate for the program. To have two coordinators would draw heavily on limited resources otherwise available for use in implementing the program. The Director Education position in Central Office also has considerable involvement in the management of the program.

The current National Coordinator position is a Central Office position outposted to Broome. With the extension of the program in the eastern states the position will be re-located in Canberra to facilitate coordination of the remote area and the urban aspects of the program.
13. The Australian Electoral Commission take immediate steps to fill all vacant field officer positions in their current locations and undertake to maintain AIEIS staffing at an optimum level (4.4)
Agreed, subject to resource availability (as with the rest of the AEC, the program is subject to the efficiency dividend and this has had an impact on the AEC's ability to fill positions).

"All positions existing at the time of the JSC enquiry are filled with the exception of a position in WA. This position will be filled in December 1992. In addition, two positions (NSW and QLD) funded by a New Policy Proposal in 1991 have been filled. The 1992 New Policy Proposal has provided funding for five additional positions. Of these positions, one field officer (QLD) has commenced duty. Recruitment action has commenced for the other four positions and the new officers will commence work by the end of 1992.
14. Community Electoral Assistant selection occur only as a result of consultation between field officers and the community concerned (4.27)
This is standard practice in all communities.

15. The Assistant Commissioner, Information Education report regularly to the Australian Electoral Commissioner on the way in which the AIEIS program is operating on a nationally coordinated basis (5.27)
Agreed.

16. Field Officers' monthly reports and any additional relevant management information be forwarded simultaneously from Australian Electoral Officers to the Australian Electoral Commissioner and the relevant program coordinator (5.27)

The reports required by Recommendation 15 will be in sufficient detail to obviate the need for the Electoral Commissioner to read some 13 field reports each month. Field reports are currently circulated to the National Coordinator, State Supervisors and the Director Education.
17. In its annual report the Australian Electoral Commission report more fully on the AIEIS program with specific reference to staffing, funding and the achievement of objectives (5.27)
Agreed. Recent Annual Reports have carried increasing detail on this and other programs.
Other Recommendations

18. The Australian Electoral Commission explore the possibility of securing funding from state and local government bodies for the development of state and local government components in the AIEIS program (3.22)
Agreed. Such bodies will be approached for financial contributions to these components.

19. The Australian Electoral Commission investigate funding options open to AIEIS and develop a strategy for the exploitation of alternative funding sources, especially the further use of the Community Development Employment Project scheme where appropriate (4.41)
Agreed.

On the initiative of the AEC, some AIEIS activities have already been funded by CDEP. In some states, however, the interpretation of guidelines for the use of these funds is such that AIEIS can make only very restricted use of them. Further discussions will be held with ATSIC in this regard.
20. The Australian Electoral Commission make all information concerning AIEIS funding publicly available both within and outside the Commission (4.39)

Information in AIEIS funding should be available within and outside the Commission on the same basis as funding information on its other programs. Funding information for this program is available to all Commission staff and to a wider public on request or through its listing in the ATSIC consolidated list of government spending on Aboriginal programs. More detailed information will also be included in the Commission's Annual Report (see Recommendation 17). The forthcoming introduction of the AEC's FMIS should also assist in the provision of funding information.
21. The Australian Electoral Commission undertake immediate recruitment action to fill the Western Australia field officer position in the Kimberleys (4.10)
See response to Recommendation 13.
22. In the selection of field officers, greater emphasis be placed on the desirability of applicants:
having a background or training in, or aptitude for, education; and
being willing and capable of spending most of their time in the field (4.18)
These qualities are already essential criteria for the selection process for these positions. This is reflected in the selection documentation.
23. Field officers be provided with adequate, suitable and properly equipped office accommodation (4.21)
The Commission currently provides satisfactory accommodation and equipment for all Field Officers who are also supported by non-dedicated AEC resources.

24. The Australian Electoral Commission specify that field officers' resources and facilities are for the AIEIS program and not to be appropriated for other Australian Electoral Commission activities (4.23)

This is already done. Careful monitoring of the program ensures that to the maximum extent possible funds allocated to the program are used for the program. Operational requirements and effective use of resources mean, however, that on occasions there must be appropriate flexibility across program lines. It should also be noted that non-dedicated AEC resources are used to support the program.

25. The Australian Electoral Commission immediately institute policies which ensure fair and consistent treatment for all Community Electoral Assistants and that their value to the Australian Electoral Commission be recognised and promoted throughout the Commission, especially at divisional level (4.31)
The instances that lead to this recommendation have been rectified.
26. The recruiting of AIEIS officers for urban areas be carried out only after the development of a separate urban strategy which includes selection relevant to urban areas (4.36)
Agreed.

It should be noted that the Commission is recruiting a Field Officer in early 1992 to work in NSW. With reference to the response to Recommendation 4, the urban area strategy will be in place by the time that this officer has been recruited and completed initial training.

27. In performing their respective roles, especially with regard to the conduct of elections, AIEIS and other Australian Electoral Commission officers develop strategies for benefiting from each others' skills and experiences (5.9)
Agreed.
28. The new coordinator position be funded using the additional resources sought in the current budget (5.27)
Not Agreed.
See response to Recommendation 12. The additional resources allocated in the current budget were sufficient to employ only 2 additional Field Officers.
29. Both coordinators report directly to the Director of Education, Australian Electoral Commission (5.27)
The coordinator has always reported directly to the Director Education. (Note: With reference to Recommendation 12, only 1 coordinator position is supported).

30. Both coordinators be used as a source of advice for state managers on the best methods of implementing the program in their state including advice on dealing with any problems that may arise (5.27)
This has always been an important aspect of the role of the coordinator and will continue to be so.
(See note to response to Recommendation 29).

31. The Australian Electoral Commission recognise the importance of the Education Officer to the AIEIS program and that it ensure the provision of well-planned and high-quality resource material by maintaining in the Education Officer position a permanent officer with appropriate training and skills (4.13)

The AIEIS education officer position is currently filled by a two-year appointment. The occupant was appointed in April 1991. Consideration will be given to the long-term nature of the position prior to the end of the current 2 year appointment.
32. The Education Officer report to the Director of Education and provide curriculum materials and support for both the Remote and Urban Area Strategies (5.27)

This recommendation was made in the context of there being two coordinators (Rec 12). With the Electoral Commission Coordinator position to be located in Canberra, it will be even more effective for the Education Officer position to work directly to the Coordinator.
33. The Australian Electoral Commission apply existing performance indicators to assessment of the AIEIS program and report on them in its Portfolio Performance Statements (5.32)
Agreed.

34. Twelve months after the tabling of this report, the management of the AIEIS program be subject to an internal evaluation by the Australian Electoral Commission and that the report of that evaluation be referred to the Minister (5.29)
Agreed.

In assessing the outcome of such a review, however, it should be noted that, until additional resources are provided via the 1992/93 budget process (with funding actually being allocated to the Commission in December 1992 should funding be approved), it will not be possible to expand the program nationally prior to the proposed time of the review.

35. All policies for the future of AIEIS include an achievable timetable and provide for the program's reduction to a care and maintenance level within a timeframe which allows for the satisfactory realisation of all goals (3.28)
Agreed.

Since 1989 the remote area strategy has included this information and it will be included in the forthcoming urban strategy. Timetables are revised if necessary following program reviews, electoral events or other matters impinging upon the program.

36. Experience and information gained in the field be used as a basis for reorientating the AIEIS program toward greater emphasis on local priorities thereby making it more relevant to the electoral education and information needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people (6.3)
The whole thrust of the program, the field officer structure and the relative independence with which field officers go about their work allows for the meeting of local priorities.
37. The Australian Electoral Commission explore the possibility of developing formal working relationships with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and groups (6.14)
Agreed.

The Commission will discuss with ATSIC and the other relevant bodies the re-establishment of a small committee to formalise the Commission's already close and productive working relationship with such bodies.
38. That AIEIS field officers work with schools and other secondary educational institutions with a view to introducing the AIEIS program to older high school students (6.14)
Agreed.

This has been done in an ad-hoc manner in the past. School visits have now been formally incorporated into the program objectives and strategy documents and work has commenced on resource materials for use in remote community schools.
39. In the production of AIEIS curriculum and motivational materials, greater emphasis should be given to the use of local material and content and local input should be solicited (6.18)
This has been done to some extent since the inception of the program and has been done increasingly in recent years for the vast majority of information and education materials used by the program.
40. Audio-visual aids, particularly videos, become a major method of delivery for AIEIS curriculum and motivational materials (6.21)
Audio-visual materials have long formed a major method of delivery of the program. Additional audio-visual materials are currently being produced.
41. The Australian Electoral Commission explore all options for the exploitation of the Broadcasting for Remote Aboriginal Communities Scheme (BRACS) as a means of conveying AIEIS material (6.21)

BRACS has already been used in a minor way for information/advertising purposes. This use will increase considerably in the future with a stronger recommendation of the use of BRACS in the program strategy.

42. The Australian Electoral Commission immediately institute a thorough review of the AIEIS program's content, its methods of delivery and the materials it uses with a view to making the program accessible to and effective for the widest possible client base (6.24)

The content, method of delivery and material used in this program are reviewed on an annual basis with input from all field officers. The program's objectives and remote area strategy were comprehensively reviewed in January 1992, with representatives of client groups being involved in the review.
43. Information and materials for a parliamentary education component of the AIEIS program be planned and developed in cooperation with the Parliamentary Education Office (3.26)
Agreed.
Current materials already include information on the Federal Parliament. This section will be reviewed and the Parliamentary Education Office will be consulted for that purpose.

44. Before the next ATSIC regional council elections, the Australian Electoral Commission design and conduct pre-election information briefings on the management of elections for all ATSIC regional officers likely to be involved in the elections (7.12)
Agreed.
Such briefings were carried out prior to the 1990 ATSIC election as part of routine election preparation and it is planned that they will be carried out in the future.
