SPEECH.PARA: This is an important annual report from the Department of the Treasury, one of the pre-eminent departments in our structure of government. Unfortunately, given the short time we have had in which to read the report and make comments, I plan to restrict my remarks to two aspects. The report in my view deals very inadequately with one of the major issues which surrounded the Treasury during the last year. I refer to the establishment in the Treasury, at the instructions of the Government, of the so-called micro-economic modelling unit whose prime task is to work over the Fightback document which has been presented by John Hewson and Peter Reith as the coalition's policy as we go towards the next election.

PARA.TAB: This action by the Treasury, the way that unit was run, has become a matter of high public controversy. A number of Estimates committees have dealt with that issue, particularly the role that the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury, Mr Cole, and the Deputy Secretary to the Treasury, Dr Preston, played in the establishment of the unit and the apparent lack of proper control over the work of that unit. If one reads this report, one will not be greatly enlightened as to the nature of the controversy which surrounded the unit. It is referred to very briefly in a number of sections. It is referred to on pages 10 and 15, with a larger section on page 43. Essentially, the Treasury tells us that the software, the so-called PRISMOD, was used at the request of the Government to analyse the effects of some elements of the Opposition's Fightback package. It principally proposed changes to indirect taxes, personal income taxes, transfer payments and changes to health insurance arrangements.

The report points out that the results of the analysis were publicly released on 3 March—and honourable senators will recall the events surrounding that release. I have spoken on this particular issue on a number of occasions in this chamber. I wish again to record the fact that it is interesting that here we have a document which purports to be a summary of the Treasury's activities in the year 1991-92 and, so far as I can see in the short period of time I have had to flip through this document, no comment has been made about the nature of the dispute which surrounded the role of the Treasury in the analysis of the Fightback document.

I am on record in stating my belief that this was a fundamental change in the role of the Public Service. It was an astonishing use of the Treasury. It showed a complete lack of any sort of ethical behaviour by the Government to involve the Treasury in this type of work. Regrettably, it showed that the Treasury officers directly involved perhaps had forgotten the great traditions of public service in this country. The Government instructed them to get up out of the trenches, fire shots at the Opposition and then, when a couple of shots were fired back, there were enormous complaints.

I say to people in the Public Service that if they are foolish enough, upon being asked by the Government, to get out of the trench and start firing at the political enemies of the Government, they are extraordinarily hopeful if they think that they can emerge unscathed from this type of dispute. I think the incident which occurred in relation to Treasury is regrettable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you making a threat?

—Senator Cook's fellow Ministers asked Treasury officers to get up and start firing bullets at the coalition. Then, of course, when we had the Treasury officers before the Estimates Committee, there were complaints as to the nature of the questions being asked of them. In my view, if officers want to get out of the trenches at the instructions of their political masters and start to take pot shots at the Opposition, they cannot expect to escape unscathed. In my view, it is Senator Cook's colleagues who have to be very careful about using public servants in that manner. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking on the third annual report of Landcare Australia Ltd, I first want to congratulate all of those throughout the Australian community who are making strenuous efforts to promote soil conservation activities across Australia. I want especially to congratulate the two Queensland winners of the national Landcare Australia awards who are mentioned here in the report. I refer to Dr Brian Roberts, who is head of land use studies at the University College of Southern Queensland and the Hermitage Fallow Management Group in Queensland. Dr Roberts has spent his entire working life in teaching, researching and spreading the word about soil conservation and land use planning, while the fallow group has led the way in reduced tillage and stubble retention practices in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: In recent years we have often heard of several pressing environmental matters, including energy, pollution and the greenhouse effect, which have been competing for the public's attention. But soil degradation is our most basic issue, I venture to say. It is often forgotten in the media and there do not seem to be very many votes in this issue when politicians parade before the public their concerns about the environment. Yet, as I have said, soil degradation is Australia's No. 1 environmental issue. Indeed, the report notes:

SPEECH.PARA: The company's awareness raising activity during the year has targeted a wider audience of urban and rural Australians thanks to the support of . . . the National Soil Conservation Program.

Over thousands of years floods, dry spells and the prevailing wind patterns have combined to strip numerous layers of the fine fertile soil from Australia's surface. Regrettably, that is what is happening in Queensland at the present time—or to the vast majority of Queensland—while southern parts of Australia, down here around Canberra, Victoria and very many other States are having the most wonderful rain. Even in Western Australia, Mr Acting Deputy President, I think you have had good rain, too.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably, a lot of this fine, fertile soil has been blown away and has ended up in the Pacific and Indian oceans, stretching out from the coastline in two plumes to the north-west and the south-east, mirroring the prevailing wind systems. We all would have read numerous stories about windblown soil from the Australian mainland which is regularly dumped on the New Zealand alps. Nothing is more important to a nation's environment than its soil and the preservation of the quality of its land.

The loss of our thin and fragile soil, the progressive degradation of our land and the expansion of the desert and arid areas of the Australian continent are our number one environmental challenge. We have seen in our Queensland papers the story of how so much of inland Queensland is gradually turning into desert. It really makes one very sad and feel very sorry for people who are on the land out in far-flung western Queensland, where they are having such a bad time.

By 1983, about 66 per cent of all our land was in need of some conservation measures. Significant long term problems have also arisen as a result of the progressive breaking down of the structure of Australian soils. Soil conservation is not only of particular importance to the Greenies, to whom the Government and the media often pander, but also of vital importance to those Australians who often have much more to do with the environment—that is, the man and the woman on the land.

Only in the past few years has soil degradation come a little into focus. This has been partly because during the past few years Australia has experienced a series of storms, droughts and floods which were directly or indirectly related to the problem. Indeed, the disastrous drought experienced by Queensland last year, and still being experienced in some areas, resulted in unheard of dust storms blanketing cities, such as Brisbane, with a constant haze of fine soil swept off the once beautiful topsoil of the Darling Downs.

It is estimated that about half of Australia's rural land requires treatment for degradation. Human activity has been responsible for about half of that degradation. That, of course, is why we are very interested in the Landcare Australia Ltd third annual report. It is something that we really want and need. Australian farmers play a leading role in the environment, caring for over 200 million animals and millions of square kilometres of land. To a remarkable degree the care of this nation's environment is already in their hands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak briefly on the third annual report 1992 of Landcare Australia Ltd. I take this opportunity of congratulating a number of people on the effort they have put into the land care and national soil conservation program during the past 12 months and, of course, since its inception. I particularly draw the attention of the Senate to two award winners from Western Australia. The first one was Alcoa Australia Ltd, which set up a number of programs demonstrating rehabilitation techniques. In congratulating Alcoa, I also acknowledge that there are a number of other companies in Western Australia, and I guess elsewhere in Australia, which are putting significant resources into this very important initiative and requirement for tackling the issue of degradation. In Western Australia we have seen a revolution in the soil conservation program over the past 10 years since the program's inception.
—Where did it start?

—Senator Panizza asks me where it started. I think it started fairly close to his property. I acknowledge that his property is in the first conservation district in Western Australia; I believe that it was also the first conservation district in Australia. I congratulate and acknowledge the Kalannie-Goodlands Land Conservation District Committee, which is in an area not very far from where Senator Panizza farms. I note particularly that Combined Rural Traders is one company that is providing assistance and awards recognising people for what they do. I also acknowledge Mr Elton Butcher, a Pithara farmer, who became chairman of the Soil and Land Conservation Council in Western Australia 10 or 11 years ago and has filled that position in a very capable, positive and strong manner. He has given distinguished service to Western Australia in the area of conservation. Mr Butcher travels from one end of the State to the other assisting in the various conservation districts. I was honoured a couple of years ago when Elton Butcher drove through my front gate to talk to me and other farmers in the area when we were analysing farms within a catchment area.

PARA.TAB: In Western Australia, over 1,240 farm plans and 11 catchment plans are in progress or have been completed. Many people put their efforts into that and they should be recognised for what they have done. The development of the training program needs highlighting. Last year, 2,155 person days of training were given in the following areas: group skills, 848; technical courses, 487; and Community Landcare technicians, 820. There is now what I would call a small army operating in Western Australia giving advice and assisting in this operation.

I also bring to the attention of the Senate the very successful Landcare pavilion at Perth Royal Show this year, which attracted some 80,000 visitors. It got over to many people the message that there is a responsible attitude to land care in rural Western Australia. I reiterate my congratulations to the people I have mentioned, and I look forward to developments over the next 10 years as much as I have enjoyed what has happened in the past 10 years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming from Queensland, which is a very important State for tourism in Australia, I am very pleased to be able to say something about the report of the Bureau of Tourism Research. Tourism is one of Australia's largest and fastest growing industries. It has the potential to make a significant contribution to the nation's future economic development, and perhaps our Government ought to listen to that point. The report states:
By any standard it is already a significant industry. In 1990/91 tourist expenditure within Australia amounted to $25 billion and tourism's contribution to GDP exceeded 5 per cent.

Tourism accounts for around 450,000 jobs, either directly or indirectly, or 5.8 per cent of the work force. During the 1990s, the industry is expected to create up to 200,000 new jobs, representing 16 per cent of all new jobs in the economy. As the report notes:
. . . employment in tourism related industries increased during the period that the Australian economy was in recession while employment overall declined.

I suppose it would be easy to say that our tourism performance is going fairly well, but in reality there are a number of difficulties within the Australian tourism industry. While the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) might say that the recession is over, one knows that the figures prove that it is certainly not. One has only to look at the latest reports released in October by the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation to see that a number of our major tourist attractions are in some trouble because people just cannot afford to stay there.

PARA.TAB: Seventy per cent of the tourist industry is the domestic industry. We are seeing a boom in caravan parks and in low cost accommodation while a lot of Australia's very important infrastructure is being under-utilised because Australians just cannot afford to go there. While the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government is very much the promotion of Australia overseas, we in the Opposition have some very real criticism of the way the Government is approaching the situation. The decisions that will have to be made about Australian tourism over the next 18 months to two years are the most important in the industry's history. If we play our cards correctly, we have a great opportunity to become a major force in world tourism.

In its studies of last year, the World Tourism Organisation estimated that, by the year 2000, 140 million Asians annually will be travelling offshore for their holidays. If Australia got five per cent of that business, it could not handle it. Since 1985, overseas visitor numbers have more than doubled to a record 2.4 million in 1991. Our major markets are Japan and New Zealand, which account for 43 per cent of all visitors.

During the 1990s overseas visitor numbers are expected to more than double again, to between 4.8 million and 6.5 million by the year 2000. This will be accompanied by a significant change in the market mix, with Japan and Asia becoming more dominant markets. However, as I said earlier, domestic tourism is still the lifeblood of the industry, accounting for over 70 per cent of tourism business. Indeed, this time last year the Courier-Mail published a report that stated:

SPEECH.PARA: More Australians are spending their holidays at local resorts rather than going overseas, a national travel agency survey says.

PARA.TAB: For the first time in more than a decade, four local destinations have appeared in the Harvey World Travel Top 10 holiday destinations for Australians.
Cairns and Queensland island resorts have replaced the Gold Coast as the top Australian holiday spots: the Gold Coast dropped to No. 10 on the preferred holiday list.
Cheap domestic air fares . . . were said to be the main reason for the shift.
Far North Queensland Promotion Bureau general manager Mr Geoff Donaghy said the Harvey World Travel survey results reflected a shift by Australians to more natural holiday locations.
"We're one of the few tropical destinations that has political stability, geographical stability and you can drink the water.

SPEECH.PARA: which I suppose is something that cannot be said about overseas—

PARA.TAB: "The diversity and natural attractions are what the great percentage of travellers are looking for.
Australians' top holiday destinations were the American West Coast and Hawaii, Bali, the United Kingdom and Europe, Cairns, Fiji, Asia, New Zealand, Perth, the Queensland islands and the Gold Coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes that I have had to peruse the report from the Bureau of Tourism Research, I have been impressed with the detail it has gone into, and I congratulate the Bureau on the work it has done. I join with my Queensland colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen in paying tribute to the tourism industry in Australia in general but to the tourist industry in Queensland in particular. The area where I live in the north of Queensland—around Townsville, Cairns and the Whitsunday Islands—is indeed one of the premier tourist attractions and destinations for both Australian and international tourists.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Bjelke-Petersen has mentioned, and as is mentioned in this report of the Bureau, in 1990-91 tourist expenditure within Australia amounted to $25 billion. Tourism contributed a fraction more than 5 per cent to the nation's GDP. Expenditure by international visitors exceeded $7 billion in 1990-91, and the return from tourism has superseded our more traditional exports such has coal, wool and wheat in terms of its contribution to export earnings.

In that same year, the number of jobs generated by tourism reached around 450,000. It is significant that this increase in job numbers occurred at a time when Australia was in the depths of the worst recession since the 1930s—a recession this Government created. In spite of that, the tourism industry has managed to expand. A report issued just last week, I think, by a Cairns based economic unit indicated that over half of the new jobs created in Australia in the last year were created in the Cairns region as a result of tourism.

Whilst the Government has done everything possible to impede business generally in Australia, and that includes the tourism industry, under the new government which will take office after the next election the tourist industry will get a real boost, particularly from a couple of areas. The labour market reform that the coalition has proposed will be of significant benefit to the tourism industry. No longer will the tourism industry be impeded by inflexible, centralised wage and industrial relations rules and conditions. Conditions will be able to be negotiated between the tourist industry and the employees in those areas themselves. That is particularly important in an industry which requires wide flexibility—it requires an ability to work at odd sorts of hours and on all days of the week.

The coalition's proposals for labour market reform will be particularly significant to the tourist operators. I might say that this is one of the coalition's policies that is being particularly well received up my way in the far north of Queensland.

As Senator Bjelke-Petersen has mentioned, a significant part of our tourism in Australia is internal tourism—tourism that travels principally by road. Our proposal to remove some 19c a litre—almost 20c a litre—from the price of petrol will be a real boost to those Australians who drive to their holiday destinations. That, to a general extent, encompasses the lower end of the market—the ordinary Australians who once every couple of years get in the car and go for a holiday at some tourist caravan park. That significant reduction in the price of their fuel will encourage them.

I guess what will encourage them more is that once there is a new government people's jobs will be guaranteed again. At the present time people are unwilling to take holidays because they are not quite sure that they will still have a job when they come back. Under the new government, people will be able to take those holidays with the certainty of a job on their return, and that will be tremendous for the tourism industry. All of the coalition's policies will be great for tourism. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the time for the debate on the report today to five minutes per speaker. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clock accordingly.

—I rise principally to welcome the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade relating to a review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. Although I have not had a chance to do more than glance at it today, it will obviously be a very worthwhile addition to source material on this very important subject of Australia's contribution to promoting and protecting human rights. Even in the few moments I have had in which to look at the report, I am pleased to see that a number of issues which have been raised have principally found support of the Committee in that it is supportive of matters that the Opposition has put forward in the past.

PARA.TAB: One of those matters relates to a suggestion that we have been pursuing of promoting a human rights forum within the region. A lot of publicity is given to obvious leverage that is used by Australia to try to influence improvements in international human rights. Pressure is applied diplomatically, sometimes through restraints upon Australia's foreign aid, as in the case of Burma; sometimes through restraints on trade, with the application of trade sanctions, as in the case of South Africa. However, not so much attention is given to efforts to encourage change through the development of regional bodies.

Throughout the world, in many regions, human rights mechanisms have been established, usually in the form of some type of regional human rights convention supported by, in some instances, a human rights court and other mechanism. But it certainly has not been attempted within the Asia-Pacific region. I have been suggesting encouraging Asian states, in particular—where sadly there are deficiencies in their human rights records—to join together and look to enhance their standing internationally by sponsoring a human rights forum to encourage each other to develop and be party to a regional convention and also to encourage each other to adhere to the standards that would be contained within that convention.

I am pleased that that idea has been taken up by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of this Parliament. I hope the Government will now also respond positively. If it does, that will be a worthwhile contribution in a constructive, positive way towards improving human rights throughout this region.

I am also pleased to see that the Committee took up the issue of Sri Lanka. Some years ago we suggested that Australia should seek to get the Commonwealth involved in the very sad Sri Lankan conflict in which there had been an enormous amount of death and suffering. On examination of that tragedy, the UN found the level of disappearances in Sri Lanka higher than anywhere else it had studied in the world.

The Australian Government, to some limited degree, did take up that suggestion and there was some lobbying for a Commonwealth role. I took it up with the Commonwealth secretariat and other states. Whereas there has been some mouthing of support, because the Sri Lankan Government has not been prepared to invite the Commonwealth, the issue has not gone any further. I am pleased this Committee sees merit in Commonwealth involvement and I hope that also will give greater support to the Australian Government to get back into that debate and urge Sri Lanka to take advantage of the good offices of the Commonwealth to help find a way through its problems.

I am pleased the Committee took up the issue of denial of democracy in Burma and, in particular, the possibility of a UN sponsored arms embargo. Earlier this week at a conference in Brisbane, I suggested it was time that the Security Council look at the issue of Burma. Whereas that might be difficult with China, because China is the principal supplier of arms to Burma, the mere fact of that supply of weapons would be on the international agenda and could be a step in the right direction.

The last issue I have time to mention is Vietnam. Despite the building of relationships—economic and political—between Australia and Vietnam, an unsatisfactory human rights situation still exists. I am pleased that has been recognised by the Committee, which is more than can be said of the Australian Government. I hope that, with new confidence, the Australian Government might also take up that issue. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to see the release, finally, of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on a review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. It is about time we had one of these reports. I am very pleased that quite a while ago I had a hand in getting this started and that it has finally come to this outcome. This report is a very useful source book on human rights generally and on Australia's attitude towards them.

PARA.TAB: As one would expect, there has been some interest from the press in the report, particularly paragraph 6.24—which I should know by heart by now—which relates to East Timor. The fact that the Committee said that it believes the Australian Government should be consistent in its reaction to human rights outrages of this kind—we do not believe the Australian Government was consistent when it came to the Dili massacre in East Timor—only gives the Committee credibility. It does not take away from what the Committee has done or from this report; it only adds to it. I am very pleased that we had the unanimous support of the Committee for that recommendation in paragraph 6.24.

The Committee looked at a lot of places in the region, including East Timor, West Irian, Bougainville, Sri Lanka, Burma, Thailand, Vietnam, the Philippines, China, Tibet and many places outside the region. It is interesting to note that a lot of people came to us with information about places all around the world. More and more people came to us as the word spread that we were carrying out our inquiry. It was heartening to see that people trusted us to get information on the record and to say something about a particularly difficult part of the world, and indeed a particularly difficult part of foreign relations.

We have not let ourselves off. We included a chapter on domestic compliance, which says that we are not up to the mark in the way we treat our own Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. We do not believe we are up to the mark on juvenile detention, in particular the Western Australian experience, on women or on refugees. We have to acknowledge that we ourselves have problems in human rights, although everybody would agree that we have far fewer than many other countries in the region.

We have said many things in the report about East Timor which have to be acknowledged by the Government. The Government has handled the latest East Timor problem reasonably well, but I think we could be a lot stronger. We should be pushing much harder for more independent access to Xanana Gusmao and for an independent assessment of what is going on with his family and his friends and everywhere in East Timor. According to all reports—the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) told me this earlier today in answer to a question—there is still a problem in that area. The position is much worse than it has been even in the recent past and we have to look for independent confirmation that things are not as bad as they seem.

We have also mentioned other places, including Bougainville. We have not let the Bougainville Revolutionary Army off the hook. We believe that a number of human rights abuses are occurring in Bougainville, and that they involve the Papua New Guinea defence force and the BRA. Nobody is innocent, except the ones who are being hurt—the ones who belong to neither side and who are just getting in the way.

We also deal in our report with Burma. We would all agree that that is one of the worst regimes in the world and that abuses in that country have to be stopped so far as that is possible. Austrade still has an office in Burma. We believe that that office should be closed. The Minister said yesterday that it probably will not be. I would like to reiterate now that I believe it should be.

In our report we reiterated what was in my motion on China and Tibet of a couple of years ago—namely, that there should be close cooperation between the Chinese Government and the Dalai Lama. It is the only way we will get any response in Tibet and the only way we will get peace in that region.

I cannot conclude without saying that the other members of the Committee did a very good job on this report. I would like to thank Margaret Swieringa, the Committee Secretary, who did the basic drafting of the report very well. She chose the very moving picture on the front cover by Goya and chose all the quotes throughout the report. She has done a magnificent job. Indeed, everybody associated with the Committee has done a great job and I look forward to the Government acting on all our recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief points about the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled A review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. I believe that this is a very important report. I have not been a member of this Committee, but I think it serves this Parliament and this country exceptionally well. I have not read the report thoroughly, since we received it only around midday today. However, as Senator Bourne said, it is now and will be for some time an excellent source document. For that reason I want to put on record my appreciation of it.

PARA.TAB: Before making a particular point arising from a couple of the areas discussed in the report, I should say that, in general, as Australians we can be reasonably satisfied with, if not somewhat proud of, the record of our nation. I think the people of Australia are concerned about human rights for people around the world. It has been our experience generally in public life in this country that actions against outrages and abuses of human rights around the world tend to gain support from a fairly wide cross-section of the Australian community. It is commendable that this report contains a chapter relating to the question of human rights compliance in this country and that the areas of Aborigines, juvenile detention, women and refugees are dealt with.

Although Australia has a good record on human rights—which of course can be improved, and almost daily in this chamber there is some instance where the need for improvement is pointed to, particularly from these cross benches—I sound a note of caution. I take a particular interest in a number of the areas, particularly in the region, referred to in this report. About a month ago I rose to give notice of a motion in which I expressed concern that, when a recent delegation of the Joint Committee planned to visit Indonesia, the Indonesian Government refused that delegation access to East Timor. This was at a particularly delicate time. I commend the Committee for the comments at paragraph 6.24, where it criticises the Australian Government for watering down the resolution drafted by the European Community. I support that criticism.

I felt that the acceptance by the Government of that refusal to allow the delegation into East Timor may have been one of the reasons why, without adequate explanation, a subsequent human rights delegation going to China, following up its visit there the year before, was refused entry into Tibet. I and others in the Parliament have taken a particular interest in the human rights of people in Tibet. I felt that we might be seeing an instance where Australia might be seen in the region to be a little soft on human rights issues. At the time I expressed the view that, on those grounds, the delegation should not travel to China; it was difficult to see how those human rights issues could be properly investigated if it was not allowed to go into Tibet. I also felt that two in a row was not a good record and meant that Australia might be seen as being a bit of a soft touch in this area. I may be wrong; I hope I am.

No doubt both delegations did their best to obtain the best information they could. I am not questioning that at all. I suppose that eternal vigilance is the price of democracy—or is it the other way around? I congratulate the Committee on its report but express my concern that Australia might be seen as slackening off, if we are not very careful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to commend this report and to say that I am a very grateful participant in the activities of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which has submitted this report. I replaced Senator Jo Vallentine on the human rights subcommittee, so I entered this process part way through. It was a most worthwhile and helpful experience to enter Parliament with this kind of opportunity. I think the public hearings, in particular, were very helpful and rewarding in two ways.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, community groups, who hold very deeply human rights concerns for countries throughout the world, had the opportunity to address the Committee and the Committee was able to show its readiness to listen to and take very seriously the concerns and the evidence that were brought to it. This was extremely positive. Also it was challenging to the Departments and the officials of the bureaucracy who had to be open to scrutiny and accept the probing questioning that they received from time to time about their own involvement in our international relations regarding human rights.

This report needs to be commended as a very useful source book. Every member of the Senate will find it useful in that it provides a helpful overview of Australia's efforts worldwide in relation to the promotion and protection of human rights. However, it should be pointed out that the report is not exhaustive. As more and more people became aware of the availability of the opportunity to make submissions, more and more countries' concerns were added. I think we could have gone on. That is why it is a helpful beginning. By the time of the annual review that may be necessary, we will be able to add to that.

However, it is a very helpful overview. It is a document that, through its appendices, will be enormously useful in a practical way because it shows us at a glance the international covenants to which Australia is a party. But, as the report points out, it is not complete. I would like to support the recommendation, made by Senator Schacht at the National Press Club luncheon today, that we should take very seriously our response as a Federal Parliament to ratify fully these international covenants to which we have become party and to exert our responsibility in a full way.

In looking at many areas—some have been mentioned already such as East Timor, Bougainville and Burma—this document exposes the double standard that we bear. As has been noted, there is criticism of the Australian Parliament and the way in which we have responded to certain issues—in particular, to that of East Timor. As Senator Bourne has said, this exposure of our double standards within the document adds to the credibility of the Committee and of the Australian Parliament's willingness to scrutinise our own attempts at being part of the international community.

I think the double standards that have been raised, such as continuation of an Austrade office in Burma and an unwillingness to refuse diplomatic representation to Indonesia and China when we are restricted in our access, are encouragements to be more courageous in our stance, and to demonstrate our willingness to stand up for human rights. We could not afford to do that if we were not already looking at our own compliance with international human rights standards.

I, too, commend chapter 5 on domestic compliance. In particular it relates to Aboriginal people, juvenile justice, women and refugees. As a senator from Western Australia, I would commend appendix 9, which shows a very revealing correspondence between the Human Rights Commissioner and the Premier of Western Australia. Regrettably, there is not sufficient time to draw out parts of this document. I can go no further without adding my thanks to Mrs Margaret Swieringa, the Secretary who has done such a magnificent job. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the debate on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade relating to a review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights will remain on the Notice Paper, because at this point we have only five minutes each in which to comment on it. I welcome this report and congratulate those who have been involved in its preparation. It is very important for the Australian Parliament to focus continually on this question of human rights. What are we here for if it is not to preserve and develop those human rights and to protect them whenever they are threatened?

PARA.TAB: I believe that, to the extent that the Committee has sought to highlight violations of human rights, this report will be most welcomed. The Committee dealt with matters which came before it by way of evidence. Some areas of concern for people in various parts of the world are not contained in this report. I do not suggest that the Committee considers this report to be a totally definitive document on human rights. However, the report contains some very interesting comments. It talks laudably about the universality of human rights and it rejects forthrightly the concept of cultural relativism. Frankly, I believe that is in advance.

I do not share the view of Senator Powell that Australia can really hold its head high on the question of human rights. We are trying to get there and this is one indication of that effort. In our internal policies and sometimes in our external policies we do fail, but I believe that it is important for the Parliament to be ever vigilant to ensure that the Government places the highest priority on the protection and advancement of human rights both within Australia and outside.

The issue of human rights is close to the hearts of many Australian citizens. One such person died last week. I attended the funeral of Stan O'Doherty in George Town on Friday of last week. He was born in Belfast. He knew what it was to be discriminated against. He was forthright in his condemnation of human rights violations. Whilst he condemned human rights violations, in a quiet and persevering manner he sought to overcome the problems with which he and others were faced. In recent times he was very forthright in his condemnation of abuses of human rights in Burma and in fact made practical contributions to alleviating the distress of the Burmese people.

Incidentally, it is interesting to note the UN's report—and I have the document in my hand—on human rights violations in Burma. This is a very interesting document, a key document which ought to be studied along with the document that we have before us. Again, I would like to commend the document that we have before us to honourable senators for reading. I am going to study it further and I hope to be able to engage in further debate when the matter comes before us on another occasion.(Extension of time granted)
Finally, I refer to page 25 of the report, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Human rights is one of these universal questions. Nation states have no sovereign right to abuse their own people and they should be answerable to the international community for the treatment of their people. Conversely, the international community has a responsibility to assist those who cannot protect themselves. This is not a luxury to be determined by strategic considerations although it is often used in that way. It is a matter of our intrinsic humanity. Law at its best is a noble conception. Applied equally, without fear or favour, it can be a civilising thing which curbs the cruelties of tyrants. International law should reflect the importance we attach to those interdependent and universal values we have identified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It is an important report. I have not had the opportunity, as my colleague Senator Harradine has, to read the report and look at it in detail. But my own view is that any institution which seeks to advance the cause of human rights, which seeks to maintain pressure so that people can be protected from oppressive acts, whether by members of their own nation or others, is worth while. I believe that Senator Schacht has shown a strong particular interest in the area of human rights and we have had cause to comment on that from time to time from this side of the chamber. Despite exchanges which may have occurred, I am happy to give credit to Senator Schacht for chairing this Committee and I look forward to reading the report in close detail.

PARA.TAB: I have two brief views which I want to bring to the attention of the chamber. I am less happy, I suspect, than many others that Australia seems to be opening up wide areas of appeal to foreign courts. One of the oft repeated achievements of the Labor Government was to cut out appeals to the Privy Council. Since then, it seems to me that in a number of areas we have opened up appeals to other courts and other bodies. I believe that often we have been subjecting our people to the judgment of people in courts and tribunals, the appointment of whom we have very little or no say over. I raise a cautionary note there.

The second issue I raise is that, certainly from the recommendations I have had a chance to quickly flick through, Senator Schacht and his colleagues on the Committee have recommended that we ratify a large number of treaties. Some of these may well be most worth while; others may not. Certainly I would want to study those carefully.

I remember—as would Senator Schacht and I guess a few others who were on the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, of which you were also a member, Mr Acting Deputy President—that it is one thing to ratify a convention and it is another thing to apply it. I think that the history of that particular action on political advertising shows this complexity. I do not raise that in a point-scoring manner but to show that these things are not as simple and as straightforward as they may be.

We now have emerging, in relation to the ILO, issues such as voluntary unionism, the access of people to independent arbitration, and so on. Those issues are going to involve the Australian community for a long time. When we give holus-bolus endorsement to particular conventions, whereas it may well reflect an intention that is desirable and honourable, it can also lead to great complexities. One of the challenges in our system is the interpretation of how these things may be applied in our own community.

I do not raise those two points in such a way as to demean the work of the Committee and Senator Schacht. I am sure that the Committee has pursued its studies and worked with great vigour. However, I do say, on the one hand, that I am less comfortable than others about putting Australians at the mercy of foreign bodies; on the other hand, while the intentions in ratifying treaties may well be worth while, I have some concerns about some of those areas and how they may be applied to our own society. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a few brief remarks. When I tabled this morning the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I incorporated a tabling speech, without speaking to the motion, to save time for Government Business. I respect the fact that this evening other members of the Senate have restricted themselves to five minutes when commenting on the report.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this is a substantial report—not just because I am a member of the Committee that compiled it—which raises many significant issues, including the ones Senator Kemp has raised. I can assure Senator Kemp that those issues were debated very vigorously backwards and forwards within the Committee. They are issues that need wider debate, and I hope that at a later stage in the Senate's life—if not this year, then next year—there can be more time put aside to debate the major issues to which other senators, including Senator Harradine, have referred. I think honourable senators need some days to read and digest the recommendations and to come to grips with the complexities of some of these international issues so that they can debate them more thoroughly.

I want to point out a couple of things about the report. First of all, it was a unanimous report. Thirty members of the Committee, representing all political parties from both chambers, unanimously supported the report. That means that many of us made compromises on particular points to get a unanimous decision. All members of the Committee realised that, as it is the first report on human rights, it would be very unfortunate if there were dissenting reports either way about major recommendations. I am pleased that the members of the Committee were able, after a lot of discussion, to make recommendations that may not be 100 per cent what they believe in but that generally they can all live with in relation to the major thrust of the recommendations.

Secondly, the report overwhelmingly commits Australia to a view that it should have dialogue at the international level and in the appropriate forums, either multilaterally or bilaterally, in advancing human rights. As Senator Harradine said, we reject cultural relativism as saying that human rights in one country are different from human rights in another. We believe that there is something absolutely universal about human rights. No matter where we are, nobody likes the idea of being summarily executed, tortured or abused, whether in a Third World country or a First World country. That is a theme of the report that has to be strongly noted. We rejected very strongly the view of cultural relativism.

The Committee also recognises that Australia will cause irritation in other countries by raising at the international level issues of human rights, but in the long run we believe that it is in Australia's best interests to be consistent in raising those issues with the various countries, even our closest neighbours within the region, with whom we have differences about them. We should not back away and we should be mature enough to be able to handle those issues. We also raise the issue that we ourselves have to come under examination from time to time. We cannot criticise other countries without accepting that they have the right to criticise us and ask us to ratify the various international conventions. That is a debate Senator Kemp and others may wish to have, but that is the basis of our recommendation.

In conclusion, I should like to thank the members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade secretariat for their hard work in preparing this report, particularly Margaret Swieringa, the secretary, and Denise Picker, the assistant secretary. This Committee has already adopted a workload way beyond that of most subcommittees or committees in the Australian Parliament, in view of the large number of submissions received. To them I give my personal thanks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the time for the debate and that the speaking times during the debate will be as follows: Senator Alston, 10 minutes; Senator Kernot, 10 minutes; the Manager of Government Business, Senator McMullan, 10 minutes; Senator Watson, five minutes; and Senator Sherry, five minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration)(Charge Percentage) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 288 and made on 1 September 1992 under subsection 20(4) of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992, be disallowed in accordance with paragraph (b) of that subsection.

SPEECH.PARA: These are very important regulations. They were inserted as an attachment to the superannuation legislation that passed through the Parliament in June of this year at the specific request of the Australian Democrats in order to enable the Parliament, if necessary, to disallow the increase in the proportion of wages to be paid by way of superannuation contributions for firms with payrolls in excess of $1m.

PARA.TAB: At that time, it was the specific intent of those who did the deal that if the economy could not afford such an increase the Parliament ought to be able to disallow it. In other words, it was being said by both parties to that deal that we simply should not automatically proceed with an increase irrespective of the state of the economy. To the extent that that constituted some glimmer of economic enlightenment, it was welcome. Otherwise, both the Government and the Democrats were quite prepared to put in place automatic mechanisms which totally ignored capacity to pay and which, as we well know—even on the admission of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins)—put many jobs at risk.

That is one of the consequences that has to be lived with when one proceeds with automatic enforcement mechanisms designed to require employers to pay extra money. It is like all other oncosts, whether they are workers compensation charges or anything else, it simply adds to the price of labour and, accordingly, makes it more difficult for employers to afford their existing work force, let alone to employ others.

We have reached the point where, for the last week or so, we have had some extraordinary grandstanding on the part of the Australian Democrats who, hitherto, I would have thought, would have been very much aware of the total unaffordability of this increase. Indeed, I have challenged Senator Kernot on more than one occasion to table any documentation from any interest group that has been urging her to side with the Government and let this regulation go ahead. I would be very interested to hear any argumentation in support of that proposition.

Even at the eleventh hour it is not too late for the Democrats to jump on the jobs bandwagon. It is quite clear that the Government has no intention of backing away, as, indeed, it never did; it was always much more intent on an accord deal which would impose the burden entirely on employers, making us almost unique in the Western world not only in terms of compulsion but also in terms of not requiring any employee contribution. Two countries in the OECD have compulsion but no requirement for an employee contribution. So the prospects of the Government ever seeing reality in that regard have never been alive.

It is a great tragedy that to date the Democrats have had to be dragged screaming and yelling from the grandstand. I hope that it is not too late for them to recognise economic reality. Indeed, the way in which they perform tonight will be a good test of their economic literacy.

As recently as 28 October, Senator Kernot said that the Australian economy could not afford this increase. If one thing ought to be abundantly clear in the economic debate, it is that since that time the economy has gone from bad to worse. The current account deficit is $1.8 billion. Unemployment is 11.3 per cent. Foreign debt in gross terms is over $200 billion, there being a one-off increase of $13 billion in one quarter. It has been an extraordinarily dismal performance. On any measure—and certainly the test adopted by Senator Kernot when the deal was done—there is no possible basis on which Australia can afford to put jobs at risk in this way.

It will be a big challenge. We despair of the Government ever displaying the necessary flexibility or concern for the impact on those who might be at risk in terms of losing jobs. The deal, as we say, has been done.
I want to refer to a letter from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to Senator Kernot of today's date. It contains some very important messages, and I would be—

TALK.START.PARA: —A well-known neutral and impartial body.

—Indeed. But Senator Kernot pretends to consult widely; to consult with these people and take account of what they say; to wring her hands at the appropriate time; and to generally genuflect in the direction of economic responsibility and capacity to pay. If Senator McMullan wants to refute these statements, I would be very interested to hear him. Ian Spicer had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Productivity growth makes higher wages affordable. It is only if we can conspire to raise productivity that real wages are ever going to increase without increasing unemployment.
With something like half of each year's productivity growth being soaked up in paying superannuation, future increases in real earnings will be unavoidably minimal.

The fact is that real wages have continued to rise, even in the depths of the recession. In large part, this is due to the failure of those who are reaching agreements to take account of the fall in the domestic rate of inflation. If inflation is less than 2 per cent and wages are running at 4 per cent, there is no possible basis to ever expect that the ACTU will do any more than pay lip service to the proposition of discounts. If what the Government wanted to achieve is for the IRC to take matters into account, that is already in the Act and it is a requirement.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Kernot or the Government want to pretend that somehow we will see wages moderation as a result of an increase in the SGC, I suggest that that is defying not only economic reality but also Australian political history. The fact that the SGC will be rising each year from now until the year 2002 will have virtually no effect on the claims made by the union movement—and nor has it to date, perfectly understandably and predictably. So it would be not only fatuous but also disingenuous to pretend that somehow any assurance that there might be some wages moderation as a result of the increase is worth the paper that it presumably will not be written on.

Therefore, this is the moment of truth. It is hard to conceive under what conditions the increase in the SGC would be rejected if the current conditions of the Australian economy do not provide more than enough justification for rejecting this increase. If ever there was a time when the economy deserved a breather, it is now. Treasury's own estimates are that this increase alone will put up to 10,000 jobs at risk over the next two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Garbage in, garbage out.

—Senator Kernot should not wag her finger at me. As she well knows, no-one is saying that 10,000 jobs will be lost. Treasury is saying that if the burden is borne fully by employers, there will be up to 10,000 jobs lost. Senator Kernot has no idea to what extent it will not be borne by employers. To date, all the evidence suggests that it will be and that the ACTU will not discount wages.
—Which it is not.
—You cannot deny that it will add $700m to the cost of employment. You cannot deny that it will be—
—Order! Speak through the Chair, Senator Alston.

—Senator Kernot cannot deny that it will be a very significant burden on business and that it will make it that much harder for businesses to prosper and expand, and to create productivity increases which lead to job increases. All it can do is smother any prospect of a flickering recovery. If the Democrats want to be a party to that, let them wear the consequences. I cannot believe that they could be so insensitive to the need to promote an Australian recovery that they would protect the Government yet again rather than protect the jobs of Australian workers.

PARA.TAB: I only hope that the Democrats will see the light and acknowledge that it is necessary at this time to have a deferment for six months, which is what this is all about. Unlike our decision in relation to taxation cuts on personal contributions, this decision is not reversible; this harm will be irreparable. Our decision can be easily reversed after the election by very generous tax incentives; this one cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're all leaving—

—And the Democrats will wear it. I gather from Senator Kernot's fury at this stage that she has already thrown in the towel. If that is the case, it will be a very sad day for the Australian work force, for those businesses that are struggling to survive, and for those who were hoping that somehow sanity would prevail in the Parliament on this very important issue.

—Tonight we are talking about the Senate's decision on a Government proposal for an extension of what is already a very important social reform: the extension of superannuation coverage, which significantly enhances Australia's retirement income arrangements and significantly contributes to the very important economic goal of enhanced national savings. This debate is important in three ways. It is important firstly as to the substance of what it can deliver to Australian employees; secondly, as to what it symbolises in terms of the whole debate about superannuation; and, thirdly, as to whether the Parliament is prepared to give recognition to Australian workers for the restraint which they have shown up to this time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston asks, `What is the interest group that is pushing for this extension?' There is a very typical Liberal Party approach these days, under Fightback and Dr Hewson—to say that any group of Australians who want something is a special interest group. We are talking about a special interest group which is 5.8 million Australian wage and salary earners. They are the people who want this increase. They will be the beneficiaries of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? They want their jobs.

—Senator Alston can dismiss them as an interest group if he wishes. It may not suit him to recognise that they are Australians with a legitimate interest in enhanced retirement income and enhanced national savings. We get this continuation of the ridiculous assertion about the 10,000 jobs at risk. That is an insult to the intelligence of Senator Alston, who is an intelligent senator. It is a pity that he has to fall back on that argument. Senator Alston then trots out the letter from Mr Spicer which I think is in all employer groups' offices around Australia. I have had the same letter read—with only the date on the top changed—for the last 25 years, every time anybody has proposed any improvement for any worker in any condition. They just change the signature and the date at the top and say, `Now is not the right time'.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about an apparently minor increase. Of course, it cannot be a minor increase for workers if it is going to have that enormous effect on jobs which Senator Alston thinks it will have—the hundreds of millions of dollars—but on the face of it it is only an extension from 4 per cent to 5 per cent to some workers at 1 January instead of 1 July. Of course, that is a benefit to those workers. It will enhance their retirement income, particularly for those who are close to retirement, for whom those six months will be a considerable period of their remaining working lives. No-one can pretend that anybody's retirement income will be transferred by one per cent over six months—that is not the case—but it is important and it is positive.

However, if the deathbed conversion that Dr Hewson has reported tonight in terms of changing Fightback should by some sad miracle result in the Opposition being elected next year, then what we are talking about is deferring the increase from 4 to 5 per cent for three years until we can defeat the lot opposite, throw them out and start the process of getting a decent retirement income system in place again. They would freeze the rate at whatever it is when they get in. What they want to do is make it 4 per cent, not 5 per cent. So it is much more significant than it appears. It is also significant in terms of symbolism: it symbolises the whole contrast in approaches to superannuation, between compulsion and voluntarism.

The trouble with the voluntary approach is that, for all the high-minded rhetoric, there is not a skerrick of evidence in Australian history or around the world that it will work. It is an ideological binge that says, `This is what we think should work. If only people would read the economic textbooks, they would know this is the way it should work'. The trouble is that it never has and it never will. Voluntarism certainly will not and cannot deliver to lower income workers who do not have discretionary income with which to save, irrespective of the incentive.

This will mean that we have an unfair voluntary system put on top of a very small compulsory system that is not large enough to drive decent retirement incomes for lower income earners. It will make the policy that is proposed by the Opposition even more unfair than it would be if it goes ahead as planned without this regulation being disallowed.

Thirdly, it is important that, notwithstanding the cynical remarks of Senator Alston, we give recognition to the very significant wage restraint that has been shown by the trade union movement and the workers of Australia for the last decade and in particular for the last 12 months or so. The accord partners have given their commitment to work towards wage outcomes consistent with keeping Australia's inflation rate at a level comparable with those of our major trading partners, which we are achieving. On each occasion in the past when those commitments have been made, they have been kept.

There is no reason to suspect that this will not be the case. That restraint continues to be shown. Every time it is proposed in recognition of that to have some enhancement of other benefits, to those opposite it is never the right time. They say, `Don't do it now. The workers don't deserve it'. We never get support from the Opposition for any proposal that means enhanced benefits to Australian workers. I accept that from time to time the Democrats get put in the gun because we know the Opposition will never support anything that delivers improved benefits to Australian workers, and it never has. The rhetoric sometimes changes about why, but the Opposition never supports it. It has never supported a wage increase. It has never supported an improvement in wages; it has never supported any increase in working conditions. Each time the Opposition puts forward a proposal it is to cut something away; never to enhance it.

The Government has made it clear that we intend to pursue and persist with a policy of wage restraint. The Government has offered the ACTU support for either a modest general wage increase or a $10 increase in minimum award rates targeted at lower paid workers payable from March 1993. The Government has expressed a very clear preference for the second alternative, which would apply to only about one-third of wage and salary earners and which would assist in maintaining low inflation. It would provide special assistance to lower paid workers and an incentive for workers and their unions to participate in productivity-based workplace bargaining. The Government is confident that the ACTU will honour its longstanding commitment to low inflation outcomes, and we will support its preferred option for an increase targeted at lower paid workers.

Significant wage restraint has been shown, and it is time we gave some recognition to that. As I said, I know that the bogey about the 10,000 jobs will be trotted out. We could have written that already. It was on the cue cards because at the Estimates hearings Senator Alston asked a question with ridiculous assumptions built into it which was designed to get that answer. Treasury came back and said, `The assumptions are ridiculous. We do not think they are in any way reasonable'. But if all those absurd assumptions were to come true, it is true that the outcome Senator Alston predicts might occur. But it is extremely unlikely because the assumptions are so extraordinary.

Many employers are already paying 5 per cent. There are already employers out there—a large number of good corporate citizens—who have been contributing this and more for many years, and they are paying tax twice. In effect, they are paying for the superannuation for their own employees and they are paying tax to fund the retirement income of the employees of their competitors who are not doing the right thing. We are saying that it is time that the double jeopardy for those people ceased and that they had to provide only for their own employees. It is time their competitors had to do the same, and it is time that they had to be responsible employers and good corporate citizens as well. It is time we gave some recognition to those good corporate citizens.

I know people are concerned about the accumulation of imposts upon employers and they see the dual operation of the superannuation guarantee and the training guarantee as an unreasonable burden. But at the end of the day both are designed in the hope that there will be such compliant behaviour that people will not be paying the levy. In the case of the training guarantee, that is clearly what is happening. In the last financial year for which data is available, which is 1990-91, the level of compliance was so high that only $3m was paid to the Tax Office under the training guarantee levy. Very few people are paying, and it is scarcely an impost at all. It is true that some people want us to look at what training might be funded to comply with the levy requirements, and if that is something that needs to be done in the future we are prepared to look at it.

Let us come back to the key issue. It is always the case that the conservatives argue it is never the right time to provide an improvement in living standards or any improvement in working conditions for Australian employees. We are saying that this is a very important social reform. It is important about retirement income, national savings, delivering some recognition to workers for the wage restraint they have given and for going about the process of cooperative change in Australia. Therefore, the regulations should not be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was a very difficult decision for the Democrats to make. We did consider the economic indicators, imposts on business and wages outcome, all of which factors are relevant. We will not be supporting the disallowance, but only because we believe that we have negotiated a better outcome for business. We have negotiated with the Government and the ACTU to contain total labour costs, which is the other important element in the superannuation charge equation. It is not possible to look at one impost on business in isolation as Senator Alston is trying to do.
—Why five weeks ago did you say that we couldn't afford it?

—The fact of the matter is that real wages growth over the past 10 years has been extremely low. If workers are denied adequate superannuation, obviously there will be a substantial wages claim to compensate for this. Senator Alston and I do not have much control over that, but by linking any increase in superannuation with an agreed upon wages outcome, I assert that business will be better off. Privately Senator Alston knows that many businesses concede the benefit of managed wage outcomes.

PARA.TAB: A one per cent SGC increase translates to one-third of one per cent of total wage costs. That, plus a delayed wage claim targeted to only one-third of the work force—low income earners and those most vulnerable, including many women—is an excellent outcome. It is a very low aggregate wage outcome. Total labour costs determine employment and unemployment, not one factor in isolation like the SGC, as Senator Alston well knows.

The question arising from Senator Alston's misrepresentation relates to the impact an SGC increase will have on employment. I will quote from Access Economics' Murphy model, the Opposition's beloved model. The Murphy model has been used to quantify the first year—the year-one effect of the SGC. It assumes the Alston line of no wage offsets, which we know is an absurd assumption and is untrue. Senator Alston tried this back in June. He talked about 100,000 jobs and 10,000 jobs this time, totally misrepresenting what Treasury said about the assumptions in the model that he asked for.

Assuming no wage offsets, the Murphy model found that in the first 12 months after the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge, there would be only a minor impact on jobs. That is even with Senator Alston's assumption. To minimise even that minor impact, it is necessary to recognise that the demand side of the labour market is driven by total labour costs. At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Treasury response to Senator Alston.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston *Hansard page B521* asked for an estimate of the employment losses that would flow if the prospective increase in the SGC from 4 per cent to 5 per cent is borne purely as an increase in employers' costs rather than being borne by employees?

The assumption specified in the question is not regarded as realistic. Increasingly in the new wage setting environment wage increases are being determined at the enterprise level. This allows total remuneration for employees to be determined according to the financial capacity of individual enterprises based on a range of factors, including improvements in productivity. In such circumstances it would be unrealistic to assume that real unit labour costs in such enterprises would necessarily increase as a result of an increase in the SGC from 4 to 5 per cent.

In addition, even in circumstances where wage increases are determined through more centralised arrangements it is reasonable to assume that total labour costs, including wages and superannuation, will be a guiding consideration. Accordingly, the cost of the SGC is likely to be largely, if not fully, offset by lower growth in other forms of remuneration, especially wages. In this regard the Government indicated in the `One Nation' Statement that the scope for wages growth from other sources will necessarily be lower as a result of introducing the SGC than would otherwise be the case.

If the unrealistic assumption is made that increasing the SGC from 4 to 5 per cent would be fully reflected in higher real unit labour costs, economic modelling suggests that employment would be about 10,000 lower after two years than would otherwise be the case. It is stressed, however, that the significance of this result is only as meaningful as the validity of the assumption on which the result is based.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the ACTU made a public commitment to act responsibly by further delaying any wage claim until at least 1 March next year and then to make that claim targeted to low income earners, that is, 30 per cent of the work force and those most in need of an increase in disposable income.

PARA.TAB: Because of the inability of the Opposition to negotiate with these nasty stereotypical unions and because of its blinkered opposition at all costs, the coalition delivers to business an unknown, risky outcome. In the short term, this may be to the benefit of some businesses, but in the long term when times improve I guarantee that businesses will seek the protection of managed aggregate wage outcomes.

That is not to say that unemployment is not a serious problem. It is serious, but it is structural unemployment. Senator Alston will find that many of the unemployed in Australia are middle-aged Australian males who have been retrenched because of technological change. No unemployment can be laid solely at the feet of the superannuation guarantee charge.

The coalition wants to disallow this increase because it opposes any increase in guaranteed superannuation for ordinary Australians. Senator Alston quoted what I said on 28 October. A lot has happened since 28 October, not to mention Senator Alston's totally politically motivated backflip by which he denied one million Australians the capacity to top up their award super by voting with the Government to eliminate tax deductibility of personal superannuation. One small way some of these Australians can be compensated for this totally callous and cynical move is for them to get the one per cent increase six months earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's happened to make us afford it now?

—Senator Alston should stop messing around with the retirement income of one million Australians. It is no good Senator Alston reversing his decision because 2,800 people are already bailing out of their policies and paying the exit fees now.
—We are not reversing it. We never contemplated reversing it.

—They will not join up again should the Liberal Party win government. Let us not forget in this debate that we are talking about only those employers with a pay roll in excess of $1m. Small businesses—and this really bears repeating—are completely exempted from this rise for a further two years. So what will this money be used for? It will increase total retirement savings and provide capital for business to borrow and invest. The Democrats believe that some of this capital should be put aside for cheap development capital to promote employment in Australia for Australian-owned small businesses.

PARA.TAB: Finally, this money will improve the retirement lifestyle of millions of retired Australians and consequently reduce pension outlays. If we do not do this now, then employers will simply have to pay it out as future wage rises. The Opposition is always saying in this chamber how terrible business oncosts are and how much lower oncosts are in New Zealand.

I would like to add breadth to that debate by looking at the international comparison. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard figures from the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, which show that, far from having high oncosts—and Senator Alston is arguing that this is another oncost to add to the already high oncost of business—Australia is internationally quite low.
Leave granted.
