TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true to assert that these oncosts make us internationally uncompetitive. In fact, the GST proposes a 15 per cent oncost on every sale in Australia. That is not to say that the issue of imposts on business is not important or not worthy of examination. It is important, and the Democrats have argued for 15 years that payroll tax is stupid and should be removed.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, we think it is time for a serious review of the training guarantee levy. It was a good idea, but it seems to us that perhaps its time has passed. Corporate culture towards training has changed and we believe it is time for an objective review of this levy. I propose a reference on this to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

In summary, the whole premise of this disallowance motion has been based on the deliberately misleading use of Treasury calculations by Senator Alston. In reality, voting against this motion will lead to lower aggregate wage outcomes. That is what has changed; guaranteeing lower aggregate wage outcomes is what has changed. That is better for business, it is about protecting jobs, it is reducing the risks, it is guaranteeing lower aggregate wage outcomes and higher retirement incomes. Despite all Senator Alston has said, the fact remains that Access Economics has said that the SGC, in its first year, will have a minor impact on jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the motion moved by my colleague Senator Richard Alston to disallow the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Charge Percentage) Regulations contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 288. The intention of this regulation is to increase from 4 per cent to 5 per cent the superannuation guarantee levy on employers with payrolls of $1m or more. The purpose of Senator Alston's motion is to disallow this increase.

PARA.TAB: Australian business does not need to be reminded that this additional impost is a further wrecker for business. Australia is suffering its worst recession in 60 years, with the unemployment level over 10 per cent. The last thing that business really needs is policies which undermine the capacity of employers not only to expand their enterprise but also to continue employing people.

The statistics from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry are chill reminders of the depth of this recession at present. There is not a lot of confidence out there. This increase is another nail in the coffin—a further impost. This Government is familiar with loading businesses and employers with increased costs—not only the superannuation guarantee levy. We have to contrast that with John Hewson's Fightback package which is taking off a lot of costs, including some of these, particularly the payroll tax. When one sees the penetration of New Zealand goods and businesses into the Australian market, it is cool testimony to the impact that all these indirect charges are having on Australian business.

We are becoming less competitive and that means our standard of living is falling. Senator Cook, the Government's Minister for Industrial Relations, has estimated the outstanding amount needed to be paid within six months is $700m. One can divide that figure by average earnings and that sort of thing to give some idea of the number of jobs and the cost to business involved.

We have seen another situation where the Democrats have changed their minds. When we were examining this whole concept previously they got a lot of publicity by stating that business could not afford this increase. They have now allegedly done another deal—another shabby deal—with the Government. Contrast that with what the Liberal Party is offering. We are providing incentive for people—employees—to invest in insurance as a form of saving. We are providing long term concessions; this Labor Government is taking away concessions, and that is unfortunate.

The Australian Democrats' deal with the Government is allegedly to contain real wage costs. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that these statements are nothing more than pie in the sky plans. They talk about managed wage increases. I do not think the community out there in the real world, outside this artificial atmosphere we have here, really believes this. It defies political reality. It contains the seeds of further economic and social disaster. Living standards are declining in this country.

If Australia is to become competitive, if we are going to turn around from this deep, sad depression which so few people in this chamber seem to feel the economic effects of, we have to do something better. We have to become truly competitive as quickly as possible. We are doing everything possible at the present time to hinder that turnaround. We must do everything possible to try to improve and lower our export cost structure, not make increases.

I remind honourable senators of the minority report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which was examining the superannuation guarantee Bills some weeks ago. Even the ardent advocates of compulsory superannuation, such as National Mutual, were concerned that legislated contribution levels make no allowance for the capacity of various employers and industry to meet these requirements. The legislated approach assumes that everybody can pay the higher rates at the same point in time, and this is the cardinal point that both the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party have missed. This burden is falling entirely on employers, unlike every other compulsory system in the world. Of course, some employers have a better capacity to pass that on than other employers. It is unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the disallowance motion moved by Senator Alston. The debate tonight is about the proposed increase from 4 per cent to 5 per cent of the superannuation guarantee levy for employers with a payroll of greater than $1m. That movement from 4 to 5 per cent is part of a phase-in of the superannuation guarantee levy of up to 9 per cent by the year 2002, and during the period up to the year 2002 there will be an additional 3 per cent contribution by employees. It is a very responsible way to address a very serious problem.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, of which I am Chairman, carried out an international survey of 23 countries around the world. Interestingly, there were only two countries—New Zealand and Australia; New Zealand has had a bit of a run tonight from Senator Watson—which did not have, in any true sense, a properly funded national pension or superannuation fund. That is what this Government has done; it has established a national pension superannuation fund.

When we looked at the international comparisons, we found that the average level of employer contribution in most comparable countries around the world was approximately 11 per cent—some were more. The average employee contribution was between 4 and 5 per cent. What the Government has proposed here and is phasing in is not, by international comparisons, onerous or unduly harsh or high.

One of the interesting aspects about this increase is that the Government has chosen to phase it in over a period of 10 years. It is a very responsible approach to a serious problem. Many of the countries overseas, such as Germany, France and Italy, introduced measures of this sort when economic circumstances were far worse than they are in this country at present. So the approach is very responsible and it has been aided and assisted by the Democrats.

Members of the Opposition constantly used the terminology `shady deals'. Occasionally, I agree with Senator Kernot—more often than not we agree than disagree when sitting on our Committee on superannuation—but I always believe her motives and her principles to be correct. I do not think it does any good to this very important debate to talk about shady deals behind closed doors. It is just not the way it works. The Democrats have accepted this measure as a critical measure to ensure that we have adequate savings for retirement in 30 or 40 years time when the number of persons in the work force will decline rapidly and the number of persons over the age of 65 will double. It is a very important measure.

New Zealand has been mentioned by Senator Watson. Interestingly, after this measure has been effected in Australia, New Zealand will be the only country of the 23 we surveyed which does not have an appropriate tax or funding of its pension system. What has happened in New Zealand—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has GST and likes it.
—What about Canada? If Senator Walters wants to delude herself that the goods and services tax is going to be popular here, let her do so and we will see what happens at the next election.

PARA.TAB: New Zealand does not fund its retirement pension funds. Every government of both political shades—National and Labor—before each election has promised increases in pensions, grossly irresponsibly. New Zealand has a very good pension system, with very high levels of benefits, but it is not funded. As a consequence, the National Government, when it was elected 18 months ago, attempted to reduce and restrict the pay-out of its pensions because it cannot continue the ever increasing load on its budget. It is important to look at the New Zealand example and the fact that New Zealand is having to tackle this issue, because it does not fund its pension system, by trying to significantly reduce the pay-outs.

There are a number of other issues related to this measure. The Opposition relies on voluntarism. It argues that if sufficient incentives are provided, people will voluntarily save for their retirement. It does not work. We had great incentives in the tax system prior to 1983 and only 40 per cent of people saved. If the Opposition is elected to government, its policy will be to hold the levy at this level. I do not think it will be elected to government. Should that occur, the administration charges in these funds—which are flat charges in the main—will be quite a high proportion of the superannuation guarantee paid into the funds.

Finally, I seek leave to incorporate a document in Hansard indicating the increase in the membership of funds since the superannuation guarantee charge was introduced. It indicates that employers are making the contributions nine months ahead of schedule in a responsible manner.
Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: SEX DISCRIMINATION AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and amendment Nos 2, 11 and 21, as moved by Senator Hill. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in the middle of explaining what the problems were with these amendments before the suspension of the sitting for lunch. Returning to the substance of these amendments, I stress again that the Industrial Relations Commission has expertise in awards but not expertise in the area of discrimination while the Sex Discrimination Commissioner has expertise in discrimination but not in awards. Surely, it seems a sensible process to get the two together, and this is exactly what the Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Bill does.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the Opposition has failed to grasp that there are two aspects to the complaints process: the alleged discriminatory act and the possibility of the alleged discriminatory award. If I can go through the process again, a complaint about a discriminatory act under an award can be made to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Secondly, arising out of that initial complaint, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner can follow up the separate issue of a discriminatory award by referring it to the Industrial Relations Commission. As I said, this process seems to be appropriate. The Democrats will therefore not be supporting the Opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to the Committee earlier in the consideration of the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 that the object of the Bill is to try to ensure that those discriminatory acts which can be undertaken in accordance with awards are removed from the Australian workplace and employer-employee relationships. It is fair to point out that this legislation, which will apply only to new awards and award variations, will be of a protective and preventative character.

PARA.TAB: Over the years the Industrial Relations Commission has required parties to address any cases where award provisions discriminate against sections of the work force. A considerable amount has been done to eliminate some types of practices that could be regarded as discriminatory on the grounds of sex. There is no doubt that with enterprise bargaining and the evolution of certified agreements, which are not subject to the same degree of scrutiny by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as are awards, it has been thought to be very useful to incorporate machinery within the Act so that complaints will be able to be made to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission alleging that a person has been discriminated against under an award or certified agreement, which is captured by the definition of `award'.

If it appears to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner that the award is discriminatory, the Commissioner must refer the award to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. That would generally be true. The Commission will then convene a hearing to review the award. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner will have standing to appear before the Commission. If the Commission is of the view that the award operates in a discriminatory way, it will be required to take whatever action is necessary to remove the discrimination, unless it considers that a variation would not be in the public interest.

These sorts of machinery mechanisms—including a recognition that a certified agreement is made in a way which makes it appropriate that the parties ought to be given a chance to renegotiate the certified agreement before the Industrial Relations Commission moves in a heavy way to remove the discriminatory provision—are entirely consistent with the attempt to ensure that throughout the employment market in Australia discriminatory provisions that depend on the employee's sex are eliminated. I believe that this provision is very worth while and ought to be supported by the Committee. The Government will reject the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I was heartened when Senator Lees put some questions to me. I thought it meant that if I was persuasive the Democrats might support us. She has announced tonight that the Democrats will oppose the amendment without hearing my answers, so I do not know whether there is much point in rising. No doubt she will say afterwards that she was not persuaded in any event.

PARA.TAB: I would like to think that where discriminatory provisions do exist in current awards a party to those awards would seek change. According to current practices, one would expect the Industrial Relations Commission to take account of the desire to remove discriminations and the problem is solved. From what the Minister said, I thought he was in effect agreeing that that would be the case. One therefore has to ask the question: why do we need the mechanism of a complaint to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and a further mechanism for the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to appear before the IRC to put a case? That seems to me to be unnecessary. It is quaint having a commissioner in one jurisdiction appearing to argue a case on principle before the Commission in another jurisdiction. Quaint though it might be, what is more important is that it seems to me to be unnecessary.

That is why we were not persuaded that these new initiatives the Government has included within the Bill are necessary or, in the sense of having one quasi-judicial officer before another, even desirable. That is why we proposed this amendment to remove them. I do not think we are in a very different position either in spirit or in our objectives. We just doubt that the mechanism the Government has adopted is necessary to achieve the goal it is seeking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister a question. I refer to page 12 of the Bill, which relates to the amendments to the Industrial Relations Act. The subsection proposed to be inserted after subsection 113(2) of the principal Act states:

PARA.TAB: (2A) If:
(a)an award has been referred to the Commission under section 50A of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984; and
(b)the Commission considers that the award is a discriminatory award;

SPEECH.PARA: the Commission must take the necessary action to remove the discrimination, by setting aside the award, setting aside terms of the award or varying the award.

As indicated by Senator Lees, `removing the discrimination' has been determined by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. She has determined that prima facie there is a discriminatory provision in the award. Can the Minister tell me whether I am right thus far?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a determination of the matter. It is just that it appears to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner that that is the case.

—I thank the Minister. I think I used too strong a word. Nevertheless, it is to identify discrimination in a particular award. The question I ask is a practical example. If there are provisions in a particular award relating to the carrying and lifting of weights and a certain limit is set to protect women workers, would that be regarded as a discriminatory provision? I want to know whether a provision in an award which sets a limit in respect of the weights to be lifted by women would be regarded as a discriminatory provision.

—An award which restricted the tasks that could be performed by a female by reference to the maximum weight which she should be permitted to lift could appear to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to be discriminatory. That would allow the matter to be taken to the Industrial Relations Commission, which would itself then make a determination with the benefit of any argument that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner would put. A decision would then be made as to whether the award should be varied or, in the case of a certified agreement, whether the parties should negotiate a new agreement, taking account of the determination by the Industrial Relations Commission.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Commission could find that, despite the fact that the award was discriminatory in those terms in preventing women from undertaking certain tasks because of a different maximum weight that they could be permitted to lift, it was nevertheless in the public interest that the provision remain. That is always a possibility under the new subclause. In general that is the way I think it would work.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting construction but it does not answer the question that I asked. I did not ask whether the provision was discriminatory in the sense that it prevented women from taking particular jobs. That was not the question. In most awards there are a number of provisions, and amongst those are classification provisions which classify the particular areas of work for which particular payments are made pursuant to the award. A particular rate of pay is applicable for those particular classifications.

PARA.TAB: This was the whole argument that was adduced when equal pay for work of equal value was being considered in the late 1960s. I was one of the first to obtain equal pay for work of equal value in a particular award. I remember arguing the case before the 1967 or 1969 ACTU Congress when the ACTU executive, of which I was a member at that stage, recommended to the Congress that the policy be equal pay for work of equal value. A section of the Congress proposed that that should be equal pay for equal work—namely, having to lift the same weights and working under the same conditions in order to qualify for the equal pay.

In the Public Service, for example, at that time certain senior filing clerks were getting more than a stenographer. Because of our policy that went through the ACTU Congress, the equal pay for work of equal value meant that in the consideration of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, as it was then, and that of other authorities, the work of a stenographer was of greater value than the work of a senior filing clerk. Therefore the stenographer got more money.

I am asking the Minister a genuine question because I know that there have been these provisions in a number of instruments that cover workers. I do not want to see this legislation being used to undermine the protection that unions have obtained for their women members. I am very conscious of this—particularly in regard to shops, for example. It is important that there be some sort of legislative protection which prevents an employer from insisting, for example, that a girl shop assistant, together with another girl shop assistant, lug a roll of lino across the shop.

If these provisions are in the awards or, as has been the case, if they are in State legislation, I certainly do not want to see the sex discrimination legislation override those protective provisions. I do wish to know, and I think the Minister should tell the Committee, how many of those awards are likely to be affected. This legislation does not appear to reach into State legislation, but how many awards are there and which ones have such protective provisions which could possibly be affected by this legislation, well-meaning as it is?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has raised some interesting matters, particularly in relation to the evolution of the recognition of the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. This was a primary concern of his and he was a pioneer in the field. That ought to be noted and acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the Bill itself, the new provisions which are the concern of the Committee at the moment operate only prospectively, only into the future, in relation to new awards or new certified agreements that might be made. They do not affect current awards. If one looks at clause 4, Application of Amendments, one sees that subclause (4) provides that the amendments relating to the review of discriminatory awards by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are to apply to awards and variations to awards made after the commencement of the Act. To that extent it preserves the current provisions, such as there are, that might be of the type which Senator Harradine would describe as protective, but which from another point of view might be regarded as discriminatory. It does not affect those current awards.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing the question of discriminatory awards and the industrial relations system, I believe that we should also look at the approach by the unions to this whole question of discrimination. I was minded to do that because of the outburst from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) this afternoon at Question Time about the effect on women of the Opposition's industrial relations policy. The sad thing is that for many years in this country the unions have virtually ignored female workers. There have been some notable exceptions, but if one talks to women in the union movement, one finds general agreement that there has been a most unsatisfactory failure of unions to represent working women.

PARA.TAB: The unions have certainly started to take a bit more notice of women lately, which seems to coincide with a drop in union membership generally in the private sector. From the union leadership's point of view, it has been a fairly alarming drop in membership. Women have never been all that enthusiastic about union membership. The compulsion of it may have something to do with that.

I was recently at a conference about discrimination against women and equal employment opportunities in the workplace where the union movement was criticised roundly by both a former industrial relations commissioner for not having taken matters of importance to women before that Commission over the years and the Sex Discrimination Commissioner for not having supported female union members in taking cases before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. One of the real black marks against the union movement is that so many women have taken cases of various kinds before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner without the support of their unions. It is no wonder that women start to wonder what relevance there is in union membership. This question of discrimination in awards should not surprise anybody when the union movement has been so insensitive or so little attuned to the needs of women in the workplace.

That is also the failure of the Federal Government, which, as we know, has a heavy reliance upon the union movement. Its Ministers and backbenchers are members of unions even to this day. It reflects this blind spot, if you like, towards the working women of Australia. Unfortunately, nearly 400,000 women are not working any more; they are unemployed women of Australia—women who would be in the paid work force if they possibly could be. There are about 700,000 more women who are either marginally attached to the work force or who fit into other categories, according to the ABS, such as discouraged job seekers.

Both the union mates and the Labor Government have failed women in terms of the workplace. It is interesting that the Lavarch Committee reported in Half Way to Equal on a wide range of issues affecting women. It made recommendations concerning the need for flexibility of working hours and leave provisions in both awards and enterprise bargaining. We have not seen any move by this Government to pick up these recommendations. It has picked up about seven of the 79 recommendations. A number of them related to women in the workplace. All we have here is a fairly esoteric area relating to so-called discriminatory awards.

When one recalls the flourish with which we heard the Government endorse the ILO convention into the needs of workers with family responsibilities, it is interesting to consider its lack of real action in protecting workers with family responsibilities, many of whom are women, in terms of flexibility of hours, flexibility of conditions and opportunities to get workplace contracts which meet their personal needs. These are the sorts of entitlements which will be available to women with the introduction of the Opposition's industrial relations policies. These are the liberating forces which will be available to women once the Opposition wins office. As we saw today in Question Time, the Minister for Industrial Relations tried to take a very misleading swipe at our industrial relations policy as part of what is clearly a campaign by the Government to put fear into the minds of Australian men and women as to the effect of the Opposition's policies on them personally.

It is true to say that the past industrial relations system in this country has not been female friendly. It is quite clear that the record of both the union movement and the Labor Government has not been woman friendly, even family friendly. As I said, we hear a great number of scare stories about how bad a coalition government will be for women. I have been on platforms around this country where members of the Labor Party and their friends in the union movement have tried this scare tactic about how bad our industrial relations policy will be for women workers. We continually hear the cry about vulnerable women and how they will be unable to survive in a new environment. Of course, it is a lot of garbage. I have always maintained that that puts down women and that it denies their natural ability to survive by their skills of negotiation and the skills which they achieve both in the playground—perhaps through lack of muscle power; they certainly have the power of the tongue—and in family situations where they have an innate ability to negotiate the competing demands of family members. From my experience, I have no doubt that women will be able to overcome any possibility of discrimination in the workplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, we have three amendments before the Chair. Any comment in the Committee should be related to those amendments. You are making a second reading speech.
—I believe that the amendments that we are looking at relate—
—It's a good one!
—Senator Brownhill, I do not care whether it is a good one or a bad one, it is out of order.

—In speaking to the question of discriminatory awards, I believe that it is important to set the scene of the current industrial relations system for women workers and to contrast that with what could be an alternative under an alternative government. The Director of the Office of the Status of Women in my home State of Tasmania has been reported in the last week as saying that those who voiced concern about the capacity of women to negotiate their wages and conditions were talking down women skills. Ms Liz Little talked about the implications of enterprise bargaining and said that women were excellent negotiators.
—Senator Newman, you are out of order. If you do not come back to the three amendments before the Chair, you will have to take your seat.

—Mr Chairman, I acknowledge your ruling. I recognise that the Government sees the amendments which it has before the chamber tonight as somehow redressing the wrongs which have been done to women employees over many years. I say to the chamber that nothing of the sort will be achieved by these amendments. What is needed is a total change in the industrial relations system.

PARA.TAB: From this Government, women of Australia can expect more of the same—a tired government which is bereft of policies and a government which is tied up in an unholy alliance to its union bosses. The union bosses are not elected by the voters of Australia but carry enormous power. They have shown no interest in the women workers until very recently, as I said before. All this Government can offer women workers and unemployed workers is unfounded fear of the coalition's policies based on a scare campaign. In contrast, the Opposition offers hope for the future for both the women themselves and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Harradine, the Chair will not accept any further second reading speeches.

—Mr Chairman, I am sorry that you will not accept a rebuttal of the widespread unfounded allegations that the Committee has just heard from Senator Newman. I would like Senator Newman, and more particularly the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), since we are dealing with discriminatory awards, to give the chamber an example or some examples. If it is a major issue, they should give us some examples.

PARA.TAB: We have been asked to adopt provisions in respect of discrimination in awards. I stand here quite clear in my conscience that, for the organisation of which I am the president, there are no awards in which there is discrimination or discriminatory practices. Indeed, the membership of the elected State council of our organisation is predominantly women. I only wish that two of the women industrial officers in Tasmania were here; they would be able to respond quite vigorously to what Senator Newman has said.

I think it is legitimate for me to ask a direct question about this amendment to the Sex Discrimination Bill which deals with discriminatory awards. I ask, first of all, for Senator Newman to give us an example of discrimination in awards. More particularly, I would like the Minister to give us some examples of discriminatory provisions in any award.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Harradine's remarks concerning the way in which women in the work force have been assisted by the membership of trade unions.
—Ask the women!

—I will go out and ask the women, and I believe that I will get a response in accordance with the experience they have had in certain industries. Senator Harradine's question, which is a fair one, nevertheless does not give enough weight to what I was saying: that over the last several years the Industrial Relations Commission has required the parties to address questions of discrimination, and many discriminatory provisions in awards have been removed as a result of that process.

PARA.TAB: This particular provision is prospective; it looks to the future. It looks to awards or variations of awards, certified agreements and so on—particularly certified agreements. Under enterprise bargaining pressures, the final agreement that is reached may contain provisions that hark back to those sorts of clauses and provisions that have been removed over the last several years due to the action of unions taking these matters before the Industrial Relations Commission, or the Industrial Relations Commission itself requiring the parties to deal with such matters. There are old examples, if you like, in Federal awards—awards with restrictions on the working of overtime by women—

TALK.START.PARA: —They went out about 12 years ago.

—Yes, but we want to make sure that they do not creep back—awards restricting the working of shift work by women or providing for males only to do the shift work; awards with certain allowances applying to males only or providing that an allowance for females is less than for males—for example, 75 per cent of the male rate—and so on. I agree with Senator Harradine's general comment that a lot of these went out the window a long time ago. This is simply being provided in the Bill as a protective and pre-emptive measure so that, if these matters come back within awards or certified agreements, a person can take the matter to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, get the assistance of the Commissioner's assessment of the matter, and take it before the Industrial Relations Commission for determination.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

This second group of amendments relate to our concerns about representative complaints. I mentioned earlier that the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Race Discrimination Act 1975 and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 already contain provisions with respect to representative complaints. These amendments have been designed by the Government to bring procedures into line with those in the Federal Court Amendment Act 1992, which we passed a short while ago. We objected to those provisions at that time and we object to these for the same reasons.

PARA.TAB: We do not support the opt-out system whereby people are automatically joined to an action by virtue of being members of the class described, without their knowledge or consent, and where it is up to individuals to specifically opt out. An individual's right to take action is distinguished by the class action. In our assessment, it is totally contrary to the notions of justice to have individual rights subsumed by those of a class in this way. Therefore, we are moving these amendments to omit from the Bill the provisions relating to representative complaints.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —No amount of discussion on these amendments will convince the Democrats to support them. We have always been strong supporters of representative or class action and we will be remaining so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will, of course, oppose these amendments put by the Opposition.
—Naturally; you are anti-business. You want to kill small business.

—`Why wouldn't you oppose it?' might be a better question. We went through this argument with the amendments to the Federal Court Act in relation to representative procedures, and the world has not collapsed on the business community of Australia as a result of the passage of that Bill.
—Have a look at the bankruptcies.
—That has nothing to do with the representative actions procedure, and Senator Macdonald knows it.
—It will.

—I think Senator Macdonald is just muttering away there, without giving any attention to the real impact of this procedure. This procedure will allow for complaints to be dealt with in the one proceeding by several persons who are affected by a particular discriminatory action. I think even Senator Macdonald would recall that, in the early 1980s, 34 women had sought employment as steelworkers with Australian Iron and Steel in Wollongong. They had sought employment, they had been denied it, and they brought complaints under the New South Wales Act. The New South Wales Equal Opportunity Tribunal found that the employment practices of the company relating to job vacancies for women, threat of retrenchment and actual retrenchment were discriminatory. This involved the necessary conclusion that not only the individual complainants but also other women in similar circumstances had been discriminated against.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry undertaken was initially restricted to dealing with the individual complaints, presumably because damages, which the complainants were seeking, could not be obtained in a representative complaint. If the representative complaints were to have been pursued and damages sought, individual complaints would have had to be lodged. I mention that case because it is well known to many people. I believe it indicates the worth of a procedure which would allow the complaints to be dealt with in the one proceeding and all the relief sought, including damages, to be granted.

We will maintain our policy in relation to these representative actions. We believe also that we are not being particularly revolutionary; representative complaints procedures are also to be found in State discrimination legislation. I believe that the improvement that is to be incorporated by these amendments ought to be supported.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Schedule, page 8, amendments of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, proposed new subsection 4A(2), after definition of `child', insert:

SPEECH.PARA: "`de facto spouse', in relation to a person, includes a person of the same sex as the first-mentioned person who lives with the first-mentioned person on a bona fide domestic basis;".

In moving this amendment, I refer to proposed section 4A of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1992 which provides for a definition of family responsibilities, which is somewhat widely drawn. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the Australian Democrats welcome the provision and believe it is long overdue to ensure that employers cannot discriminate against employees who have family responsibilities and, in particular, may not dismiss them. However, the definition of spouse in the Bill includes a former spouse, a de facto spouse and a former de facto spouse.

PARA.TAB: On the basis of that definition, I assume that it also includes de facto spouses where both persons are of the same sex. I checked that with the Minister's office, to be told that that was not the Government's intention and that the amendments were based on ILO convention No. 156 and that that convention did not permit the Government to extend the definition in that way. However, ILO convention No. 156 is not mentioned anywhere in either the Bill or the explanatory memorandum. I have received high level advice from an impeccable source that it is open to the Government, and therefore to me in seeking to amend it, to use ILO convention No. 111 which quite clearly prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex, which is interpreted as meaning sexual preference.

I have moved this amendment because the Democrats recognise that there is a very great need in this area. The community is only too aware of the havoc wreaked by AIDS in our community and of the many occasions where partners are looking after their de facto spouses who are stricken with that disease. If ever there is a situation where such a provision should be used to protect them, to prevent employers from discriminating against them, it is this situation. I therefore commend the amendment to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs to be made clear that ILO convention No. 156—the full title of which is `A Convention Concerning Equal Opportunities and Equal Treatment for Men and Women Workers: Workers with Family Responsibilities'—which came into effect in March 1991, is mentioned in the second reading speech which accompanied the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment (No. 2) Bill as the foundation for the provision which has led to the definition which Senator Spindler has referred to concerning family responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, our legal advice is that the definition of family in ILO convention No. 156 is unlikely to include same sex partners. Therefore, we believe that we are restricted in our powers to cover same sex partners in legislation based on ILO convention No. 156—workers with family responsibilities. Further work is being done in these matters. If I heard Senator Spindler correctly, he was mainly concerned about discrimination against those who are living with HIV or AIDS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly including those.

—Yes, but I think Senator Spindler specifically mentioned that as a major concern, and perhaps also the carers of such people. I have not got a definitive legal opinion here, but I think it would be worth reflecting on the Disability Discrimination Bill that we passed through this Senate only a few weeks back which includes AIDS within the definition of disability and also provides that a person who cares for a person with a disability, which would therefore include AIDS, cannot be discriminated against in the terms and conditions of their employment on the basis of their care for the person with a disability. I believe that may give an opportunity for such a person to lodge a complaint with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission if he or she alleges that he or she has been discriminated against. But, basically, we did not believe that the legal basis for the sort of provision which Senator Spindler is moving is available to us on the basis of ILO convention No. 156. Therefore, we cannot support the amendment.

—I would like to ask the Minister whether he can give me any reason why ILO convention No. 111 could not be used as a basis for the amendment I have moved or whether the Government had intended to include that definition in the Bill.

—I am advised that there is consultation taking place on ILO convention No. 111, which deals with discrimination in employment and occupation, but that at the moment we are not in a position to say that would be a satisfactory basis for the sort of provision which Senator Spindler has moved this evening. The Act in which this amendment is being inserted is the Sex Discrimination Act, which does not cover sexual preference. Sexual preference discrimination in employment is covered by the functions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission under ILO convention No. 111. On determination in employment and occupation, the Commissioner can inquire into an attempt to conciliate on complaints of sexual preference discrimination and can make a report to the Minister. However, sexual preference discrimination is not unlawful.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we have to further consider and deliberate upon ILO convention No. 111. Sexual preference was not one of the grounds originally covered by ILO convention No. 111. It was declared an additional ground by Australia under a procedure provided for in the convention, but the Sex Discrimination Act itself does not depend on ILO convention No. 111; nor is that convention a schedule to the Sex Discrimination Act.

So I do not believe we have sufficient foundation within the ILO conventions to advance the sort of provision which Senator Spindler wishes to insert tonight. But, as I say, this particular convention will be the subject of further consultation to try to determine whether it has any more scope or possibility within it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister, with respect, has not offered any cogent reasons as to why ILO convention 111 could not be used as a basis for the amendment that I have moved. But I hear him say that further consultation is being undertaken by the Government. If that further consultation and research discloses that ILO convention 111 can be used in this way, will the Minister undertake that the Government would then be prepared to introduce an amendment to cover that situation?

—I believe that our responsibility at this stage of the deliberation and consideration of this matter is to determine the scope and power within ILO conventions 111 and 156. When we come to a definitive view as to that matter, we will then consider the policy issue, which may be able to be supported by those conventions.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —At two minutes past midnight this morning, I was asking the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) a question about the composition of the Refugee Review Tribunal. I wish now to pursue that question with the Minister in the committee stage. I asked the Minister why it was considered desirable for the refugee review tribunals to be single member tribunals. The Minister might correct me if I am wrong, but there appears from the legislation to be no ability to have more than one member on each tribunal. I contrasted this with the provisions in the same Bill in respect of the Immigration Review Tribunal, which can have more than one member. I just wondered what the reason for the difference was. Perhaps the Minister will explain the reason for the difference.

PARA.TAB: I also indicated that it is my advice that in Canada and New Zealand, for example, there are provisions for multi-member tribunals. The advantage of this is that persons on the tribunal can discuss the merits of the application with each other in a manner which enables them to come to a joint conclusion. I believe that the very fact that they have to come to a joint conclusion means that all of the aspects that have been presented to the tribunal by the applicants for refugee status will necessarily then be fully considered.

I am not saying that a single member tribunal may not do this, but there could well be the odd occasion where this takes place. So I just wonder about the rationale behind the provision of single member refugee review tribunals and, in particular, I wonder why the legislation does not enable multi-member tribunals to be established for particular cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was brought up around midnight last night. I think I had indicated that one has to recall that the single member Refugee Review Tribunal will provide, we hope, not only a workable but a qualitatively excellent means of review of decisions taken in relation to an application for recognition of refugee status. But the Refugee Review Tribunal member will be one of several such persons or tribunals and no doubt will have discussions from time to time with fellow tribunals—if that is the expression to use—about the sorts of cases that present themselves. They will have the benefit of discussions in that sense, although I know that it is not the exact sense that Senator Harradine means in relation to any particular matter or individual case that has to be determined by the Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: In addition, one operates within the context of the provision which allows a matter to be referred to the AAT so the general principles of importance and of high directive value to the Refugee Review Tribunal member can be laid down. In that way there will not be total isolation or the inability for a member to be properly affected by, for example, the way in which the AAT might indicate certain matters ought to be dealt with. The worth of the single member tribunal will lie in its capacity to deal speedily with a matter.

I suppose that the other side of the conversations which Senator Harradine refers to amongst tribunal members could be delay in the consideration of matters as those deliberations and discussions continue. In so far as one has a single member in relation to these matters, it will help speedy determination. But one hopes that under the method of guidance provided for by the AAT that will not be an inferior method of coming to decisions in this area. For that reason, the Government has thought that the single member Refugee Review Tribunal will be adequate to the task which is given to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up on that particular matter. I will leave the next series of questions until later which, incidentally, relate to the question of how.

PARA.TAB: I noticed an advertisement for members of this tribunal. It is interesting to note that advertisements are being placed prior to this legislation going through the Parliament—they were placed in the newspapers last week. The advertisement says:

SPEECH.PARA: Members will be individually responsible for hearing and determining cases. Members will be expected to have the ability to review fairly and quickly, through oral hearing, decisions unfavourable to the applicant. It is essential that Members demonstrate a sound understanding of administrative and international law, possess analytical and written and oral communication skills of the highest order and have a depth of awareness of international, political and cross-cultural issues.
I will be asking questions about the information that these people will get regarding the situation in the various countries from which the refugees who are applying for refugee status come.

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact, as has been indicated in this advertisement, that there will be approximately 30 of these appointments and that the salary package will be between $84,000 and $93,000 a year? That is for the members, not the principal member—the advertisement does not say what the principal member will get. Is that the situation? Who determined that level of remuneration? What are the types of individuals who are expected to apply for these particular positions? Is it expected that these positions will be long term positions?

I see that under the legislation their appointment is for two years. I ask the Minister: is two years appropriate to maintain a degree of independence? Which other tribunal members are appointed for a period of two years? I thought that the minimum appointment to tribunals was normally for a considerably longer period. Why is the period two years? Perhaps the Minister could answer those sorts of administrative questions before I yield to Senator Spindler.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the level of remuneration for the Refugee Review Tribunal members was determined by looking at the AAT and at an appropriate level for IRT members. I understand that that particular level of remuneration was considered to be appropriate by comparison with those other tribunals that I have mentioned.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine asked why two years was thought to be appropriate. The Government has given an undertaking that at the end of two years it will consider the question of whether the Refugee Review Tribunal system is operating as well as the Parliament and the Government hopes that it will. The question may well arise at the end of two years as to whether indeed the Refugee Review Tribunal ought to be merged into or subsumed within the Immigration Review Tribunal process. It was thought that the two-year operation of the Refugee Review Tribunal process would be sufficient time to allow that judgment to be made. As I understand it, that is why the two-year period was chosen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer the Minister to the High Court decision today in Lim v. Commonwealth in which section 54R of the Migration Act was invalidated. That section provides that a court is not to order the release from custody of a designated person. In that decision the High Court took the view that the High Court must be the authority to decide whether detention is, in fact, lawful or unlawful as a basis of that section. That provision was strenuously opposed by the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine and Senator Chamarette in May of this year. At that time all the speakers against that provision stated quite clearly that it was an unacceptable denial of basic legal rights of individuals for a court to be directed by this Parliament to find in a particular fashion.

PARA.TAB: I refer the Minister to the judgment of the High Court and I ask him whether, in the light of this judgment, the Government should not reconsider some of the amendments that are before the Senate in this Bill, in particular those amendments that limit the grounds for judicial review by the Federal Court. I put to the Minister that this is parallel with what the Government sought to achieve by section 54R. Should not the Government now withdraw those sections or, alternatively, agree to the Australian Democrats' amendments which remove those sections?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I must admit that, because of other obligations during the course of the day, I have not had a chance to closely read the decision by the High Court of Australia. If Senator Spindler is seeking to allow the Senate to note that at least a majority of the bench agreed with his prophecy of some months ago in relation to the fate of this section and its constitutional validity, then I am very willing to acknowledge that.

PARA.TAB: But the fact is that the decision on that point was to the effect that it is an inherent part of the judicial power that a court be able to exercise its jurisdiction to ensure that a person who is being unlawfully detained should be released. That is a very traditional concept, but a sufficiently narrow one not to have the further implications which would favour supporting Senator Spindler's remarks about the way in which the Federal Court might be given codified powers to replace the more general common law powers that flow from considerations of natural justice and procedural fairness.

I believe that the decision by the High Court ought to be greeted with proper deference—I am trying to think of a word which means that I think it is a proper and good decision to ensure that no Executive government can unlawfully detain a person without that person being able to approach a court to seek to be released. That is a good principle to have affirmed by the High Court.

The Bill before us does not deal with that matter. What it does deal with is, I think, given a lot of support and foundation by the Court's decision in relation to the other major questions before it. For example, Chief Justice Mason agreed and said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that authority to detain an alien in custody, when conferred in the context and for the purposes of executive powers to receive, investigate and determine an application by that alien for an entry permit and (after determination) to admit or deport, constitutes an incident of those executive powers and that such limited authority to detain an alien in custody can be conferred upon the Executive without contravening the investment of the judicial power of the Commonwealth in Ch.III courts.

I believe that that well sustains the major policy objective of this statute in regard to detention of those who arrive in Australia without valid entry permits. It allows for them to be detained and held in custody while there is a determination process to investigate the claims that may be made, for example, that refugee status be recognised.

PARA.TAB: Whilst this judgment is very important for delimiting the proper boundaries between the exercise of Executive power and the exercise of judicial power, the exercise of Executive power authorised or affirmed by the Court is really the substance of the policy of this Bill in regard to those who arrive on our shores without proper authority. The question Senator Spindler is raising is not squarely dealt with by this judgment today. As I say, it is a narrow but very important matter of affirming that no court can be ousted from its jurisdiction to determine that no person is held unlawfully in custody in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. I agree with him that the facts of Lim v. the Commonwealth are not squarely within the current amendments the Government is seeking to introduce. However, with respect, I disagree that that case is any authority for the proposition that the Executive decision should not be subject to judicial review or that that judicial review can be limited by the Executive government, which is what the Government is seeking to do through this Bill.

PARA.TAB: It was never at issue in the debate on this Bill that the Executive government does or does not have the right to make an Executive decision on whether a particular person is or is not a refugee within the definition of our legislation and whether that person should or should not be given a visa. What is at issue is whether such persons have the legal right—similar to appellants in other areas of the law—to have administrative decisions reviewed by a court, without the limitations that this Bill imposes. I put to the Minister that the very act of imposing a limitation on the court's capacity is very much like telling the court that it may not find in a particular way. It is very much a parallel situation. I believe that the Minister will find that he will pass a law today and will have to amend it tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say that there is a long-running battle between Parliament and the courts so far as the supervisory jurisdiction of the courts is concerned, not relating to unlawful detention but in relation to the observance of principles of natural justice or procedural fairness by persons who are required to undertake a task conferred upon them by a statute.

PARA.TAB: It is quite feasible for the Parliament to oust totally—if it can find appropriate and strong enough language—the supervisory jurisdiction of the courts. If it were to do that, the court would have to accept that. Therefore, a limitation on the supervisory jurisdiction of the court must also be possible to the Parliament, and I believe that it would survive any challenge. Senator Spindler and I have to disagree on the proper boundaries between the Parliament and the courts in relation to the supervisory jurisdiction about which we are speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a series of questions to do with the detention of unlawful non-citizens. I preface my questions with a comment on the point Senator Spindler put to the Minister. I do not think it is quite correct to say that the High Court's decision in the Lim case is not relevant to the discussion tonight. In clause 54W we talk about detention of unlawful non-citizens and the changing of that detention from being discretionary in the principal Act to mandatory. The principal Act states that an officer `may arrest' and keep in custody a person who is reasonably supposed to be an illegal entrant; that has been changed in this Bill to `must detain' the person.

PARA.TAB: By agreeing to mandatory imprisonment for people who are under suspicion of being illegal entrants, we are making imprisonment lawful and we are therefore refusing the right of that person to obtain judicial access and to have the lawfulness of that detention reconsidered. We are automatically providing that it is lawful to detain that person when his status is unknown. I want to make that point very clearly. If the Minister disagrees with me, I would be glad to hear his reply.

I will go on to ask a series of questions about the detention of people who are regarded as unlawful non-citizens. I use the example of Indonesian fishermen, who have been fishing off the Australian coast for centuries. They have been arrested and towed into our ports and then detained in various ways in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland. Can the Minister tell me whether this legislation will impose a change of policy in two of those three States—at present Western Australia does detain in custody. Will the Minister clarify the implications of that part of the legislation on those people?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the policy established by this Bill will be that such persons must be detained and held in custody. They will not be able to apply for a bridging visa. They will be held in custody until their matter is properly disposed of. It does not matter which State they find themselves in or in which Territory they come into port. This provision will be Australia-wide in its operation.

—In the sense that the legislation does not make the discrimination, it does matter. There is a considerable cost differential from the previous policy. Western Australia has a far greater cost attached to detention than does the Northern Territory, which actually has the boats in the harbour and the fishermen live on the boats. The system that operates in Queensland is that the boats are not brought in or detained; they are actually towed back. So there will be a considerable cost increase as a result of the increased detention that will operate in the Northern Territory and Queensland. The costs will increase, presumably, to a level a lot closer to that in Western Australia. Who will bear the increased costs of this detention? Have any calculations been made as to the quite significant monetary increases that will be involved in carrying out the provisions of this Bill?

—I think there might be a minor confusion. In so far as we are dealing with immigration matters, the obligation on the Australian authorities in relation to persons who arrive in our territorial waters without proper authority will be to detain them. The variation from jurisdiction to jurisdiction may be in relation to State laws dealing with fisheries offences or some such matter, in which case the States or Territories may variously deal with the question of the illegal fishermen. In so far as we are dealing with migration, there will be a common Australia-wide policy in force.

—That is why I asked initially whether the Bill would apply to Indonesian fishermen, the boats that are currently brought in and the people who are detained. I thank the Minister for clarifying that and indicating that that policy will not necessarily be made uniform by this Bill. I am sure that the concerns of people who are responsible for the budgets will be eased in that regard.

PARA.TAB: I want to move on to clause 66. Perhaps I should ask the Minister to clarify the fact that this Bill is referring to refugees or people who are coming in who are classified as illegal non-citizens who have not had their status evaluated. Clauses 66, 66A and 66B refer to the detainees being liable for the cost of the detention—that is, mandatory detention laid down by this Act. We are asking those people, who have no access to the judicial process, to challenge that detention. Are we asking them to be liable for the cost of that detention? In clause 66A we are laying down in the legislation that removed or deported non-citizens should be liable for the costs of removal or deportation, not simply the costs of detention while they are here for maybe three years, but also for the costs of their removal, and in section 66B, the cost of their detained spouses and dependents.

I could go on because the Bill talks about carriers and similar matters, which is why I started looking at fishing boats. I can see how I may have made that jump. I would like to know how the Government intends to fulfil the requirements of these provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Administrative arrangements will have to be made to carry this provision into effect. For the Australian community to bear the cost of those who are detained and removed or deported from Australia because it has been found that they have no lawful claim to remain in Australia would seem to most reasonable observers to be an unfair burden to place on the rest of the Australian community. To ask that those concerned contribute and pay the costs of their detention or removal seems to be perfectly fair in that situation. If they cannot pay because of extreme poverty or lack of assets, of course they will still be removed, but consequently such persons—I do not know whether by law or by the fact of not having paid a lawful debt to Australian authorities—would not be able to expect to come back into Australia under any of the lawful categories that could be provided.

PARA.TAB: The Government does not apologise for requiring such persons to pay the costs which are incurred by the Australian community in dealing with their unlawful entry, as it would then be determined to be, into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not at all surprised that increasing numbers of honourable senators are involved in consideration of immigration matters, migration Bills, the conduct by this Government of the refugee determination process and the intolerable situation of the huge delays faced by the boat people after arriving in Australia. We join in the concern that is expressed by independent senators, by the Australian Democrats and by the Liberal and National parties.

PARA.TAB: It is all the more evident by the public's lack of confidence in the Government over these matters that these sorts of questions are arising. Even when we have legislation before us that ought to be passed to tighten it up and make up for the errors of the Government, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has to answer question upon question. The Government has made a rod for its own back through the inadequacies and failures of its administration of immigration in this matter.

The second matter I wanted to refer to relates to the importance, as we see it in the Senate, of fairly representing all Australians and all potential Australians. We have every duty to represent the taxpayers of Australia and to ensure that there is not a liability that falls upon the taxpayer that is unfair or that we allow any laissez-faire thinking in this Parliament, or indeed in the community at large, that just because we rightly have compassion for those who are detained or for those who are in process, even though they are here unlawfully, this cost should automatically fall to the long-suffering taxpayers of Australia, including one million unemployed. This nation has a debt of more than $200 billion. Whilst this is the fault of the present Labor Government, it is right that there be some redress and some protection of the citizens of Australia—the taxpayers—in the way that is provided for in this legislation.
Again, I make it clear to the Government that, by its failures, it has made a rod for its own back and may even have to try to defend the good principle of protecting the taxpayers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The long-suffering taxpayer will be paying through the nose for this legislation. The cost of imprisonment is enormous; it is $50,000 a year per person. This legislation is guaranteeing that we provide it. We are trying to drag it out of people who have, in desperate straits, come from other economies where the cost of imprisonment is nowhere near what it is in Australia. I would like to ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) whether he is aware that this legislation will be enormously expensive and that there will be very few people in the category that we are considering who will be able to repay anywhere near the cost of their detention or deportation.

PARA.TAB: Compassion is important. Some of us are spending so much time on our feet because there needs to be a voice for a change of values in this Government. That needs to come from both sides of the chamber. That need for compassion causes us to look at the implications of this Bill. It will be extremely expensive to have mandatory detention and we will not be able to reclaim it from many people. Those we reclaim it from will be the very people we are forcibly repatriating. We will be depriving them of any monetary source which will help them to readjust in a very traumatic situation. I think that should be pointed out.
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Chamarette, I would indicate that some of the contributions I have heard since I have come back into the Chair have been bordering on second reading speeches. We do not want any second reading speeches. We have the Bill before us and the question is that the Bill stand as printed.

—I was in the process of asking a series of questions before Senator Teague interrupted and caused me to wax a trifle eloquent. I will resume my series of questions. Could the Minister give us some indication of the costs of this imprisonment? He has already answered that by saying that we were intending to try to defray some of the massive costs of this mandatory imprisonment by taking it from people whom we were trying forcibly to repatriate. I believe that the responsibility for the costs of the imprisonment lies fairly and squarely in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Morally, I do not believe that it is justifiable. I know that may not carry weight at this stage in the debate, but I wonder whether it could not be challenged in some way so that people, who have no say or judicial access but who are mandatorily imprisoned, are then asked to pay for the costs of their imprisonment and for the costs of their deportation. Secondly, what happens to people who are detained in custody for a lengthy period of time and who are then given some kind of recognition in the form of either refugee status or a visa? What happens to the cost of their detention?

TALK.START.PARA: —I may have missed the very last part of Senator Chamarette's series of questions, but basically I think one has to keep in mind that under this Bill most of those who are initially detained under the provisions of the Act, as it will become, will be able to apply for a bridging visa and therefore move into the general Australian community. Those who will be unable to do so are a very small group of those who arrive without any lawful authority and are held in custody while their application—usually for recognition of refugee status—is considered.

PARA.TAB: One hopes that that determination can be made, at least at the initial level, within a couple of months. Then, if the decision is a negative one, it is up to the person reacting to it to decide whether it merits review or engaging in further processes. One would certainly never want to see the long term or year-after-year detention which has been an unfortunate feature of arrangements in some past and current situations.

One has to consider the cost. I am informed that detention at Port Hedland runs at about $35 per day. If that is true, it certainly would not amount to the $50,000 a year which has been mentioned by Senator Chamarette. Even so, for some persons that will be a considerable amount unless they have brought certain resources with them into the country or have them immediately available. In those situations obviously the debt remains, even if the payment is not forthcoming. Such persons will be removed from Australia, still bearing the requirement to pay that lawful debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister could give us an estimate of this `small number' who might be detained for a couple of months? The costs of imprisonment are different from the $35 a day that he mentioned and if we charge that amount then we will not defray the actual costs of imprisonment. My final question is this: in the case of somebody who is detained mandatorily and then granted refugee status, what access does he or she have to compensation? Rather than paying the costs of detention, what access do such people have to compensation from us for their mandatory detention?

—I do not see why there should be any compensation. The High Court has said today that it is a lawful, constitutionally grounded procedure for an executive government to detain in custody those who arrive without any lawful authority in order that their claims might be properly assessed, considered and dealt with.

PARA.TAB: In that situation I do not believe that any compensation would be required to be paid, either morally or certainly legally. As to the numbers, one can only hazard a guess. But if one is asked the likely number of people who might arrive illegally, by boat or by aircraft, one would have to say that it would probably be in the very low hundreds in any one year, if that. I think it would be most speculative to try to put a figure on it, but it would not be any great number.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a couple of questions about the Minister's powers. Under section 115 of the principal Act, the Minister does have power to grant persons who have been refused a refugee permit a temporary entry permit on humanitarian grounds—a domestic protection entry permit. Under the provisions of this legislation, as I understand it, that situation will still apply. Is that the case?
—I understand that to be the case.

—I thank the Minister. I refer to the High Court's decision. I am not standing here saying `we told you so' last time this legislation was before us because I was not aware that there would be an appeal to the High Court. An action has been taken in the High Court against the legislation which was passed by the Senate, despite my strong opposition and that of the Democrats and Senator Chamarette.

PARA.TAB: I am not gloating—indeed, some of the matters that I went into at the time were not actually dealt with by the High Court—but I must indicate to those who have not seen the High Court decision, that I did have a look at it. It was in my hands at about 11 o'clock, by courtesy of the Parliamentary Library in its usual efficient manner. It was an interesting decision. The most accurate and best potted summary that I have seen of the decision thus far—and I have not seen many I must say—was contained in an AAP report which was issued at 14.59 and that said:

The High Court has upheld the right of the Commonwealth government to detain people who arrive illegally in Australia, including asylum seekers, but has rejected limits on the power of courts to release them.

In five judgments delivered today, several justices also found that some boat people had been detained unlawfully before parliament passed the controversial laws which were the subject of today's ruling.
Several justices also found the parliament had exceeded its powers in prohibiting courts from ordering boat people be released.
Today's decision allows the government to retain its policy of mandatory detention for all illegal arrivals.
However, by declaring invalid the limit on the court's power the High Court has left open the possibility for people to challenge their detention in certain circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to read all of the report, but I do seek leave, for the purpose of clarity, to have this AAP report incorporated in Hansard. I believe it to be a very succinct, readable and accurate reflection of the decision of the High Court which ran into 75 pages. How people can condense that into a page and a quarter, I do not know. That is a gift that they have and one that I obviously do not have.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS DETENTION BUT REJECTS LIMITS ON COURT POWERS BOATPEOPLE NIGHTLEAD
CANBERRA, Dec 8 AAP

PARA.TAB: The High Court has upheld the right of the Commonwealth government to detain people who arrive illegally in Australia, including asylum seekers, but has rejected limits on the power of courts to release them.

In five judgments delivered today, several justices also found that some boat people had been detained unlawfully before parliament passed the controversial laws which were the subject of today's ruling.
Several justices also found the parliament had exceeded its powers in prohibiting courts from ordering boat people be released.
Today's decision allows the government to retain its policy of mandatory detention for all illegal arrivals.
However, by declaring invalid the limit on the court's power the High Court has left open the possibility for people to challenge their detention in certain circumstances.
These include when nine months in custody has passed, although the legislation suspends the clock when determinations are appealed.
The High Court was ruling on the validity of legislation passed in May to amend the Migration Act.
Parliament passed the amendments two days before the Federal Court was to resume hearing a case in which 37 Cambodian detainees were seeking release from custody.
The legislation made it impossible for the case to continue.
All seven justices upheld provisions in the May legislation allowing boat people to be detained, and five rejected the provision prohibiting a court releasing a detainee.

Justices Gerard Brennan, William Deane and Daryl Dawson found the provisions the Immigration Department relied on to detain people who arrived illegally by boat before the May legislation were directed at temporary custody, not long-term detention.
(Most of the boat people have been in custody for more than two years, some for three years, and some had their boats burned.)

"The view was apparently taken by the (Immigration) Minister's department that, in a case where a vessel can never leave because it has been destroyed, temporary custody . . . can continue indefinitely," they said.
Such a view was mistaken, they said.
". . . the continued detention of each plaintiff in custody after the destruction of the boat on which he or she arrived in Australia was unlawful.
The justices also commented on the object of the government's intent when it rushed the legislation through parliament.

"Indeed, in the context of the pending proceedings in the Federal Court, it appears that one of the objects of the Act was to clothe with legislative authority the custody in which the `boat people' were being kept, a custody that might have been brought to an abrupt end once a court ascertained that that custody was unlawful," the justices said.
Justice John Toohey agreed that custody before the May legislation was unlawful in some cases and Justice Mary Gaudron raised doubts about the lawfulness of the detention.
Justices Brennan, Deane and Dawson also found the law prohibiting a court releasing a boat person "manifestly exceeds the legislative powers of the Commonwealth and is invalid".

They said the attempt to direct the courts on the manner and outcome of the exercise of their powers "constitutes an impermissible intrusion" into the judicial powers which the Constitution gives the courts.
