None of the seven justices addressed the question of whether the May laws breached Australia's international obligations set out in two treaties.
One concerns the treatment of refugees, while the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is given effect to in part in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act.
The justices said the question of the force of these treaties did not (not) arise because the laws parliament passed stated those laws should take precedence over any other law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The Cambodians were the plaintiffs in this case. I am very concerned because yesterday the delegate of the Minister notified these plaintiffs, who are in detention in Port Hedland, that they would have to leave the country as soon as possible. It seems rather tragic that the High Court said, as quoted in the AAP report, that parliament had exceeded its powers in prohibiting courts from ordering boat people to be released.

SPEECH.PARA: The AAP report states:

PARA.TAB: In five judgments, several High Court justices found that some boat people had been detained unlawfully before Parliament passed the controversial laws which were the subject of today's ruling . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me unfair that, due to the Parliament passing legislation in early May, the judge was ordered not to release persons who might appeal. That was the effect of that legislation. It has now been overturned by the High Court. It has been stated by several of the judges that some of those people had been unlawfully detained in custody. The report states:

PARA.TAB: Justices Gerard Brennan, William Deane and Daryl Dawson found the provisions the Immigration Department relied on to detain people who arrived illegally by boat before the May legislation were directed at temporary custody, not long-term detention.
(Most of the boat people have been in custody for more than two years, some for three years, and some had their boats burned.)

SPEECH.PARA: The judgment is then quoted as follows:

PARA.TAB: "The view was apparently taken by the (Immigration) Minister's department that, in a case where a vessel can never leave because it has been destroyed, temporary custody . . . can continue indefinitely". . .
Such a view was mistaken . . . "the continued detention of each plaintiff in custody after the destruction of the boat on which he or she arrived in Australia was unlawful.

SPEECH.PARA: We can see the catch 22 situation that these Cambodians were in. It was illegal to detain them other than to detain them temporarily. There was a possibility of their shoving offshore, but they could not leave offshore because their boat had been burnt, not by them, but by agencies of the Commonwealth Government. So they were detained for such an extraordinarily long time. I will not go over that, but I appeal to the Minister that these people have now been told that they have to go. As the judgment said, some of them have been here for over three years. If the Minister still has the power under the legislation to allow these people to stay in Australia on humanitarian grounds, I believe that the Minister should, in the interests of justice to these people and in a compassionate manner, exercise this discretion.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Minister that it is not setting a precedent. It is not saying that persons have queue-jumped; these people clearly cannot have queue-jumped, because at the time of their departure from Cambodia in 1989, the Australian Government did not recognise the regime in Cambodia. At the time that these Cambodians left Cambodia it was no longer Democratic Kampuchea, which in any event the Australian Government did not recognise; it was called the state of Cambodia. As everybody recalls, it was a Vietnamese controlled government in Phnom Penh, and Australia did not recognise that state. But Australia does now recognise the SNC, the Supreme National Council, and has done so since June 1991.

These boat people have been denied their rights to appeal their detentions. They have been detained for a considerable period. They are extremely fearful—I know, because I have spoken to a number of them—about going back and what will happen to them. Their lives have been traumatised and disrupted in both Cambodia and Australia. If the Minister still retains that discretion—and he has indicated he does—I believe it would be a magnanimous gesture on his part to release these people from detention and allow them to stay in Australia on humanitarian grounds.

I believe that was the gravamen of the recommendation made by one Refugee Status Review Committee, which was the body to hear an appeal for refugee applications from some of these Cambodians. That Refugee Status Review Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising, inter alia, the way in which families in Cambodia had suffered during and after the Pol Pot regime, the Committee invited DILGEA to explore the possibility of permanent residence in Australia for this applicant.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Chair is that the Bill stand as printed. Comments must be related to that. We have just had a second reading speech again.

—In so far as the questions raised by Senator Harradine can be related to the Bill, I ought to clarify a matter. I am advised that in relation to the discretion of the Minister to grant a domestic protection entry permit, I think it was called, to a person who has been denied refugee status in some situations, I need to emphasise `in some situations'. They relate to such a claimant being lawfully present in Australia in the first place and then overstaying, for example, the period for which that person was entitled to stay in Australia and then claiming that refugee status. If a person arrives in Australia unlawfully, without any lawful entry permit, and then makes a claim for recognition of refugee status, for example, and is denied that recognition, such a person cannot under the law and regulations be subject to the Minister's discretion to grant that particular domestic entry permit on humanitarian grounds.
—We have bridging permits under the Bill we are discussing at the moment.
—Senator Harradine, the argument you should be advancing really is whether the Bill should or should not stand as printed.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. If the Minister is saying that an entry permit cannot be granted on humanitarian grounds after a refugee status application has been refused—and that is, as I understand it, what the Minister said—there ought to be something in this legislation that would enable the Minister, in circumstances such as the one I have described, to grant permanent residence in Australia for an applicant or applicants on humanitarian grounds. If there is no such provision—if there is, I would like the Minister to show me where it is—then I do not believe that the Bill should stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the recommendation by the RSRC—the Refugee Status Review Committee—in respect of one of those Cambodian applicants where the Committee invited DILGEA to explore the possibility of permanent residence in Australia for this applicant. All I am asking the Minister is whether he can show me in the Bill before the Committee that ability being available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, my previous answers were, of course, in relation to the current Act. Perhaps we were trespassing on your indulgence in even responding. In relation to the Bill before the Committee, I understand it to operate in this way, differently from the current situation: if a person arrives in Australia unlawfully and is detained and makes a claim that he or she should be recognised as a refugee, that matter can be determined. There is then a legal right to appeal to the Refugee Review Tribunal. Under this Bill, if the Tribunal refuses the recognition sought—that is, determines that the person is not a refugee—at that stage the Minister will be able to exercise the discretion to enable the person to have the benefit of lawful presence in Australia in accordance with humanitarian principles.
—Now we are getting somewhere. But that does not come into operation until 1 July next year; is that not so?
—Yes, 1 July 1993.

—So we have that impasse, that problem, between now and then. I suppose that under the current legislation the Minister can exercise his rights. In the current situation, I suppose the Minister's delegate could review his decision. I am asking the Minister now whether, on humanitarian grounds, there is any possibility on the part of the Minister, as recommended by the Refugee Status Review Committee, of permanent residence in Australia for particular applicants whose refugee status has been refused finally by the delegate of the Minister?
—I am advised that under the current law that particular possibility in the Minister does not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there amendments to this legislation? I think this is a matter that ought to be taken up between now and, if there are amendments, when they are considered by the House of Representatives. This is an important matter, and perhaps there is a way around the problem. I know that the time is late, but perhaps it ought to be considered prior to the matter going before the other chamber. If the legislation goes through as it is at the moment, it is deficient in that it does not enable the Minister so to make a determination. I refer to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regula-tions, Achieving a balance between refuge and control, points 5.52, 5.53, 5.54 and particularly 5.54. I do want to press this issue. Point 5.54 says:

PARA.TAB: According to DILGEA, the procedures for obtaining stay on discretionary humanitarian grounds are `elaborate' and `in many ways an artificial process'. Those refugee applications eligible for humanitarian discretion are considered both as refugee and potential humanitarian cases. The first level case officer may form a judgment that a case is a humanitarian case and not a refugee case. The case officer can arrange to have the case `fast-tracked', but the person must be refused refugee status, be denied a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit and then proceed to the second tier of decision making to get access to the Minister's discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: These people have proceeded through those procedures, and what the Minister is saying does not appear to me to coincide with what is stated in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. This appears to me to be saying that the Minister does have a discretion. In fact, 5.55 says:

PARA.TAB: The decision to recommend and refer a case as a deserving humanitarian one is currently a decision of the RSRC or a senior delegate. The senior delegate is the review authority under the existing processing scheme. . .

SPEECH.PARA: Under those circumstances, why can the senior delegate now not decide that the Cambodians in Port Hedland are deserving of humanitarian considerations? If that is not the case, I believe we are failing in our duty. There are many in Australia who believe that these people have been traumatised to such an extent that they deserve consideration on humanitarian grounds for permanent residence in Australia. If this legislation closes off that option to the Minister prior to 1 July of next year, then I do not think this Bill should stand as printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Bill stand as printed. Those of that opinion say aye; the contrary no. I think the ayes have it.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for some sort of response to that important question.
—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: the question has been put and carried.
—I have put the question and I have said that the ayes have it.
—I draw your attention to the state of the House. I saw the Manager of Government Business go over and tell Senator Tate not to say anything more.
—A quorum is not present. Ring the bells.
—That is not right. That is not the slightest bit true.
—Senator Harradine repeated a point that he had made before. I did not think I needed to repeat my answer.
—The Minister was wrong last time and he will be proved wrong this time. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.
Amendments (by Senator Spindler, on behalf of Senator Sowada)—by leave—proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 5, page 2, proposed paragraph 4A(2)(b), lines 28 and 29, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(b)provide that on enrolment arrangements are made for fees to be paid".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 6, page 3, proposed section 4B, line 4, after "provided", insert "by teachers whose qualifications satisfy the requirements of State education authorities for the teaching of English to adult migrants".
3.Clause 6, page 3, proposed section 4C, line 14, omit ", or arrange the provision of,", substitute "a minimum of 510 hours of tuition by allocating per capita funding to cover".
4.Clause 6, page 4, proposed paragraph 4D(3)(b), line 6, after "matters", insert ", including circumstances of hardship,".

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to the amendments to the Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 in globo so as not to take up the time of the Committee. We have moved these amendments after consultation with a range of groups and after having heard the arguments for and against this legislation by the Department, the Minister and the community groups concerned.

PARA.TAB: I will take honourable senators through the amendments one by one. The first amendment provides for cases where payment for courses may be somewhat difficult for migrants in financial hardship. The clause to which the amendment relates seeks to provide that arrangements can be made for the payment of fees in relation to the charging and recovery of fees for English as a second language courses. It has been suggested to me that hardship provisions or arrangements for the deferment of fees in special cases of hardship are in some way implicit in this legislation. We would suggest and maintain that it is not in any way implicit that there is some provision for deferment, or at least that the Bill includes hardship provisions, if a migrant who is currently engaged in ESL training is unable to meet payment of the $250 fee.

I bring to the attention of the Committee that this fee which will be imposed by clause 4A will be imposed on people who are currently engaged in English language courses, not migrants who will come to Australia in future; they will have another schedule of fees to contend with. This fee of $250 applies to those people currently engaged in English language training. There may well be people currently engaged in English language training who will find it difficult to find the $250.

So we would like to submit to the Government and the Opposition that a hardship provision needs to be included to ensure that those people who cannot meet the immediate payment of that $250 on enrolment, which is what the clause says, can use some sort of deferred payment mechanism or at least have their hardship difficulties taken into account in the payment of the fee.

The second amendment relates to clause 4B. We believe it is an important amendment, given that much of the funding for these courses will be tendered by DEET. The amendment is simply to ensure that those who are teaching English language to adult migrants are in fact qualified to do so. We think this is certainly an important measure to ensure that the quality in the teaching of English to migrants is maintained.

Before the implementation of the export education legislation last year, we saw that there were tremendous problems. In fact, quite a lot of shonky providers ripped off the taxpayer and overseas students with courses in English which did not meet quality control standards, and were prepared to abscond with funds. I am sure that DEET will ensure that quality control mechanisms are in place in the tendering process. Those mechanisms have not yet been outlined to us. Certainly, not a great deal of detail was given to the Senate Committee this morning when we asked questions of officials that related to the evaluation and control of tendered courses. We submit that it is a reasonable expectation that people who teach English to migrants should have the appropriate qualifications to teach that language.

The third amendment relates to this very thorny question of the 510 hours of tuition. Perhaps the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who represents the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), is able to provide some detail of, or at least put on the record here in the chamber, some of the undertakings that the Minister, Mr Hand, has given to me personally and, I believe, to community groups through his representative, Mr Laurie Ferguson, at a public meeting 10 days ago. The Minister has said that funding for English language courses in respect of this 510 hours of tuition will be rolled over for other students if a particular student acquires functional English before the 510 hours have expired.

We have raised this issue before. The whole concept of this 510 hours worth of English language training is a very thorny one. As I said yesterday in my speech during the second reading debate, it has no educational basis whatsoever. It seems to have been reached on the basis of a number of surveys which showed that people could acquire functional English after something like 370 hours. But certainly those involved in teaching English as a second language to migrants have found that, in many cases, 510 hours is inadequate and that many more hours are needed.

When we asked questions about this issue this morning in the Senate Committee hearing—it was not a public hearing; it was an informal hearing—the question was put to DILGEA officials about people who reach the 510 hours and who still do not have functional English. It seems that they just simply fall out of the system, unless they are going to be job seekers and end up on a DEET program which is targeted towards job seekers. Clearly, many women who may not end up in the job market—who may be at home looking after children or who may not even be seeking paid work—could possibly be very disadvantaged by this measure.

We were told this morning that what happens to people after this 510 hours has expired is a `question for the future'. The Minister, Mr Hand, needs to look very closely at this question to ensure that people are not falling through the gaps and are not receiving 510 hours worth of tuition which, for all utilitarian purposes, is not adequate to meet the needs of these migrants. It is certainly a conundrum that is yet to be resolved. This question of the rolling over of the funds or the hours for students who may need more than 510 hours tuition is not resolved by this legislation. We would like to see some provision which would ensure that the funding of students who do not need their full quota of 510 hours is rolled over to other students. But as I said, nowhere in this Bill is that issue addressed.

We were told this morning that the matter is a question of policy. That may well be, but is not this whole legislation a question of policy? I submit to the Government that if it is the Minister's intention to roll over this funding for other students then there should be some legislative effect to that. I ask the Minister in the chamber, firstly, to tell the chamber whether it is correct that the hours will be rolled over to other students; and, secondly, to tell us how the Department or the Minister plans to give some kind of legislative effect to that undertaking.

The fourth issue relates to registration and the commencement of courses within three and 12 months respectively. I have also spoken to Mr Hand about this issue. He accepted that a small number of migrants—perhaps 10 per cent, which is the figure that has been bandied around in a lot of circles—would perhaps be unable to register within three months of arrival and commence their tuition within 12 months of their arrival because of various hardship circumstances. For example, a woman might be raising a family or a migrant might be simply too traumatised to register. There could be a whole range of reasons.

The Minister indicated that regulations relating to circumstances of hardship would be made under the regulatory power provided for in clause 4D(3)(b). We certainly support that. In a sense, our amendment is an attempt to at least symbolically give effect to the Minister's undertaking that regulations would be made for hardship provisions. I ask the Minister to confirm to the chamber that it is the Minister's intention to make these regulations for provisions of hardship, and to tell us when those regulations may be forthcoming. We will be waiting for those regulations to appear so that we can give them close scrutiny. I accept that the Minister, Mr Hand, has given us the undertaking that those regulations will be made, and I accept that he will do that. However, as I said, this amendment simply seeks to give some indication to the Minister from this chamber that we certainly expect him to draft the said regulations for hardship provisions.

With those few words, I commend the regulations to the chamber. As I said in my opening remarks, we have looked at these issues very closely. We have not accepted all the arguments put to us by the various lobby groups. We have looked at each of these issues very carefully. I put it to the chamber, and certainly to the Opposition, that these are not unreasonable amendments. If the Government is not prepared to accept them, will the Minister at the table address here some of the concerns that I have raised by way of questions and these amendments, and put on the record some of those undertakings that the Minister has given publicly—certainly through his representative, Mr Laurie Ferguson—about the rolling over of those hours and the fact that hardship provisions will be provided for in the regulations in relation to the registration and enrolment of students?

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be helpful for the Opposition very briefly to indicate its views on the four amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. I have enormous sympathy for the intentions that Senator Sowada has indicated. Because I believe that the words set out in these amendments do not achieve her intentions—and I have heard her informal explanation of these amendments as well as what she has just said in this chamber—the Opposition will not be supporting any of the four Democrat amendments.

PARA.TAB: I do not seek to detain honourable senators, so I will refer to these four amendments very briefly. Of course we interpret the words, `provide that fees are payable on enrolment in the English course', as allowing for administrators to make deferred payment arrangements. That is the case in all other legislation that I know of, and I do not see why it ought not be administratively allowable here. There is no need to complicate the matter with regard to the proposed amendment. As to the second amendment, I of course wish to see the very best qualified teachers involved in English language tuition for adult migrants, but I am opposed to credentialism per se, and I am opposed to our tying ourselves to State definitions. I believe that on merit the very best teachers should be available for these courses. Of course, nobody who is not able to teach the courses ought to be employed. I do not believe that we need the second amendment.

The third amendment is an attempt to enforce on the Minister an ability that he administratively has anyway; that is, that the administrator can go beyond the minimum guarantee or obligation that is set out in this legislation for the very first time, but it is put in a different form of words. To build out what is not intended in the legislation is, I believe, to take from what should be administratively in the hands of the Minister to make a statutory obligation. The Opposition does not support that.

The fourth amendment is rather tautological because the Minister has the power to bear in mind circumstances of hardship. Let me name my colleagues who want the Minister to take situations of hardship flexibly into account. Senator Crane, Senator Walters, Senator Calvert, Senator Tierney and other Opposition senators—and I will include myself on the list—have had careful discussions in recent days to ensure that there is a provision in this Bill that will allow for flexibility in enrolment in circumstances of need such as a mother with young children who, for quite practical reasons, might not be able to begin a course of English language tuition after 12 months.

The very fact that we have paragraph 4D(3)(b) satisfies the Opposition that it is perfectly possible for the Minister to set out regulations. The reason why I am speaking before the Minister is to re-enforce the call which I have already initiated. When we deferred these two Bills yesterday to be considered later than the other four in the package, I spoke and referred to this clause. I believe that the Minister will set out regulations to give flexibility to this matter. Therefore, these words are not necessary. In fact, they may even be read down to limit the full prescription power of the Minister. For these very sound reasons, the Opposition does not support the Democrats' four amendments. But let it be very clear: we are looking to the Government to be flexible, to be humane, to be reasonable in the administration of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support briefly the amendments moved by Senator Sowada. I also wish to express extreme disappointment at the decision of the Opposition not to support these amendments. Once again, we have heard a lot of pious words, and it is a matter of great regret that the coalition parties are not prepared to back up those pious sentiments and best wishes to the Government with action that will actually produce some results.

PARA.TAB: Late last year, Sir Alan Bullock, an eminent British historian, visited Australia. During his visit he was asked what he thought was the most significant achievement that Australia has been able to make since the war. Without hesitation, he said, `It is your multicultural society where 140 plus nationalities are able to live together cooperatively and tolerantly'. That multicultural society depends on two principles: first, the practical tolerance and support enabling all the nationalities to maintain their links with their cultural background; and, secondly—what this Bill is about—the assistance in achieving full participation in the social, cultural, economic and political life of the nation.

The amendments that the Australian Democrats have moved would ensure that the defects in the Bill, which Senator Sowada has outlined, which actually stop us from pursuing and achieving this second objective, would be cured. I believe that on these grounds the amendments should be supported by both the Opposition and the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some pretty long bows drawn in this chamber but to suggest that the cultural transformation of Australia into a multicultural society would be affected by the requirement that fees be payable on enrolment in an English course seems to me to be somewhat absurd. When one considers that that is in the context of a provision which provides for exemptions for the holders of a health care card or registered job seekers, one can see that already in that provision there is recognition of the fact that some people currently within Australia who want to enrol or re-enrol in these courses will not even be able to find the $250 which is required. It does not seem to be particularly onerous to pay 50c per hour for tuition in the English language, which is so necessary to their social, recreational and business participation in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: As to the second point about who should teach these courses, I agree with Senator Teague's sentiments in that regard. The Commonwealth does not see why it should be bound with respect to a requirement that State education authorities certify who may teach these courses. Our obligation is to ensure that the English language providers with whom we enter into arrangements fulfil their contractual requirements to provide English courses of quality and effect. They may, in order to achieve that, have their own internal rules as to the qualifications of those who should teach. We do not believe we should go into that detail. Our obligation is with the service providers. At least their obligation to us is to fulfil their contractual arrangements.

As to the third matter, it is important to keep reiterating that the great social reform to be carried out by this Bill is to entitle those who arrive in Australia as migrants or refugees or who are currently in the community, to 510 hours of tuition in the English language at the expense of the Australian community. That is a very generous response by the Australian community to the need of such people.

In so far as a person may attain proficiency within 400 hours or 370 hours, which is the average at the moment, a notional surplus of hours might be available that would otherwise be funded for that person. My belief is that that surplus ought to be redistributed to enable others to come into the course rather than to add to the entitled hours of any particular person. Therefore, the Government does not believe that it should move from its present very generous provision on the part of the Australian people. If a person requires more than 510 hours to attain English proficiency, there are other schemes available within the TAFE systems and so on to enable that to be undertaken, and funding is provided. In fact, there is a very significant increase in funding altogether to enable that English teaching to occur.

As to the final matter about what might be prescribed as circumstances which would allow for some variation in the 3-month, 12-month provisions, I do not know of any undertakings which are supposed to have been given by the Minister, and I do not accept—because I do not know—that those undertakings were given. However, one can assume that, in prescribing the situations which might have an effect that would acknowledge that it was unreasonable for an obligation to cease in regard to the provision of English tuition, regard will be had to the arguments put forward by Senator Sowada and others. The Government does not accept any of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Teague, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, and Senator Spindler for their contributions. I am very disappointed that the Government and the Opposition have not seen fit to support at least two of my amendments—amendments 1 and 4. I assure Senator Tate that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) did give me undertakings that the regulations would provide for hardship provisions, and given that Senator Tate is unable to give me that undertaking here, I will be writing to Mr Hand seeking written confirmation that those regulations will in fact be made.

PARA.TAB: Is the Minister suggesting that after the 510 hours, this rollover provision that seems to be floating around—and was certainly suggested to me by Minister Hand and by his representative at this meeting—will not occur? What is the status of that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What I was affirming was that the legal obligation being untaken by the Australian community as a result of the passage of this Bill into law will be to provide 510 hours of tuition, unless proficiency to a certain level is attained earlier. It seems that what Senator Sowada is saying is that if proficiency is attained earlier by a large number of people, then a funding amount ought to be made available in a way which perhaps adds up to 600 or 700 hours of tuition to those who have not attained a certain proficiency at the end of the 510 hours.

PARA.TAB: I certainly have expressed my opinion that if there is funding available because of that attaining of proficiency by a considerable number before the 510 hours, that ought to be made available to enlarge the number of persons who can receive the 510 hours at any one time, rather than by adding hours to those who have already been given the 510 hours. That is the way I look at it and I believe that that is a fairer and better way to enable a greater number of people to have earlier access to the provision of this tuition than would otherwise be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —One further question. Is the Minister suggesting that this suggested flexibility with the hours is in fact non-existent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it may be possible to indulge in that flexibility in the way that Senator Sowada has suggested. I have indicated that I do not favour that as a way to redistribute the funding that would otherwise be available, but I am not the Minister.
—Public undertakings have been given.
—I do not know of any such public undertaking.
—Martin Ferguson stood up and represented your Party at a public meeting and said they would be rolled over.

—Mr Ferguson is not the Minister. I am simply stating that I am now advised that some such flexibility had been envisaged and it may be available in certain situations. I find that unlikely to be pursued on any great scale, because it is incompatible with the basic policy of the Bill, which is to provide 510 hours of tuition. That is the obligation of the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sowada's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1992
MIGRATION (DELAYED VISA APPLICATIONS) TAX BILL 1992
MIGRATION (OFFENCES AND UNDESIRABLE PERSONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1992
IMMIGRATION (EDUCATION) CHARGE BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that the remaining Bills be taken together? There being no objection, it is so ordered. The question now is that the Bills be agreed to without amendment or request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to speak to the last listed Bill which is the Migration (Offences and Undesirable Persons) Amendment Bill 1992. After careful consideration of this measure and the reasons for which this legislation was seen to be necessary, the Opposition supports the Bill. I draw attention to clause 180B(3) which reads:

PARA.TAB: If the Minister makes a decision under subsection (1), the Minister must cause notice of the making of the decision to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which the decision was made.

SPEECH.PARA: In circumstances where the Minister is uniquely powerful to make a decision to ban a person or persons from entering Australia and where that decision is not reviewable, of course the details of that decision must be given to the Parliament. But I ask for one step more—not a statutory step but an informal and, I believe, bona fide arrangement. If there is public controversy or even controversy that comes to the ears of a section of the Parliament, I ask that the Minister of the day openly explain to the shadow Minister of the day all the reasons that led to the ban on the person or persons; and that it not be left until even 15 sitting days before that explanation is laid on the table of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: If there is any hiding behind this new legislation by a government of the day in banning persons not welcome by that government, if there is any censorship, any exclusion of freedom of speech, any political decision making carried out under the guise of this legislation, it would not be in the spirit in which we are passing it tonight. There ought to be accountability between a Minister and a shadow Minister to enable a fuller explanation to be given so that we are seen not to be adopting legislation that is in any way totalitarian.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the fact that where the Minister decides in the national interest that certain persons are to be excluded, he or she may issue a certificate declaring the person to be excluded. That decision by the Minister must be taken personally. If the Minister makes such a decision, it must be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Teague is suggesting any process whereby there is any need to alert, to consult with or to discuss the matter with the shadow Minister before the decision is made, that would not be appropriate. It would be a diminution of the proper responsibilities of the executive government of the day, in this case the Minister, who is required by the Act to take the decision personally. If Senator Teague is saying that once the decision is taken—given the fact that some 15 sitting days hence, the decision is to be laid before the Parliament subject to scrutiny and no doubt the need for justification if it is raised as an issue in the Parliament—it might be appropriate for the Minister to give a preview to the shadow Minister, then that could probably be undertaken. I cannot give an undertaking on the part of the Minister; I certainly will convey that request to him. In no way could the consultation with the shadow Minister be a precondition to the decision making by the Minister personally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not ask the former; I ask the latter. I thank Senator Tate for taking that matter on board and for putting it to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). The Opposition regards this as a reasonable preview given after the decision has been made to the appropriate shadow Minister so that a bona fide decision is made on behalf of all Australians and made in light of the fact that the explanation, when eventually given to Parliament, will be acceptable to the Parliament. It would, of course, be made by the Minister with the view that he would be a representative of the Parliament. So it is in the latter sense in which I make the appeal. I think that assurance could be given, not in a legal way or as a statutory requirement, but in terms of a bona fide intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief. I do not wish to hold up the Committee. I am forced into making these comments because I believe that the Committee has not been given the full information that it really deserved. I may not have correctly heard what the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was saying. It was also the case that I had not turned up the paragraphs—which I was desperately looking for—that I wanted to outline to the Minister from the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations.

PARA.TAB: During the committee stage on one of the other Bills I asked a question about the exercise by the Minister of a discretion to grant permanent entry to the Cambodians who are under threat of forcible deportation and whose case was so clearly correct before the High Court. I ask the Minister whether the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) had a discretionary power to grant permanent residence to those persons on humanitarian grounds. I have now found the paragraph in the report of the Joint Select Committee. It is paragraph 6.27. It applies to both illegal entrants and border claimants. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Additional processing measures were announced by the Minister on 12 February 1992. These are outlined at paragraph 6.31. The new procedures are intended to allow complete processing of applications from border claimants and arrested illegal entrants within two months.
Paragraphs 6.27 to 6.43 make it perfectly clear in my mind that the Minister does have the ability to exercise discretion on humanitarian grounds. Paragraph 6.43 states:

After the RSRC's consideration of the review application, a senior delegate of the Minister, who is the review authority in the processing scheme, makes the final decision on whether the applicant is a refugee and whether to grant a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit. The delegate bases his or her decision on the RSRC's recommendation and the applicant's comments on the findings of the RSRC. The delegate's decision is documented and forwarded to the applicant.
That is what happened in the Cambodian case. It continues:
While this is generally the final point of the process, the Minister may consider granting entry on humanitarian grounds under the Minister's section 115 discretionary powers.

That is what the report of the Joint Committee says. I may have misunderstood the Minister's response. I believe it is important, prior to this motion being put, for the Committee to be fully aware of that situation. I ask the Minister whether he would kindly clarify that situation. Is the Joint Standing Committee correct in what it has said and does the Minister have discretion? If he has discretion—it is intended to give him discretion under the new system from 1 July 1993—why cannot this measure be amended now?

PARA.TAB: As a result of the Minister not getting up to speak again I was denied the right to ask a number of other questions relating to the situation in China and to provide the Committee with the proof that I have that the persons who were deported from Port Hedland to China forcibly are now languishing in prison.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Harradine has spoken and drawn on a report of a parliamentary committee, I have had the advice of very senior officers within the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and I adhere to the previous advice I gave the Committee on the lack of power of the Minister to allow, on humanitarian grounds, a prohibited immigrant to stay in Australia. Whilst I am not an expert in this area, I have experts available to me. They claim that Senator Harradine's understanding of the matter is not in accordance with the law as it presently exists.
—Are they in prison?

—I am coming to that. That has nothing to do with what I have just been talking about. As to the other matter, Senator Harradine seems to claim that he was gagged at the end of consideration of a Bill and prevented from putting evidence to the Committee in relation to a particular matter. There was no gag and there was no guillotine. As I understand it, the question was put. I was not aware that Senator Harradine wished to speak. The Chair obviously was not aware. If Senator Harradine had risen in his place, he would have been permitted to continue. I make it very clear that the Committee was under no constraints from the point of view of the Government in its fullest consideration and deliberation of these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Orders prevented me from asking any further questions since the Minister did not respond to my question. No other honourable senators stood in their place; therefore, standing orders prevented me from asking any further questions. That was the situation.
—That is not quite right. If no other senator stands, the senator who was speaking may stand again.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard pages 120 to 125 of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, dated August 1992.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The document read as follows—
Revised Procedures

6.25On 26 June 1990, the Government established an Interdepartmental Working Group to develop a streamlined refugee determination model which would ensure the speedy settlement of on-shore refugee status claims. The new procedures, which were announced by the Minister on 26 October 1990 and which came into effect on 10 December 1990, included 3 stages:

PARA.TAB: .a primary stage for applications to be assessed and decisions taken quickly on the grant of refugee status;
.a review stage, consisting of an examination of negative assessment by the RSRC and a determination by a senior delegate who is the review authority in the scheme; and

.Ministerial discretion to grant temporary stay on humanitarian grounds where the applicant fails to win refugee status but the Minister is of the view that there is a compelling case for humanitarian stay (humanitarian claims are discussed in detail in Chapter 5).

SPEECH.PARA: 6.26DILGEA advised that this working group model was expected to cost the Commonwealth approximately $1.83 million per 1,000 applications.

6.27Additional processing measures were announced by the Minister on 12 February 1992. These are outlined at paragraph 6.31. The new procedures are intended to allow complete processing of applications from border claimants and arrested illegal entrants within 2 months. For other on-shore refugee claimants it is intended that the procedures will provide a six month process for the primary stage, and three months for the review stage.
Primary decision stage: 10 December 1990 to February 1992

6.28Under the processing arrangements in place between 10 December 1990 and February 1992, at least 10 separate procedural steps were undertaken before a refugee application was submitted for a primary decision. These steps included the following:

PARA.TAB: .receipt of application and checking against the departmental data base;

.a registration check, involving the input of the applicant's details on the departmental data base, creation of a separate file for each applicant, acknowledgment of the application, and circulation of the application to UNHCR;
.preliminary assessment by a case officer, involving the identification of priority cases for fast tracking, and seeking information from overseas posts;
.in some cases, approving permission to work;
.interview with the applicant, which was fully documented;
.preparation of a statement of reasons, which may have required clearance from the Legal Branch, and which was required to be signed by the Delegate and then forwarded to the applicant;
.processing of any Freedom of Information claims which were made;
. a further registration check;
.preparation of minutes; and
.referral of assessment to the applicant and UNHCR for comment.

SPEECH.PARA: 6.29In the initial version of the processing system, applicants and the UNHCR were given 21 days to comment on a negative assessment by the case officer. When comments were received, they may have necessitated further investigation by the case officer. When such further investigation was
completed, the case officer prepared a submission to the Delegate, documenting the case officer's findings, any comments from the applicant or UNHCR, and the case officer's recommendation.

6.30The final step of the primary decision stage prior to February 1992 was the decision by the delegate, made on the basis of the case officer's assessment and the comments by the applicant and UNHCR on that assessment. The delegate documented his or her findings. In the case of a negative assessment, a statement of reasons was prepared for the applicant.
Primary decision stage: from February 1992

6.31Under the new refugee determination procedures announced by the Minister on 12 February 1992, the primary decision stage has been streamlined. There is no longer a separation between the case officer and primary decision delegate. As noted by DILGEA in evidence to the Committee, from February 1992 the person who interviews the claimant is also the person responsible for assessing and deciding on the case.

6.32Decision makers at the primary stage are to be at the administrative officer class 6 level. They are to receive extensive training in law, case management and positive interview techniques. These case officers are supervised closely by senior managers who mentor and monitor their decision making.

6.33The primary decision stage is crucial in refugee processing. In the present system, the case officer is the only person to see and evaluate the applicant. The case officer's assessment is relied upon by decision makers at the current review stage.
6.34In his February 1992 announcement, the Minister also foreshadowed a package of regulations intended to give greater control over the primary decision stage of refugee processing. These include:

PARA.TAB: .imposing binding time limits on the period after arrival in Australia when applications for refugee status must be lodged;
.imposing binding time limits on responses to correspondence and lodgement of review applications;
.requiring applicants to advance all details relevant to a claim at the application stage;
.restricting repeat applications; and
.requiring accurate details of change of address for the purpose of serving directions and correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: 6.35The proposed regulation requiring applicants to advance all details at the application stage represents a modification of the previous application and natural justice consultation arrangements. The primary level natural justice provisions included extensive consultations with applicants. Experience showed that this extended the investigation stage, delaying decision making, as applicants provided more and more case details on each consultation.

6.36All applicants now will be interviewed. The interview provides the occasion for ascertaining case details, and assessing case merits and the credibility of the applicant. Under the announced arrangements, the application and assessment procedures are joined. As DILGEA noted:
It brings the process from application. . . and assessment to decision.

6.37Applicants will be given the opportunity at the interview and afterwards to respond to adverse material. This is in accordance with natural justice principles. Regulations will set down time limits for responding to adverse material and lodging review applications. DILGEA informed the Committee that the model which has been adopted can be flexible. DILGEA noted that if the applicant needs further time to get evidence to satisfy an interviewing officer on some point, the processing mechanisms could be `stalled while better information is sought and a better judgement established'.

6.38Under the new arrangements, the processing of border claimants and illegal entrants in detention is to be expedited considerably. As noted by the Minister, increased efficiency will derive from a changed approach. Instead of waiting for claimants to lodge lengthy and comprehensive applications, DILGEA is to actively investigate refugee claims. In this regard, it is worth noting that recent long delays in processing Cambodian border claimants occurred because of delays in lodging their refugee applications.
6.39The new procedures for border claimants and detained illegal entrants include:

PARA.TAB: .scheduling a claimant for interview with a DORS official within days of the border claimant or detained illegal indicating an intention to apply for refugee status;
.requiring the claimant to fill out a brief one page statement that he/she wishes to apply for refugee status, rather than requiring the usual multi-page form to be completed;
.exploring all aspects of the refugee claim at the interview; and
.providing applicants with a statement of reasons for negative decisions and a specified time in which to apply for review.

SPEECH.PARA: 6.40Prior to the introduction of these measures, DILGEA told the Committee:

. . . the essential difference in procedure is that we will allow persons who are in the community. . . to come to us with the written details of their claims. For border claimants, we will go to them and interview them to extract the claims.
Review stage since 10 December 1990

6.41Under the review system which has been in place since 10 December 1990, but which is to be replaced as of 1 July 1993, an applicant who has been notified of a primary decision denying him or her refugee status has 28 days within which to apply to the RSRC for review of the refusal decision. The RSRC is comprised of one representative each from DILGEA (Chair), Attorney-General's and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, as well as one community representative nominated by RCOA. In addition, an UNHCR representative attends in an advisory capacity. The departmental representatives on the RSRC are all senior officers within their respective departments.
6.42As at May 1992, the following steps were involved in the review of an application by the RSRC:

PARA.TAB: .an application for review is received and a registration check is carried out;
.all papers are circulated to RSRC members;
.the case officer can be called on to make a presentation to the RSRC on his or her detailed assessment, except in relation to manifestly unfounded cases, for which no case officer is in attendance;
.minutes of proceedings are prepared and the findings of the RSRC are documented;
.a negative assessment by the RSRC is referred to the applicant for comment within 21 days;
.a submission to the delegate is prepared by the RSRC, documenting the RSRC's recommendation and the applicant's comments; and
.in the case of a negative recommendation for refugee status, the RSRC can make a recommendation direct to the Minister for granting entry on humanitarian grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: 6.43After the RSRC's consideration of the review application, a senior delegate of the Minister, who is the review authority in the processing scheme, makes the final decision on whether the applicant is a refugee and whether to grant a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit. The delegate bases his or her decision on the RSRC's recommendation and the applicant's comments on the findings of the RSRC. The delegate's decision is documented and forwarded to the applicant. While this is generally the final point of the process, the Minister may consider granting entry on humanitarian grounds under the Minister's section 115 discretionary powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my speech on the second reading debate, the Australian Democrats do not support the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill regarding user pays education for all the reasons that I outlined. I would like to put that on the record once again.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make one other remark in relation to ministerial briefings. I am very disappointed by what the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has said tonight. It makes me wonder what value there is for us to have a ministerial briefing in order to secure our support. I had a briefing with the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand, on this legislation. We went through a number of issues. Certain undertakings were given to us in order to secure our support for this Bill. Tonight we find that the Minister is unable to confirm those discussions and the issues that were raised and is unable to put on the record the undertakings that were given that secured our support. I think this illustrates an appalling lack of communication between the Minister's office, the Department and the Minister who is responsible for the carriage of this legislation.

I accept that Senator Tate is not the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, but I do expect, if we have a briefing on legislation, undertakings given to us to be able to be confirmed in this chamber by the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I would like to put that disappointment on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the same officers present?
—None of the officers has been able to give those undertakings. On what authority was the Minister speaking?
—Were the same officers at the briefing?
—No, they were not present at the briefing. This was a briefing with the Minister and one of the Minister's advisers.
—Order! I remind the honourable senator that the question is: That the Bills be agreed to without amendment or requests.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman, I accept that. I want to get those issues on the record because I am extremely disappointed. It will certainly make me look very closely at the undertakings given to us by Ministers in the future.

PARA.TAB: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendments or requests; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long. I seek leave to table two evaluations of a headlight helmet for bicycle riders made by Technisearch technical services division, one on 11 May 1992 and one on 5 August 1992.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I am doing this on behalf of Mrs Fran Bailey, the shadow Minister for consumer affairs and a member of the House of Representatives. As shadow Minister for sport, I am concerned about a report in the December issue of Choice magazine that raises questions and sounds alarm bells about Standards Australia, just as questions were raised with Mrs Bailey concerning bicycle helmets that failed safety testing but were accredited by Standards Australia.

PARA.TAB: With Christmas coming up, I am worried that parents may buy unsafe helmets for their children due to the laxity of Standards Australia's certification and testing procedures, which the Federal Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) is apparently prepared to help cover up. As the article in Choice notes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a product carrying the Standards Mark will not necessarily be the safest or most efficient choice. Nor will it necessarily be the best performer.

That certification mark is meant to signify the highest standard of quality and safety. Consumers may be misled into believing that products bearing the standards mark are the safest and best. Mrs Bailey has previously called on the Minister for Consumer Affairs to initiate an inquiry into Standards Australia because of concerns about bicycle helmets that had failed testing procedures but had been accredited by Standards Australia.

PARA.TAB: About a fortnight ago, the Government refused to allow Mrs Bailey leave to table in the House of Representatives the entire 5 August 1992 Technisearch report, which I have now tabled here. It clearly states that many bicycle helmets failed safety testing, were allowed to be modified by manufacturers and were never recalled. For four months, the Minister for Consumer Affairs has had a copy of the 5 August 1992 Technisearch report, which states quite clearly that not only has the helmet Mrs Bailey named in Parliament failed safety testing, but also that many other models of helmets have failed safety testing, some around ventilation openings and others which split open when tested in wet conditions; that manufacturers were permitted to modify their products to eliminate faults and no helmets were recalled; that many models of helmets on the Australian market failed testing and that the problems were widespread; and that, in practice, this has meant that helmets remain in circulation which could be expected to fail.

This was in a report the Minister claimed supported her view that the helmet in question raised by Mrs Bailey `stood up to testing under normal, reasonable conditions'. If that report had been quoted in full by the Minister instead of selectively, all those concerns would have been revealed, thus confirming Mrs Bailey's concern. Given that it is now compulsory for all cyclists to wear a helmet and that Christmas is fast approaching and parents are looking for presents for their children, a report which raises serious questions about the safety of helmets on the Australian market should have been investigated immediately. Unfortunately, the Minister's lack of action on this issue is denying parents their right to know this information so that they can make decisions to protect the safety of their children.

There are some questions that must be answered, particularly in the context of the article in Choice magazine, which is put out by the Australian Consumers Association. I ask: which are the helmets that failed safety testing and are still out in the community being worn by cyclists? Are those helmets still available for sale on the Australian market? Do those helmets carry the Standards Australia certification mark of quality and safety? Why were manufacturers not required to recall those helmets that failed testing? Why have Australian consumers not been notified of these risks to their safety?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to pay tribute to one of Tasmania's honorary citizens. Last weekend, Mr Tsuneichi Fujii, the head of the great Japanese company Fujii-Koeri, died at the age of 81 after a long illness. Mr Fujii took the Tasmanian superfine wool industry onto the world stage and over two decades formed a close relationship with Tasmania. His work promoted not just the Tasmanian wool industry but the State he came to love. In his many visits he formed lasting relationships which went beyond the boundaries of business.

PARA.TAB: Mr Fujii first came to Tasmania in 1972. His enthusiasm for Tasmania began from this time. Every year since then Mr Fujii, accompanied by his entourage of around 80 people, would visit my home town of Launceston for the annual wool sales. Frequently, his company would bring its own film crew to make films promoting the place where the world's best extra fine wool is grown. Not infrequently, such filming found its way onto Japanese television. The northern Tasmania superfine wool industry owes its survival to this man. From 1973 onwards, Mr Fujii again and again made headlines throughout the world's textile markets for his unmatched series of world record prices paid for Tasmanian wool. In 1989, Mr Fujii's son Kenroku, the company's executive director, stunned the world when he paid 300,850c a kilogram for a 100 kilogram bale of wool from Connorville property at Cressy. This price was 10 times higher than the previous highest price paid.

Mr Fujii is reputed to have once told a meeting of growers in Launceston that in Japan the company's motto is `No. 1—the highest quality'. He continued to say, `Where the Fujii garments are marketed, so is Tasmania'. Tasmania was publicised in Japan through the Fujiis' manufacture of high quality fabrics produced from the superfine wool purchased from the Launceston wool sales. The Fujii company stressed the importance of retaining the Launceston wool sales after discussions were held concerning the possible centralisation of the Australian wool sales. The Fujiis emphasised that such a decision could put an end to the payment of record prices for the Tasmanian product by the textile manufacturer Fujii-Keori Ltd as the superfine quality of our wool would be lost amongst the mainland clip. The Fujii company has stressed the importance of the `bought in Launceston' cachet attached to the wool, as the wool is considered throughout the textile and fashion industries to be a guarantee of the very highest quality. The business community of Launceston was grateful for this support and its annual wool sales are still probably Launceston's biggest single trading event.

Mr Fujii had a love for Tasmania. This love was recognised in 1982 when Mr Fujii became Launceston's first honorary citizen. In 1984 he was made an honorary representative for Tasmania in Osaka. In that year alone he spent more than $1m promoting the State. More recently Mr Fujii was appointed an honorary member of the Order of Australia. His love extended to his making a substantial donation to the Tasmanian Government, which resulted in the establishment of the Tsuneichi Fujii Fellowship Trust. This Trust, administered by the Tasmanian Premier's Department and Cabinet, was set up to promote goodwill between Tasmania and Japan. Annual awards are made available for

SPEECH.PARA: educational, cultural, scientific, trade and business exchanges between Tasmania and Japan.

PARA.TAB: Over the years numerous Tasmanians have had the pleasure of being awarded this prize. The most recent award was won by a Mrs Anna Stewart, a senior teacher at Flinders Island District High School. The award will allow her to produce a range of educational materials for Tasmanians visiting Japan and Japanese visiting Tasmania. Mr Tsuneichi Fujii is survived by his wife. To her and the rest of the family I extend my condolences on behalf of the people of Tasmania because, with the death of Mr Fujii, Tasmania has indeed lost a friend.Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 27 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the decision by the Commonwealth to grant five sand mining leases at Shoalwater Bay to Pivot Projects Pty Ltd and Pivot Mining NL:
(1) Has Section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 been fully complied with, in particular:
(a) has action been taken to ensure that prudent and feasible alternatives to the Shoalwater Bay proposal have been fully explored; if not, why not; if so, what were the results of the action;
(b) is there no prudent and feasible alternative site in Australia to the Shoalwater Bay site; and
(c) can the Minister guarantee that adverse effects will not occur in the lease areas; if not, why not.

(2) With reference to the fact that the proposal in the Additional Information document was substantially different to the proposal in the Supplement to the Draft EIS, is the Minister in breach of the Section 8 of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 by having failed to observe the procedures for public comment, for proponent response and for departmental assessment of the Additional Information document as set out in the Act.

(3) With reference to the 1983 Terms of Settlement which purportedly oblige the Commonwealth to issue sand mining leases if it finds the proponent's EIS satisfactory, what constitutes a satisfactory EIS in respect of this proposal.

(4) Does the Environment Management Plan required by the Government from Pivot Projects Pty Ltd and Pivot Mining NL involve consideration of each lease in isolation of the impacts on the large area; if so, has the Australian Heritage Commission expressed `extreme concern' if this were to be the case.

(5) Given that the RAKES report ranked Shoalwater Bay of higher conservation value than Fraser Island (and Daintree), will the Minister ensure that Shoalwater Bay is nominated for World Heritage listing; if not, why not.

(6) Will an inquiry be conducted in respect of the environmental aspects of the Commonwealth's involvement in the issuing of mining leases at Shoalwater Bay, as provided for under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Obligations arising from the provisions of Section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 are the responsibility of the relevant action Minister or Department. The Minister for Administrative Services has, therefore, provided the following answer to part (1) of the question.
(1) Yes.
(1a) Yes. As a result of the consideration of feasible and prudent alternatives, it was decided to grant leases imposing strict conditions relating to the protection of the environment.
(1b) There is no prudent and feasible alternative site. The Commonwealth is not in a position to provide access to alternative equivalent sites.
(1c) It is likely that adverse effects will occur in the lease areas should mining take place. However, stringent lease conditions have been imposed to minimise these adverse effects.

(2) No. The Additional Information was made available for public comment from 2-16 January 1990 and the proponent's response addressing issues raised during this period of public review was incorporated in the Department's Assessment Report of February 1990.
(3) A satisfactory EIS is one which has been prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

(4) The agreement between the Commonwealth and the companies specifies that, should the companies decide to proceed beyond exploration stage, an Environmental Management Plan will be prepared for each lease area. The exact scope and requirements of the Environmental Management Plan has not yet been determined.

The Australian Heritage Commission did advise that is `extremely concerned that the proposed Environmental Management Plan involves consideration of each lease in isolation of the impacts on the larger area'. If it becomes necessary for any or all of the Environmental Management Plans to be prepared, their scope will not necessarily be restricted to actions and impacts within the particular lease area and the concerns of the Australian Heritage Commission in the preparation of each Environmental Management Plan will be taken into account.

(5) The process by which a decision whether or not to nominate an area of Australia to the World Heritage list is made has recently been formalised in the Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment. Under the terms of this Agreement the Commonwealth will consult the relevant State before placing an area on the indicative list of possible World Heritage nominations. This is the first step in considering a nomination. During consultations with Queensland the question of nominating Shoalwater Bay has not arisen. At this stage it is by no means clear that Shoalwater Bay meets the stringent criteria laid down for World Heritage listing.

(6) No. The provisions of both the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 have been complied with and a decision has been taken to issue leases. An inquiry under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 would, therefore, serve no useful purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that Australia has recently completed a double tax agreement with Vietnam what are the impediments for recognising Vietnam as a comparable tax country for foreign tax purposes.
(2) Is Australia's trade with Vietnam impeded by a lack of recognition of the comparable tax jurisdiction status within the Australian foreign tax regime.
(3) Is tax status under review.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Vietnam's tax system has been in rapid evolution. Published information on the tax system suggests that Vietnam does not have a comprehensive, settled tax law. Moreover, business reports suggest Vietnam's tax arrangements may vary across different projects. The tax system may well be subject to further change as Vietnam's economy grows and as the Vietnamese Government reduces its direct controls of the economy.

(2) Australia's trade with Vietnam is unlikely to be affected by the latter's current `unlisted country' status under Australia's tax law. Listing as a comparable-tax country may be relevant, at the margin, to Australian direct investment in Vietnam. If Vietnam remains unlisted, profits earned by branches of Australian companies established there, and dividends paid to Australian companies from their Vietnamese subsidiaries, are taxable under Australia's Foreign Tax Credit System which provides credit for tax paid in Vietnam. It would not be appropriate to exempt all such Vietnamese source income from Australian company tax (as would occur if Vietnam was listed) until it can be clearly established that Vietnam is a comparable-tax jurisdiction.

It is important to emphasise that if Vietnam remains unlisted, most Australian companies that have established subsidiaries there, or intend to do so, would not be subject to accruals taxation (at the Australian company tax rate) under the controlled foreign company regime. This is because those companies are virtually all engaged in active businesses, and would qualify for the active income exemption.
(3) The Government has received a number of submissions from taxpayers requesting that Vietnam be added to the list of comparable-tax jurisdictions. It is currently reviewing Vietnam's status.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Please provide a list of all advocacy groups for the aged.
(2) What amount of Commonwealth funding was granted to each advocacy group in the financial years: (a) 1990-91; (b) 1991-92; and (c) 1992-93.
(3) Under the terms of reference of the Gregory Review into nursing home funding, is it possible for increased funding to be recommended, or is this excluded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Advocacy groups funded under the Residential Aged Care Program are:

ANSWER.PARA: Residential Care Rights sponsored by the Older Persons' Action Centre Inc. (RCR)
Advocacy for the Aged Association Inc. (AFTAA) (from August 1990 to June 1992)
Older Person Advocacy Service sponsored by the Northern Suburbs District Senior Citizens' Centre (OPAS) (from 1 October 1992)
Tasmanian Advocacy and Information Service Inc. (TAISI)
Central Australian Advocacy Service sponsored by YWCA of Alice Springs (CAAS)
ACT Disability, Aged and Carers' Advisory Service (ADACAS).

PARA.TAB: (2) Approved funding for these organisations from the Residential Aged Care Advocacy Program are:

(3) The Nursing Home Funding Structure Review will examine the efficiency and effectiveness of the nursing home funding system. The Principal Consultant to the Review, Professor R G Gregory, will present options which:
ensure that funding provided for direct care is used for that purpose;
take account of, and complement, the achievement of labour market efficiencies through current reforms in industrial relations (eg workplace bargaining, multi-skilling); and
provide incentive and scope for greater efficiencies in the operation of nursing homes.

These issues are focused on the structure rather than the level of nursing home funding. However, these terms of reference are broad and the Principal Consultant may need to make comment on the level of funding in order to fully address the issues encompassed by the terms of reference.
